meanings.definition: the 21st letter of the English alphabet

abbreviation for 
        
         universal  : in the UK, a film or a symbol for a film that is considered suitable for children of any age

abbreviation for 
        
         universal  : used in the UK to refer to a film that is considered suitable for children of any age
(of behaviour or ways of speaking) acceptable to or expected to be used by people of high social class
the 21st letter of the English alphabet
a U-shaped piece of pipe, especially one under a toilet or sink, that holds water in its lower part and prevents unpleasant gases from getting out

a line on a graph that starts high, gets much lower, and then rises again, giving it the shape of the letter 'U'. It is also used to refer to situations in which something decreases and then increases again:
examples: The report found that happiness is a u-bend, decreasing until middle age and then rising again.

meanings.definition: a German submarine, used especially in World Wars I and II

informal for 
        
         U-turn
relating to the activity of picking fruit or vegetables yourself at a farm and then paying for the amount you have picked:
examples: We sell U-Pick apples, pumpkins and raspberries.
Next time you see a local produce stand or pass a u-pick berry farm, get out of the car and pick some produce yourself.

meanings.definition: a farm or part of a farm where customers pick fruit and vegetables themselves and then pay for the amount they have picked, or this method of selling fruit and vegetables:
examples: They had dreamed of opening a U-pick for many years.
The local U-pick focuses on strawberries but also features tomatoes, peppers, cucumbers, squash, and lettuces.
Customers don't realize that U-pick is hard work for farmers, who have to advise customers and clean up after them.

meanings.definition: a turn made by a car in order to go back in the direction from which it has come:
examples: It is illegal to do/make a U-turn on a motorway.

meanings.definition: a complete change from one opinion or plan of action to an opposite one:
examples: The prime minister did/made a quick U-turn in response to all the adverse publicity.

meanings.definition: a turn like a U, made by a vehicle to go back in the direction from which it came:
examples: I was making a U-turn into the southbound lanes.

meanings.definition: a complete change from one opinion or plan to an opposite one

abbreviation for 
        
         unidentified aerial phenomenon  : an object seen in the sky whose origin is not known, and that cannot be explained:
examples: UAP are officially defined as sightings "that cannot be identified as aircraft or known natural phenomena from a scientific perspective".
Research has shown that the "mystery helicopter" is a typical UAP.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for 
        
         unidentified anomalous phenomenon  : any object that is seen in the sky, ocean, or space whose origin is not known and that cannot be explained:
examples: The acronym UAP stood for "unidentified aerial phenomenon" until December 2022, when the Pentagon updated its terminology to "unidentified anomalous phenomenon".

The question about UAPs (unidentified anomalous phenomena, formerly unidentified aerial phenomena) is whether a mundane explanation, in terms of natural phenomena or human technology, exists for all reported sightings.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         user acceptance test
abbreviation for unmanned aerial vehicle: an aircraft that is operated from a distance, without a person being present on it:
examples: UAVs of various types are integral parts of the United States airpower arsenal.

meanings.definition: a type of yam (= a root vegetable) that is purple in colour:
examples: a vegetable curry made with ube

meanings.definition: used before nouns to mean "extreme" or "extremely good or successful":
examples: über-model, Gisele
über-billionaire

meanings.definition: the act or process of changing the market for a service by introducing a different way of buying or using it, especially using mobile technology:
examples: the uberization of banking
The idea behind uberization is providing on-demand services for as many needs as possible.

meanings.definition: to change the market for a service by introducing a different way of buying or using it, especially using mobile technology :
examples: Even restaurant reservations could be uberized.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for 
        
         universal basic income  : an amount of money that is given regularly to everyone or to every adult in a society by a government or other organization and that is the same for everyone:
examples: The idea of UBI is to give every citizen, regardless of means, a regular sum of money for life.
Its supporters claim that the financial security of a UBI would increase people's willingness to take risks, creating a culture of inventiveness and entrepreneurship.

meanings.definition: the state of being in a definite place or position
seeming to be everywhere:
examples: Leather is very much in fashion this season, as is the ubiquitous denim.
The Swedes are not alone in finding their language under pressure from the ubiquitous spread of English.
The mobile phone, that most ubiquitous of consumer-electronic appliances, is about to enter a new age.

meanings.definition: found or existing everywhere:
examples: The eel grass limpet used to be ubiquitous on the New England coast.

meanings.definition: in a way that seems to be everywhere:
examples: Coconut milk features ubiquitously in Thai cooking.
Television brings entertainment ubiquitously into every home.

meanings.definition: the fact that something or someone seems to be everywhere:
examples: the ubiquity of fast-food outlets

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         uniform business rate
abbreviation for Universities and Colleges Admissions Service; an organization in the UK that deals with university and college applications:
examples: You will find more information below on how to fill in your UCAS application.

meanings.definition: the organ of a cow, sheep, or other animal, that produces milk and hangs like a bag between the legs
the part of a cow, goat, or other animal that hangs between the back legs and produces milk
thick noodles (= long strips made from flour or rice) used in Japanese cooking:
examples: You can choose between thin noodles and thick udon.
I made this salad of raw cabbage mixed with cold udon noodles.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for unidentified flying object: an object seen in the sky that is thought to be a spacecraft from another planet:
examples: Several UFO sightings have been reported.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for unidentified flying object (= an object seen in the sky that some people believe is a spacecraft from another planet)
the study of unidentified flying objects or UFOs (= objects seen in the sky whose origin is not known and which some people think may be spacecraft from another planet):
examples: Behind the more bizarre aspects of ufology there are some phenomena that are worthy of study.
Scientists have generally dismissed ufology as pseudoscience, and believers in unidentified flying objects and aliens as irrational.
Read this book if you want to know what's going on in UFOlogy today.

meanings.definition: a country in East Africa
belonging to or relating to Uganda or its people
a person from Uganda
used to express a strong feeling of disgust (= disapproval and dislike) at something very unpleasant:
examples: Ugh, I think I stepped in something really gross.
Ugh, I'm not eating that!

meanings.definition: the written form of the sound people sometimes use to express a strong feeling of disgust at something very unpleasant:
examples: Ugh, that smells really bad!

meanings.definition: a brand name for a type of fruit that is a mixture of a tangerine and a grapefruit:
examples: Remove the peel and halve the Ugli.
Ugli fruit are pretty widely available nowadays.
Ugli is good for your health and may help protect you from heart disease.

meanings.definition: the quality of being unpleasant to look at, or not attractive:
examples: the ugliness of the buildings
He makes comedy out of his ugliness.

meanings.definition: the quality of being unpleasant and threatening or violent:
examples: Some activists are dismayed by the occasional ugliness of the debate.
The revelation of abuse of prisoners displayed an ugliness to the war that shook even those who supported it.

meanings.definition: the quality or state of being extremely unattractive in appearance:
examples: The city’s ugliness struck me.

meanings.definition: something that is unpleasant and threatening or violent:
examples: He has ugliness in his heart.

meanings.definition: unpleasant to look at; not attractive:
examples: I think a lot of modern architecture is very ugly.
Yesterday I saw the ugliest baby I've ever seen in my life.
I feel really fat and ugly today.
He was a really unpleasant man and as ugly as sin (= very ugly).

meanings.definition: unpleasant and threatening or violent:
examples: There were ugly scenes outside the stadium.
The demonstration turned ugly when a group of protesters started to throw bottles at the police.

meanings.definition: extremely unattractive in appearance:
examples: He’s a really ugly dog.

meanings.definition: unpleasant and threatening or violent:
examples: This policy could have some ugly consequences.

meanings.definition: someone or something that is ugly and not successful when young or new but will later become beautiful or successful
used in writing to represent the sound that people sometimes make when they are thinking what to say next:
examples: It's not too far - it's about, uh, five miles from here.

meanings.definition: the written form of the sound people sometimes make when they pause in speaking, thinking of what to say next or how to say it:
examples: I try not to, uh, rely on my parents.

meanings.definition: used in writing to represent the sound that people sometimes make in order to agree with or show understanding of something that has just been said:
examples: "Did you hear what I just said?" "Uh-huh."
"You know that strange guy we saw yesterday?" "Uh-huh."
"I'll be back a little late because I have to stop at the shops." "Uh-huh."

meanings.definition: said to express agreement to what has just been said, or to mean yes:
examples: "Did you hear what I said?" "Uh-huh."

meanings.definition: used in writing to represent the sound that people make when they discover that they have made a mistake or done something wrong:
examples: Uh-oh, I think I just locked my keys in the car.

meanings.definition: the written form of the sound that people sometimes make when they have made a mistake or when something bad has happened:
examples: Uh-oh, I think I just locked my keys in the car.

meanings.definition: used in writing to represent the sound that people sometimes make to give a negative answer:
examples: "You didn't have time to get food?" "Uh-uh, no chance."

meanings.definition: the written form of the sound that people sometimes make to say no:
examples: "Did you do the shopping?" "Uh-uh."

meanings.definition: abbreviation for ultra-high definition: used to describe or refer to a system for showing extremely clear pictures on a television or computer screen:
examples: The PC has a UHD 4K display with a broad colour gamut, making it a great home entertainment system.
TVs with 4K resolution, also known as UHD TVs, have four times as many pixels as standard 1080p resolution TVs.
Planet Earth was streamed in UHD and HDR on supported devices.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for ultra-high frequency: radio waves between 300 MHz and 3,000 MHz
abbreviation for ultra heat treated: used to refer to milk that has been heated to a very high temperature so that it will last for a long time if it is kept in a container that has not been opened:
examples: UHT milk/cream

meanings.definition: abbreviation for ultra heat treated: milk that has been heated to a very high temperature so that it will last for a long time if it is kept in a container that has not been opened:
examples: a pint of UHT
The milk typically used in cafés for coffee is UHT.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for user interface: the way in which the information on a computer, phone, etc. and instructions on how to use it are arranged on the screen and shown to the user:
examples: Generally I found this UI to be clear, functional, and pretty self-explanatory.
When you design your UIs, make sure that you pay close attention to how you talk to your user.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         UKPA
used to describe someone who lives in the UK or an organization with its main office in the UK:
examples: A UK-based internet company has made an offer for its rival.
UK-based investment funds

meanings.definition: used to describe a company whose shares are traded on a stock market in the UK:
examples: UK-listed Irish shares performed well.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for UK Association of the History of Nursing: an organization that does research and provides education in the history of nursing
abbreviation for UK Independence Party: a political party in the UK whose main policy has been that the United Kingdom should leave the European Union
abbreviation for UK Payments Administration: an organization in the UK that manages payment systems for banks and other financial organizations
a country in eastern Europe
belonging to or relating to Ukraine, its people, or its language
a person from Ukraine
the main language spoken in Ukraine
a small guitar or banjo with four strings:
examples: George Formby made the ukulele famous in his films in the 1940s.

meanings.definition: the mark of the Underwriters Laboratories, used to show that a product has been tested by them and is safe, according to their standards
a break in the skin, or on the surface of an organ inside the body, that does not heal naturally:
examples: a mouth/stomach ulcer

meanings.definition: a sore on the skin or inside the body that will not heal without treatment:
examples: a stomach ulcer

meanings.definition: Ulcerated skin is covered in ulcers:
examples: She had lain in bed for so long that her shoulder blades had become ulcerated.

meanings.definition: the process of forming an ulcer or ulcers:
examples: ulceration of the bowel
mouth ulceration

meanings.definition: affected by or involving ulcers (= breaks in the skin, or on the surface of an organ inside the body, that do not heal naturally):
examples: The area is healing well and appears not to be becoming ulcerative.
An endoscopy revealed an ulcerative tumour.

meanings.definition: an illness in which parts of the bowels are inflamed (= red, painful and swollen) and can produce ulcers (= breaks in the skin, or on the surface of an organ inside the body, that do not heal naturally):
examples: Ulcerative colitis can result in abdominal pain, diarrhoea and weight loss.

meanings.definition: relating to or being affected by an ulcer (= a break in the skin or on an organ that does not heal naturally):
examples: Soon he had several huge, ulcerous sores on his legs.
A physical examination revealed live maggots in the ulcerous wound.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for ultra low emission zone: an area of a city that you must pay to enter if you are driving a vehicle that produces more than a very low level of harmful emissions (= waste gases):
examples: Private hire vehicles, like other cars, will have to meet the emissions standards to enter the ULEZ without paying.
Vehicles need to meet the ULEZ emissions standards or their drivers must pay a daily charge to drive within the zone.

meanings.definition: the space in a closed container of liquid that is not filled by the liquid:
examples: Most wines are bottled for immediate consumption, and the ullage should be small.
The requirement to determine ullage before beginning oil delivery applies to all above ground storage tanks.

meanings.definition: a long, thin bone in the lower part of your arm

plural of 
        
         ulna   specialized
relating to the ulna (= the long, thin bone in the lower part of the arm):
examples: the ulnar artery

meanings.definition: pain in the wrist on the side opposite the thumb:
examples: Ulnar wrist pain occurs especially during twisting movements.

meanings.definition: a Latin word meaning "ulnar" (= relating to the long, thin bone in the lower part of the arm), used in medical names and descriptions
one of the four provinces (= historic areas) of Ireland, part of which is now in Northern Ireland and part in the Republic of Ireland:
examples: He founded a cathedral in the town of Armagh in Ulster.

meanings.definition: a name for Northern Ireland, which is part of the UK:
examples: The Assembly elections were a referendum on the proposals for the future of Ulster.

meanings.definition: (of a reason) hidden or secret:
examples: She had no ulterior motive for helping them out – she just wanted to do it.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         ultimatum
most extreme or important because either the original or final, or the best or worst:
examples: Of course the ultimate responsibility for the present conflict without doubt lies with the aggressor.
My manager will make the ultimate decision about who to employ.
Infidelity is the ultimate betrayal.
the ultimate luxury cruiser

meanings.definition:
another word for 
        
         Ultimate Frisbee
most important, highest, last, or final:
examples: Your ultimate goal is to play the game as well as you can.

meanings.definition: Ultimate also means the best, most, or greatest of its kind:
examples: Some people believe that he is the ultimate painter of this century.

meanings.definition: last in a series:
examples: The CEO is responsible for making the ultimate decision.
We are stopping off in Brussels and Cairo, but our ultimate destination is Chennai.

meanings.definition: having more importance or more influence over what happens than all others:
examples: Only one in 100 workers will achieve the ultimate goal and retire on two-thirds of final salary.
The manager has ultimate responsibility for all investment advisory services.
The corporate HQ in the UK has ultimate authority over all our overseas operations.

meanings.definition: the person or organization that buys a product to use, rather than to sell it to someone else:
examples: The law ensures the most effective protection for the rights of the ultimate consumer.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         ultimate consumer

a sport in which two teams of seven players throw a Frisbee (= a circular piece of plastic) to other members of their team and score points by getting the Frisbee into an area at the end of the playing area:
examples: He and other students would get together to play Ultimate Frisbee.
I also love to play any kind of sports, from basketball to ultimate frisbee.
He's looking to find new people eager to play Ultimate.

meanings.definition: finally, after a series of things have happened:
examples: Everything will ultimately depend on what is said at the meeting with the directors next week.
Ultimately, of course, he'd like to have his own business but that won't be for some time.

meanings.definition: used to emphasize the most important fact in a situation:
examples: Ultimately, he'll have to decide.

meanings.definition: finally; in the end:
examples: Our plans ultimately depend on the weather.

meanings.definition: a threat in which a person or group of people are warned that if they do not do a particular thing, something unpleasant will happen to them. It is usually the last and most extreme in a series of actions taken to bring about a particular result:
examples: He gave her an ultimatum - she could either stop seeing Peter and come back to him or it was divorce.
On Wednesday night the UN issued its toughest ultimatum to date, demanding that all troops withdraw from the city.

meanings.definition: a demand that a person or group do something to avoid something unpleasant:
examples: The workers got an ultimatum – go back to work or face dismissal.

meanings.definition: a warning, usually the last and most threatening one in a series, in which someone is told that if they take a particular action, something unpleasant will happen to them:
examples: The chairman has issued an ultimatum: sort out the problems, or the expansion will not take place.
Should I give him some kind of ultimatum to encourage him to retire?

meanings.definition: a person who has extreme political or religious opinions, or opinions that are more extreme than others in the same political party, etc.:
examples: Soon the ultras on the right of the party will resume their criticism of the prime minister.

meanings.definition: an extreme supporter of a football club, often one who is part of an organized group that may also have extreme political opinions:
examples: The only sign of tension came when several hundred Napoli ultras protested against the closure of their clubs's ground.

meanings.definition: a running race that is longer than a marathon (= a race that is approximately 26 miles):
examples: This six-day ultra, the US's version of the Marathon des Sables, covers 148 miles.

meanings.definition: extreme or extremely:
examples: ultra-expensive
ultra-modern architecture
ultra-sensitive
an ultra-short haircut

meanings.definition: involving longer distances than is usual:
examples: He was famous as a runner of ultramarathons.
ultra-cycling/ultra-running events

meanings.definition: extreme or extremely:
examples: ultraconservative
ultramodern

meanings.definition: used with adjectives to mean 'extremely':
examples: These ultra-thin loudspeakers can be hidden as paintings on a wall.
an ultra-conservative political group
The network uses ultra-fast fiber-optic cable.

meanings.definition: beyond the legal power or authority of the person performing an action:
examples: The company's actions in entering into a contract with him were ultra vires, and therefore the contract was void.
A shareholder could restrain the company from undertaking ultra vires activities.

meanings.definition: extremely bright (= full of light or shining with a lot of light):
examples: It was an ultra-bright day and I wished I hadn't forgotten my sunglasses.
An ultrabright neon sign glowed in the window.

meanings.definition: extremely bright in colour:
examples: She was wearing a new ultra-bright lip gloss.
The markers are sold in a range of ultra-bright shades for kids, including Flamingo Pink and Electric Lime.

meanings.definition: extremely intelligent:
examples: The university attracts ultra-bright students from all over the world
The magazine hired an ultrabright new editor-in-chief who has ideas for keeping the publication fresh and relevant.

meanings.definition: extremely careful:
examples: He has always been ultra-careful about safety.
I had expected her, as a speechwriter for the president, to be ultra-careful in choosing her words.

meanings.definition: extremely informal:
examples: He has a down-to-earth manner and dresses for the office in ultra-casual blue jeans.
He writes in the ultracasual tone of a chatty e-mail to a friend.

meanings.definition: not taking or not seeming to take much interest at all in something:
examples: "How's Mary?" he asked, trying to sound ultra-casual.
The staff were ultracasual about serving us.

meanings.definition: extremely careful and not taking any risks at all:
examples: She is ultra-cautious when it comes to investing her money.
The team will be ultra-cautious in managing the player's injury and make sure she doesn't rush back to the field too soon.
The spokesperson deflected difficult questions from reporters with a deadpan, ultra-cautious style.

meanings.definition: extremely cheap:
examples: They are working on building an ultra-cheap car for the masses that is easily affordable.
Chicken has been ultra-cheap for years compared to other foodstuffs.

meanings.definition: extremely stylish and fashionable:
examples: We walked through an ultra-chic Parisian neighbourhood that was home to several designer boutiques.
She got a job as a photographer at an ultra-chic fashion magazine.
The store sells the kind of high-end clothing that will appeal to ultrachic customers.

meanings.definition: If a person or their behaviour is ultra-civilized, they are extremely polite and behave in a very calm and reasonable way:
examples: The ultra-civilized nation decided to crack down on people who spit in public.
The man carried a suave, ultracivilized air and wore a devious grin that hid his true intentions.

meanings.definition: extremely pleasant or comfortable:
examples: The ultra-civilized resort spa catered to a high-end clientele.
We were at an exclusive, ultracivilized bar in Central London.

meanings.definition: extremely clean:
examples: Ultra-clean children, some believe, are more likely to suffer from allergies.
The samples are analysed in ultraclean laboratories.

meanings.definition: extremely commercial (= produced with the aim of making money and therefore having very little artistic value):
examples: The concert consisted of three hours of ultra-commercial tunes delivered at maximum volume.
The magazines sold near the checkout rely on ultra-commercial covers, covered in large lettering and bright colours.

meanings.definition: extremely small:
examples: Living in the city, she gets around in an ultra-compact electric car.
It's a stylish and ultracompact digital camera that you can carry in your pocket.

meanings.definition: extremely good at doing something:
examples: She has a hard, ultra-competent exterior but is dealing with a lot of internal struggles.
The TV host would be lost without her ultracompetent assistant, who keeps her affairs in order.

meanings.definition: extremely competitive (= wanting very much to win or be more successful than other people):
examples: He is so ultra-competitive that he can occasionally be seen getting angry with his teammates.
Growing up, his brother was always the ultra-competitive type; everything had to be a contest.

meanings.definition: extreme conservatism (= the quality of not usually liking or trusting change, especially sudden change):
examples: The candidate's display of ultra-conservatism helped him win the primary in the deeply Republican state.
The town's ultra-conservatism went on display when she tried to open an adult-toy shop.

meanings.definition: extremely conservative (= not usually liking or trusting change, especially sudden change):
examples: She was criticized for her ultra-conservative views against homosexuals and abortion.
Longtime members of the organization are ultra-conservative and bound by tradition and don't want to see any major changes.

meanings.definition: very traditional and not at all fashionable or modern in appearance:
examples: In recent years, the company has been transformed from a producer of ultra-conservative clothes to an upscale designer label.
The ultraconservative dresser will love these traditional shirts.

meanings.definition: extremely modern in style or appearance :
examples: The architecture combines old materials with ultra-contemporary fixtures and fittings that give the house character.
The district has a variety of bars, some ultracontemporary, others of a more retro design.

meanings.definition: extremely convenient (= suitable for your purposes and needs and causing the least difficulty):
examples: Canned baked beans might be ultra-convenient, but in terms of taste and value they are no match for the kind you can make at home.
The file directory provides users with quick and ultra-convenient access to their most recent documents.

meanings.definition: extremely fashionable in a way that people admire:
examples: The hotel features an ultra-cool lounge and bar.
Those are some ultra-cool sunglasses you have on.

meanings.definition: extremely calm and not at all worried or frightened :
examples: She had hoped to remain ultra-cool in spite of whatever provocation was thrown at her.
The illusionist's low-key, ultracool manner leaves spectators amazed.

meanings.definition: extremely critical (= saying that someone or something is bad or wrong):
examples: Don't be discouraged if your supervisors are ultra-critical about your work.
Among the criticisms levelled at him by the ultra-critical news media is that he takes himself too seriously.

meanings.definition: extremely dense (= containing a lot of things or matter in a small space):
examples: They're building some new ultra-dense housing to try and solve the city's housing crisis.
A pulsar is an ultradense, rapidly rotating object that is left over when a supernova explodes.

meanings.definition: relating to events in running, swimming, or cycling that take place over extremely long distances:
examples: He bicycled across the continent, coast to coast, as part of an ultra-distance bike race.
His goal is to train for and compete in an ultra-distance triathlon.

meanings.definition: extremely far away in space:
examples: They calculated that the light from the ultra-distant galaxy travelled for over 13 billion years before it reached the Earth.
The astronomers are observing several ultra-distant objects that might suggest the presence of a planet in the far reaches of the solar system.

meanings.definition: extremely dry:
examples: The rain quickly evaporates into the ultra-dry atmosphere.
This moisturizing cream works well even on ultradry skin.

meanings.definition: (of a drink) not at all sweet:
examples: The champagne was ultra-dry and a little too austere for my palate.
Their new product is an ultradry cider.

meanings.definition: funny in a way that is clever and not obvious, so it may seem that you are being very serious:
examples: She has an ultra-dry sense of humour.
Even the ultradry director was heard cracking a joke.

meanings.definition: working or operating very well without wasting any energy, fuel, or other resource such as water:
examples: They are looking to develop ultra-efficient cars that get high mileage and run on clean fuels.
What we need is an ultra-efficient wood-burning cooker.

meanings.definition: working quickly and effectively in an extremely well-organized way:
examples: The service at the restaurant is ultra-efficient, yet the atmosphere is casual and relaxed.

meanings.definition: having or involving a very large amount of energy:
examples: The third movement of the concerto had an ultra-energetic ending with dynamic chords reminiscent of bells.
The actress's performance is skilled and ultra-energetic, but this is not enough to disguise the poorly written part.

meanings.definition: extremely exclusive (= limited to only one person or group of people and especially to those who are very rich or belong to a high social class):
examples: He drives an ultra-exclusive, hand-built luxury car that only the truly rich can afford.
The mansion stands in an ultra-exclusive enclave just outside of the city.

meanings.definition: costing a very large amount of money compared to other, similar things:
examples: You can acquire most of the ingredients at any grocery, though one recipe does call for ultra-expensive truffles.
The more well-known restaurants in the city are ultra-expensive, but more affordable options can be found with a little research.

meanings.definition: very easy to recognize because of being seen, met, heard, etc. many times before :
examples: Although the songs were ultra-familiar, the live versions came out sounding fresh and new.
When a story is as ultrafamiliar as "Cinderella", we're less interested in what is told than in the way it's told.

meanings.definition: extremely fast:
examples: We paid extra for ultra-fast broadband, as there were four of us working from home as well as streaming films and TV.
The latest trend in preventive medicine is ultrafast radiological scanning on demand.

meanings.definition: extremely fastidious (= giving too much attention to small details and wanting everything to be correct and perfect):
examples: His writing has the same highly polished quality as his literary idol, the ultra-fastidious Gustave Flaubert.
The ultrafastidious charity kept detailed records on the donations made to both political parties.

meanings.definition: very glamorous (= attractive in an exciting and special way):
examples: The shoes are silk-lined and feel sexy and ultra-glamorous.
The TV show is notable for its ultra-glamorous cast of young, beautiful actors.

meanings.definition: (especially of chemicals or other substances) extremely dangerous:
examples: The court had to decide whether a laboratory that handles ultra-hazardous materials had a responsibility to the general public to make sure they are never intercepted.
Ammonium nitrate is an ultra-hazardous chemical that has been used in the making of homemade explosives.

meanings.definition: very heavy:
examples: A committed cyclist, he rode an ultra-heavy, dark red bicycle to get anywhere he needed to go in the city.
He became the great hockey player he is by practising his shooting with ultra-heavy pucks every day during his youth.

meanings.definition: at a very great level or height :
examples: The evidence for the meteorite hinges most strongly on the presence of tiny diamonds, which were probably formed by the ultra-high pressure of the impact.
They aim to design an affordable car that gets ultrahigh mileage without sacrificing performance.

meanings.definition: used to describe a system for showing extremely clear pictures on a television or computer screen:
examples: Participants in two locations are able to meet "face-to-face" using ultra-high definition video and superior audio.
An ultrahigh-definition television system with 4000 scanning lines was developed.

meanings.definition: a system for showing extremely clear pictures on a television or computer screen:
examples: This week, they released the same image in ultra-high definition.

meanings.definition: very hip (= fashionable) :
examples: She took us to an ultra-hip restaurant where you have to know the host to be allowed in.
They live in an ultra-hip part of the city with a lot of underground bars and an active night life.

meanings.definition: very hot in temperature:
examples: The sun has an ultra-hot core that works like an enormous nuclear furnace.
The research team uses sound waves to generate ultrahot temperatures.

meanings.definition: very spicy:
examples: He couldn't talk after eating Mum's ultra-hot curry.
These chillies are ultra-hot.

meanings.definition: very fashionable, popular, or attractive:
examples: The contemporary art market is ultra-hot at the moment.
He played an ultrahot doctor on the long-running soap opera.

meanings.definition: having more powers than, or seeming outside the powers of, a human:
examples: I do not claim to have any ultra-human abilities when it comes to forecasting the weather.

meanings.definition: very characteristic of the qualities, faults, and feelings that people have, as opposed to gods, animals, or machines:
examples: Unlike robots, we keep making the same ultra-human emotional errors over and over again.

meanings.definition: having or relating to opinions that are on the extreme political left:
examples: The organization draws its members from both the ultra-left and ultra-right wings of politics.
The group's activities at the time were associated with an ultra-Left fight against capitalism.

meanings.definition: support for the extreme political left:
examples: At that time she was associated with what many of her critics labelled ultra-leftism.
Her novels include a number of political themes, including the ultraleftism that characterized politics in Italy in the 1970s.

meanings.definition: having or relating to opinions that are on the extreme political left:
examples: She said that while she does not see herself as conservative, she is not "ultra-leftist" either.
He quoted the former ultra-Leftist German Foreign Minister, who had had similar views.
The time of the ultraleftist policies was now over and a new political era had begun.

meanings.definition: a person who has opinions that are on the extreme political left:
examples: He was an ultra-leftist in the Seventies who later mellowed into a mainstream politician.
She was known in Spain as an ultra-Leftist.

meanings.definition: believing or relating to the opinions of the political left, especially that society should change so that money, property, and power are shared more fairly, but in a way that seems extreme to many people :
examples: She believes that the senator's ultra-liberal values are far from the beliefs of ordinary folks.
He tried to get voters to believe that his opponent, if elected, would press an ultra-liberal agenda that included the raising of taxes.

meanings.definition: believing strongly in allowing a lot of freedom for businesses to buy, sell, and make money without many rules or limits, and with low taxes:
examples: The candidate cannot afford to be associated with the ultra-liberal right.

meanings.definition: a person who has very liberal political opinions:
examples: No one expected him to choose an ultra-liberal to be his chief foreign policy advisor.
Her opponent tried to paint her as an ultra-liberal who would raise taxes on the middle class.

meanings.definition: weighing very little or much less than average:
examples: My daughter asked if she could use my ultra-lightweight laptop when she travels for work.
The tent is made of ultralightweight material.

meanings.definition: at a much lower level or amount than usual:
examples: Political leaders fear that ultralow oil prices will curtail domestic production.
The company divested of the repossessed properties by selling them off at ultra-low prices.

meanings.definition: shining extremely brightly or producing a very large amount of light:
examples: Scientists are trying to make sense of ultraluminous infrared galaxies, which emit most of their energy in infrared waves.
The astronomer believes that these ultra-luminous sources in space may have x-rays beaming towards Earth, and possess ten times the mass of the sun.

meanings.definition: active, determined, and willing to use force, especially in order to achieve political aims:
examples: Ultra-militant workers led a violent rebellion against the new labour laws.
The men were part of a small ultra-militant group that was held responsible for the kidnapping of a prominent journalist last year.

meanings.definition: made extremely small, especially using modern technology:
examples: Advances in nanotechnology--the development of ultra-miniaturized tools and devices--help us explore places not previously possible, such as spaces inside the human body.
They envision a day in which an ultra-miniaturised computer is able to fit inside a contact lens.

meanings.definition: using very modern styles or ideas:
examples: The kitchen is equipped with ultra-modern, stainless steel appliances.
Each room was decorated in a different style, ranging from Victorian to ultra-modern.

meanings.definition: following the styles or ideas of modernism (= a movement that uses new styles in art, music, dance, etc. in a way that is very different from the traditions of the past) in a very noticeable way:
examples: The plans for the museum call for a four-story, ultra-modernist structure made primarily of zinc and glass.
The ballet is an ultramodernist work set to the sounds of electronic noise.

meanings.definition: an extreme belief in nationalism (= a very great love for your country and a belief that it is better than others):
examples: A country's political and economic collapse might cause it to retreat into ultra-nationalism.
The stricter citizenship laws are attributed to a rise in ultranationalism that has spread across the country.

meanings.definition: a person who has an extreme belief in nationalism (= a very great love for your country and a belief that it is better than others):
examples: He is one of a group of ultra-nationalists who demand stricter controls on immigration.
Changes in governmental policy have led to a surge of violence by ultranationalists who demand a return to the country they once knew.

meanings.definition: having an extreme belief in nationalism (= a very great love for your country and a belief that it is better than others):
examples: The newspaper has been the target of ultranationalist protests.
Many ultra-nationalist members of the party did not want the country to sign onto the international accord.

meanings.definition: Ultra-pasteurized milk, cream, etc. has been pasteurized (= heated at a controlled temperature for a fixed time in order to kill bacteria) at a higher than normal temperature, especially so that it stays fresh for a long time:
examples: They refuse to drink any ultra-pasteurized milk.
Milk is usually sold in plastic bottles, unless it's ultra-pasteurized.

meanings.definition: extremely patriotic (= showing love for your country and being proud of it):
examples: In the current flag-waving, ultra-patriotic climate, a foreign film like this is unlikely to do well.
Both these businessmen are from middle-class backgrounds and are ultrapatriotic.

meanings.definition: (of a sport, activity, etc.) involving a lot of very energetic movement of the body, and sometimes a lot of rough touching or hitting between people:
examples: The ultra-physical nature of modern football means that even the best players might not have very long careers.
She became famous for her latest dance show, which has a lot of ultraphysical and expressive choreography.

meanings.definition: (of places and things) very expensive and of high quality, or relating to or suitable for people of a high social class:
examples: The famous department store, Harrods, is found in London's ultra-posh Knightsbridge.
He is the owner of an ultra-posh golf club, which counts royals among its members.

meanings.definition: having a very strong effect:
examples: Astronomers discovered the new planets using an ultra-powerful space telescope.
Chemists developed an ultrapowerful weedkiller that was supposed to be safe on food crops.

meanings.definition: (of a person) having a very large amount of power to control people and events:
examples: As the ultra-powerful head of a movie studio, he had a lot of sway in the industry.

meanings.definition: very useful and suitable for using in a particular situation:
examples: The travel bag is ultra-practical, with three spacious compartments to keep your belongings organized and easy to reach.
The artist devised an ultrapractical solution for storing his supplies.

meanings.definition: very exact and accurate:
examples: With special optical instruments, physicists are able to make ultra-precise measurements of nanoparticles.
His diction when he sings is ultra-precise and clear.

meanings.definition: the quality of being extremely accurate or exact:
examples: He is a master of comic timing, bringing ultra-precision to his physical gags and verbal reactions.
The eyeliner's applicator has an ultra-precision tip to help you achieve that perfect look.

meanings.definition: (of food) prepared using industrial processes, usually involving a large number of ingredients, many of which would not normally be used in preparing or cooking food at home:
examples: The study found a positive correlation between the consumption of ultra-processed food and obesity.
People often choose ultraprocessed foods because they are cheap and easy to prepare.
Fast food is often ultra-processed and filled with empty calories.

meanings.definition: having a lot of the qualities that you connect with trained and skilled people, such as effectiveness, skill, organization, and seriousness of manner:
examples: The repairman showed up on time and was ultra-professional, focused exclusively on the task at hand.
The band was made up of a dozen ultraprofessional performers who put on a quality show every night.

meanings.definition: having opinions that are very new and modern, or that encourage change in society or in the way that things are done:
examples: His views about public education were well ahead of their time and still might be thought of as as ultra-progressive by some people today.
Some of the more ultraprogressive candidates might have a hard time wooing rural voters.

meanings.definition: extremely quiet; making very little or no sound:
examples: The fan has an ultraquiet motor so that you hardly notice it is running.
The navy uses sonar to detect ultra-quiet submarines that might be lurking in nearby waters.

meanings.definition: operating, moving, or happening very quickly:
examples: The engineers designed new, more powerful computer chips for use in ultra-rapid processors.
The cells are preserved by ultrarapid cooling.

meanings.definition: very unlikely to be seen, experienced, etc.:
examples: They stumbled upon ultra-rare footage of the band's first concert, played when the members were still in high school together.
Birdwatchers were eager for a glimpse of the ultra-rare hawk that was said to live in the forest.

meanings.definition: influenced only by reason and not by emotion:
examples: We have to remember that voters are not puppets or ultra-rational robots, but flesh-and-blood humans.
They might be expected to reject the offer as unfair, but in this case their ultra-rational side wins out over their emotional reaction.

meanings.definition: trying to represent life as it really is, rather than in an imagined way, so that the things that are shown seem real:
examples: Her directorial debut is an a bleak, ultra-realist drama that chronicles the lives of squatters and addicts in the city.
The ultra-realist sculptor makes figures that look eerily like real humans, right down to the muscles and hair.

meanings.definition: very realistic (= seeming to exist or happen in real life):
examples: The film feels artificial, despite the ultrarealistic urban locations.
Some companies design complex flight training simulators that are ultra-realistic.

meanings.definition: An ultra-refined substance has been made extra pure by removing other substances from it:
examples: High-fructose corn syrup is an ultra-refined sweetener found in many processed foods.
I began supplementing my diet by taking capsules of ultra-refined fish oil.

meanings.definition: of a very high quality, and showing a lot of skill or the result of many improvements:
examples: The bedpost had beautiful carvings accented in ultra-refined goldwork.
Their music is traditional but their playing is ultra-refined, with many delicate embellishments.

meanings.definition: very polite and showing a lot of knowledge of social rules:
examples: He is known to many as an ultra-refined and sensitive aesthete.
The presenter spoke with ultrarefined eloquence.

meanings.definition: very reliable (= able to be trusted or believed due to working or behaving well in the way you expect):
examples: The team can always count on their ultra-reliable goalkeeper.
If you have an ultra-reliable internet connection, you can stream the entire presentation.

meanings.definition: very respectable (= considered to be socially acceptable because of your good character, appearance, or behaviour):
examples: He is the son of ultra-respectable middle-class parents, his father a police officer and his mother a nurse.
In those days it was unusual for someone like her, whose background was ultra-respectable, to become an actress.

meanings.definition: having an extremely large amount of money or property:
examples: He says politicians listen more to their ultra-rich donors than they do their constituents.
As a valet he takes care of the luxury automobiles driven by the hotel's ultra-rich clientele.

meanings.definition: (of food) containing a large amount of things such as eggs, butter, or cream that make you feel very full:
examples: The pie had an ultra-rich custard filling, and I could only manage a few bites.
We were served a delicious oyster stew in a savory, ultrarich broth.

meanings.definition: having or relating to opinions that are on the extreme political right:
examples: The leading member of that country's ultra-right party is a candidate for prime minister.
There has been an ultra-right movement to remove certain books from school libraries.

meanings.definition: support for the extreme political right:
examples: A wave of ultra-rightism culminated in a military coup and the installation of a new leader.
The new history book looks at a time when ultra-rightism influenced much of the politics in the country.

meanings.definition: having or relating to opinions that are on the extreme political right:
examples: He was the founder of an ultra-rightist party in Spain.
The ultrarightist dream of recreating a militarist nation after the war never happened.

meanings.definition: a person who has opinions that are on the extreme political right:
examples: He was an ultra-rightist who had been sentenced for the murder in 1980 of a left-wing student.
Supporters of the ultrarightist gathered to celebrate his victory.

meanings.definition: very romantic (= expressing or related to love, especially between people who are or want to be in a sexual relationship):
examples: The pianist played a string of ultra-romantic compositions and dedicated them to the lovers out in the audience.
He surprised his wife with an ultraromantic getaway cruise for their 20th anniversary.

meanings.definition: showing very strong support for a ruling king or queen or the very strong belief that a king or queen should rule a country:
examples: Ultraroyalist protestors occupied the airport and shut it down for a week.
The queen addressed the nation, with her ultra-royalist supporters hanging on her every word.

meanings.definition: a person who shows very strong support for a ruling king or queen or the very strong belief that a king or queen should rule their country:
examples: Otto von Bismarck became known as an ultra-royalist within the Prussian parliament, vociferously defending the divine right of the monarchy.
He unseated an ultraroyalist in the most recent election to assume leadership of the party.

meanings.definition: a person who runs very long distances or competes in running races, such as ultramarathons, that are longer than usual races:
examples: A marathon is simply a stroll for an ultra-runner.
Perhaps the most accomplished ultrarunner ever from the United States, he completed the Barkley in 58 hours 21 minutes.

meanings.definition: the activity or sport of running very long distances or competing in running races, such as ultramarathons, that are longer than usual races:
examples: Ultra-running is any run that exceeds the 26 miles of a marathon.
To prep his body, Robinson took up ultrarunning and began putting in 50 miles a week training on dirt trails.

meanings.definition: very unlikely to cause harm:
examples: Motor racing now is ultra-safe compared to how it was in the past.
A few extra minutes on the grill will make the meat ultra-safe.

meanings.definition: very unlikely to lose value:
examples: Their advisor recommended that they transfer their savings to an ultra-safe money market fund.
Investors eagerly bought up the ultra-safe government bonds at low interest rates.

meanings.definition: extremely secret (= kept from being seen or known by others):
examples: He had been part of an elite, ultra-secret spy unit, but he was never able to speak about what he saw behind enemy lines.
Ultrasecret classified documents had fallen into the enemy's hands.

meanings.definition: needing to be handled very carefully in order to avoid upsetting people:
examples: The show handles ultrasensitive issues such as racism and domestic abuse in a thoughtful way.
My relationship with my mother is an ultra-sensitive topic that I'd prefer not to talk about.

meanings.definition: very likely to get upset:
examples: It's not easy to be a writer if you are ultra-sensitive to criticism.
Be careful how you tell him, because he's ultrasensitive.

meanings.definition: very likely to experience a reaction or be affected or harmed by something:
examples: In people with the condition, eyes become ultrasensitive to drugs that dilate the pupils.
I'm very careful about which cosmetic products I use as I have ultra-sensitive skin.

meanings.definition: able to notice or record very slight changes or details:
examples: Scientists have devised an ultrasensitive MRI technique that can detect the spin of a single electron.
The ultrasensitive seismograph records underground waves of energy generated by earthquakes.

meanings.definition: not joking or trying to be funny at all:
examples: The judge has an ultra-serious persona in the courtroom, but those who know her personally admire her sense of humour.
His character provides the comic relief on the show in contrast to his ultra-serious partner.

meanings.definition: very determined to try hard and do well in a job, task, hobby, etc.:
examples: The magazine features gourmet recipes for the ultraserious home cook.
His friends describe him as ambitious, driven, and ultra-serious.

meanings.definition: having a very thin edge or point that can cut something or make a hole in something easily:
examples: The tool has an ultra-sharp blade that zests perfectly and grates big piles of cheese with no effort.
Be careful with the saw blades because they're ultrasharp.

meanings.definition: very clear and easy to see or understand:
examples: Our new digital television allows us to watch the match with an ultrasharp high definition picture.
The way the two characters respond to a crisis bring their distinct personalities into ultra-sharp relief.

meanings.definition: not at all difficult or complicated:
examples: This is an ultra-simple recipe, using ingredients that you probably already have in the kitchen.
This free, ultrasimple program will enable your computer to work with your other devices such as camcorders.

meanings.definition: made, done, or working in a very skilful way as if without any effort :
examples: The candidate launched his campaign for governor with an ultra-slick announcement video.
The new movie is an ultra-slick production, with dynamic special effects and a jazzy soundtrack, in contrast to the director's first feature, which was much more raw.

meanings.definition: (of a person) doing things in a very impressive and skilful way, as if without any effort:
examples: The petroleum company's ultra-slick public relations director gracefully deflected questions about the oil spill.

meanings.definition: very attractive, modern and fashionable:
examples: The elite, ultraslick nightclub gives celebrities a place to hang out while getting away from prying tabloid photographers.
She upgraded to an ultra-slick wardrobe after earning her promotion to regional vice-president.

meanings.definition: extremely slow:
examples: The band was playing an ultra-slow version of a classic song.
The ultra-slow roasting of spice seeds gives this dish its special flavour.

meanings.definition: extremely small:
examples: They are developing a new range of ultra-small computers.
They use ultrasmall particles to make the material stronger.

meanings.definition: A place or event that is ultra-smart attracts extremely fashionable, stylish, or rich people:
examples: She lives in an ultra-smart area of Paris.
We stayed in an ultra-smart villa that had its own private beach.

meanings.definition: extremely intelligent:
examples: He plays the part of an ultra-smart computer programmer.
She specializes in ultra-smart putdowns of audience members.

meanings.definition: having an extremely smooth surface:
examples: Her hair was ultra-smooth and sleek.
ultrasmooth paper

meanings.definition: happening or working without any sudden changes or interruptions at all:
examples: The recording features some ultra-smooth saxophone playing.
This vehicle has an ultra-smooth suspension system.

meanings.definition: without any difficulties at all:
examples: Opening night was ultra-smooth - everything went perfectly.
The horse had an ultra-smooth victory.

meanings.definition: having an extremely pleasant flavour that is not sour or bitter:
examples: an ultra-smooth malt whisky
a wine with an ultra-smooth flavour

meanings.definition: extremely polite and confident, but in a way that is not sincere:
examples: an ultra-smooth quiz-show host
The sales adviser was poised and ultra-smooth.

meanings.definition: extremely soft:
examples: This shampoo will leave your hair shiny and ultra-soft.
a rabbit with ultrasoft fur

meanings.definition: having a lot of parts or made in an extremely complicated way:
examples: The film uses ultra-sophisticated special effects.
a new range of ultrasophisticated cameras

meanings.definition: having an extremely good understanding of the way people behave or a very good knowledge of culture and fashion, or liked by people who are like this:
examples: My ultra-sophisticated friends all rushed out to buy the latest new gadget.
The coffee-making machine comes in an ultra-sophisticated black case.

meanings.definition: having an extremely small distance between two opposite sides:
examples: This laptop uses an ultra-thin battery.
They launched a new range of ultra-thin television sets.

meanings.definition: An ultra-thin person has hardly any flesh on their bones:
examples: ultra-thin fashion models
She dresses in clothes that suit her ultra-thin body.

meanings.definition: Things that are ultra-tiny are even smaller than other small things:
examples: They specialize in producing ultra-tiny comic books that are smaller than your fingernail.
The shop sells the sort of ultra-tiny swimsuits that no normal person would ever wear.

meanings.definition: extremely traditional :
examples: The apartment is furnished like an ultra-traditional French family home.
They had planned an ultratraditional marriage ceremony.

meanings.definition: the use of extreme force to hurt or kill people:
examples: The film is a strange mixture of gentle humour and shocking ultra-violence.
The novel is notorious for its scenes of ultraviolence.

meanings.definition: showing or involving the use of extreme force to hurt or kill people:
examples: This is what happens when children stay up all night playing ultra-violent video games.
The novel concerns the ultra-violent adventures of a young drug addict on the streets of Glasgow.

meanings.definition: having a much larger distance from one side to the other than is usual or expected, especially in comparison with the length of something:
examples: I use a laptop computer with an ultra-wide screen.
The ultra-wide lanes provide plenty of room for cyclists to pass each other.

meanings.definition: extremely cold:
examples: A new freezer stores tissue at ultra-cold temperatures.
The physicists are able to produce complex molecules in ultracold quantum gases.

meanings.definition: someone who has no special knowledge of a subject but who expresses an opinion about it:
examples: I avoid commenting on football for fear of being called an ultracrepidarian.

meanings.definition: expressing an opinion about something that you have no special knowledge of:
examples: Her ultracrepidarian husband seems to know everything about everything.

meanings.definition: consisting of extremely fine (= small or thin) pieces or drops:
examples: People may develop heart disease when they are exposed to ultra-fine particles that are common pollutants in urban air.
A grinder is used to crush the mesquite seeds into an ultra-fine powder.

meanings.definition: very delicate and thin:
examples: The ultra-fine wool from the flock is used to make a line of high-end clothing.
It's time to swap winter’s warm woollens for super-soft cottons and ultra-fine knits.

meanings.definition: an extremely light and small aircraft with a very small engine, designed to carry only one or two people
a running race that is longer than a marathon (= a race that is approximately 26 miles):
examples: I'd just run my first ultramarathon, a 50-kilometer race.
He won the Badwater Ultramarathon across 135 miles of Death Valley.

meanings.definition: a bright blue colour:
examples: The plant has hooded flowers of deepest ultramarine.
The rocks shelved steeply and the colour of the water deepened to ultramarine.

meanings.definition: of a bright blue colour:
examples: Often when she went out she wore an ultramarine evening dress.
Below is an ultramarine sea, streaked emerald green.

meanings.definition: (of a substance) completely clean and not mixed with anything else:
examples: The tiny machines are sculpted out of the ultrapure silicon that is used to make microchips.
The system is designed to filter out waste completely from the water so that the remaining water is ultra-pure.

meanings.definition: extreme realism (= a style in art, film, literature, etc., that tries to represent life as it really is, so that the things that are shown seem real):
examples: The actor was said to have eaten live insects as part of the film's search for ultra-realism.
Her art is known for its ultrarealism.

meanings.definition: Ultrasonic sound is too high for people to hear.
(of sound waves) too high for people to hear
a method of producing images that uses sound waves to view structures inside the body:
examples: The diagnosis was based on ultrasonography.
renal ultrasonography

meanings.definition: special sound waves used in such processes as examining organs inside the body and directing the route of submarines:
examples: They'll use ultrasound to monitor her ovaries.
ultrasound scanning/imaging

meanings.definition: an ultrasound scan
sound waves that are higher than people can hear, esp. ones used to examine and treat medical problems:
examples: An ultrasound scan revealed tissue damage.

meanings.definition: Ultraviolet light has a wavelength that is after the violet (= light purple) end of the range of colours that can be seen by humans. Light of this type causes the skin to become darker in the sun.
describes light at the purple end of the spectrum (= set of colors into which light is separated), which cannot be seen by human beings
a measurement of how effective a fabric is in preventing harmful ultraviolet radiation from reaching the skin:
examples: The ultraviolet protection factor, used to label fabric, indicates how much of the sun's ultraviolet radiation is absorbed.
The UPF (Ultraviolet Protection Factor) specified on the UV protective clothing shows how long a person can stay in the sun wearing this clothing without suffering damage to their health.
Clothes in sun-protective fabrics should have labels that show a UV protection factor (UPF).

meanings.definition: to make a long, high cry with the mouth and tongue that changes between two or three notes, often to show emotion at a ceremony such as a wedding or funeral:
examples: By night, Bamako is a riot of noise as singers ululate at wedding parties.

meanings.definition: a long, high cry with the mouth and tongue that changes between two or three notes, often to show emotion at a ceremony such as a wedding or funeral:
examples: Even the shrill ululations from the temples seemed oddly comforting.
the ululation of Middle Eastern funerals

meanings.definition: used in writing to represent the sound that people make when they are pausing or deciding what to say next:
examples: "What do you think of this jacket?" "Um, I don't know if I like the colour."
"So what did you talk about?" "Um, I don't remember."

meanings.definition: uh
a strong taste that is not sweet, sour, salty, or bitter and that is often referred to as "the fifth taste":
examples: The paste is based on the fifth taste, umami, which is the intensely savoury taste imparted by glutamates that occur naturally in many foods such as meat, fish, and vegetables.

meanings.definition: a cluster (= group) of small flowers on short spreading stems that come from the same point and form a shape similar to an open umbrella:
examples: The flowers are small, greenish-white, and clustered in large rounded umbels.
The elder tree blossoms with huge umbels of starry white flowers.

meanings.definition: a type of plant with hollow stems and flowers that grow in umbels:
examples: Common umbels with edible roots include carrots, celery, celery root (celeriac), and parsley.
the umbel family

meanings.definition: relating to the umbilical cord (= the long tube that connects a baby before it is born to its mother's placenta):
examples: Foetal blood drains towards the placenta through the umbilical arteries.
Resistance to placental flow was created by compression of both umbilical veins.

meanings.definition: relating to the area around the centre of the abdomen (= the lower part of the body):
examples: Hernias may occur in the groin area or around the umbilical area.
Pain in lesions of the small intestine are localized, always in the umbilical region.

meanings.definition: If one person or thing has an umbilical connection with another, it is very closely connected with it and often depends on it:
examples: He was associated with the party's almost umbilical links with the trade union movement.
Entire careers of country artists have been founded on their music's umbilical connection to poor childhoods, picking cotton and hard drinking.

meanings.definition: an umbilical cord (= the long tube that connects a baby before it is born to its mother's placenta):
examples: Premature clamping of the umbilical should be avoided as it can result in brain damage.

meanings.definition: a tube that carries something important, for example a tube carrying air to a diver under the sea:
examples: All divers working in the North Sea use umbilicals.
The company makes umbilicals, tubes that protect and carry cables.

meanings.definition: the long, tube-like structure that connects a baby that has not yet been born to its mother's placenta (= the organ that provides it with food and oxygen):
examples: The nurse cut the baby's umbilical cord.

meanings.definition: the tube that connects a baby to its mother before birth and carries oxygen and food to it

meanings.definition:
plural of

examples: The patient had congestion around the umbo.
The lateral surface of the membrane is concave and the most depressed part of this is the umbo.

meanings.definition: a raised, rounded part at the place where the two shells of a mollusc (= an animal with a soft body inside a shell) join:
examples: Such material is particularly common around the valve margins and umbones.
The surface of the shell has fine concentric ridges which disappear towards the umbo.

meanings.definition: having or relating to the umbo of a shell (= a raised, rounded part where the two shells of a mollusc join):
examples: The shell has rounded, irregular ribs, with a weak ventral median groove originating in the umbonal region.
In the study of bivalves, it is often necessary to break off the umbonal infilling.
