a device for protection against the rain, consisting of a stick with a folding frame covered in material at one end and usually a handle at the other, or a similar, often larger, device used for protection against the sun:
examples: I felt a few drops of rain, so I put my umbrella up.
I left my umbrella on the bus yesterday.
a folding umbrella

meanings.definition: something that includes or represents a group or range of similar things:
examples: He runs a group of companies under the umbrella of Universal Foods.
The Organization of Islamic Conference is an umbrella organization representing 57 Muslim nations.
Existentialism was really an umbrella term to lump together the works of several philosophers and writers.

meanings.definition: a cover that protects from rain or sun, esp. waterproof material fitted on a folding frame with a handle at one end:
examples: A figure carrying an open umbrella walked slowly through the rain.

meanings.definition: An umbrella is also something that includes a number of similar things:
examples: an umbrella term
an umbrella organization

meanings.definition: something that includes or represents a group or range of similar things:
examples: They provide an umbrella of work force development services.
An awful lot of damage is done under the umbrella of ecotourism.

meanings.definition: an investment fund that invests in other funds:
examples: Umbrella funds can be formed to enable investors to switch more easily between funds run by the managers.

meanings.definition: an organization that controls or organizes the activities of several other organizations, all of which have a similar purpose:
examples: The council is the umbrella organization representing about 20,000 tradespeople in the Pittsburgh region.

meanings.definition: a mark put over a vowel in some languages, such as German, to show that the pronunciation of the vowel is changed:
examples: The German word "Gebäude", which means "building", has an umlaut over the "a".

meanings.definition:
informal for a 
        
         umpire  :
examples: The ump blew his whistle.
The umps were consulted, and they correctly ruled it a home run.

meanings.definition: a person who is present at a sports competition in order to make certain that the rules of that particular game are obeyed and to judge if particular actions are acceptable:
examples: a cricket/tennis umpire
The umpire overruled the linesman and ordered the point to be replayed.

meanings.definition: to be the umpire of a game:
examples: Starmers has been chosen to umpire the next cricket test match.

meanings.definition: (in some sports) a person who controls a game and makes sure that the rules are followed

past simple and past participle of 
        
         umpire
to be the umpire of a game:
examples: Starmers has been chosen to umpire the next cricket test match.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         umpire
to be the umpire of a game:
examples: Starmers has been chosen to umpire the next cricket test match.

meanings.definition: very many; a lot (of):
examples: We've been there umpteen times and she still can't remember the way.

meanings.definition: used to say that something happened or came after many other similar things:
examples: I drank my umpteenth cup of coffee.
For the umpteenth time, Anthony, knives and forks go in the middle drawer!

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Universal Mobile Telecommunications System: a system for sending text, voice, and video data to mobile phones and computers:
examples: UMTS will make video phones a commercial reality.

meanings.definition: An un-air-conditioned building, room, or vehicle does not have special equipment that keeps the air in it cool: :
examples: We drove across the country in an un-air-conditioned van.
They had to train in the institute's un-airconditioned gym.

meanings.definition: guilty of activities, behaviour, or beliefs that show opposition or no loyalty to the US and its political system:
examples: From 1940 to 1943, he was general counsel of the House committee investigating un-American activities.

meanings.definition: showing opposition or a lack of support for the US and its political system:
examples: It seems un-American to tell me how to run my business.

meanings.definition: using the soft pedal (= the part on a piano that you press with your foot in order to make the notes sound quieter): used in written music to show how a piece, or part of a piece, should be performed:
examples: The piece is a series of rising arpeggios marked una corda.

meanings.definition: using the soft pedal (= the part on a piano that you press with your foot in order to make the notes sound quieter): used to describe how a piece of music, or part of a piece of music, is performed:
examples: The piano is played una corda in a high register.

meanings.definition: played while pressing the soft pedal (= the part on a piano that you press with your foot in order to make the notes sound quieter) :
examples: After the introduction comes a mysterious una corda passage.

meanings.definition: without any worry about possible criticism or embarrassment:
examples: She is to this day unabashed in her patriotism.
He is an unabashed capitalist.

meanings.definition: not worried about being criticized or embarrassed:
examples: an unabashed critic of Congress
an unabashed supporter of the team

meanings.definition: in an unabashed way (= without any worry about possible criticism):
examples: an unabashedly romantic story
This may be the most unabashedly sentimental piece of theatre you'll see this year.

meanings.definition: without becoming weaker in strength or force:
examples: The fighting continued unabated throughout the night.

meanings.definition: without weakening in strength or force:
examples: Their arguments continue unabated.

meanings.definition: not able:
examples: I was unable to find a pay phone.

meanings.definition: An unabridged book, speech, or article is in its original form and has not been made shorter.
not having been taken into something:
examples: Drain off any unabsorbed liquid before serving.
Seeds are often unabsorbed by the body's digestive system.

meanings.definition: not very interested in something:
examples: She remains unabsorbed by the world of fashion.
He seemed to be quite unabsorbed in his task.

meanings.definition: not able to take liquid in through the surface and hold it:
examples: The soil was very dry but unabsorbent.
The map was printed on smooth, unabsorbent paper.

meanings.definition: not involving a lot of studying and thinking:
examples: She prefers unacademic subjects such as drama and sport.
His work is sometimes criticized by his colleagues for being unacademic.

meanings.definition: Someone who is unacademic does not enjoy studying and learns more from experience than from books:
examples: He made some friends in a group of unacademic older boys.
We should provide better options for unacademic children.

meanings.definition: spoken without any accent (= the way people from a particular country or area pronounce words):
examples: He speaks perfect unaccented English.

meanings.definition: too bad to be accepted, approved of, or allowed to continue:
examples: The teachers' union has described the latest pay offer as unacceptable.
The taking of hostages, said the president, was totally unacceptable under any circumstances.
The report found what it described as "unacceptable levels of air pollution" in several major cities.

meanings.definition: too bad to be accepted, approved of, or allowed to continue:
examples: These mistakes are unacceptable.
The proposal is unacceptable to theater owners.

meanings.definition: in a way that cannot be accepted, approved of, or allowed to continue:
examples: unacceptably high risks

meanings.definition: not made welcome as a member of a group:
examples: He was unloved and unaccepted by his family.
She sometimes felt unaccepted as a teenager.

meanings.definition: If an offer or invitation is unaccepted, someone has not said yes to it:
examples: The invitation to appear at the festival remains unaccepted.
She made an unaccepted offer to extend the contract for another year.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         unacclimatized  :
examples: The unacclimated troops were gasping for breath.
Denver's thin air can make unacclimated tourists feel unwell.

meanings.definition: not having changed to suit different conditions of life, weather, etc.:
examples: We were unacclimatized to the tropical heat.
The soliders had only just arrived in the region and were still unacclimatised.

meanings.definition: not eager or willing to help other people, for example by changing your plans:
examples: The staff in the restaurant were extremely rude and unaccommodating.
I would like to take more time off to help but I have a very unaccommodating boss.

meanings.definition: not having anyone with you when you go somewhere:
examples: The airline's policy on unaccompanied minors states that children aged 5 to 7 can fly only on direct and nonstop flights.
An estimated 30 unaccompanied children arrive at the city's train stations every day.
To everyone's great surprise, the princess arrived at the ball unaccompanied.

meanings.definition: not having the owner present:
examples: Unaccompanied baggage is a possible vehicle for a bomb.

meanings.definition: not having something else happen or be present at the same time:
examples: These accusations are unaccompanied by any real proof.
A fever unaccompanied by any other symptoms of being sick may not need treatment.

meanings.definition: Unaccompanied music is produced by a singer or by someone playing a musical instrument without anyone else singing or playing at the same time:
examples: People are often more capable of good unaccompanied singing than they realize.
She sang the first three verses with a piano and the last verse unaccompanied.

meanings.definition: without anyone with you, or (of the voice or an instrument) sung or played without other musical instruments:
examples: Unaccompanied teens were banned from the mall.
The kids sang an unaccompanied version of "Skylark."

meanings.definition: not able to be explained or understood:
examples: For some unaccountable reason, he keeps his wallet in his underwear drawer.

meanings.definition: not able to be explained or understood:
examples: For some unaccountable reason, he forgot his car keys.

meanings.definition: Someone who is unaccountable does not have to explain his or her actions to anyone in authority.
in a way that cannot be explained or understood:
examples: I felt unaccountably happy this morning.
Unaccountably, the lawyer never called this supposed witness.

meanings.definition: If a person is unaccounted for, it is not known where they are or whether they are still alive:
examples: A fire on the ship killed a hundred or more passengers - some likely victims are still unaccounted for.

meanings.definition: If something such as an amount of money is unaccounted for, it is not present and there is no explanation for what has happened to it:
examples: An audit of the police department found that $100,000 in cash and one handgun were unaccounted for.

meanings.definition: not officially recognized or approved:
examples: She holds a degree from an unaccredited university.
They will not allow unaccredited foreign journalists to enter the country.

meanings.definition: not familiar with something, or not used to something:
examples: The weather presented a particular challenge, especially for soldiers unaccustomed to subarctic conditions.

meanings.definition: not usual:
examples: The Olympic and world champion finished in the unaccustomed position of fourth.

meanings.definition: (of a person) not familiar with or experienced at something:
examples: She was unaccustomed to driving in heavy traffic.

meanings.definition: Unaccustomed can also mean unusual or unexpected:
examples: His unaccustomed nervousness made us all anxious.

meanings.definition: An unachievable task, ambition, etc. is one that is impossible to achieve:
examples: Cheap, pesticide-free food is probably an unachievable objective.
Engineering limitations rendered the goal unachievable.

meanings.definition: not able to be done, reached, or finished successfully:
examples: Doubling our sales figures in the next year is an unachievable goal.
Many critics believe that unbiased journalism is unachievable.

meanings.definition: If your aim is unachieved, you have not succeeded in reaching it, especially after a lot of work or effort:
examples: The objectives that we set ourselves five years ago remain unachieved.
I worry that so many of my goals are still unachieved as I approach the age of thirty.

meanings.definition: not accepted, admitted, or recognized:
examples: Her contibution to the field of astronomy often goes unacknowledged.
Workers can feel unacknowledged in a large organization.

meanings.definition: If a message or gift is unacknowledged, the person who received it does not tell the person who sent it that it has arrived:
examples: Both of my letters have gone unacknowledged.
A month after he sent it, his appeal to the directors remained unanswered and unacknowledged.

meanings.definition: not knowing or being familiar with a person:
examples: Marta and Toni were unacquainted.
All of the people in the group were previously unacquainted.

meanings.definition: unfamiliar with something, because you have not studied it or experienced it before:
examples: I am unacquainted with her work.
He said that he was totally unacquainted with Vietnamese cookery.
She seems to be unacquainted with the realities of the modern business world.
For those unacquainted with his religious views, this article may come as a surprise.
They were evidently unacquainted with the rules of cricket.
I'm not unacquainted with his work - I studied his writing at university.

meanings.definition: not done or performed:
examples: He used his writing as an outlet for unacted desires.
Among her papers were several long poems and unacted plays.

meanings.definition: If a wish is unacted upon, you do not do anything to try to make it happen:
examples: His violent inclinations remained unacted upon.
Your application must remain unacted upon until after the election.
Her criminal instincts, mostly unacted upon, caused her friends to be wary of her.
We put forward a motion but so far it is still unacted upon.
He admitted that he had feelings for Sarah which remained unacted upon.

meanings.definition: not able or willing to change or be changed in order to suit different conditions :
examples: He was a Southern gentleman and that made him unadaptable to life in the hustling Midwest.

meanings.definition: (of an artistic work) not able to be changed into a different form:
examples: Long thought unadaptable, Mervyn Peake's fantastical tale finally makes it to the small screen.

meanings.definition: not having been changed for a particular purpose or use:
examples: Many disabled people cannot cope with unadapted buses and taxis.
Most of her books have been adapted for television, but this novel remains unadapted.

meanings.definition: If a matter or problem is unaddressed, no one has given attention to it or dealt with it:
examples: This review aims to identify some important issues that remain unaddressed.
The issue of bullying was left unaddressed by school officials.

meanings.definition: If an envelope or parcel is unaddressed, there is no name or address written on it:
examples: The letter was unaddressed and unsigned.
Someone had left a large unaddressed parcel on my desk.

meanings.definition: If a crime or legal case is unadjudicated, a judge has not made a formal decision about it:
examples: The court left the claim unadjudicated.
Many of the complaints that were brought before the panel went unadjudicated.

meanings.definition: not having changed or been changed for a particular situation or use:
examples: I was still jetlagged and unadjusted to the time change even after a week in Australia.
Unadjusted, a detergent would be an unattractive, thin, colourless liquid with little or no smell.

meanings.definition: Unadjusted figures (= numbers) have not been changed slightly to become more correct or useful:
examples: The figures are unadjusted for inflation.
The firm recorded an unadjusted operating loss of a million pounds.

meanings.definition: unadjusted figures do not consider particular things such as inflation, which would make the figures easier to compare with others:
examples: Retail sales will grow at a 1.4% annual rate, unadjusted for inflation.
In data unadjusted for service quality improvements, productivity declined by an average of 2% per year for the past five years.
On an unadjusted basis, a 0.7% rise in overall output prices in October was the biggest month-on-month gain since March of last year.
At an unadjusted rate of 7.3%, Janesville had the 33rd highest unemployment in February.

meanings.definition: If someone or something is unadmired, people do not think that they are attractive or pleasant, or that they deserve respect:
examples: The work of such a fine artist cannot be unnoticed or unadmired.
He was a pathetic creature who died friendless and unadmired.

meanings.definition: not publicly or openly admitted:
examples: The government has made an unadmitted reversal of its policy.
He had an unadmitted motive for accepting the job.

meanings.definition: not allowed to enter or join something:
examples: There was a long queue of unadmitted customers stretching along the pavement.
The children stood unadmitted outside the house.

meanings.definition: If an animal or child is unadoptable, there is some reason why they cannot be adopted (= permanently taken into someone's home as part of their family):
examples: Many of the dogs have behavioural problems that make them unadoptable.
Very young children are rarely found to be unadoptable.

meanings.definition: (of a child) not having been adopted (= taken legally into another person's family and taken care of as their own child):
examples: She said the proposal might block grandparents from purchasing health insurance for unadopted grandchildren in their custody.

meanings.definition: (of an animal) not having been taken from a place such as a rescue centre to become someone's pet:
examples: He helped create Best Friends as an alternative to shelters killing unadopted animals to make space.

meanings.definition: (of a road, etc.) private rather than owned and maintained (= kept in good condition) by a local government:
examples: Unadopted roads normally have to be maintained by residents, although the local authority may provide street lighting.

meanings.definition: plain and simple, with little or no decoration:
examples: her unadorned beauty

meanings.definition: not spoiled or made weaker by the addition of other substances; pure:
examples: People injecting drugs can never be sure that they're using unadulterated substances.

meanings.definition: complete:
examples: a feeling of unadulterated joy

meanings.definition: not spoiled or made weaker by the addition of other things:
examples: She sings pure, unadulterated gospel.

meanings.definition: not willing to try new or difficult things:
examples: He was often criticized for his unadventurous tactics.
I find her books repetitive and unadventurous.

meanings.definition: not exciting or dangerous:
examples: I prefer a quiet and unadventurous existence.
He led a leisurely, unadventurous life in the suburbs.

meanings.definition: If a product or service is unadvertised, no advertisement has been been made for it:
examples: Products that are advertised on television can be twice as expensive as unadvertised alternatives.
The store is offering some great unadvertised deals.

meanings.definition: not having been made known to the general public:
examples: She ordered something from the unadvertised vegan menu.
The band played an unadvertised acoustic concert at a local club.

meanings.definition: If something is unaesthetic, it is not attractive or beautiful:
examples: Her lipstick left an unaesthetic smudge on the glass.
He was wearing purple socks and a very unaesthetic pair of brown shoes.

meanings.definition: not influenced, harmed, or interrupted in any way:
examples: The west of the city was largely unaffected by the bombing.
Flights out of most major airports were unaffected by the snow.

meanings.definition: natural and sincere in your behaviour:
examples: For someone who has spent 40 years in show business she seems relatively unaffected by it all.

meanings.definition: not influenced or changed in any way:
examples: Internet access will be unaffected by the upgrade.

meanings.definition: natural and sincere:
examples: Her writing is very unaffected and easy to read.

meanings.definition: in a way that is natural and sincere:
examples: They are both tremendously, unaffectedly nice people, who have become great friends.
He is most unaffectedly modest.

meanings.definition: not causing a strong emotion, especially sadness:
examples: Watching the play is a disappointingly unaffecting experience.
The special effects are unaffecting despite all of the money that appears to have been spent on them.

meanings.definition: not showing feelings of liking or loving someone:
examples: My mother was a harsh and unaffectionate woman.
She was raised by a distant, unaffectionate father who refused to let his daughter play with other girls in the neighbourhood.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not show liking or love:
examples: She pushed her daughter away unaffectionately.
The school was unaffectionately nicknamed "Colditz" by some of its students.

meanings.definition: not connected with or controlled by a group or organization:
examples: The man who helped him was unaffiliated with the church.

meanings.definition: used to refer to people who do not state that they support a particular political party when they register to vote:
examples: Of the district's 476,535 registered voters, 39% are Republicans, 34% are unaffiliated and 27 % are Democrats.

meanings.definition: too expensive for people to be able to buy or pay for:
examples: For many people, this type of treatment remains unaffordable.

meanings.definition: not afraid:
examples: The party leader has been unafraid to speak his mind.

meanings.definition: not behaving in an angry and violent way:
examples: She was a tiny, unaggressive kind of person who made people want to protect her.
The dunlin is a small and unaggressive bird.

meanings.definition: not using forceful action to win or to achieve success:
examples: He decided to take the cautious, unaggressive route to victory.
They have picked up market share from some of their more unaggressive rivals.

meanings.definition: without any help from anyone else; independently:
examples: Since his accident, he hasn't been able to walk unaided.
The two explorers attempted an unaided walk across the South Pole.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         inalienable formal
feeling that you have some connection with the people around you or that you are part of a group:
examples: Our ancestors were unalienated from their society.
An unalienated perspective can promote solidarity and belonging.

meanings.definition: Unalienated land cannot legally be sold or given from one owner to another:
examples: Much of the county's land area consists of unalienated public land.
The country's indigenous people may have a right to unalienated lands.

meanings.definition: People or things that are unalike are not similar to each other:
examples: The political views of the two women could hardly be more unalike.
At first sight, the two cities are entirely unalike.

meanings.definition: If something bad such as pain or a problem is unalleviated, nothing happens to make it less severe:
examples: The last few months have been a time of unalleviated misery for us.
The dull plot is unalleviated by any moments of humour.

meanings.definition: not having been given to someone as their share of a total amount, to use in a particular way:
examples: The hospital has hardly any unallocated cash that it can use for emergencies.
The seats for the concert are unallocated, so we need to arrive early.

meanings.definition: (especially of a positive feeling) not spoiled by any amount of negative feeling; pure:
examples: Spending time with one's family is never an unalloyed pleasure (= there are bad things about it too).
We had the perfect holiday - two weeks of unalloyed bliss.

meanings.definition: not attractive or exciting:
examples: She had a small flat in one of the more unalluring parts of the town.
This book is actually well worth reading if you are not put off by its unalluring title.

meanings.definition: not able to be changed:
examples: He considered evil to be an unalterable fact of the world.
Data stored in this system is unalterable and read-only.

meanings.definition: that has stayed the same or not been changed:
examples: The museum has remained unaltered for a very long time.
All the documents that you present must be unaltered originals certified by the issuing agency.

meanings.definition: (of an animal) that has not been castrated or spayed (= had part of its sex organs removed), or that has not had another body part changed or removed:
examples: Owners must pay a $7 registration fee for neutered pets and $30 for unaltered pets.
The ears of this breed are traditionally cropped, although some modern dogs are unaltered.

meanings.definition: expressed in a way that makes it completely clear what is meant:
examples: The minister promised a clear and unambiguous statement on the future of the coal industry.

meanings.definition: expressed in a way which makes it completely clear what is meant:
examples: an unambiguous answer

meanings.definition: in a way that makes completely clear what is meant:
examples: Her lawyers stated unambiguously that she's not aware of any unethical conduct.
The rules need to be unambiguously clear.

meanings.definition: An unambitious person does not have a strong wish to be successful, powerful, or rich:
examples: She plays a competent, attractive young woman stuck with a slovenly and unambitious young man.
He left school at 16, not because he was unambitious, but because he wanted to get on with his working life.

meanings.definition: An unambitious idea or plan does not need much skill or effort to be achieved or to be successful:
examples: The initial idea for the festival was something quite small and unambitious.
He called the current proposals "very lazy and unambitious".

meanings.definition: If you are unamenable to something, you are not willing to accept it or be influenced by it:
examples: These children are totally unamenable to discipline.
Few people are unamenable to his considerable charm.

meanings.definition: If something is unamenable to study, measurement, etc., it cannot be studied, measured, etc.:
examples: The disease turned out to be unpredictable and unamenable to scientific study.

meanings.definition: If the words of a text, especially a law or a legal document, are unamended, they have not been changed:
examples: The bill is unlikely to pass into law unamended.
The customer was referring to an old, unamended copy of the catalogue.

meanings.definition: not pleasant and friendly:
examples: He comes across as a gruff, unamiable sort of person.
She has managed to reach the top of her profession without becoming at all unamiable or pretentious.

meanings.definition: An unamortized debt or cost has not been reduced by small regular amounts:
examples: We have included the unamortised part of the expenses in the calculation.
All unamortized amounts relating to the terminated lease have been written off.

meanings.definition: Unamplified sounds have not been played through an amplifier (= an electrical device) in order to make them louder:
examples: I really enjoy listening to unamplified live music.
The power failed, and I had to make the presentation using just my unamplified voice.

meanings.definition: not funny:
examples: The seemingly never-ending saga of his injured foot was tiresome and unamusing.
He whacks bystanders with a balloon and cracks elaborately unamusing jokes.

meanings.definition: not given an anaesthetic (= a substance that makes a person or animal unable to feel pain) for an operation, test, etc., or done without an anaesthetic:
examples: The tests were done on unanaesthetized rabbits.
He performed an emergency C-section on an unanaesthetised patient to save a foetus in distress.

meanings.definition: impossible to analyse (= study or examine in detail, or explain):
examples: The researchers ended up with a large amount of unanalysable recorded data.
He argues that the concept of "good" is indefinable and unanalysable.

meanings.definition: not having been studied or examined in detail:
examples: A backlog of unanalysed samples can delay criminal investigations for months.
These are merely unanalysed gross figures.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         unanalysable

US spelling of 
        
         unanalysed

a US spelling of 
        
         unanaesthetized
the state of being unanimous
complete agreement among every member of group:
examples: No one has ever suggested that there is unanimity in the party on all issues.

meanings.definition: If a group of people are unanimous, they all agree about one particular matter or vote the same way, and if a decision or judgment is unanimous, it is formed or supported by everyone in a group:
examples: The jury returned a unanimous verdict of guilty after a short deliberation.
After a lengthy discussion we reached a unanimous decision on the proposal.
The new format has unanimous support.

meanings.definition: in complete agreement or showing complete agreement:
examples: The school board was unanimous in its support of the decision.
The jury reached a unanimous verdict.

meanings.definition: if a feeling, decision, action, etc. is unanimous, everyone in a group feels it or agrees to it:
examples: This is a sound plan that enjoys the unanimous support of the Board of Directors.
In the Senate, 60 votes are needed if there is not unanimous consent to proceed with a bill.
We reached a unanimous decision on the proposal.
It would require the unanimous vote of the board of supervisors to enact the rule.

meanings.definition: if a group of people is unanimous, everyone agrees to something:
examples: The committee was unanimous, and the new rules were made official.

meanings.definition: in a way that is agreed or supported by everyone in a group:
examples: All four proposals to the committee were unanimously approved.
The Board voted unanimously to terminate his three-year contract.

meanings.definition: An unannotated document does not have any explanations or notes added to the text:
examples: When I managed to unearth my old, unannotated edition, I found that the missing passage amounts to 37 words.
All 50 sections of the US Code, unannotated, easily take up an entire bookshelf at a law library.

meanings.definition: If someone arrives unannounced, they arrive suddenly and unexpectedly:
examples: She appeared unannounced and took control of the meeting.

meanings.definition: not made publicly known:
examples: The Texan singer will be supported by two other bands, as yet unannounced.

meanings.definition: sudden and unexpected:
examples: Several unannounced acts made this concert special.
The President appeared unannounced.

meanings.definition: If an argument or claim is unanswerable, people cannot disagree with it because it is so clearly true:
examples: In economic terms the need to reduce inflation is unanswerable.

meanings.definition: (of a question) without an answer:
examples: As to how long this war will last, it's an unanswerable question.

meanings.definition: not answered or explained:
examples: Questions from local residents remained unanswered.

meanings.definition: scored one after the other during a period in which the person or team competing against you fails to score:
examples: They scored six unanswered goals to beat the opposing team.
He knocked his opponent out with eight unanswered punches at the close of the seventh round.

meanings.definition: (esp. of a letter, question, or telephone call) not reacted to or explained:
examples: She wondered why her calls went unanswered.

meanings.definition: not having been expected to happen:
examples: This was yet another unanticipated event that upset the administration's plans and expectations.
It is also not the case that these sorts of issues were unanticipated.

meanings.definition: not sorry about having caused someone problems or unhappiness, even though people might expect you to be sorry:
examples: They were very rude and completely unapologetic about it.

meanings.definition: without being sorry about having caused someone problems or unhappiness, even though people might expect you to be sorry:
examples: She has made a few enemies on Instagram by unapologetically supporting causes she's passionate about.
He is unapologetically himself.

meanings.definition: not easy to see, recognize, or understand:
examples: Two thirds of the patients may already have been suffering mild, clinically unapparent lung disease.
This would happen so quickly that it would be unapparent to an outside observer.

meanings.definition: not attractive or interesting
If a person or their feelings are unappeased, they still have the same feelings:
examples: This is just the latest proof that the business community remains aggrieved and unappeased.
Eventually, the crowd dispersed with unappeased curiosity and suspicion.

meanings.definition: Unappetizing food does not look or smell attractive and does not make you want to eat it:
examples: If you overcook pasta before freezing it, its texture will be unappetizing once it's defrosted.

meanings.definition: not attractive or pleasant:
examples: The waterfront is distinctly unappetizing: a mixture of broken concrete, raw sewage, and piles of garbage tossed over garden walls.

meanings.definition: If someone is unappreciated, other people do not recognize how good or important they are:
examples: People view nurses as working for low wages and being undervalued and unappreciated.
From time to time, we all feel unappreciated in the home or the workplace.

meanings.definition: not showing that you understand how good something is, or not grateful for something
Someone who is unapproachable seems unfriendly or a little frightening, so that other people are less likely to speak to them:
examples: As a boss I found him rather unapproachable.

meanings.definition: not kept for a particular person or organization, or for a particular purpose:
examples: The Salt Basin is an unappropriated new water source.
Legislators left £3.74 million of revenue in the current year budget unappropriated.

meanings.definition: Unappropriated profit is profit (= money earned) that is kept in a business and not given to owners or shareholders (= people who own part of a company and therefore get part of the company's profits):
examples: Reserves created by the bank, and retained earnings, i.e. unappropriated profit, also form part of the bank’s resources.
Whether to issue dividends, and what amount, is calculated mainly on the basis of the company's unappropriated profit and its earning prospects for the coming year.

meanings.definition: not officially accepted as correct or satisfactory:
examples: Patients must be protected from unapproved drugs that could be unsafe.
It is a priority for the agency to remove unapproved products from the market.

meanings.definition: not generally or officially accepted as correct or satisfactory:
examples: They violated regulations against promotion of drugs for an unapproved use.
unapproved devices/parts/products

meanings.definition: not able to be argued
not armed
not carrying or having a weapon:
examples: How could an unarmed man be so frightening?

meanings.definition: the activity of fighting without weapons:
examples: All the bodyguards have been trained in unarmed combat.
I tried to remember the techniques of unarmed combat that I had learned in my youth.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         unarmoured
(of a person or vehicle) not wearing or covered in strong protection :
examples: They taught unarmoured men how to kill using everyday weapons.
They wore bulletproof vests but no helmets as they sat in their unarmoured truck.

meanings.definition: not good at creating or understanding art:
examples: Almost overnight, this previously unartistic individual had been transformed into a painter of large, complex, and highly original canvases.
Even to an unartistic person like me, it would seem simple enough to personalize each house in an attractive way.

meanings.definition: not skilfully or attractively made:
examples: The pictures, which at first seemed so appallingly or excitingly unartistic, in fact bear the hallmarks of modern art.
These people seem to be quite happy to spray horrific and unartistic graffiti on memorials.

meanings.definition: not ashamed; without hiding behaviour or opinions that other people might consider unacceptable:
examples: Afterwards he spent five minutes with the president, of whom he is an unashamed admirer.
We then checked into the hotel for a weekend of unashamed luxury.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows someone is not ashamed or embarrassed:
examples: The school's headmistress is unashamedly traditional and refuses to allow the girls to wear trousers.

meanings.definition: (of a spoken sound) not involving the use of the breath:
examples: In Indian English, all voiceless stops are unaspirated.
In Cantonese, the stops and affricates have aspirated and unaspirated pairs.

meanings.definition: in such a strong position that you cannot be defeated:
examples: This win has given the team an unassailable lead.
The president looked unassailable with over 60 percent of the vote.

meanings.definition: impossible to doubt or argue with:
examples: unassailable logic
The conclusions were unassailable.

meanings.definition: impossible to attack:
examples: an unassailable fortress

meanings.definition: not doubted, criticized, threatened, or attacked:
examples: One truth remains unassailed: the president had ordered an unprovoked invasion of another country.
These people are proud of their island fortress, nearly a thousand years unassailed.

meanings.definition: not assembled (= put together from separate parts):
examples: They sell unassembled furniture that customers must put together when they get home.
We serve this taco unassembled so that you can combine the elements just the way you like them.

meanings.definition: not given to or kept for a particular person or purpose:
examples: The apartment complex offers tenants ample, unassigned parking.
The lead roles for Romeo and Juliet are still unassigned.
The two remaining seats in Row 8 were unassigned.

meanings.definition: unable to become part of a group, country, or society:
examples: I would guess that this right-wing newspaper is invested in the idea that the two cultures might be unassimilable.
They were seen as being unassimilable and even a threat to the social order.

meanings.definition: unable to be absorbed by the body:
examples: The author believes salt is both indigestible and unassimilable, but there is a lot of argument on this point.
Enzymes convert parts of the fruit which are otherwise unassimilable by humans into compounds that can be digested.

meanings.definition: without being helped by anyone or anything:
examples: She decided on an unassisted birth at home.
Base jumpers using special wing suits have shown that unassisted human flight is possible.
The work was performed by the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, unassisted by electrical amplification.
Ventilators are used to assist with or substitute for breathing when a patient cannot breathe unassisted.

meanings.definition: not connected with something:
examples: Back pain that is unassociated with posture or movement should be investigated further.
How many different, apparently unassociated factors might come together in one of those blinding flashes of inspiration?

meanings.definition: (of a feeling) not made less strong or easier to bear:
examples: After half an hour she left, her curiosity unassuaged.
Maybe there's an element of unassuaged guilt in his actions.

meanings.definition: Someone who is unassuming is quiet and shows no wish for attention or admiration:
examples: He was shy and unassuming and not at all how you expect an actor to be.

meanings.definition: quiet and not attracting attention:
examples: a shy and unassuming person
an unassuming little restaurant

meanings.definition: not strong and healthy, or not good at sport:
examples: Bookish and unathletic, she hated games lessons.
Richard's two friends escaped, but the unathletic youngster was not quick enough.

meanings.definition: not married or not having a relationship with anyone; single:
examples: He's gorgeous, he has his own house and, what's more, he's unattached.

meanings.definition: not physically joined to something else:
examples: The cover of the book was stained and almost completely unattached.

meanings.definition: not feeling connected to a person, group, or idea:
examples: Feeling unattached to the community is one of the risk factors for drug abuse.

meanings.definition: not joined or connected; independent
not married or involved with anyone:
examples: an unattached woman

meanings.definition: not able to be achieved:
examples: an unattainable ideal
Many economists think that full employment is an unattainable goal.

meanings.definition: not being watched or taken care of:
examples: Please do not leave your luggage unattended.
According to the report, most accidents occur when young children are left unattended in the home.

meanings.definition: not being watched or taken care of:
examples: unattended boxes and packages
unattended children

meanings.definition: not reduced or made weaker:
examples: People were shocked at the unattenuated severity of the sentences given by the judge that day.
The researchers inoculated the mice with a live, unattenuated, meningitis virus.

meanings.definition: unpleasant to look at:
examples: This is modern architecture at its most unattractive.
He was short and overweight and generally unattractive.

meanings.definition: lacking good or positive features that make someone want to do something:
examples: All of the options were equally unattractive.

meanings.definition: ugly in appearance, or unpleasant in character:
examples: an unattractive room
an unattractive personality

meanings.definition: in a way that is unpleasant to look at:
examples: Most of the catwalk models were unattractively, freakishly thin.
When the burger arrived, it was rather unattractively soaking in its juices.

meanings.definition: in a way that lacks good or positive features that make someone want to do something:
examples: They charge consumers an unattractively high price for their product.
unattractively low interest rates

meanings.definition: If something is unattributable, it is impossible to know who said, made, or did it. :
examples: As well as being almost unattributable, these remotely-operated cyber attacks offer a low-risk way of conducting espionage.
Most of the reports are from unattributable, unnamed sources on one side or another.

meanings.definition: If something is unattributed, no one knows who said, made, or did it:
examples: In journalism, we're taught that the use of unattributed sources should be avoided as much as possible.
Most of their music is unattributed, and has been passed down over centuries.

meanings.definition: not able to understand or recognize something:
examples: Unattuned to the subtle methods of marketing, the author of the article seems to be unaware of its subversive effects.
Coming from the city, I was so unattuned that I exclaimed, "Oh look! They've put fairy lights in the trees!"

meanings.definition: (of the accounts of a business) not having been officially checked :
examples: The company's unaudited accounts show net liabilities of £340,851 as at 31 January.
Companies have to submit audited or unaudited quarterly financial results within 45 days of every quarter.

meanings.definition: used to describe accounts or the amounts in them that have not been approved by outside accountants:
examples: According to unaudited figures, we ended the year with a surplus of $1.1 million.
The company will release unaudited financial statements for the past three years by Aug 31.
Each fiscal year, you will receive an audited annual report and an unaudited semi-annual report.

meanings.definition: not real, true, or what people say it is:
examples: This piece of software is designed to help academic institutions identify unauthentic material.
I confess to adding my own, very unauthentic addition to the recipe: I stir a bunch of chopped kale into the broth.

meanings.definition: without someone's official permission to do something or be in a particular place:
examples: Unauthorized personnel are not admitted beyond this point.
This unauthorized biography of the star has sold over 10,000 copies in its first week in print.

meanings.definition: without official permission:
examples: an unauthorized biography
An unauthorized version of the software is being sold abroad.

meanings.definition: not officially allowed:
examples: He concealed huge losses made from unauthorized trading on Asian futures markets.
Unauthorized entry into the United States is illegal, but being in the country after having entered illegally is not necessarily a crime.
The company has started to more aggressively prosecute unauthorized use of its technology.

meanings.definition: not carried out or organized using machines or computers, but needing human control:
examples: What used to be a difficult and unautomated process is now much easier.
By the late 1930s, any remnants of unautomated transportation raised strong disapproval.

meanings.definition: the fact of being difficult or impossible to get or use:
examples: The unavailability of healthcare professionals to provide a satisfactory level of medical care is a serious concern.
Many of the treatments in common use are not mentioned because of data unavailability.

meanings.definition: the fact that something is not able to be bought, owned, etc.:
examples: Local farmers were angered by the unavailability of cheap fertilizer.

meanings.definition: If someone is unavailable, they are not able to talk to people or meet people, usually because they are doing other things:
examples: News outlets tried to contact the Senator, but she was unavailable for comment.

meanings.definition: If something is unavailable, you cannot get it or use it:
examples: This information was previously unavailable to the public.

meanings.definition: (of things) not able to be used or obtained, or (of people) not willing or able to be met or talked to:
examples: Fresh fruit and vegetables had been unavailable for some time.
I’m sorry, the colonel is unavailable now.

meanings.definition: not able to be bought, owned, etc.:
examples: Much of their clothing is custom-made and unavailable to the public.

meanings.definition: if someone is unavailable, they do not have time free for doing something or they are not able or willing to do it:
examples: He is away from the office and was unavailable for comment.

meanings.definition: When an attempt to do something is unavailing, it is unsuccessful or has no positive effect:
examples: Diplomatic efforts at peace-making have so far proved unavailing.

meanings.definition: impossible to avoid
unable to be prevented or stayed away from:
examples: War is now unavoidable.

meanings.definition: in a way that is impossible to avoid:
examples: Due to adverse weather conditions, the trains were unavoidably delayed.
Food safety is, unavoidably, a global issue.

meanings.definition: not stated publicly:
examples: His behaviour demonstrates an unavowed disregard for others.

meanings.definition: not yet having started to understand or feel something:
examples: His unawakened soul knows nothing of the anxieties of the spiritual mind.

meanings.definition: (of a prize, money, or an advantage) not given :
examples: The prize still sits unawarded in the vaults of the bank.

meanings.definition: not understanding or realizing something:
examples: He was unaware that the police were watching him.

meanings.definition: not knowing that something exists, or not having knowledge or experience of something:
examples: I was unaware of the risks involved.

meanings.definition: the fact of not knowing, understanding, or realizing something:
examples: Part of the problem in recent years has been the unawareness of the importance of history among our political leaders.

meanings.definition: suddenly and unexpectedly without any warning:
examples: The overnight invasion took the military experts unawares.

meanings.definition: suddenly and unexpectedly; without warning:
examples: We were caught unawares by the fierce storm.

meanings.definition: to cause something or someone to be unbalanced:

meanings.definition: to make someone mentally ill, especially temporarily
to make something unfair or not equal
not firm but likely to fall or change position suddenly
mentally ill:
examples: His relatives have said he became unbalanced after the death of his father.

meanings.definition: not fair or equal; false:

meanings.definition: not consisting of a combination of the correct types and amounts of food:
examples: an unbalanced diet
an unbalanced meal

meanings.definition: emphasizing one thing or one side over another:

unbalanced reporting

meanings.definition: A person who is unbalanced is mentally ill.

examples: I have some unbalanced accounting entries in the spreadsheet.

meanings.definition: not fair or equal:
examples: Their reporting on the election has been unbalanced and often misleading.

meanings.definition: likely to change in a way that is not controlled:

meanings.definition: a budget in which more money is spent than comes in during a particular period:

examples: A local resident who witnessed the accident said that several parts of the dangerous route had been left unbarricaded.

meanings.definition: too painful or unpleasant for you to continue to experience:

meanings.definition: so unpleasant or painful that you find it hard to accept:

meanings.definition: in a way that is too painful or unpleasant for you to continue to experience:

meanings.definition: unable to be defeated or improved because of excellent quality:

meanings.definition: unable to be defeated, or better than any other:

Unbecoming behaviour is not correct or not acceptable:

meanings.definition: not having a duty to someone or something:

meanings.definition: extremely surprising:

meanings.definition: unable to be believed because unlikely:

meanings.definition: not able to be believed because unlikely:

meanings.definition: in a way that is very surprising or difficult to believe:

meanings.definition: a person who does not have any religious beliefs:

meanings.definition: not believing that something is true:

meanings.definition: not having any religious beliefs, or not following a particular religion:

meanings.definition: not loved, liked, or wanted:
examples: The insurance company is seeking a buyer for its unbeloved bank unit.

meanings.definition: to relax and become less formal and serious in your manner:

examples: He has earned a reputation as a stern and unbending politician.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of

able to judge fairly because you are not influenced by your own opinions:
examples: unbiased advice

meanings.definition: able to judge fairly because you are not influenced by your own opinions:
examples: He admits that his newspaper was not an unbiased observer in the conflict.

meanings.definition: not affected or influenced by someone's beliefs or opinions:
examples: Every effort is made to present unbiased information.

meanings.definition: not invited or wanted:

meanings.definition: not mentioned in a list of performers:

meanings.definition: not charged for, or relating to products or services that have not been charged for :
examples: A combination of falling income and unbilled work led to the company's financial problems.

meanings.definition: to release someone or something from a rope, string, etc. that has been tying him, her, or it up:
examples: My hands were unbound and my blindfold removed.

meanings.definition: not injured by an insect making a small hole in your skin:

examples: unbleached cotton

meanings.definition: An unblemished reputation, character, etc. has no faults and is not spoiled in any way:

meanings.definition: (of skin) without any marks that spoil its appearance:

meanings.definition: An unblended drink, liquid, or product contains only one type of that product, not two or more mixed together:

meanings.definition: not limited to one way of thinking, and considering other people's beliefs:

He needs to see as much of real life as possible if he is going to develop into an unblinkered individual.

meanings.definition: looking straight at someone or something in a steady way without blinking (= closing and opening your eyes quickly):
examples: He leaned threateningly towards me and fixed me with an unblinking stare.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves looking directly and continuously at a person or thing:
examples: She listened unblinkingly as the judge read out the sentence.

meanings.definition: in a way that is completely clear, or shows no doubt or fear:
examples: The film is unblinkingly honest in its observations.

meanings.definition: to clear something by removing something that is blocking it:
examples: to unblock a pipe/drain/toilet

meanings.definition: to make it possible to use a phone, website, etc. again:
examples: Learn how you can unblock a phone number or remove it from the Auto Reject List.

meanings.definition: not closed with a bolt (= a metal bar on a door or window that slides across to lock it):
examples: Someone had left the gate to the yard unbolted and thieves got in during the night and stole a large amount of copper piping.

meanings.definition: (of flour) that has not been put through a sieve (= a wire net shaped like a bowl) to break up or remove large pieces:
examples: Wholewheat flour is an example of unbolted flour.

meanings.definition: not interested in reading books or studying:
examples: Growing up in a house full of unbookish people, I was unaware of the various careers open to me as a language lover.

meanings.definition: not yet born; in the mother's womb:
examples: the protection of the unborn child

meanings.definition: not yet born; in the mother’s uterus:
examples: an unborn child/calf

meanings.definition: Unbought goods have not been bought:
examples: Her books remained unbought on the shelves.

meanings.definition: An unbought politician is not influenced by rich people who have given money to his or her party:
examples: She is still the spunky unbought politican she ever was.

meanings.definition: used to describe a positive feeling that is very great and seems to have no limits:
examples: her unbounded enthusiasm for her subject

meanings.definition: very great; seeming to have no limits:
examples: an unbounded commitment to excellence

meanings.definition: (of a book, play, film, etc.) not having had words or parts that are considered unsuitable or offensive removed:
examples: Just like the old, unbowdlerized versions of fairytales, it contains quite a bit of death, violence, and cruelty.

meanings.definition: proudly refusing to accept defeat or to lose hope :
examples: Though fiercely attacked, he remained unbowed.

meanings.definition: not bent over:
examples: She has been compared to a tree - solid and unbowed - no matter how hard the wind blows.

meanings.definition: to take something out of a box, for example something that you have recently bought or have moved to a different place:
examples: We bought the laptop to replace our 5-year-old desktop that we have never unboxed after moving.

meanings.definition: the activity of taking new products out of their packaging, especially on videos on the internet
Unbracketed text is not in brackets (= two symbols, put around a word, phrase, or sentence in a piece of writing to separate it from the main part):
examples: In the transcript, unbracketed ellipses represent a hesitation, and bracketed ones signal an omission.
The unbracketed symbols reflect a compromise between phonetic accuracy and the constrants of the keyboard.

meanings.definition: without brakes (= devices that make a vehicle go slower or stop), or relating to vehicles or parts that have no brakes:
examples: The catalogue includes metal castors with nylon, rubber or polyurethane wheels, braked or unbraked.
I have an automatic vehicle, and want to use it for towing a small, unbraked trailer.

meanings.definition: An unbranched structure has a single, usually straight, main part with no smaller parts connected to it or growing from it:
examples: All their flowers arise unbranched from ground level.
Sweat glands are unbranched tubes, with a long duct which conveys the secretion to the surface.

meanings.definition: An unbranded product is sold under the name of a shop or under the name of the product itself, rather than the name of the company that made it:
examples: Unbranded goods can be half the price of big name brands.

meanings.definition: unbranded products do not have a brand name and do not legally belong to a particular company, so any company can manufacture them:
examples: Sales of the supermarket's unbranded goods are down.

meanings.definition: not able to be broken through, entered, or crossed:
examples: The team prides itself on its unbreachable defence.

meanings.definition: If there is an unbreachable difference between two people, groups, or things, it is not possible to make them understand each other or agree:
examples: The study reveals a clear and apparently unbreachable gulf between the interests of management and the needs of employees.
The story brings to life the seemingly unbreachable divide between the dirty backstreets of Notting Hill and the rich neighbourhood of Belgravia.

meanings.definition: An unbreachable rule or law cannot be broken:
examples: Company policy sets out unbreachable rules about disclosing the address of an employee.
The limits of freedom of speech are marked by a few unbreachable taboos.

meanings.definition: impossible to break:
examples: unbreakable glass/plastic

meanings.definition: used for describing differences or divisions between people that are so big they will never be made smaller:
examples: There is an unbridgeable divide between the country's two main political camps.

meanings.definition: An unbridged river, stream, etc. does not have a bridge over a particular part of it:
examples: In order to get to church, we had to cross an unbridged river.
The route took us over seven, as yet unbridged, canals.

meanings.definition: If there is an unbridged difference between two people, groups, or things, it has not been possible to make them understand each other or agree:
examples: She worried about the unbridged chasm between Lucy and herself.
The climate conference closed with many gaps still unbridged.

meanings.definition: not controlled or limited:
examples: unbridled ambition/enthusiasm/lust

meanings.definition: not controlled or limited:
examples: unbridled joy/fury/greed/authority

meanings.definition: not having been given any instructions or information about a situation:
examples: He arrived ten minutes before the press conference, unbriefed, claiming he had overslept.

meanings.definition: not very exciting or special:
examples: Next to these sophisticated girls, Kate felt hopelessly unbrilliant and untalented.

meanings.definition: not damaged by being broken or opened:
examples: I looked at the window. The glass was unbroken.

Make sure you only buy bottles where the seal is unbroken.

meanings.definition: not damaged emotionally by something bad that has happened, in a way that makes you lose your confidence, determination, or ability to control yourself:
examples: With heads bowed but spirits unbroken, New Yorkers filled the city's places of worship yesterday.

meanings.definition: continuous, with no pauses and not ended:
examples: The Giants' winning streak remained unbroken for an impressive 19 games.
The coughing fit continued unbroken for five long minutes.
The company has maintained an unbroken record of growing sales for over 20 years.
I try to get at least six hours of unbroken sleep a night.
We had several days of unbroken sunshine.
There are a few nervous smiles, but the uncomfortable silence is unbroken.

meanings.definition: (of an area of land, etc.) not changing in appearance for a particular distance:
examples: I walked through miles of forest as it stretched unbroken up the Rift Valley escarpment.
From this point there is an almost unbroken stretch of 30 miles of uninhabited beach.
This is the largest unbroken expanse of ancient woodland anywhere in eastern England.
Mauritius is a green tropical island of volcanic origin surrounded by virtually unbroken coral reef.

meanings.definition: (of a record) not improved on by someone doing something better:
examples: In 1902, he set a speed record of 136mph on his motorcycle - a record that remained unbroken for nearly 25 years.

meanings.definition: (of a horse) not yet trained to be tame (= not wild or frightened of people, and safe around them) so that it can be ridden or used to pull a vehicle:
examples: He learned to rope unbroken horses on his grandfather's ranch.
An unbroken horse paws the ground and jumps away at the sight of the bridle.
You might find the first time you try to pull away you have to fight to prevent the car from bucking like an unbroken horse.

meanings.definition: not emotionally hurt after a bad experience:
examples: It's a great feeling to emerge unbruised by life's hard knocks.
Unbruised by life, he thought that once he decided to have something, he could get it.

meanings.definition: (of fruit) not damaged:
examples: Select unbruised, slightly soft berries with a deep colour and a pleasant smell.
Dessert apples will keep until Christmas if stored unbruised, ideally on cardboard trays.

meanings.definition: without bruises (= marks where the skin is darker in colour, often as a result of being hit by something):
examples: She placed her hand on the unbruised side of his face.

meanings.definition: Unbrushed hair has not been made smooth with a hairbrush:
examples: Her blonde hair looked unbrushed, and she was wearing a scruffy old T-shirt.

meanings.definition: Unbrushed teeth have not been cleaned with a toothbrush:
examples: I was still in my pajamas with my teeth unbrushed.

meanings.definition: to release the buckle (= metal fastener) of a shoe, belt, etc. so that you can remove it

past simple and past participle of 
        
         unbuckle
to release the buckle (= metal fastener) of a shoe, belt, etc. so that you can remove it

present participle of 
        
         unbuckle
to release the buckle (= metal fastener) of a shoe, belt, etc. so that you can remove it
Unbudgeted costs are not included in a budget (= a plan of how much money you will spend on something):
examples: The Department of Finance estimates the agency will spend another £37 million in unbudgeted costs this year.
Hurricane damage accounted for about £710 million in unbudgeted expenses.

meanings.definition: Unbuffered information, or an unbuffered part of a computer system, does not use a buffer (= a temporary memory store for information while it is being dealt with or sent):
examples: Channels are message queues which can be buffered or unbuffered.

meanings.definition: An unbuffered substance is not mixed with another substance to make it neutral (= neither an acid nor an alkali):
examples: An unbuffered pocket of highly acidic juice is observed in the stomach after a meal in healthy subjects.

meanings.definition: impossible to build or to build on:
examples: All too often, her designs were dismissed as brilliant but unbuildable.
The plots tend to be unbuildable hillsides, swamps, or ditches.

meanings.definition: to divide a business into separate parts:
examples: The gas company will unbundle its three businesses - storage, connection and metering.

meanings.definition: to start to sell a product or service separately when previously it had been sold together with others:
examples: The media giant was legally compelled to unbundle its media player.

meanings.definition: not involving too much bureaucracy (= complicated rules and processes that make something slow and difficult):
examples: Most consulting firms seek to be as unbureaucratic as possible to enable fast and flexible decision-making.

meanings.definition: not buried in the ground:
examples: unburied bodies/corpses/dead
The bodies of the dead were left unburied.
As the cables were unburied, they often got damaged and needed to be repaired.

meanings.definition: If something is unburnable, it is not possible to burn it, or people do not want to burn it, for example, for environmental reasons:
examples: There's a system for sorting household waste into paper, stuff for the compost bin, and unburnable stuff such as tin.
The majority of fossil fuel reserves are unburnable if the world is to avoid dangerous climate change.

meanings.definition: not burnt:
examples: Active fires are shown on the map in red, and unburned areas are shown in green.
A large portion of the exhaust from these engines is unburned fuel.

meanings.definition: not burnt:
examples: There were no unburnt trees for at least several hundred metres.
Unburnt fuel creates pollution in the form of air-borne hydrocarbons.

meanings.definition: not showing the behaviour or qualities that are expected in business:
examples: I feel it is unbusinesslike and rude to completely ignore my correspondence.
I didn't mind the nickname, but others might think it sounded unbusinesslike.

meanings.definition: not busy or full of activity:
examples: I try to do the food shop during the week on an unbusy day.
Parents need to find unbusy, unhurried time every week to check in with their kids about school.

meanings.definition: Unbuttered food, such as bread, has no butter on it:
examples: Place a slice of cheese on the unbuttered side of the bread.
Unbuttered or slightly buttered popcorn is low in calories.

meanings.definition: to unfasten the buttons on something such as a shirt:
examples: He unbuttoned his jacket and sat back comfortably in his chair.
His shirt was unbuttoned to show off a gold medallion.

meanings.definition: relaxed and informal:
examples: These musicians are keen to communicate the joy of classical music in a more unbuttoned style.
Today people want to see their politicians authentic, natural, and unbuttoned.

meanings.definition: Uncalcified body tissue is not calcified (= hard because of an increase in the amount of calcium, sometimes because of injury):
examples: This uncalcified early bone is termed the osteoid.

meanings.definition: An uncalibrated measuring instrument or other device has not had the controls checked or changed to make sure it is accurate:
examples: The touchpad is still uncalibrated and doesn't provide the pressure sensitive functions.

meanings.definition: Uncalibrated numbers, dates, or other information are in the form they were collected and have not been changed to make them more accurate or standard:
examples: All the radiocarbon dates are given as conventional, uncalibrated ages.

meanings.definition: in the form of shares or investments that a company has not completely paid for:
examples: The group said last month it had £1.25bn of uncalled capital commitments.

meanings.definition: If an action that is against the rules or illegal is uncalled, it is not noticed or punished by officials:
examples: The would-be penalty went uncalled by the officials.

meanings.definition: not asked for or invited to do something:
examples: When all the names were crossed out, one child remained uncalled.

meanings.definition: not telephoned:
examples: We'd been phoning registered voters for weeks, but 2200 were uncalled when we ran out of time.

meanings.definition: capital that a company has in the form of shares that have not been completely paid for by shareholders:
examples: The top 10 managers in private equity have $197 billion in uncalled capital available to them.

meanings.definition: If a criticism, insult, remark, or action is uncalled-for, it is unfair, rude, or unkind and therefore considered to be unnecessary:
examples: an uncalled-for remark
There's no reason to make personal comments - that was completely uncalled-for.

meanings.definition: not suitable and therefore unnecessary:
examples: uncalled-for rudeness

meanings.definition: Uncalloused hands or feet are soft and have no areas of hard skin:
examples: She shook his hand, which was small, soft and uncalloused.

meanings.definition:
a UK spelling of
        
         uncalloused

US spelling of 
        
         uncancelled
If an event or a service is uncancelled, it has not been cancelled (= stopped or no longer happening):
examples: Passengers wait to find out where they might find an uncancelled train to get them home.

meanings.definition: If an event or a service is uncancelled, it is cancelled (= stopped or no longer happening), but then a decision is made that it will happen or continue:
examples: She talks about a movie release that got cancelled, then uncancelled, with a lot of drama in between.

meanings.definition: If a stamp is uncancelled, it has been used but not marked to show it has been used:
examples: Is it dishonest to re-use uncancelled stamps?

meanings.definition: not honest and telling the truth:
examples: This is the last place I would have expected to encounter such uncandid and ungenerous treatment.

meanings.definition: in a way that is uncanny (= strange and mysterious):
examples: Her predictions turned out to be uncannily accurate.
His new girlfriend looks uncannily like his ex-partner.

meanings.definition: the fact of being strange or mysterious, often in a way that is slightly frightening:
examples: The uncanniness of a disembodied voice being transmitted via a telephone line, as experienced by early telephone users, is quite hard to imagine now.
In her novel "The Little Stranger" she achieves a slow build-up of uncanniness.

meanings.definition: strange or mysterious, often in a way that is slightly frightening:
examples: It was uncanny the way that she always knew what he was thinking.
She bears an uncanny resemblance to her father's best friend.

meanings.definition: strange or mysterious; difficult or impossible to explain:
examples: He has an uncanny ability to pick a winner.
Barb’s uncanny resemblance to Tia is scary.

meanings.definition: used to refer to the unpleasant feeling that some people have when they see robots (= machines that can carry out actions automatically), or pictures of a human being created by a computer, that appear very similar to a living human:
examples: Uncanny valley describes a situation in which a machine looks so eerily "almost but not quite human" that it just creeps people out.

meanings.definition: not following the rules, principles, or laws of the Christian Church:
examples: He attempted to impose unity by uncanonical coercion against six clergy in his diocese.

meanings.definition: An uncanonical work of art, literature, etc. is not part of the canon (= works that are generally agreed to be good, important, and worth studying):
examples: The anthology surprises us with the rediscovery of formerly uncanonical poems and poets.

meanings.definition: to remove the cap (= lid or cover) from something:
examples: He uncapped the bottle and poured out some rum.

meanings.definition: to make small changes to a modem (= device for connecting to the internet), especially in order to use the internet without paying a particular internet service provider
An uncapitalized word is not written with capital letters or with the first letter as a capital letter:
examples: People's names are often uncapitalised in logins and email addresses.

meanings.definition: An uncaptioned picture or photograph has no caption (= text that describes the picture):
examples: The collection contains thousands of photographic prints, most of them uncaptioned.

meanings.definition: An uncaptioned video or television show has no subtitles (= words at the bottom of the screen that show what is being said):
examples: He can lipread but sometimes has trouble understanding English, especially uncaptioned television.

meanings.definition: not taken care of well enough:
examples: He looked unwashed and uncared for.

meanings.definition: not worrying about other people's troubles or doing anything to help them:
examples: The charity criticized the city for its "callous, uncaring attitude" to the homeless.

meanings.definition: An uncarpeted room has no carpet on the floor:
examples: His footsteps echoed on the uncarpeted floor.
I followed her up a flight of uncarpeted stairs.

meanings.definition: to remove something from a case:
examples: He uncased his guitar and joined in with the others.
The law prohibits uncased or loaded firearms to be carried in vehicles.

meanings.definition: not exchanged for cash or put into a bank account:
examples: More than a million share dividend cheques stay uncashed every year.

meanings.definition: An uncastrated man or male animal has not had its testicles (= the two round male sex organs) removed:
examples: A stallion is any uncastrated male horse that is one year of age or older.

meanings.definition:
a US spelling of 
        
         uncatalogued
not recorded, especially in a list or catalogue (= a list of all the books, paintings, etc. that exist in a place):
examples: The film footage was found in uncatalogued boxes at the back of a BBC warehouse.

meanings.definition: If a person or a sports team are uncatchable, they are too fast or too skilled for others to reach, or they have too many points in a game or competition for others to beat:
examples: His speed and touch made him look uncatchable.
They now have an uncatchable 10-point lead at the top of the league.

meanings.definition: If an object, such as a ball, is uncatchable, it is impossible to catch it in your hands:
examples: The ball looked uncatchable.

meanings.definition: (especially of a name) not easy to remember or pleasant to say :
examples: It's a curiously uncatchy title for a series.

meanings.definition: difficult or impossible to put into a category (= a group of things having some features that are the same):
examples: Her new novel is defiantly uncategorizable.
The band's wholly uncategorisable music incorporates disparate influences.

meanings.definition: not found and stopped or dealt with:
examples: Her killer remains uncaught.
There is a risk that serious health problems will go uncaught and untreated.

meanings.definition: continuing and unlikely to stop or become less:
examples: The authors are grateful for the unceasing support of the editors in London and New York.

meanings.definition: in a way that is continuing and unlikely to stop:
examples: He worked unceasingly for international childrens' charities.
The rain continued to fall heavily outside, rattling the windows unceasingly.

meanings.definition: An uncensored book, film, document, etc. has not been censored (= had parts removed because it is considered offensive or harmful):
examples: An uncensored version of the video was soon circulating online.
His comments went out live and uncensored on national TV.

meanings.definition: not criticizing people for the things that they do or the choices they make:
examples: The nursing staff are kind and uncensorious.

meanings.definition: not censured (= criticized, especially formally):
examples: The show was utterly unacceptable and cannot be allowed to go uncensured.

meanings.definition: done in a rude, sudden, or informal way:
examples: an unceremonious refusal

meanings.definition: in a way that is unceremonious (= rude, sudden, or informal):
examples: He was unceremoniously removed from the list of members, for gross misconduct.
She was unceremoniously dropped from the team.

meanings.definition: not knowing what to do or believe, or not able to decide about something:
examples: She's uncertain whether to go to New Zealand or not.
Ariana was uncertain about meeting him.

meanings.definition: not known or fixed, or not completely certain:
examples: These refugees face an uncertain future.
The political outlook is still uncertain.

meanings.definition: unclear, or not sure:
examples: She faces an uncertain future.
We’re uncertain of the cause of death.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you do not know what to do or believe, or are not able to decide about something:
examples: She laughed a little uncertainly.
He got off the bus and stood uncertainly on the street.

meanings.definition: not confidently or surely:
examples: She looked at John uncertainly.

meanings.definition: a situation in which something is not known, or something that is not known or certain:
examples: Nothing is ever decided, and all the uncertainty is very bad for staff morale.
Life is full of uncertainties.

meanings.definition: the feeling of not being sure what will happen in the future:
examples: The rule changes are complicated and cause uncertainty for workers and headaches for employers.
At a time of economic uncertainty, risk taking can seem particularly difficult.
There are uncertainties that loom over commodities prices.
When there is uncertainty about financing, then private equity is not so quick to make deals.

meanings.definition: not having an official document to show that something or someone has reached a particular standard, or that information is true:
examples: Although the system has tried to attract qualified new teachers, the number of uncertified teachers has risen.
The report cited the use of untrained, unqualified and uncertified contractors.

meanings.definition: If a person or an idea is unchallengeable, you cannot challenge them (= question whether they are correct):
examples: People like that have an unchallengeable authority.
The view that eating too much fat was the cause of heart disease had become almost unchallengeable.

meanings.definition: accepted without asking questions or criticizing:
examples: We can't allow her comments to go unchallenged.

meanings.definition: not difficult; that does not test your ability or determination:
examples: The work I had at that time was secure, but unchallenging.

meanings.definition: that does not change, or that cannot be changed:
examples: Culture cannot be seen as static and unchangeable.
These fares have fixed and unchangeable outward and return dates, and allow a maximum stay of one month.

meanings.definition: staying the same:
examples: The area has remained virtually unchanged in 50 years.

meanings.definition: not changed from an earlier time; the same as before:
examples: The average combined SAT score for 2007 was unchanged from the previous year, according to results released last week.

meanings.definition: not changing; not becoming different:
