examples: Some Greeks felt that the universe was static and unchanging; others believed that change was constant.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         unchannelled
If a strong feeling is unchannelled, it stays inside someone because they do not have anywhere to direct it:
examples: We need to find ways to prevent this unchannelled aggression erupting into violence.

meanings.definition: (of children or young people) without an adult present who will keep them safe :
examples: Most movie theaters will require photo IDs from unchaperoned teenagers.
I won't let them go unchaperoned; will a parent be there?

meanings.definition: without a chaperone (= someone who stays with a young woman who is not married when she is in public):
examples: It was one of the few places where unchaperoned young women could meet together while maintaining respectability.

meanings.definition: not typical
in a way that is not typical of someone:
examples: I noticed that this usually social young man was uncharacteristically silent.
He looked down at his hands, uncharacteristically shy.

meanings.definition: having no charisma (= a natural ability to attract people's attention and admiration):
examples: The party is led by a decidedly uncharismatic former bureaucrat.
The media portray him as grey and uncharismatic.

meanings.definition: unkind and unfair:
examples: The uncharitable explanation is that she's too afraid to ask.

meanings.definition: in a way that is unkind or unfair:
examples: She thought uncharitably that he looked like a gangster.
He stopped himself from thinking uncharitably about someone who had helped him.

meanings.definition: (of a person or their behaviour or comments) not polite or pleasant:
examples: Arguably, it's during the uncharming stages of adolescence when kids need the most parental support.
She has become the butt of uncharming remarks about her fashion sense.

meanings.definition: (of a place) not pleasant or attractive:
examples: The horses end up in a most uncharming setting: standing in filthy water and their own waste.

meanings.definition: An uncharted area has not had a map made of it and has not been described:
examples: During survival training, he was criticized for venturing recklessly into uncharted wilderness.
Most of the underground tunnels and cave networks are uncharted or inadequately mapped.

meanings.definition: completely new and not previously described or experienced, and therefore possibly difficult to deal with:
examples: Nuclear fusion has taken physicists into previously uncharted territory.
We are going into uncharted waters with this new experiment.
She urged young people to be more daring, to take more risks and venture into uncharted seas.

meanings.definition: (of a place) never before described, or (of a situation) completely new:
examples: New drugs lead doctors into uncharted territory.

meanings.definition:
not standard for
        
         uncharted
to remove a tick from a box on a computer screen, so that the box is no longer selected:
examples: Uncheck the items you don't want.

meanings.definition: If information is uncheckable, it is impossible to check whether it is correct:
examples: The reports rely upon uncheckable word-of-mouth reminiscences.

meanings.definition: Uncheckable power or an uncheckable activity cannot be limited or prevented from continuing:
examples: The panel has virtually uncheckable power to put through its changes.
The practice continues, uncheckable, and no-one has the courage to point out how harmful it can be.

meanings.definition: If something harmful is unchecked, it is continuing or increasing without or despite any limits or attempts to prevent it:
examples: If current trends go/continue unchecked, obesity will become the number one cause of death in this country.
The war raged on, unchecked by the UN's efforts to stop it.

meanings.definition: not stopped or ended:
examples: These problems will worsen if current trends continue unchecked.

meanings.definition: difficult or impossible to chew (= bite or crush with your teeth):
examples: They remove the protective shells from nuts and seeds which would otherwise be unchewable.
The crusts of the loaf were dry and unchewable.

meanings.definition: not chewed (= bitten or crushed by the teeth of a person or animal):
examples: His dog never learned how to bring the golf balls back unchewed.
It happened so fast that she still had a mouthful of unchewed sandwich.

meanings.definition: not stylish or fashionable:
examples: She was an unfussy, unchic woman of plain tastes.
She lived in a small apartment in an un-chic part of town.

meanings.definition: not typical of a child, or not behaving like a child:
examples: There was a most unchildlike determination in her expression.
It's disturbing to read about children engaging in behaviours that are so un-childlike.

meanings.definition: Unchlorinated water has no chlorine (= a chemical with a strong smell) to kill bacteria added to it:
examples: an unchlorinated swimming pool
She celebrates the joys of swimming in wild, unchlorinated water.

meanings.definition: (of an action) not carefully planned before it happens:
examples: The clearly unchoreographed move took journalists by surprise.

meanings.definition: (of a dance or other performance) including movements that are not planned in an exact way:
examples: The dance group brings its unchoreographed, created-on-the-spot performances to the festival.

meanings.definition: Someone who is unchristened has not officially been made a member of the Christian Church in a service of baptism (= a ceremony in which water is put on someone's head or they are put under water for a short time):
examples: Paying his initial visits around the parish, he found a couple with an unchristened child.

meanings.definition: not yet formally given a name:
examples: The baby rhino, as yet unchristened, was born at the zoo a week ago.

meanings.definition: not good, kind, or showing any care for other people; not showing the qualities expected of a Christian:
examples: He said that it would be unchristian to refuse to help the refugees.

meanings.definition: not recorded, especially in writing:
examples: It's an event that is virtually unchronicled by historians.
Nowadays, there is hardly any moment of a celebrity's life that goes unchronicled.

meanings.definition: relating to a small curved bone in the wrist, below the little finger:
examples: The short flexor of the little finger is fixed in one part to the process of the unciform bone.

meanings.definition: relating to any bone or organ that is curved in the shape of a C at one end:
examples: Immediately beneath this plate of bone is an irregular hook-like layer of bone called the unciform process.

meanings.definition: a small, curved bone in the wrist, below the little finger:
examples: Two palmar ligaments connect the pisiform to the unciform.

meanings.definition: An unciliated cell or organism does not have cilia (= very small parts like hairs) on the surface:
examples: The eggs adhere to the substrate and hatch to give a crawling, unciliated larva.

meanings.definition: relating to any bone or organ that is curved in the shape of a C at one end:
examples: A large, soft tumour involving the uncinate process of the pancreas was found.
The uncinate fasciculus is a major white matter pathway between the amygdala and ventromedial prefrontal cortex in the brain.

meanings.definition: not typical of or not suitable for films:
examples: In fact, real science is rather uncinematic these days.
The editing and the music turn an uncinematic game of chess into an edge-of-your-seat drama.

meanings.definition: not polite:
examples: He was most uncivil to your father - called him an old fool.

meanings.definition: not suitable for a well developed, peaceful society where people are treated fairly:
examples: He described the punishment as "barbaric and uncivilized".

meanings.definition: (of a society or country) without what is thought to be a highly developed culture and way of life, or (of a person) rude and not showing care for others:
examples: uncivilized behavior

meanings.definition: a very early or very late time in the day:
examples: Sorry to call you at such an uncivilized hour.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not polite:
examples: He accused me of having acted uncivilly.
When treated uncivilly, people stopped performing as well as they could.

meanings.definition: (of a person) not wearing any clothes:
examples: The magazine featured pictures of unclad models.
The poster for the play shows two unclad people wearing masks.

meanings.definition: (of a building or structure) with the surface not covered:
examples: We could just leave the exterior unclad.

meanings.definition: If something is unclaimed, no one has said that it belongs to them or that they should have it:
examples: unclaimed prizes
More than €2.5 million lies unclaimed in bank accounts.

meanings.definition: if something is unclaimed, no one has said that it belongs to them or that they want it:
examples: More than €2.5 million lies unclaimed in bank accounts.
The proposed bill requires transfer of unclaimed deposits to the state Environmental Protection Fund.

meanings.definition: not explained clearly or with enough detail:
examples: Several basic questions remain unclarified.
The resolution leaves a number of key issues unclarified.

meanings.definition: Unclarified butter or fat has not been heated to remove water and unwanted substances. :
examples: In a hot climate, unclarified butter spoils quickly.

meanings.definition: impossible to classify (= say which group or type something or someone belongs to):
examples: The event is unclassifiable, with music, lighting, performance, and art set against a dramatic backdrop.
The three remaining patients had unclassifiable tumours.

meanings.definition: the brother of someone's mother or father, or the husband of someone's aunt or uncle:
examples: I have lots of uncles and aunts.
We invited my Uncle Steve over.
Did you bring me a present, Uncle Jack?

meanings.definition: any male adult that you know who is older than you:
examples: John Uncle

meanings.definition: the brother of someone’s mother or father, or the husband of someone’s aunt:
examples: My aunt and uncle moved to Arizona when they retired.

meanings.definition: the US, or its government, sometimes represented by an image of a tall, thin man with a white beard and a tall hat
the US, or a symbol for the US or its government that is pictured as a tall, thin man with a white beard (= hair on the face) and a tall hat wearing clothes colored like the American flag
an offensive word for a Black person who is considered to be too eager to agree with white people or too willing to be treated in a way that is not equal to white people
an African American who is considered to be too eager to be friendly and helfpul to white Americans in authority
not clean and therefore likely to cause disease:
examples: The health risk from drinking unclean water is considerable.

meanings.definition: not clean or pure, or morally bad, as described by the rules of a religion:
examples: Jews and Muslims consider pigs unclean.

meanings.definition: not clean or not pure and therefore likely to cause disease:
examples: unclean water
unclean kitchens

meanings.definition: not acceptable or usable according to religious or moral standards:
examples: unclean thoughts/practices

meanings.definition: a document showing the details of the products sent from a seller to a buyer that states that either the products or their containers are damaged:
examples: An unclean bill of lading is issued when it is determined that the packages are not in their original condition.

meanings.definition: not cleaned:
examples: The frying pan was still uncleaned from breakfast.
Once the food is cooked, do not let it touch any uncleaned surface it touched when raw.

meanings.definition: not obvious or easy to see or know:
examples: The ownership of the painting remains unclear.
It's unclear what actually happened that night.
It's unclear whether he arrived before or after the shot was fired.

meanings.definition: If you are unclear about something, you are not certain about it:
examples: I'm unclear about a couple of points in your proposal - could you go over them again?
I'm unclear (as to) whether we're supposed to stay here or not.

meanings.definition: not obvious or easy to see or know:
examples: It’s unclear what actually happened that night.

meanings.definition: A person who is unclear about something is not sure about it:
examples: I’m unclear about a couple of things he said on the phone.

meanings.definition: cheques, etc. that a customer has put into their bank account but for which their bank has not yet received payment from the banks of the people who wrote them:
examples: The bank expressly reserved the right to postpone payment of cheques drawn against uncleared effects.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not obvious or easy to see, understand, or know:
examples: The regulations are often unclearly presented.
The swollen tongue is causing the child to speak unclearly.

meanings.definition: not clichéd (= often said, used, or done, and therefore not original):
examples: The film's angle on military life is refreshingly unclichéd.
You can rely on the festival director for unclichéd programming.

meanings.definition: to unfasten something that is fastened with a clip (= a small metal or plastic object), or to become unfastened:
examples: She switched off the engine and unclipped her seatbelt.
The cover simply unclips.

meanings.definition: to clear something by removing something that is blocking it:
examples: In this video you can learn how to unclog a sink or a toilet.
Someone came in and unclogged the drains.

meanings.definition: (of a taste or smell) not too sweet:
examples: The flavour is floral and distinctive with a clean, uncloying finish.

meanings.definition: expressing feelings in a way that is not too emotional:
examples: The reviews picked out her uncloying likeability as the movie's strongest point.

meanings.definition: (of a room, etc.) not having too many objects in it, and looking tidy:
examples: A clean, uncluttered home will always appear elegant.

meanings.definition: not containing too many small details or different parts:
examples: The website has been given a new, uncluttered design.

meanings.definition: with no coating (= a layer of a particular substance that covers a surface):
examples: It's made from recycled, uncoated paper.
Moisture will pass through the uncoated fabric.

meanings.definition: not written, sent, or stored in code (= a system used to represent a message or information in secret form):
examples: Many companies still leave sensitive information uncoded.
The system does not have direct access to the original uncoded message.

meanings.definition: not arranged into a formal written system:
examples: This is particularly true in the British political system, with its uncodified constitution.
A lot of the knowledge that is available is vague and uncodified.

meanings.definition: not the result of physical force or some other kind of pressure to persuade someone to do something they do not want:
examples: His confession was voluntary and uncoerced.
The person must make a free, uncoerced choice and understand the risk involved.

meanings.definition: (especially of money owed) not able to be collected:
examples: Debts which are known to be uncollectable are written off.
He said that the cost of uncollectible debts reflects a reduction in the number of people who have health insurance.

meanings.definition: If something is uncollected, it has not been collected:
examples: piles of uncollected rubbish
The US state had at least $600 million in uncollected taxes.

meanings.definition: not paid:
examples: The company was told it owes $1 million in uncollected sales taxes.
Eventually, uncollected bills for the uninsured get paid for by taxpayers or through higher insurance premiums.

meanings.definition: (especially of money owed) not able to be collected:
examples: Debts which are known to be uncollectible are written off.
In the spring quarter, commercial banks wrote off nearly $3 billion in uncollectable credit card debt.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         uncoloured
having no colour or with no extra colour added:
examples: It is made from the clear, uncoloured juice of the black grape.
Cook the onions gently until soft and uncoloured.

meanings.definition: (of an opinion) not influenced by something, especially in a negative way:
examples: Jurors should be able to reach a fair verdict, uncoloured by what they read in the papers.

meanings.definition: Uncombed hair is untidy and has not been made smooth using a brush or comb (= a flat object with a thin row of long, narrow parts along one side):
examples: She wore no make-up and her hair was uncombed.
He had tufts of uncombed hair poking through a baseball cap.

meanings.definition: existing separately and not combined with other things:
examples: Silicon does not occur uncombined in nature.
Every medicinal substance must be administered in a state of the most perfect purity, and uncombined with any other.

meanings.definition: not attractive in appearance:
examples: She was seventeen, and not uncomely.
The exterior masonry now looks defaced with its uncomely masses of rough brick.

meanings.definition: not feeling comfortable and pleasant, or not making you feel comfortable and pleasant:
examples: I've eaten so much, I actually feel uncomfortable.
These shoes are really uncomfortable.

meanings.definition: slightly embarrassed, or making you feel slightly embarrassed:
examples: an uncomfortable silence

meanings.definition: not comfortable or relaxed, or feeling anxiety:
examples: an uncomfortable chair
She feels uncomfortable in a room full of strangers.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not feel comfortable and pleasant:
examples: I was warm but not uncomfortably so.
She lay awkwardly on her back, shifting uncomfortably, unable to sleep.

meanings.definition: in a way that makes you feel slightly embarrassed, or that shows that you feel slightly embarrassed:
examples: She glanced away uncomfortably, staring down at her plate.
I smiled uncomfortably while he processed my information.

meanings.definition: not funny:
examples: He's a comic character involved in very uncomic deeds.

meanings.definition: (of a place) not having many businesses, shops, restaurants, etc. or much advertising:
examples: Thirty miles north of the city, you will find one of the few uncommercialized beaches remaining in the area.
When I went to the island ten years ago, it was almost completely uncommercialised.

meanings.definition: (of an activity) not organized to make a profit:
examples: The technology is still new and uncommercialized, but it will only be a matter of time before someone finds a way to market it.
The church carol singalong was one of the few remaining uncommercialised activities about Christmas that she could enjoy.

meanings.definition: having made no promise to support any particular group, plan, belief, or action:
examples: 25 senators have admitted they are still uncommitted on the taxation question.

meanings.definition: not seen, happening, or experienced often:
examples: Accidents due to failure of safety equipment are uncommon nowadays.
It's not uncommon for people to become ill when they travel.

meanings.definition: An uncommon quality, especially a human quality, is larger in amount or degree than usual:
examples: a woman of uncommon beauty

meanings.definition: not seen, happening, or experienced often:
examples: It’s not uncommon for someone to change jobs several times.

meanings.definition: (esp. of a human quality) unusually large in amount or degree:
examples: She’s a woman of uncommon kindness.

meanings.definition: extremely:
examples: She was uncommonly brave too.

meanings.definition: not willing to talk:
examples: He had a headache and was uncommunicative.

meanings.definition: not showing sympathy and sadness for the suffering or bad luck of others:
examples: I believe that our society treats its aged in a callous, uncompassionate way.

meanings.definition: If a reason, argument, etc. is uncompelling, it does not make you believe it or accept it because it is not strong:
examples: The defence tried to convince the jury that his client had been too drunk to commit the crime, but they found that argument uncompelling.
The detectives came to an uncompelling conclusion regarding the mysterious fingerprints.

meanings.definition: not exciting or interesting in a way that makes you want to watch or listen further:
examples: The movie has a long, digressive plot that I found uncompelling.
His character is too uncompelling for me to care what happens to him.

meanings.definition: not paid money in exchange for something that has been lost or damaged or for some problem:
examples: Hospitals in the state provided $3.1 billion in uncompensated care last year.
He argued that his client suffered uncompensated losses from being unable to work after her injury.

meanings.definition: An uncompensated job or position is one for which someone does not receive payment. An uncompensated worker does not receive payment for the job that they do:
examples: She serves as a trustee to the university, which is an uncompensated position.
Much of the work on the campaign was performed by uncompensated volunteers.

meanings.definition: used to describe work that is not paid for:
examples: The work is uncompensated, though board members are reimbursed for expenses.
The company provided more than $86 million in uncompensated care to uninsured patients last year.

meanings.definition: not involving or encouraging competition:
examples: We want to make sure they are not allowed to employ uncompetitive practices when they are bidding against us.
He was irritated for years by the bank's uncompetitive rates of interest.

meanings.definition: uncompetitive products and services are not as good as other products or services with similar prices:
examples: If you stop paying overtime and your competitors don't, you become very uncompetitive.
The company does not accept orders at uncompetitive prices.

meanings.definition: not complacent (= feeling so satisfied with your own abilities or situation that you feel you do not need to try any harder):
examples: He practices the guitar every day because even though he is regarded as one of the world's most talented musicians, he prefers to be uncomplacent about that.
Her latest novel is an uncomplacent work in a style vastly different from her previous books.

meanings.definition: willing to do boring or difficult work without complaining or becoming angry:
examples: The work is boring, but he's always cheerful and uncomplaining.

meanings.definition: in an uncomplaining way (= without complaining or becoming angry):
examples: They live a hard life uncomplainingly.
He uncomplainingly accepted his illness and got on with his life.

meanings.definition: not completed or finished:
examples: The building renovation began two years ago but remains uncompleted because the owners ran out of money.
We've made a lot of progress, but we have a lot of uncompleted work left to do.
There were several uncompleted canvases lying around the artist's studio.

meanings.definition: simple, and not difficult to understand or deal with; not complicated:
examples: We have an uncomplicated approach to website design.
He was an uncomplicated person who was happiest when he was with his friends and family.

meanings.definition: not having any complications (= extra medical problems that make it more difficult to treat an existing illness or condition):
examples: the treatment of acute uncomplicated cystitis
antenatal care for uncomplicated pregnancies

meanings.definition: rudely criticizing:
examples: She had some very uncomplimentary things to say about Stephen.

meanings.definition: not made up of smaller parts combined together:
examples: The physical nature of God is that He is an uncompounded Being, an essence not composed of parts.
Looking at nature under a microscope allows one to see the simple and uncompounded substances on which all of life is based.

meanings.definition: based on an original amount and not the amount as it changes because something is added to or taken away from it :
examples: Teachers receiving pensions see a 2 percent annual uncompounded increase based on their first cheque.
In one year the account earned £47 in uncompounded interest.

meanings.definition: not understood:
examples: The theme of death as an uncomprehended, mysterious force runs through much of the author's writings.
The script found on the tablets remains uncomprehended.

meanings.definition: not understanding something:
examples: They walked through the ruins of the city with dazed, uncomprehending looks.

meanings.definition: without understanding something:
examples: He listened uncomprehendingly to her technical explanations.
She gazed at him uncomprehendingly when he questioned her.

meanings.definition: not pressed into a smaller space:
examples: The sand was loose and uncompressed, not useful for building a castle.
Plant the seed in uncompressed soil so the water will drain down to the seed.

meanings.definition: (of a computer file) not made to use less space when it is stored in the memory of a computer or on a disk:
examples: We use an image processing program that directly supports receiving and generating uncompressed image data.
We played music over the computer by downloading uncompressed audio files that didn't lose their sound quality.

meanings.definition: If people or their beliefs are uncompromising, they are fixed and do not change, especially when faced with opposition:
examples: The city council has taken an uncompromising stand against the proposals for the new building.

meanings.definition: (of a person or a person's opinions) fixed and not easily changed:
examples: People are intimidated by her uncompromising ways.

meanings.definition: in a way that is fixed and not changing, even when this may cause difficulties:
examples: She was uncompromisingly hostile to him.
Her paintings are uncompromisingly abstract.

meanings.definition: not kept hidden:
examples: He speaks of his children with unconcealed pride at what they have accomplished.
"Open carry" refers to the practice of wearing an unconcealed weapon in public.

meanings.definition: not worried or not interested, especially when you should be worried or interested:
examples: The baby was apparently unconcerned by the noise.
Are you as unconcerned about the situation as you seem to be?

meanings.definition: not worried or anxious:
examples: How can you be unconcerned about how much things cost?

meanings.definition: in a way that shows someone is not worried or interested:
examples: "I hardly knew her at all," said Guy, unconcernedly.
I was about to ride by unconcernedly, when a soldier came out from the bushes and stopped me.

meanings.definition: complete and not limited in any way:
examples: the unconditional love that parents feel for their children
unconditional surrender
We demand the immediate and unconditional release of all political prisoners.

meanings.definition: complete and not limited in any way:
examples: unconditional love
He got an unconditional release from prison.

meanings.definition: complete and not limited in any way:
examples: They have my unconditional support.
The shares, which begin unconditional trading tomorrow, were priced last week at 250p.
Our unconditional guarantee gives total peace of mind to our customers.

meanings.definition: an offer by one company to buy another without particular conditions:
examples: The expected profit from a conditional tender offer is generally higher than the expected profit from an unconditional bid.

meanings.definition: in a way that is complete and not limited in any way:
examples: He thanked his mother for being unconditionally supportive.
She apologized unconditionally.

meanings.definition: (of a feeling or something you have done wrong) not admitted:
examples: I got the sense that he is haunted by demons, perhaps due to something unconfessed about his past.
If you have any unconfessed sins, it might be best for you to reveal them now.

meanings.definition: not confident:
examples: He is very unconfident about his work.

meanings.definition: not kept in a limited space; allowed to move or grow freely:
examples: Their animals are unconfined and able to roam.

meanings.definition: (of a feeling of pleasure) without any limit; very great:
examples: There was unconfined joy, I understand, when she quit last week after just three weeks in the job.

meanings.definition: If facts are unconfirmed, it is not certain if they are true:
examples: According to unconfirmed reports, two people were killed in the riots last night.

meanings.definition: (of information) not proven to be true or false:
examples: an unconfirmed report

meanings.definition: an interruption in the series of the earth's rock layers, resulting from either erosion (= gradual loss by the effect of weather) or the failure of layers to be created
an interruption in the series of the earth's rock layers, resulting from either erosion (= gradual loss by the effect of weather) or the failure of layers to be created
to make something less difficult to understand:
examples: Hopefully this explanation will help unconfuse the situation.
She's an exceptional teacher, able to lay out the material in a clear, unconfused way that doesn't prompt many questions from the class.

meanings.definition: to separate two things in someone's mind so that they no longer imagine that they are one:
examples: Their names were so similar that I had to devise a mnemonic device to keep them unconfused.

meanings.definition: (of a person) not friendly and pleasant:
examples: Unfortunately I found him almost as uncongenial as his sister.

meanings.definition: (of an activity or place) not enjoyable, acceptable, or welcoming:
examples: He found post-war college life uncongenial, and after two terms decided that it would be better to earn a living.
My liking for a bargain enables me to overlook uncongenial retail surroundings.

meanings.definition: not helpful; not likely to make something successful, or to provide the right conditions for something to happen or exist:
examples: In this period the religious climate proved uncongenial to such ideas.

meanings.definition: An unconjugated verb is not conjugated (= having the forms that a verb takes when used in different tenses, with different subjects etc.). :
examples: A verb is left unconjugated when it is used with an auxiliary verb, like with "kiss" in "you may kiss the bride".
The infinitive is the unconjugated form of a verb, often preceded by "to", as in "to know him is to love him".

meanings.definition: An unconjugated substance is not formed by the joining of one compound with another:
examples: Elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin can cause visible jaundice in infants during their first week of life.
Abnormally low levels of unconjugated oestriol during pregnancy may indicate the presence of congenital defects in the foetus.

meanings.definition: not connected; not related:
examples: It's no longer possible to argue that crime is unconnected with unemployment.
A series of apparently unconnected events led to his resignation.

meanings.definition: not able to be defeated, or not able to be successfully controlled or dealt with:
examples: Rebel soldiers and civilians believed Lee's army was unconquerable.
She had an unconquerable aversion to modern life.

meanings.definition: not taken or defeated in a war:
examples: The interior of the island was one of the few remaining territories unconquered by the imperial nation.
The remaining unconquered tribes joined forces to defend against the invading army.

meanings.definition: (of a mountain or region that is difficult to reach) not successfully climbed or reached:
examples: At over 4,400 metres, the Matterhorn was one of the last unconquered peaks in the Alps until it was finally summited by Edward Whymper in July 1865.
The ice-covered land to the north was unconquered frontier, not known to any human explorer.

meanings.definition: morally unacceptable:
examples: To make people feel shame or guilt for being ill is unconscionable.
This unconscionable policy will cause great suffering.

meanings.definition: unacceptably great in amount:
examples: After waiting for an unconscionable amount of time, we were told to come back later.

meanings.definition: unacceptable because of being too extreme:
examples: It is unconscionable to say that some kids don’t deserve an education.

meanings.definition: in a way that is morally unacceptable:
examples: They are a bunch of self-interested individuals who have unconscionably abused their power.
I find many of the recipes published in this magazine to be unconscionably high in fat.

meanings.definition: in a way that is unacceptably great in amount:
examples: The film is unconscionably long at 2 hours and 48 minutes.
The whole process took an unconscionably long time.

meanings.definition: in the state of not being awake and not aware of things around you, especially as the result of a head injury:
examples: She was hit on the head by a stone and knocked unconscious.

meanings.definition: An unconscious thought or feeling is one that you do not know you have:
examples: my unconscious desire to impress him

meanings.definition: not conscious :
examples: The fall from his horse knocked him unconscious for several minutes.

meanings.definition: Unconscious feelings or actions are ones you are not completely aware of:
examples: unconscious anxiety
There’s an unconscious classification within the group.

meanings.definition: (in psychoanalysis) the part of the mind you are not aware of but which influences behavior
feelings and thoughts that you have without being aware of them, and that influence the way you behave:
examples: Freud believed dreams are a window into our unconscious mind.
This level of consciousness corresponds to that part of the unconscious mind which functions when we are in a light sleep.

meanings.definition: without being aware of what you are doing:
examples: He may be unconsciously looking for a mother figure.
Young managers are either consciously or unconsciously uncomfortable with hiring older workers.

meanings.definition: the state of not being awake and not aware of things around you, especially as the result of a head injury:
examples: She drifted into unconsciousness.
Anaesthetics directly affect the brain and produce unconsciousness.

meanings.definition: Something that is unconsecrated has not been made holy and is not able to be used for religious ceremonies:
examples: The traitorous soldier was executed, and his remains were placed in an unmarked grave in unconsecrated ground.
We found a supply of unconsecrated communion wafers in the church's basement pantry.

meanings.definition: (of an action or remark) not carefully thought about
relating to or involving the separate financial accounts or results of each company in a group, not combined with the others:
examples: The company's unconsolidated pretax profit rose 25% to 63.87 billion yen.
The summary financial data shall include the assets, liabilities, and net worth or stockholders' equity of the unconsolidated subsidiaries.

meanings.definition: not allowed by the constitution (= set of rules for government) of a country or organization:
examples: Changing the law in this way would be unconstitutional.

meanings.definition: not allowed by the constitution (= set of political principles) of a country or organization
in a way that is unconstitutional (= not allowed by the rules of government):
examples: A court ruled that he had acted unconstitutionally.
They claim that the sentence is unconstitutionally cruel and unusual.

meanings.definition: not controlled or limited in any way:
examples: She lived the life of a freewheeling artist, unconstrained by the conventions of a middle-class lifestyle.
By living off campus in her own apartment, she was able to come and go unconstrained by the house rules of the dormitory.

meanings.definition: not controlled or limited in any way:
examples: Everyone was relaxed and having a good time at the party, unconstricted by the worries of life.
A freethinking artist confident in exploring her own style, she was unconstricted by concerns about what would sell or what was popular.

meanings.definition: able to move easily, without something such as clothing preventing this:
examples: The league introduced new uniforms for the basketball players that allow for unconstricted movement.

meanings.definition: not tight or narrow, and allowing easy movement:
examples: The blouse has a loose cut, so it feels unconstricted and can be worn over a tank top.

meanings.definition: not useful and not intended to help or improve something:
examples: The peace talks between the two heads of state were unconstructive and they found themselves back at square one.
The public comments in response to the post were unconstructive and brought nothing of help to the conversation.

meanings.definition: not eaten or used up :
examples: I picked up the popcorn bucket, but there were only a handful of unconsumed kernels at the bottom.
Any unconsumed medication should be thrown out or returned to the pharmacy.

meanings.definition: not completely destroyed by fire:
examples: There were some metal scraps and other debris that had been left unconsumed by the bonfire.

meanings.definition: If a marriage or romantic relationship is unconsummated, the people in the relationship have not had sex:
examples: The couple kept their relationship unconsummated through the first year.
They had an intense love affair, carried out over long-distance letters, though it was believed to be unconsummated.

meanings.definition: not able to be controlled or kept at a low level:
examples: Our excitement was uncontainable in the moments before the band made their way onto the stage.
The puppy had uncontainable energy, barking and dashing all around the house.
The wildfire in the canyon is uncontainable, so firefighters are working on the periphery to make a firebreak.

meanings.definition: not dirty or containing any harmful or unwanted substances:
examples: The water is safe to drink, so long as it is drawn only from uncontaminated wells.
Make sure your hands and cutting surface are uncontaminated before working with raw meat.

meanings.definition: not affected by damaging feelings, thoughts, ideas, etc.:
examples: As researchers, we try to arrive at logical conclusions uncontaminated by prejudice or ideology.
We were urged to live uncontaminated by fear and the temptation to give in to our base desires.

meanings.definition: not considered with any deep thought or seriousness:
examples: One uncontemplated consequence of leaving her job was that competing companies would try to make her divulge her former employer's secrets.
The decision generated a number of uncontemplated questions from the public for which they had no immediate response.

meanings.definition: not causing or likely to cause disagreement and argument:
examples: The measures in the bill are largely uncontentious, and it is expected to pass easily in both the House of Commons and the House of Lords.
Most of the arguments in the essay are uncontentious, but the author jumps to some strange conclusions.

meanings.definition: If something is uncontested, no one tries to stop you doing it or no one tries to fight against or defend it:
examples: Their marriage ended in an uncontested divorce.
He dribbled to the basket and scored with an uncontested layup.

meanings.definition: An uncontested election is one in which only one person is trying to get an elected position or job :
examples: The election was uncontested and the congressman retained his seat for a second term.

meanings.definition: used to describe a decision or result which nobody opposes or disagrees with:
examples: The scope of the problem is uncontested.
The waiting time for an uncontested divorce will be reduced from two years to one.
Her claim for her costs plus €200 in damages was uncontested.

meanings.definition: relating to a political race in which only one person is trying to be elected for particular position:
examples: There were six uncontested races in the state this year.
Ms. Volker retained her uncontested seat with 783 votes.

meanings.definition: not having or affected by a contract (= a legal document that states and explains a formal agreement between two different people or groups):
examples: I spent most of my early adult years working in uncontracted, low-wage or part-time jobs.
The natural gas is uncontracted and belongs to the owner of the field where it is extracted.

meanings.definition: An uncontracted form is expressed as two words, rather than the words being combined into a single word. :
examples: You might use contractions like "I'll" when speaking, but it is recommended that you use the uncontracted form "I will" in writing.

meanings.definition: If a statement, a fact, or information is uncontradicted, no one says that it is wrong or not true:
examples: The last part of the witness's deposition was uncontradicted by the defendant.
There is clear and uncontradicted evidence that Mr Lodge knew about the crime but did not notify police.

meanings.definition: not artificial or difficult to believe:
examples: His speeches connect with people because they sound natural and uncontrived.
If you are honest about what interests you, then you can write about it in an uncontrived way.

meanings.definition: too strong or violent to be controlled:
examples: I suddenly had an uncontrollable desire to hit him.

meanings.definition: too strong or violent to be controlled:
examples: an uncontrollable temper
I felt an uncontrollable desire to sit down.

meanings.definition: in a way that is too strong or violent to be controlled:
examples: I got home to find him sobbing uncontrollably on the doorstep.
We all started laughing uncontrollably.

meanings.definition: (of an emotion, vehicle, etc.) not under a person's control:
examples: uncontrolled aggression
It was said that he often erupted into fits of uncontrolled rage.

meanings.definition: without anything having been done to stop a problem from increasing, or a disease, etc. from getting worse; not limited in any way:
examples: The urbanization of the countryside was largely uncontrolled.
Uncontrolled hypertension is one of the main preventable causes of death or disability due to stroke or heart attack.
If left uncontrolled, the disease can cause a number of serious complications.

meanings.definition: not using a control (= an object or system that is not changed so that you can compare it with similar objects or systems that are intentionally changed):
examples: The number of patients is relatively small and the study is uncontrolled.

meanings.definition: existing or happening with nothing able to stop it:
examples: uncontrolled shivering
the uncontrolled spread of urban sprawl

meanings.definition: not causing much disagreement or anger, especially among the public :
examples: I tried to come up with a list of uncontroversial subjects to discuss with my girlfriend's parents over dinner.
The school's choice for a head girl this year is probably going to be someone uncontroversial after the outcry over last year's choice.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not cause disagreement or angry discussion:
examples: He began, uncontroversially enough, by stating that social inclusion is one of the Government's highest priorities.
This year's Best Picture Oscar went uncontroversially to the New Zealand director.

meanings.definition: different from what is usual or from the way most people do things:
examples: an unconventional childhood/lifestyle/marriage

meanings.definition: different from what is usual or from the way most people do things:
examples: He has an unconventional attitude toward work.

meanings.definition: in a way that is different from what is usually done or believed:
examples: The documentary takes a look at the good and bad sides of growing up unconventionally.
an unconventionally handsome actor

meanings.definition: not having changed to a new religion, belief, or opinion:
examples: We are asked to pray for our unconverted friends.
I love their new album but my wife remains resolutely unconverted.

meanings.definition: not changed in form or character; not made suitable for a different use:
examples: For sale: Two unconverted barns in a courtyard setting on a five-acre plot.
If there were a few red blood cells that were left unconverted, that really wouldn't do any harm.

meanings.definition: In some sports, when a try, free throw, or penalty shot is unconverted, no extra points are scored after it:
examples: He sprinted over for an unconverted try to take Bristol to a deserved 5 point lead.
Three Portrush penalty corners went unconverted in the first half.

meanings.definition: not persuaded to believe that something is true:
examples: The kids tried to argue that they would learn more if they stayed home from school to watch the rocket launch, but their parents remained unconvinced.
After hearing the salesman's pitch, I was still unconvinced that I should buy the car.

meanings.definition: If an explanation or story is unconvincing, it does not sound or seem true or real:
examples: They gave some unconvincing explanations for the system failure.
The dialogue was unconvincing, partly because it was American actors trying to speak London English.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not seem true or real:
examples: Various ministers claimed, unconvincingly, that they were not worried.
"I was not nervous, just tense," he said, unconvincingly.

meanings.definition: not having been cooked:
examples: Do not store cooked and uncooked meat together.

meanings.definition: embarrassing and not fashionable:
examples: My dad's so uncool.
Wearing homemade clothes was very uncool.

meanings.definition: still warm or hot:
examples: You will want to wait and not apply the frosting to the cake while it is uncooled, or else it might congeal.
Make sure you don't touch the light bulb while it is still uncooled.

meanings.definition: not made cool by ice, a fridge, or an air conditioning system (= a system that keeps buildings or vehicles cool) :
examples: With no ice, I can only offer you an uncooled drink.
The painter's studio is located in an unheated, uncooled metal shed behind his home.

meanings.definition: not willing to work with or be helpful to other people:
examples: I thought he was rude and uncooperative.

meanings.definition: in an uncooperative way (= not willing to work with or be helpful to people):
examples: "What?" she said uncooperatively.
When all players act cooperatively, each does better than when all act uncooperatively.

meanings.definition: the quality of being uncooperative (= not willing to work with or be helpful to people):
examples: Uncooperativeness may be the first sign that the patient has given up and really wants to die.
I will not stand any indifference or uncooperativeness on your part.

meanings.definition: with different parts failing to work or move well together:
examples: The marketing campaign was an uncoordinated effort by several different departments.
She was clumsy and uncoordinated as a girl.

meanings.definition: An uncopyrightable book, play, film, piece of music, etc. cannot be protected by copyright laws (= laws giving someone the legal right to control the production and selling of a book, play, etc.):
examples: Excerpts of the US legal code are uncopyrightable because they technically belong to the public.
The judge ruled that the photograph was uncopyrightable because it was never clearly determined who took it.

meanings.definition: to open a bottle by pulling out its cork (= a cylinder-shaped piece of soft wood used to close it):
examples: "Who wants some wine?" asked Sally, uncorking a bottle.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         uncork
to open a bottle by pulling out its cork (= a cylinder-shaped piece of soft wood used to close it):
examples: "Who wants some wine?" asked Sally, uncorking a bottle.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         uncork
to open a bottle by pulling out its cork (= a cylinder-shaped piece of soft wood used to close it):
examples: "Who wants some wine?" asked Sally, uncorking a bottle.

meanings.definition: not able to be corrected:
examples: The patient was diagnosed with an uncorrectable heart condition.
An uncorrectable error in the code means that the software program is doomed to fail and should be removed from the marketplace.

meanings.definition: not corrected:
examples: Although the interviewer clearly misspoke, his error was left uncorrected in the show's transcript.
I want to point out one mistake in your introduction which should not go uncorrected.
There is a serious error in the article that remains uncorrected on the website.

meanings.definition: If two or more facts, numbers, etc. are uncorrelated, there is no relationship between them:
examples: Some economists believe that the decrease in fuel prices is uncorrelated to the increase in the number of people who no longer commute to work.
It is advisable to buy a diverse portfolio of uncorrelated assets including stocks and bonds.

meanings.definition: Uncorroborated information has not been proven to be true:
examples: She said the case against her used uncorroborated evidence.

meanings.definition: not using your position or power to get an advantage, especially for money :
examples: An ideal democratic society relies on uncorrupt lawmakers and judges and a free and open press that keeps them honest.
The city was fortunate to have an uncorrupt police chief who didn't use his position to blackmail others.

meanings.definition: not morally bad:
examples: He was an uncorrupt youth from a good family who never felt the need to turn to crime.
Rumours started to swirl around her that tainted her uncorrupt image.

meanings.definition: If a plan or policy is uncosted, the cost of it has not been calculated in a detailed way:
examples: This promise of free musical tuition is uncosted and it is unclear whether the Treasury is offering any new money for it.
We will not make uncosted spending promises, but assess what needs to change and how we can do better.

meanings.definition: An uncountable noun is not used with "a" or "an" and cannot be made plural:
examples: Words like "electricity", "blood", and "happiness" are uncountable.

meanings.definition: a noun that has one form with no plural and names something that there can be more or less of but that cannot be counted:
examples: "Heat" is an uncountable noun.

meanings.definition: to separate two things that are joined together:
examples: The engine had been uncoupled from the rest of the train.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         uncouple
to separate two things that are joined together:
examples: The engine had been uncoupled from the rest of the train.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         uncouple
to separate two things that are joined together:
examples: The engine had been uncoupled from the rest of the train.

meanings.definition: not having or showing courage:
examples: It was uncourageous of him not to own up to how poorly he treated you.
Even the most uncourageous diner may be inclined to try some of the chef's dishes, which he learned to make during his journeys around the globe.

meanings.definition: behaving in a rude, unpleasant way:
examples: She thought he was loud-mouthed and uncouth.

meanings.definition: (of a person or a person's behavior) rude and unpleasant
to discover something secret or hidden :
examples: The investigation uncovered evidence of a large-scale illegal trade in wild birds.
The biography is an attempt to uncover the inner man.

meanings.definition: to take a cover or covering off something:
examples: Cover the dish and bake for 15 minutes, then uncover it and bake for another 10 minutes.
The masked men were ordered to uncover their faces.

meanings.definition: to find something buried under the ground by removing the earth on top of it:
examples: Digging in her garden, she uncovered a hoard of gold dating back to the ninth century.

meanings.definition: to remove what is covering something, or to discover what was hidden:
examples: uncover the pot
It’s the press’s responsibility to uncover the truth.

meanings.definition: without a cover or covering on it:
examples: The child fell down the uncovered drain while playing on a building site near his home.
The sun was beating down on her uncovered head and she needed to move into the shade.

meanings.definition: not protected by insurance (= an agreement in which you pay a company money and they pay your costs if you have an accident, injury, etc.):
examples: That year agriculture companies and farmers faced at least £3.6 billion in uncovered losses due to natural disasters.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         uncover
to discover something secret or hidden :
examples: The investigation uncovered evidence of a large-scale illegal trade in wild birds.
The biography is an attempt to uncover the inner man.

meanings.definition: to take a cover or covering off something:
examples: Cover the dish and bake for 15 minutes, then uncover it and bake for another 10 minutes.
The masked men were ordered to uncover their faces.

meanings.definition: to find something buried under the ground by removing the earth on top of it:
examples: Digging in her garden, she uncovered a hoard of gold dating back to the ninth century.

meanings.definition: honest and open about something:
examples: The teen health book is refreshingly uncoy about sex, body hygiene, and other subjects that most authors are too afraid to spell out.
The new mayor was uncoy about her intention to make significant changes to city government and her desire to leave her stamp on the city.

meanings.definition: not having one or more cracks (= very narrow spaces between the parts of something that usually form when it has been broken):
examples: My breakfast consisted of a single uncracked hard-boiled egg.
I panicked when I dropped my phone on the pavement, but fortunately the screen was uncracked.

meanings.definition: not solved or having the answer made known:
examples: The mystery remained uncracked for many years until an important new clue came to light.
The bottle contained an uncracked coded message that may lead to the whereabouts of the treasure.

meanings.definition: to remove something from a box made of wood, plastic, or metal:
examples: The curators at the museum carefully uncrated the sculptures as they set up the exhibition.
The antique pottery was delivered to the gallery's warehouse and uncrated on the open floor in front of a curious audience.

meanings.definition: not producing or using original or unusual ideas:
examples: Housework is generally uncreative, except for cooking, of course.

meanings.definition: An uncredentialed person does not have the necessary qualifications or documents to do a particular job. :
examples: There is a correlation between the worst-performing schools in the district and those with the greatest number of uncredentialed teachers.
The uncredentialed photographer was escorted from the room before the wealthy young socialite made her entrance.

meanings.definition: not given praise, honour, or thanks by name, especially when it is deserved:
examples: A man who was snorkelling off the coast claims to be the uncredited discoverer of the shipwreck.
Much of the designer's success was on the backs of the uncredited labour of her assistants.

meanings.definition: not listed by name among the people who helped to make a film or a television or radio programme, that is shown or announced at the beginning or the end of it:
examples: The director had an uncredited role in the movie as one of the passengers in the lift.
Thirty years after making her debut in the blockbuster drama, the actress gave a cameo in the remake for which she was uncredited.

meanings.definition: If a bank account or an amount of money is uncredited, the amount has not been shown as paid into the account:
examples: A week after I sent back the merchandise, my account was still uncredited.
The tenant's security deposit remained uncredited even after he moved out and paid for professional cleaning.

meanings.definition: not injured, damaged, or in pain in a way that prevents you from being able to move or walk freely:
examples: I would love to be able to wear flat shoes to work and walk uncrippled around the office.

meanings.definition: not severely affected or limited by something:
examples: These are rare individuals who are uncrippled by dogma.

meanings.definition: (of software) not intentionally limited in the way it works in order to make the user pay for extra software:
examples: Users can download a free version of the app with limited functionality, or they can pay £3.99 to upgrade to an uncrippled version of the software.

meanings.definition: accepting something too easily, because of being unwilling or unable to criticize:
examples: an adoring, uncritical audience

meanings.definition: in an uncritical way (= accepting something too easily):
examples: We do not think the claims should be accepted uncritically.
She admires the students, but not uncritically.

meanings.definition: (of a photo, image, etc.) not having the edges removed so that only the most important part remains:
examples: This is the uncropped version of the famous photo, which includes an unknown woman.
The uncropped image wouldn't fit on the page.

meanings.definition: (of hair, grass, etc.) not cut short:
examples: The boy had uncropped hair that spilled over into his eyes.
Uncropped grass is often a breeding ground for ticks.

meanings.definition: (of land) not used for growing crops:
examples: Farmers will sow uncropped land with wildflower seed.
New, uncropped soil was exposed.
an uncropped field

meanings.definition: not able to be crossed or not allowed to be crossed:
examples: Escape lay on the other side of an uncrossable river.
The line between television and high art was once thought to be uncrossable.

meanings.definition: If someone's arms, fingers, or legs are uncrossed, they are not in a position where one arm, etc. is placed over the other one:
examples: In an interview situation, lean forward slightly, with your hands open, and arms and legs uncrossed.
Her arms were uncrossed and her hands rested on her hips.

meanings.definition: (of a cheque) not having two lines drawn across it to show that it must be paid into a bank account:
examples: No compensation will be paid for lost packages containing money or uncrossed cheques.
I received an uncrossed benefit cheque for just under £200.

meanings.definition: not having a line drawn through it:
examples: The address was still in my notebook, uncrossed out.
In her writing all the i's were undotted and all the t's uncrossed.

meanings.definition: not having a way or path or way across:
examples: The hillside was uncrossed by any rights of way.
At that time the lake was uncrossed by bridges or tunnels and was a more formidable barrier than it is now.

meanings.definition: a cheque without two vertical lines down its centre, showing that the person named to receive the money can get the amount at the bank of the person or organization that wrote the cheque, rather than having to pay it into their bank account:
examples: The delivery company claimed that parcels containing uncrossed cheques were exempt from compensation.

meanings.definition: not full of people or traffic:
examples: With 147 miles of shoreline, the lake remains uncrowded even during the summer peak months.
You'll find uncrowded beaches right along the Glamorgan Heritage Coast.
They like the commute to work on uncrowded urban expressways.

meanings.definition: If someone is uncrushable, it is impossible to make them lose hope or confidence:
examples: In order to succeed in life you have to have an uncrushable belief in yourself.

meanings.definition: Uncrushable cloth or clothing is designed to stay free of unwanted folds:
examples: an uncrushable hat

meanings.definition: abbreviation for United Nations Conference on Trade and Development: an organization within the United Nations that deals with international trade, development, and investment, especially in developing countries
the act of putting holy oil or water on someone in a religious ceremony, in order to make them holy or give them holy responsibilities :
examples: They were waiting for the priest to administer the sacrament of unction (last rites).
Napoleon knelt to receive the triple unction from the Pope on head, arms, and hands.

meanings.definition: an ointment (= a thick substance, usually containing medicine, used on the skin to help heal it or cure a condition):
examples: Look in their bathroom and you will find enough creams, unctions, and lotions to restock a small chemist.
The whole family was infested, and so began the endless cycle of harsh chemicals, daily lotions, and overnight unctions.

meanings.definition: a strong show of emotion, especially one that is not sincere:
examples: The men sang this hymn with more unction than tune.
Naturally the prodigal's return is being celebrated with proper unction.

meanings.definition: Unctuous people or behaviour expresses too much praise, interest, friendliness, etc., in a way that is false and unpleasant:
examples: his unctuous manner/voice/smile

meanings.definition: to remove handcuffs (= metal or plastic rings joined by a short chain that lock around the wrists) from someone:
examples: After the not guilty verdict, the defendant was uncuffed and allowed to go and hug his family.
He persuaded the guards to uncuff his hands.

meanings.definition: not able to be used for growing crops:
examples: The marshy land had been polluted by industrial use and would be uncultivable for years.
There are large zones of uncultivable swamp.

meanings.definition: Uncultivated land is not used to grow crops:
examples: The agency has preserved wetland habitat and encouraged farmers to leave some fields uncultivated.

meanings.definition: Someone who is uncultivated has not had a good education and may not know a lot about art, music, painting, etc.:
examples: We must always remember that he was not an ignorant or uncultivated soldier.

meanings.definition: Someone who is uncultured has not had a good education and does not know a lot about art, music, painting, etc.:
examples: He accused modern schools of churning out uncultured children.
They regarded their country cousins as primitive and uncultured.

meanings.definition: (of a disease) not having a cure or not having been cured:
examples: We need more investment in research on cures for uncured diseases.
He had a serious liver problem that remained uncured for the rest of his life.

meanings.definition: (of a person) not made healthy again after an illness:
examples: She was discharged from hospital still uncured of her bronchitis.

meanings.definition: (of food or tobacco) not treated with smoke, salt, or a chemical in order to preserve it:
examples: Uncured bacon has not been treated with nitrites to preserve it.
Green tea is uncured and has a fresh, grassy flavour.

meanings.definition: not interested in learning more about a particular subject or person, or not interested in discovering anything new:
examples: He remained uncurious about his birth mother until three years ago, when his adoptive mother died.
I can't believe he was so intellectually shallow, so uncurious.

meanings.definition: not covered or decorated with a curtain:
examples: There was a rectangle of light on the floor cast by sunlight that passed through an uncurtained window.
Through the uncurtained window, we could see that snow had begun to fall.

meanings.definition: part of the body of a person or animal that forms a C-shaped curve at one end:
examples: The cancer originated in the pancreatic uncus.
The form of the uncus distinguishes this from most other species of moths.

meanings.definition: a curved part of the temporal lobes (= either of two large parts of the brain, one on each side behind the ear, that are especially involved in understanding sound):
examples: The olfactory projection fibres arise from the pyramid cells of the uncus and hippocampus.
The amygdala is a collection of nuclei that lies directly beneath the uncus.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not usual or typical for a particular person:
examples: His response to the question was uncustomarily rude.
I assumed that she must have been delayed since she was uncustomarily late to our meeting.

meanings.definition: not usual or typical for a particular person or in a particular situation:
examples: He approached her about the problem with uncustomary patience and delicacy.
The police held no news conference and released little information, uncustomary in such a high-profile case.

meanings.definition: complete and in its original form:
examples: the original, uncut version of a film
Uncut diamonds are worth less than those that have been cut and shaped.

meanings.definition: not made smaller or shorter, or not changed in any way:
examples: an uncut book/film/play
uncut diamonds

meanings.definition: not pleasant or attractive, especially in a way that small children or animals are:
examples: The child actor was refreshingly uncute in her role as a bratty kid.
Uncute animals—not just fluffy kittens and mischievous puppies—need love from humans, too.

meanings.definition: believing that people are interested in other people and are sincere:
examples: He is unspoilt and uncynical, whereas I'm cynical to the core.
Her mother taught her to be uncynical about love.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows you believe that people are interested in other people and are sincere:
examples: We are no longer living in a time when young people feel uncynically patriotic.
These positive tests for drugs will not make it easier to write uncynically about triumphant athletes.

meanings.definition: not harmed or spoiled:
examples: No hotel escaped undamaged, and the few with rooms still open are always filled.
The properties were relatively undamaged, unlike the burnt ruins we had seen elsewhere.

meanings.definition: (of a piece of music) impossible to dance to:
examples: If you listen to our records, you'll find that there's dance music, but there are also some very beautiful, undanceable songs, too.
The piece of music which she uses for the final section of the show is undanceable.

meanings.definition: An undated document has no date on it:
examples: The cheque/letter was undated.

meanings.definition: (of something written) without the day, month, and year on it:
examples: an undated letter

meanings.definition: not having a known or written date:
examples: The memo is undated but may have been written as early as May.
I received an undated letter saying that there would be a delay in opening the account.
The Pettigrew St. business district is shown in this undated photo.

meanings.definition: (of a bond or other investment) not having a date at which it can be redeemed (= exchanged for cash):
examples: The cash flow from an undated bond can be viewed as a continuous annuity.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         irredeemable gilts
a bond, etc. that pays interest but that will never be redeemed (= exchanged for cash):
examples: The market for these undated securities was battered, with losses estimated at $400 million.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         irredeemable stock
still determined and enthusiastic, despite problems or no success:
examples: Undaunted by the cold and the rain, people danced until 2 a.m.
The team remain undaunted, despite three defeats in a row.

meanings.definition: not frightened or discouraged, despite problems or lack of success:
examples: Undaunted by the cold and the rain, we continued our hike.

meanings.definition: If you are undecided, you have not yet made a decision or judgment about something:
examples: Are you still undecided about the new job?
54 percent of voters were in favour, 30 percent against, and the rest were undecided.

meanings.definition: not decided or finished:
examples: The whole question is still undecided.

meanings.definition: not having made a decision or judgment about something:
examples: Are you still undecided about that job in San Francisco?

meanings.definition: unable to be read or understood:
examples: The documents were old, fragile and worn, and the handwriting at times was almost undecipherable.
She spoke as quickly as she could without her words being undecipherable.

meanings.definition: not having been read or understood:
examples: They are keen to analyse other undeciphered ancient scripts, such as the Bronze Age petroglyphs from Scandinavia.
A common writing system was used, which remains undeciphered.

meanings.definition: not publicly admitted to be something or to exist, or not yet decided :
examples: The report did not mention inspections at undeclared nuclear sites.
It is illegal to bring undeclared cash into the country.
"The gap has closed between Democrats and Republicans, and that makes the undeclared voters more important than ever," she said.

meanings.definition: not decayed:
examples: They were expected to make their robes from discarded cloth, but they were not to take cloth from undecomposed bodies.
an undecomposed corpse

meanings.definition: not broken into smaller parts:
examples: Here and there we found pieces of undecomposed limestone.

meanings.definition: An undecorated object or place has nothing added to make it more attractive:
examples: She likes plain walls and altogether undecorated surfaces.
Undecorated Pavlova can safely be left overnight in the oven, to be decorated in the morning.

meanings.definition: having no paint or wallpaper on the walls, or not covered with paint or wallpaper:
examples: An undecorated, unfurnished flat in the block sold recently for £193,000.
The walls of the interior are finished with white plaster, which we have left undecorated.

meanings.definition: not believing that something is very important and therefore not giving a lot of time and energy to it:
examples: Younger people are often playing the guitar or drums for fun and are too inexperienced or undedicated.
The situation actually provided the opportunity to clear their rolls of undedicated members.

meanings.definition: not designed to be used for one particular purpose:
examples: She has warned that there will not be a big pile of undedicated money awaiting legislators.
The desert is an undedicated expanse.

meanings.definition: in sports, having won every game:
examples: The team managed to remain undefeated in the final weeks of the season.

meanings.definition: never having lost, esp. a competition, within a particular period of time:
examples: The Buffaloes upset No. 1-ranked and previously undefeated Wisconsin.

meanings.definition: not protected against attack:
examples: It is the world's longest undefended international border.
A hungry mink might find an undefended chickenhouse or fish pond.

meanings.definition: in sports or games, having no one or nothing preventing the opposing player or players from scoring points, goals, etc. :
examples: She tapped the ball into an undefended net.
He immediately took my undefended pawn with his queen.

meanings.definition: (of someone accused of something in a court of law) having no lawyer acting for them:
examples: The court advised him to take up the case, as the prisoner was undefended.
She will go on trial undefended because the government has put her lawyer under house arrest.

meanings.definition: An undefended title in a competition is something that you won before and that no one else has been able to win again:
examples: She is also favourite for the undefended girls' 16-18 years 100m butterfly title.
The women's 100m backstroke title is also undefended.

meanings.definition: not spoiled or made less beautiful or pure:
examples: The purity of my love was something that to me remained undefiled.
How refreshing it is to see the World Cup matches being played on pitches undefiled by corporate advertising.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         indefinable
not clearly described, stated, or known:
examples: The business is attempting to gauge how large a share of a new and largely undefined market it can seize.

meanings.definition: not having been given a definition (= a statement explaining the meaning of something):
examples: Certain words in the dictionary remain undefined, with only their form shown.

meanings.definition: (of a plant or crop) not treated with a chemical that is used to make the leaves drop off:
examples: In all experiments, tubers were harvested from undefoliated crops.
Defoliation treatments created large differences in seed yield, with undefoliated plants always producing higher yields.

meanings.definition: (of a power, job, duty, or right) not given to someone:
examples: If the government assumes undelegated powers, its acts are void and of no force.
The undelegated personal right is recognized in all the laws and charters of the world.

meanings.definition: to make something that has been deleted (= removed from a computer) able to be seen again

past simple and past participle of 
        
         undelete
to make something that has been deleted (= removed from a computer) able to be seen again

present participle of 
        
         undelete
to make something that has been deleted (= removed from a computer) able to be seen again
A letter, parcel, or message that is undeliverable cannot be delivered:
examples: There were thousands of undeliverable packages piling up in the sorting office.
Emails sent to addresses at these domains were returned as undeliverable.

meanings.definition: If something that was promised or planned is undeliverable, it cannot be done:
examples: We are stupid, and elect people who make the most undeliverable promises.
Several proposals have been put to customers offering undeliverable discounts on call rates, even though the customer is on the best possible rate.

meanings.definition: An undelivered letter, parcel, or message has not been delivered or cannot be delivered:
examples: We spend millions trying to return undelivered mail that is not properly addressed.
The airline's baggage problem arose last week after technical faults resulted in 7,000 bags being undelivered.

meanings.definition: If something that was promised or planned is undelivered, it has not been done:
examples: The vendor has been making undelivered promises since before shipment.
It was not the only undelivered element of the company's obligations.

meanings.definition: believing or understanding what is real or true and not tricked by false claims or common beliefs:
examples: A person who is undeluded will know what is beneficial and what is harmful.
In the play, he takes a terrifyingly undeluded look at life and human emotions.

meanings.definition: not needing a lot of time, energy, or attention:
examples: He is quiet and undemanding.
a relatively undemanding job

meanings.definition: not based on the principles of democracy:
examples: He had ruled in an undemocratic manner, deploying a secret police and press censorship.
an undemocratic regime

meanings.definition: in an undemocratic way (= not based on the wishes of most of the people ):
examples: He used violence as a political tool and governed undemocratically.
She is acting undemocratically by denying people their right to vote on this issue.

meanings.definition: certainly true:
examples: an undeniable fact
a woman of undeniable brilliance

meanings.definition: so obviously true that it cannot be doubted:
examples: It is an undeniable fact that ice is cold.

meanings.definition: in a way that is certainly true:
examples: She is undeniably good at her job.
He undeniably shares some of their views.

meanings.definition: not connected with a particular religious group :
examples: The school is strictly undenominational, but the spiritual training of the students is not neglected.

meanings.definition: not able to be trusted and not likely to do what you expect:
examples: Electricity is so undependable that lights go out in the capital several times a day.
A harsh aspect of poverty is that income is often irregular and undependable.

meanings.definition: in or to a position below or lower than something else, often so that one thing covers the other:
examples: He hid under the bed.
In AD 79 the city of Pompei was buried under a layer of ash seven metres deep.
She put the thermometer under my tongue.
She was holding a folder under her arm (= between her upper arm and the side of her body).
They stood under a tree (= below its branches) to avoid getting wet.

meanings.definition: If a piece of land is under a particular type of plant, that plant is growing on the whole of that area:
examples: The main fields are under wheat.

meanings.definition: If a book, article, or piece of information is under a particular title, you can find it below or following that title in a list, book, library, etc.:
examples: Books on Ansel Adams will probably be under Art or Photography.
Custard? That comes under Desserts.

meanings.definition: less than:
examples: All items cost/are under a pound.
The discount applies only to children under (the age of) ten (= younger than ten).
If you get under 50 percent, you fail the exam.

meanings.definition: happening during, as a result of, or according to a particular situation, event, rule, etc.:
examples: The work was completed under very difficult conditions.
Now that the deadline is approaching we all feel under pressure.
The chair broke under his weight (= because he was too heavy for it).
Under the current rules, you need the agreement of at least 6 out of 10 committee members.

meanings.definition: controlled or governed by a particular person, organization, or force:
examples: He's a Colonel, with hundreds of soldiers under him (= obeying his orders).
I wonder what Britain was like under the Romans (= during the time when the Romans controlled Britain).
People born under (= during the period of) the zodiac sign Pisces are supposed to be dreamy and artistic.

meanings.definition: using a particular name, especially one that is not your real name:
examples: He writes under the name (of) John le Carré.
For his own safety, he has to operate under a false name/an alias.

meanings.definition: below the surface of something:
examples: Because I'm a bad swimmer, I often go under and swallow a lot of water.

meanings.definition: not enough or not done as well or as much as is necessary:
examples: undercooked potatoes
underprivileged children
We're all overworked and underpaid.
His boss says he's under-performing (= not doing as well as he should) at work.

meanings.definition: below:
examples: underwear
an underpass

meanings.definition: in or to a position below or lower than (something else), often so that one thing covers the other:
examples: Our dog hides under the bed whenever we have a lightning storm.
