She was holding the umbrella under her arm (= between her upper arm and the side of her chest).

meanings.definition: less than:
examples: The price is still under a dollar.
Scholarship candidates must be under 21 and plan to attend college in the fall.

meanings.definition: in the process of, influenced or controlled by, or according to:
examples: Construction had to be done under difficult conditions.
Under current law, stores in this town can’t do business on Sunday.
We liked working under her because she made us feel appreciated.
"Where can I find books on swimming?" "Look under sports (= within the subject of sports)."
We seemed to be under attack (= in the process of being attacked) by a swarm of bees.
Your request for a transfer to our Denver office is under consideration (= being considered).
I was under the impression (= I believed) that she was married.
I find it difficult to work under pressure (= with this influence).

meanings.definition: less than something else:
examples: There is no admission charge for children six and under.

meanings.definition: below or lower than something else:
examples: Several lifeguards tried desperately to reach him before he went under (= sank below the surface of the water).

meanings.definition: not enough:
examples: The potatoes were undercooked.
Classes were too large because the school was understaffed.

meanings.definition: in any situation or under any conditions:
examples: We will not quit under any circumstances.
She says that she will not be resigning under any circumstances.
We oppose capital punishment in any circumstances.
In any circumstances, this would be a huge and complex job.

meanings.definition: provided with weapons and willing to fight:
examples: The rebels now have thousands of people under arms.

meanings.definition: in a tent:
examples: I love sleeping under canvas.
Happily, there are other options besides sleeping under canvas.
We spent two chilly nights under canvas.
When I met her, she'd been living under canvas for over three months.
If staying under canvas doesn't appeal, there are one or two very nice hotels in the nearby village.
This was our second week under canvas and I'd pretty much had enough.

meanings.definition: If you do something under constraint, you do it only because you have been forced to:
examples: They confessed, but only under severe constraint.
She is not responsible for actions carried out under constraint.
I was under constraint to produce a chapter a week.
I would not want anyone to work for me under constraint.
We joined in willingly with their project, and were under no constraint.

meanings.definition: in the process of being created or built:
examples: A huge new hotel is under construction on the seafront.
This website is currently under construction.

meanings.definition: being dealt with or limited successfully:
examples: It seems that the disease is now under control.
Everything is under control, sir.
It took them two hours to bring/get the fire under control.
He tried to get his breathing under control and not panic.
Making a budget will help you keep your spending under control.
We are hoping that the medication will soon get his blood pressure under control.

meanings.definition: hidden or protected by something:

meanings.definition: If you do something under false pretences, you lie about who you are, what you are doing, or what you intend to do, in order to get something:
examples: He was deported for entering the country under false pretences.

meanings.definition: If you do something under false pretenses, you lie about who you are, what you are doing, or what you intend to do, in order to get something:
examples: He was deported for entering the country under false pretenses.
If you're not going to offer me a job, then you've brought me here under false pretenses (= you have deceived me in order to make me come here).

meanings.definition: being attacked with guns or with severe criticism:

meanings.definition: never, or in no case or situation:

meanings.definition: having legally promised to tell the truth:

meanings.definition: being repaired:

meanings.definition: If a shop, business, or organization is understaffed, it does not have enough employees:
examples: The hospital was desperately understaffed.

meanings.definition: not having enough employees:

meanings.definition: having fewer workers or employees than necessary:

meanings.definition: to know the meaning of something that someone says:
examples: She explained the whole idea again, but I still didn't understand.
Is there anyone here who understands Arabic?
I think he was calling from a club - it was so noisy, I couldn't understand a word he said.

meanings.definition: to know why or how something happens or works:
examples: We still don't fully understand how the brain works.

meanings.definition: to know how someone feels or why someone behaves in a particular way:
examples: My wife doesn't understand me.
Sometimes I don't understand James.
You don't understand what it's like/how it feels to have to beg on the streets.

meanings.definition: to know or realize something because you have been told it:
examples: I understand (that) you are interested in borrowing some money from us.
The Director had given her to understand (= told her) that she would be promoted.
A secret buyer is understood to have paid $1 million for the three pictures (= there is unofficial news that this has happened).

meanings.definition: used when making certain that someone knows what you mean and will do as you want:
examples: I don't want you to see that boy again. Understand?/Do you understand?/Is that understood?

meanings.definition: to know the meaning of something, or to know how a person feels and why the person behaves in a particular way:
examples: I don’t understand what he means.
Is there anyone here who understands English?
It was so noisy I couldn’t understand (= recognize) a word he was saying.
If you choose not to come, I’ll understand.
He claimed that no one ever understood him (= had any sympathy for him or knew what he was feeling).
I understand how she feels about the loss of her dog.
It is understood that (= Everyone knows and accepts that) you don’t bring food or drinks into the library.

meanings.definition: to believe something is true because you have been told something that causes you to think it:
examples: I understand (that) the show will go on, but with a different cast.
I understood him to say (= I believed that he said) that the trip had been canceled.

meanings.definition: When two people understand one another, they both know what the other means and wants and they have an agreement:
examples: I wanted to make sure that we want the same things, and that we really understand each other.
It would be best to talk in person to make sure we really understand each other.
When we first met, we did not understand each other.
When people spend time together, they often begin to understand one another.
Being able to speak openly is crucial if we want to understand one another.
I thought we understood one another, but I was clearly mistaken.

meanings.definition: to think, especially wrongly, that someone means or something is about a particular thing:
examples: When he said three o'clock, I understood him to mean in the afternoon.
I agree that she was unkind, which is what I understood you to mean.
She talked about food from a cow, and by that I understood her to mean beef, not milk.
When he talked about his house, I understood him to mean the one in London.
She talks about her religious life, by which I understand her to mean her ideas about reincarnation, not her Judaism.
The book was advertised as being about the war, which I understood to mean the Second World War, not the First World War.

meanings.definition: easy to understand:
examples: You have to put the facts into a form that's understandable to everyone.

meanings.definition: You say that something, for example someone's behaviour, is understandable, if you feel that it is usual and not strange or difficult to understand:
examples: Their refusal to cooperate is perfectly/completely understandable, considering the circumstances.

meanings.definition: able to be understood, so that you know what something means:
examples: You’ve got to tell a story to three-year-olds in a way that’s understandable to them.

meanings.definition: If you say that something a person does is understandable, you feel that it is the way most people would behave in that situation:
examples: Her actions are understandable when you consider how badly she was treated.

meanings.definition: in a way that is easy to understand:
examples: She was understandably surprised to see us there.
Understandably, he is reluctant to talk about his medical history.

meanings.definition: If you say that someone is understandably feeling a particular emotion, you mean that most people would feel the same way in that situation:
examples: She was understandably upset when no one returned her call.

meanings.definition: knowledge about a subject, situation, etc. or about how something works:
examples: She doesn't have any understanding of politics/human nature/what it takes to be a good manager.
My understanding of the agreement (= what I think it means) is that they will pay $50,000 over two years.

meanings.definition: a positive relationship between two people or groups in which they feel sympathy for each other:
examples: For peace to exist in the region there needs to be a much improved understanding between all the parties concerned.

meanings.definition: an informal agreement between people:
examples: It took several hours of discussion before they could come to/reach an understanding.

meanings.definition: An understanding person who has the ability to know how other people are feeling, and can forgive them if they do something wrong:
examples: He had expected her to be horrified, but she was actually very understanding.

meanings.definition: something that you have reason to believe:
examples: Ours was a generation brought up with the understanding (= belief) that science meant progress.

meanings.definition: An understanding is also an informal agreement between people:
examples: The two sides have come to/reached an understanding about the sale of the house.

meanings.definition: knowledge of a particular thing:
examples: He doesn’t have any real understanding of mathematics.

meanings.definition: Understanding is also a feeling of kindness and caring based on knowledge, esp. of the causes of behavior:
examples: The values he had in mind were simply family love and understanding.

meanings.definition: sympathetic and caring:
examples: an understanding friend

meanings.definition: an informal agreement:
examples: Taiwan and Hong Kong reached an understanding for a five-year commercial air agreement.

meanings.definition: to describe something in a way that makes it seem less important, serious, bad, etc. than it really is:
examples: She believes the research understates the amount of discrimination women suffer.

meanings.definition: to say that the amount or importance of something is less than it really is:
examples: The company was accused of understating potential side effects of the drug.

meanings.definition: to give an amount as less than it really is:
examples: The company's conservative accounting methods mean that results are actually understated.
understate costs/profits

meanings.definition: to make something seem less serious or important than it really is:

meanings.definition: not trying to attract attention or impress people:
examples: He's very elegant, in an understated way.

meanings.definition: not intended to be obvious:

meanings.definition: a statement that describes something in a way that makes it seem less important, serious, bad, etc. than it really is, or the act of making such statements:
examples: To say that her resignation was a shock would be an understatement - it caused panic.
"It didn't go well? " "That's the understatement of the year/decade/century. It was a disaster."

meanings.definition: a statement that something is much smaller, much less important, or much less serious than it really is:
examples: It's an understatement to say the workers are worried about their futures.

to not use something enough:
examples: Most open spaces in towns and cities are underused.

meanings.definition: the fact of not using something enough, or of something not being used enough:

meanings.definition: the fact of not using something enough, or of something not being used enough:

meanings.definition: to not use something or someone as much as it or they could or should be used:

meanings.definition: not used enough:

meanings.definition: the act of deciding or saying that something is less valuable or important than it really is:

meanings.definition: to consider someone or something as less valuable or important than he, she, or it really is:

meanings.definition: to decide or say that something is less valuable or important than it really is:

meanings.definition: feeling no excitement about or admiration for something or someone:

meanings.definition: not causing someone to feel any excitement or admiration:

meanings.definition: used to describe women's clothing made with a piece of wire under the breasts for extra support:

meanings.definition: not having enough work to do, or not having been given enough work:

If a bank or other organization underwrites an activity, it gives it financial support and takes responsibility for paying any costs if it fails.
If a company underwrites an insurance policy, someone's property, etc., that company has an agreement to pay out money in cases of damage or loss.
to support something that costs money by promising to pay for it, or by promising to pay if necessary to protect others who are risking their money:
examples: The museum show was largely underwritten by a grant from the government of Sweden.

meanings.definition: to give an activity financial support and take responsibility for paying any costs if it fails:

Many businesses have underwritten the event.

meanings.definition: if a company underwrites an insurance policy or someone's property, it agrees to pay out money in cases of damage, loss, etc.:
examples: Why should insurance companies underwrite policies for people moving into areas that have a high probability of wildfires?

meanings.definition: if a financial organization underwrites new shares when they are offered for sale, it agrees to buy any shares that are not sold:

meanings.definition: a person who decides whether a bank should give an activity financial support and take responsibility for paying any costs if it fails:

meanings.definition: a person or company that sells insurance policies (= money that you pay so that your costs will be paid if you have an accident, injury, etc.) :
examples: The insurance underwriters quietly agreed to settle the claim.

meanings.definition: an organization, or someone working for one, that underwrites insurance policies:

meanings.definition: a financial organization, or someone working for one, that underwrites new shares when they are offered for sale:

meanings.definition: impossible to describe, especially because of being extremely good or bad:
examples: I wonder if their dishes come close to the undescribable perfection of France.
There’s quite an undescribable thrill about being up in a balloon.

meanings.definition: that someone has not earned or should not have; that someone does not deserve:
examples: Librarians have an undeserved reputation for timidity.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not right or that someone does not deserve:
examples: No book has been more undeservedly neglected by critics.

meanings.definition: not having earned the right to have something; not deserving something:
examples: They have been shown to be groups undeserving of any respect whatsoever.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not right or that someone does not deserve:
examples: There was the sense that footballers were undeservingly wealthy.
I'd be devastated if they'd ended up in jail undeservingly.

meanings.definition: not officially stated to have a particular character or purpose:

meanings.definition: not wanted, approved of, or popular:

meanings.definition: not wanted or welcomed; disliked:
examples: undesirable body fat

meanings.definition: people whose behaviour or appearance makes them unacceptable in society or at a particular occasion:
examples: There are guards on the door to keep out (the) undesirables.

meanings.definition: not wanted:

meanings.definition: impossible to notice or discover:
examples: The moons of Jupiter are undetectable by the naked eye.

meanings.definition: not noticed or discovered:
examples: The longer lung disease goes undetected and untreated, the greater the risk of complications.

meanings.definition: not able to be measured, counted, or clearly known:
examples: She suffers from an undeterminable and debilitating kind of brain illness.

meanings.definition: not measured, counted, or clearly known:
examples: The park was developed in several phases, at undetermined costs, between 2015 and 2020.
Local residents will be without an emergency water supply for an undetermined length of time.

meanings.definition: still continuing to do something or enthusiastic about doing it despite a bad situation:
examples: After four years of injury problems, Thomas remains undeterred.

(of a place or land) not built on or used for farming
not developed, used, or advanced:

meanings.definition: used to describe countries that are much less developed economically than most others, with very little industry, and with little money spent on education, health care, etc.:

meanings.definition: undeveloped areas are not used for farming or industry, or do not have any buildings on them:

meanings.definition: An undiagnosable illness or condition is impossible to diagnose (= recognize and say exactly what it is):
examples: It was highly improbable for two or more children to die in infancy of undiagnosable natural causes.

meanings.definition: An undiagnosed illness or medical condition has not been diagnosed (= recognized and named after examination):

meanings.definition: an undiagnosed person has an illness or condition that has not been diagnosed (= recognized and named after examination):

meanings.definition: not considering or discussing opposite theories in order to discover what is true:

meanings.definition: (of food or parts of food) not able to be changed in your stomach into substances that your body can use:

meanings.definition: making you look silly and lose people's respect, especially because of not being controlled, serious, or calm:

meanings.definition: If a liquid is undiluted it has not been mixed with water to make it less strong.

as good, strong, or important as always:
examples: A hundred years after his death, his influence remains undiminished.

meanings.definition: staying strong without becoming less:

examples: This was an unprecedented use of undiplomatic language by the veteran diplomat.

meanings.definition: acting in a way that might cause people to be upset, hurt, or annoyed :
examples: Nobody can accuse this book of being undiplomatic; the author is unfailingly kind.

meanings.definition: in a way that might cause people to be upset, hurt, or annoyed:
examples: The playwright undiplomatically upset the cast with his harsh comments after the first performance.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not typical of or suitable for diplomats (= officials whose job is to represent their country in another country, and who usually work in an embassy):
examples: He risked damaging the country's trading ties with Europe by issuing an undiplomatically blunt message.

meanings.definition: not involving, or not having been given, rules or instructions about what to do or say:
examples: The children spend most of their time in undirected play.

meanings.definition: not having a clear purpose, or not intending to achieve a particular thing:
examples: Try not to ask the witness undirected or irrelevant questions.

meanings.definition: If a debt is undischarged, it has not been paid back completely:

meanings.definition: If a gun is undischarged, it has not yet been fired:

meanings.definition: If an emotion is undischarged, it has not been expressed or released:

meanings.definition: If something you must do is undischarged, it has not been done. :
examples: She had an uneasy sense of undischarged responsibility.

meanings.definition: someone who is legally bankrupt but who still has to pay back particular debts and cannot borrow again without telling financial organizations considering a loan that they are bankrupt:

meanings.definition: not behaving in a very controlled or organized way:

meanings.definition: If official information is undisclosed, it is secret:

meanings.definition: not announced; kept private:

meanings.definition: undisclosed information has not been made publicly available:

meanings.definition: not having lost your confidence or enthusiasm for something:

meanings.definition: impossible to discover:

meanings.definition: not discovered or known about:

meanings.definition: not talked about:

meanings.definition: An undisguised feeling is clearly shown or expressed, when it is usually kept hidden:
examples: She looked at him with undisguised contempt.

meanings.definition: (of feelings) clearly shown or expressed:

meanings.definition: not feeling unhappy and disappointed:

meanings.definition: not possible to argue about or disagree with; certainly true:

meanings.definition: If something is undisputed, everyone agrees about it:

meanings.definition: about which there is no disagreement:

meanings.definition: not absorbed by a liquid, especially when mixed:

meanings.definition: not especially respected or admired:

meanings.definition: not false or wrong:

meanings.definition: not changed in a way that makes something worse than it was before:

examples: If you do a direct digital transfer of an undistorted recording, its maximum volume is determined by the loudest sounds on the tape.

meanings.definition: not pulled into a strange or unnatural shape:
examples: The machine produced a clean, undistorted image which looked like it had come out of a laser printer.
As monitors go, it's excellent, with a clear, undistorted, and flicker-free display.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that has not been changed from its usual or original form:

meanings.definition: able to give your full attention to what you are doing because you are not trying to do something else, or thinking or worrying about something else:
examples: Programmes that allowed parents to work undistracted by family concerns were in great demand.
When he cooks, he likes to be alone and undistracted.

not given out to people, or shared between a number of people:

meanings.definition: used to describe the part of a company's profits that it has kept rather than paid to shareholders:

meanings.definition: not interrupted or changed in any way:

meanings.definition: existing as a whole, not in separate parts
existing as a whole, not in separate parts:

meanings.definition: existing as a whole, not in separate parts:

meanings.definition: to unfasten something that is fastened or tied:

meanings.definition: to remove the good or bad effects of an action or several actions:

meanings.definition: to unfasten something that is closed or tied:
examples: He undid the top button of his shirt and loosened his tie.

meanings.definition: to remove the effects of something that happened earlier:
examples: It’s difficult to undo the damage caused by a father who abandons his child.

meanings.definition: If something is undoable, it cannot be done:

meanings.definition: Something that is undoctored is in its original state or has not changed in order to deceive people:
examples: Before you book your hotel take a look at the website, which shows undoctored photographs of resorts and rooms next to the official version.

meanings.definition: not based on or following fixed beliefs:
examples: This is in many ways a thoroughly undoctrinaire book, filled with clear practical criticism and mature judgement.

meanings.definition: not supported by written proof:

meanings.definition: not having any documents to prove that you are living or working in a country legally:

meanings.definition: not having any documents to prove that someone or something is legal:

meanings.definition: not officially recorded:

meanings.definition: without the official or legal papers that allow someone to work or live somewhere:

an undocumented worker/laborer

meanings.definition: not having or agreeing with fixed beliefs about a subject; not thinking that you are always right and everyone else is wrong:
examples: This fresh, undogmatic, flexible approach freed us from the familiar patterns of thinking and feeling that we had grown up with.

meanings.definition: the cause of someone's failure, or of someone's loss of power or money:

meanings.definition: the cause of a person’s failure or loss of power or wealth:

meanings.definition: not able or willing to do cleaning, cooking, and other jobs in the home, and to take care of children:

meanings.definition: (of an animal) not brought under human control in order to provide food, power, or company:

meanings.definition: unfastened:

meanings.definition: Something that is undoubtable is definitely true or definitely exists:

meanings.definition: used to emphasize that something is true:

meanings.definition: used to emphasize that something is true:
examples: She was undoubtedly the best candidate.

meanings.definition: very likely; almost certainly:
examples: It is undoubtedly one of the best movies of the year.

meanings.definition: certain and not showing any feelings of doubt:
examples: He was often doubtful about himself but always undoubting about the truth.

meanings.definition: without the liquid having been removed or allowed to flow away:
examples: Well into modern times the major wetlands of England remained undrained.

meanings.definition: not described, shown, or performed as part of a book, play, film, etc.:
examples: The book leaves key situations undramatised, so relationships seem confusing, though in the end they become more or less clear.

meanings.definition: An undramatized narrator is someone who tells the story in a book without appearing as a character in it:
examples: The undramatised narrator is someone who, on the surface, is difficult to distinguish from the author.

meanings.definition: Undreamed of wealth, success, or progress is better or greater than anyone would think possible:

meanings.definition: better or greater than anyone would think possible:

meanings.definition: to remove your clothes or remove the clothes from someone else:

meanings.definition: relating to military clothes worn when not in full dress uniform (= the uniform that is worn on formal occasions):

meanings.definition: to remove your clothes or remove the clothes from someone else:
examples: She undressed quickly and took a shower.

meanings.definition: to look at someone's body with strong, and often unpleasant, sexual desire
with your clothes removed:
examples: The kids got undressed and ready for bed.
The doorbell rang when I was half undressed.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         undress
to remove your clothes or remove the clothes from someone else:
examples: Could you undress the kids for bed, Steve?
He undressed and got into the shower.

meanings.definition: If an object or material is undrilled, holes have not been made in it using a special tool:
examples: All panels came oversized and undrilled.
Hold the undrilled moulding in a vice, and apply glue to the cut edge.

meanings.definition: If an area of land is undrilled, holes have not been dug in it from which to remove oil:
examples: He crossed the border to Tennessee in the 1990s, intrigued by its expanses of undrilled land.

meanings.definition: If a film or television programme is undubbed, the sounds and speech on it have not been changed, especially to a different language:
examples: The song is undubbed and the sound quality is fantastic.
For undubbed versions with French subtitles, look out for the letters VO (version originale) in listings or posters.

meanings.definition: to a level that is more than is necessary, acceptable, or reasonable:
examples: Such a high increase will impose an undue burden on the local tax payer.

meanings.definition: more than is necessary, acceptable, or reasonable:
examples: The court said the state law placed an undue burden on working mothers.

meanings.definition: more than is acceptable or necessary:
examples: Another rise in interest rates so soon would risk spreading undue alarm among businesses and consumers.
A council member said the package was the best deal the city could offer the company without putting undue strain on the city's finances.
Opponents have argued that the bill is an undue burden on business.

meanings.definition: a situation in which someone uses their power or authority in an unfair way in order to influence a legal decision, a decision about who gets a contract, etc.:
examples: Government officials denied there had been any undue influence in the award of the renewal contract.
The President has been criticized for exercising undue influence over the judiciary and parliament.

meanings.definition: to have a continuous up and down shape or movement, like waves on the sea:
examples: The road undulates for five miles before a steep climb.
the undulating countryside

meanings.definition: a continuous up and down shape or movement, like waves on the sea:
examples: The fields rise and fall in gentle undulations.

meanings.definition: If an emotion or feeling is undulled you still feel it as strongly as before:
examples: Anger at fuel prices up to 10p per litre more than in the South remains undulled.

meanings.definition: If an object or someone's eyes are undulled, it is or they are still bright. :
examples: Her eyes were bright and alert, undulled by circumstance, and clearly untouched by the monotony of daily life.

meanings.definition: more than is necessary, acceptable, or reasonable:
examples: There's no need to be unduly pessimistic about the situation.
He believes this approach would unduly harm the nation's economy.

meanings.definition: Something that is unduplicated has not been done or experienced by anyone or anything else:
examples: The improvement in performance was unduplicated by any school in Scotland.
At its core, the event is about creating unduplicated experiences.

meanings.definition: only counted once:
examples: The unduplicated head count takes into account students who may be enrolled in classes on multiple campuses.
These sites have an unduplicated audience of more than 140 million unique visitors.

meanings.definition: natural, without the colour having been changed using a special liquid:
examples: Like her undyed hair, there's something very honest and exposed about her music.
She began a business importing the natural, undyed wool carpets of Tunisia.

meanings.definition: Undying feelings or beliefs are permanent and never end:
examples: He pledged undying love/loyalty.

meanings.definition: (of a feeling or a belief) permanent; without end:
examples: undying love

meanings.definition: without energy, force, or new ideas:
examples: In the end, the album just has nothing to recommend it - it's repetitive, boring and hopelessly undynamic.

meanings.definition: not changing or developing:
examples: It is recognized as one of the most undynamic economies of the world.

meanings.definition: not eager to do or have something:
examples: Most local residents are very uneager to have the area sold to developers.
She stood patiently waiting for her turn with a calm, uneager face.

meanings.definition: Unearmarked money is not kept or intended for a particular purpose:
examples: She called a meeting to discuss allocation of unearmarked funds.
It is unlikely that the university could raise the estimated £2.5 billion of unearmarked endowment needed to make up for present government funding.

meanings.definition: earned or obtained without having been worked for:
examples: unearned income

meanings.definition: money that you get from investments and property that you own, instead of earning by working
income that comes from investment in shares, bonds, etc. rather than from a salary or the sale of goods, etc.:
examples: The company could lose as much as £15m in unearned income.

meanings.definition: in baseball, a run (= point) that is scored after the opponents have made a mistake when trying to catch, stop, or throw the ball:
examples: A throwing error resulted in two unearned runs for the visitors.
The first baseman dropped the ball, allowing an unearned run to score.

meanings.definition: to discover something in the ground:
examples: Building at the site was halted after human remains were unearthed earlier this month.

meanings.definition: to discover proof or some other information, especially after careful searching:
examples: A private detective has unearthed some fresh evidence.

meanings.definition: to find something by digging in the ground:
examples: Artifacts more than 500 years old have been unearthed at the site.

meanings.definition: to discover proof or other information, often after careful searching:
examples: Two amateur historians unearthed 570 documents with Mr. Lincoln’s signature by sifting through the files of the national archives.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         unearth
to discover something in the ground:
examples: Building at the site was halted after human remains were unearthed earlier this month.

meanings.definition: to discover proof or some other information, especially after careful searching:
examples: A private detective has unearthed some fresh evidence.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         unearth
to discover something in the ground:
examples: Building at the site was halted after human remains were unearthed earlier this month.

meanings.definition: to discover proof or some other information, especially after careful searching:
examples: A private detective has unearthed some fresh evidence.

meanings.definition: An unearthly time is not at all convenient because it is too early in the morning or too late at night:
examples: I was woken up at some unearthly hour of the morning by someone knocking on my door.

meanings.definition: strange in a mysterious and sometimes frightening way:
examples: Cats' cries have an unearthly quality.

meanings.definition: strange and mysterious, and sometimes frightening:
examples: The streetlights cast an unearthly glow in the thick fog.

meanings.definition: infml If something happens at an unearthly hour, it happens at an unusual and unreasonable time:
examples: I was awakened at some unearthly hour by a telephone call from Australia.

meanings.definition: a feeling of being worried about something:
examples: The security lapses have caused widespread unease amongst air passengers.
Polls show an unease over the depth of the government cuts.
Yesterday's decision highlights an increasing unease among client companies at the broadening activities of investment banks.
He acknowledged that merger talks have created some uneasiness among employees.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows you are slightly worried or uncomfortable about a particular situation:
examples: He looked around uneasily.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not fit well or seems awkward or unlikely:
examples: The two religions have coexisted uneasily for some time.
His defense of USintentions sits uneasily with other things he says.

meanings.definition: worry or anxiety:
examples: Growing unease at the prospect of an election is causing fierce arguments within the party.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         unease
slightly worried or uncomfortable about a particular situation:
examples: I feel a little uneasy about asking her to do me such a big favour.

meanings.definition: used to describe a situation or condition that makes people slightly worried, often because it may not continue successfully:
examples: Who can predict how long this uneasy peace between the two countries will last?
She has a slightly uneasy relationship with her mother-in-law.

meanings.definition: uncomfortable or anxious:
examples: If you travel, you know that uneasy feeling you get when you arrive in a strange city and don’t have a hotel reservation.

meanings.definition: not suitable or good enough to eat:
examples: She did not tell me about the cold, or the unkind teachers or that the food was often burnt and uneatable.
We all complained bitterly about the uneatable breakfast.

meanings.definition: not eaten:
examples: Steve put his uneaten sandwich down on the table.
Think about the amount of food left uneaten every night by every household in the country.

meanings.definition: not good for the environment or for the relationships between the air, land, water, animals, plants, etc.:
examples: His speech discussed the unecological nature of many modern building techniques and the use of unhealthy chemicals, plastics, and solvents.
She urged alternatives to unecological dairy cattle farming.

meanings.definition: Uneconomic businesses and industries are not making enough profit or are losing money:
examples: They closed the factory, saying it was uneconomic.
The price of oil dropped so low that it became uneconomic to drill.

meanings.definition: Uneconomic processes or activities use more of something than is necessary, causing it to be wasted:
examples: A large room sometimes represents an uneconomic use of space.

meanings.definition: not making a profit:
examples: It is uneconomic for banks to offer wealth management services to those with funds of less than $50,000.
The low-cost airline went into receivership after failing to stem losses from uneconomic routes.
They had dropped the price to an uneconomic level.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         uneconomical
using too much money or too many resources and unlikely to make a profit:
examples: Ethanol producers are seeing their profit margins squeezed and production may well become uneconomical.
With oil prices high, companies have been returning to reserves that were uneconomical to extract during the years of low prices.

meanings.definition: unpleasant and causing people to feel no respect:
examples: We were treated to the unedifying spectacle of Congressmen fighting like children.

meanings.definition: not able to be educated or to learn:
examples: She quickly recognized that her pupils - many of whom were written off as uneducable - needed the self-confidence given by work.
Young people are getting these qualifications who, a generation ago, would have been termed uneducable.

meanings.definition: having received little or no education
having received little education
not containing a lot of careful detail or many detailed parts:
examples: The school was built of brick and glass in the functional and unelaborate manner of the early 1970s.
The continental buffet breakfast - hot croissants, fruit, yogurt and cereals - is unelaborate but appealing.

meanings.definition: (of a person or a political party) not likely to be chosen by the people that are voting in an election:
examples: If he knew the area better, he would realize that he's completely unelectable.
His leadership will make the party unelectable for decades.

meanings.definition: not having been voted into a particular important job or position:
examples: unelected bureaucrats

meanings.definition: not connected to an electrical supply or not operated using electricity:
examples: Many of the remaining unelectrified households are in remote, rural areas.
Modern diesel trains are still a good choice for most unelectrified routes.

meanings.definition: not feeling ashamed or shy:
examples: She seemed entirely unembarrassed by the long silence.
He is surprisingly unembarrassed about his wealth and power.
He praised their unembarrassed patriotism.

meanings.definition: plain and not decorated or added to:
examples: The glass bowls were simple, unembellished by anything except the light.
The bags were made from cheap, unembellished paper.

meanings.definition: If a story, fact, or way of writing is unembellished, it does not have any details added to make it more interesting or exciting:
examples: He writes just the plain, unembellished truth.
These people's stories are told candidly and unembellished.

meanings.definition: not angry, even though unfair or unpleasant things have happened to you:
examples: She emerged from her experience unembittered.
Although he lost his seat in the election, he remains unembittered.

meanings.definition: not having or expressing strong feelings, often when this is surprising or a bad thing:
examples: Investigators said the couple seemed oddly unemotional about the disappearance.
They described him as cold and unemotional.

meanings.definition: not allowing strong feelings to influence your decisions:
examples: He was rational and unemotional in his response.

meanings.definition: not strong, clear, or definite:
examples: He dedicated his life to his work, where he had an unemphatic but important impact.
We followed the river until it trickled to an unemphatic end near the sea.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not strong, clear, or definite:
examples: "I like it," he said, unemphatically.
The piece begins with a unemphatically lovely string section.

meanings.definition: based on theory, rather than on what is experienced or seen:
examples: Their position is unempirical and anti-scientific.
So far, the subject has only been studied in a relatively unempirical manner.

meanings.definition: someone who is unemployable does not have the qualifications or skills needed to do any kind of job:
examples: Increasing numbers of young people are considered to be unemployable because they haven't mastered basic high-school skills.

meanings.definition: not having a job that provides money:
examples: He's been unemployed for over a year.

meanings.definition: people who do not have a job that provides money:
examples: There are now over four million unemployed in this country.
Our department provides services for the unemployed.

meanings.definition: not having a job that provides money:
examples: an unemployed actor

meanings.definition: someone who is unemployed does not have a job:
examples: Only 2.3% of the survey sample were unemployed and seeking work.
Unemployment figures include only those who are officially registered as unemployed.
The portion of the jobless who had been unemployed for more than six months was 21.6% in June, not much changed from June last year.
We should be focussing more efforts on labour-market issues such as getting unemployed people back to work.

meanings.definition: people who do not have jobs, considered as a group:
examples: Government programs for the unemployed will place new emphasis on training, education, and relocation assistance.
According to Labor Department statistics, nearly a half million people joined the ranks of the unemployed in November.

meanings.definition: the number of people who do not have a job that provides money:
examples: Unemployment has fallen/risen again for the third consecutive month.

meanings.definition: the state of being unemployed

→ 
        
         unemployment benefit
the situation of not having a job that provides money, or the number of people in this situation at any time:
examples: high/low unemployment
The unemployment rate was 4 percent in October.

meanings.definition: the number or percentage of people in a country or area who do not have jobs:
examples: In the hardest hit areas, unemployment stands at around 14%.
Youth unemployment among those between 16 and 19 remains high.
The Office for National Statistics said the "claimant count" measure of unemployment dropped by 5,500 last month.
an area of low/high unemployment
unemployment figures/levels/statistics
widespread/rising/growing unemployment
In Arkansas, the state's unemployment rose from 4.1% in December to 4.3% in January.
Unemployment is dropping fastest in the north of the country.
Unofficial estimates put the level of unemployment in the region at around 10%.
Further increases in unemployment are expected.
Helping people out of poverty involves ensuring they have the right skills to compete in the labour market, as well as tackling unemployment.
Fed forecasts are that unemployment will remain low at about 4.75%.

meanings.definition: a situation in which someone does not have a job:
examples: Fear of unemployment is driving homeowners to trade down as a safety measure against the chance of tough times ahead.
Periods of unemployment are an inevitable feature of modern working life.
Welfare discrimination plunges thousands of young people into a cycle of homelessness, unemployment and poverty.

meanings.definition: money that the government pays regularly to unemployed people who are looking for jobs:
examples: If your contract is terminated, insist that your bosses give you a letter confirming that you can claim unemployment.

meanings.definition: money that the government pays to unemployed people who are looking for a job
money that the government pays regularly to unemployed people who are looking for a job. The term "unemployment benefit" was officially replaced in the UK by "Jobseeker's Allowance" in 1996:
examples: Some people consider that generous unemployment benefits have harmed the UK economy.
Figures showed that 50,000 people in the region were on unemployment benefit.
The number of people claiming unemployment benefit fell last week by 1,500 to 2.18 million.
A Labour Department report said people collecting unemployment benefits rose to the highest level in 18 months.

meanings.definition: money that the government pays to unemployed people who are looking for a job
payments made by a government to a person who has lost his or her job
in the US, an official request made by someone who has lost their job for money from the government:
examples: The report found that new unemployment claims fell by 7,000.
first-time/initial/weekly unemployment claims
Last week, 339,000 people filed unemployment claims in the United States.

meanings.definition: in the US, money that is paid by the government every week to unemployed people who lose their jobs and are trying to find work. Unemployment compensation is financed by taxes paid by employers:
examples: About 4,000 to 5,000 jobless Arizonans have been first-time filing for unemployment compensation each week.
Under federal regulations, undocumented workers aren't eligible for unemployment insurance.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         unemployment compensation
a type of insurance policy (= contract) that people pay into, so that they can receive money if they lose their job:
examples: We offer competitive rates for unemployment insurance cover.

meanings.definition: used to refer to the number of unemployed people in a particular place at a particular time:
examples: Locally, traditional winter cuts in seasonal jobs lengthened the unemployment lines.

meanings.definition: the number or percentage of people in a country or area who do not have jobs:
examples: Britain's unemployment rate inched up last month amid weakening job growth.
Across Tennessee, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose from 4.1% in March to 4.3% in April.
a 1.5%/5.7%/10%, etc. unemployment rate
The unemployment rate is forecast to rise to 6.1% over the next 12 months.
Germany's unemployment rate fell to 11.2% in December, from 11.4% in November.
The unemployment rate held steady at a low 4.5%.

meanings.definition: If someone is unenchanted by something, they do not like it:
examples: There was a large group of people who remained unenchanted by his vision of the future.
The ordinary reader may be both puzzled and unenchanted by this book.

meanings.definition: not exciting or special in any way:
examples: He was living an unenchanted life in the suburbs.

meanings.definition: not affected by magic:
examples: At the end of the ballet, the world returns to its unenchanted state.

meanings.definition: not surrounded by walls, objects, or structures:
examples: Almost all of the unenclosed moorland here is open to walkers.
At the front of the house is an unenclosed cement platform we call "the porch".

meanings.definition: not giving you more confidence or hope:
examples: Children from families with unencouraging parents often lack confidence in school.
This way of recycling bottles has been tried before, with unencouraging results.

meanings.definition: without something making it difficult for you to do something:
examples: People can decide how to care for their children, unencumbered by interference from the state.

meanings.definition: difficult to like:
examples: It is hard to find much to love about this cold and unendearing film.
He is good at his work but is unendearing and unpleasant to work with.

meanings.definition: used to describe activities or events, especially unpleasant ones, when they seem to continue for ever:
examples: Motherhood seemed to her an unending cycle of cooking, washing, and cleaning.

meanings.definition: without limit or end:
examples: He seemed to have an unending supply of stories.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not stop, or seems to have no end:
examples: I do not have the patience that I once had to listen to people talk unendingly about their illnesses.

meanings.definition: extremely:
examples: It is unendingly sad you have lost your child in such a cruel way.

meanings.definition: If a situation or experience is unendurable, it is so unpleasant or painful that it is almost impossible to bear:
examples: unendurable pain/suspense

meanings.definition: the quality of being too unpleasant or painful to bear:
examples: Things have to reach the point of unendurableness before people will ask for help.
He became convinced of the utter unendurableness of his situation.

meanings.definition: in a way that is so unpleasant or painful that it is almost impossible to bear:
examples: It was an unendurably sad and painful journey.
She found the routine of home life unendurably boring.

meanings.definition: If a rule or law is unenforceable, it is impossible to force people to obey it.
an unenforceable law or system cannot be accepted as legal in a court of law:
examples: Sections of the amendment are unenforceable under federal law.

meanings.definition: that people cannot be made to obey, or that cannot be made to work effectively:
examples: The proposed reforms are so complex that they will be virtually unenforceable in practice.

meanings.definition: a contract that cannot be accepted as legal in a court of law because of a condition that is not legal, information that is not correct, etc.
If a law or a rule is unenforced, people are not forced to obey or accept it:
examples: The law has remained largely unenforced for many years.
Labour and environmental laws often go unenforced in some nations.

meanings.definition: not showing understanding or knowledge; not enlightened
not giving you enough information about and understanding of something:
examples: It is the most unenlightening film on the subject of climate change that you could imagine.
The last part of the book is predictable and unenlightening.

meanings.definition: Unenriched soil has not been improved in quality by having something added to it:
examples: The plant does best in light, unenriched soil and in a sunny place.
The plants were planted in enriched and unenriched sites and allowed to grow for one year.

meanings.definition: Unenriched food has no additives (= substances that are added to food to make it healthier):
examples: The bread is made with unenriched flour.
The patient's diet consisted primarily of unenriched grain products.

meanings.definition: If an element is unenriched, the level of a particular isotope (= one form of an atom) in it has not been increased in order to make it more powerful or make it explode more powerfully:
examples: These nuclear reactors use unenriched fuel.
The system uses unenriched uranium, which is inexpensive and safer.

meanings.definition: not good at thinking of and doing new and difficult things, especially things that will make money:
examples: He was lazy and unenterprising, and expected jobs to just fly in through the window.
London can be the loneliest place on earth if you are too shy or too unenterprising to make friends.

meanings.definition: showing little or no enthusiasm:
examples: Josh seemed unenthusiastic about the plan.
He was a talented but unenthusiastic student.
Her unenthusiastic attitude did not help.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows little or no enthusiasm:
examples: She nibbled the toast unenthusiastically.
"I'm sure it will be lovely," she said, unenthusiastically.

meanings.definition: An unenviable duty, choice, or situation is unpleasant or difficult:
examples: I had the unenviable task of cleaning up after the party.
They were left with an unenviable choice - flee with their families over the border, or stay and fight.

meanings.definition: happy with what you have and not wishing you had what another person has:
examples: She is hard-working, patient, and unenvious.
The unenvious teacher was delighted to hear about her student's success.

meanings.definition: different in size, level, amount, etc.:
examples: The slices were unequal in size.

meanings.definition: not treating everyone the same; unfair:
examples: Until women are paid as much as men, they will be competing on unequal terms.
They have an unequal relationship.

meanings.definition: not the same:
examples: The unequal status of parent and child is recognized in law.

meanings.definition: not treating everyone the same; unfair:
examples: In 1954, the Supreme Court declared that racial segregation in the public schools was unequal.

meanings.definition: not divided or given in the same amounts to all the people or organizations in a group, so that some people or organizations have more money, resources, etc. than others:
examples: Pension provision is becoming increasingly unequal, with around a third of the workforce facing inadequate pensions.
The government faces renewed pressure to tackle unequal pay.
Experts say the country has one of the most unequal distributions of wealth in the developing world.

meanings.definition: unfair in a way that is harmful or dishonest:
examples: A new study by the Law Society indicated that unequal treatment for women solicitors was still continuing.
According to a recent survey, Britain is the most unequal society in western Europe.

meanings.definition: used to describe a situation in which a person or organization cannot succeed, for example, because the competition is too strong:
examples: Food prices are increasingly dictated by the large supermarkets, and many farmers are giving up the unequal struggle and leaving the land.

meanings.definition: better or more extreme than any other:
examples: Though small, this restaurant offers a range of fish dishes unequaled anywhere else in Miami.

meanings.definition: better or more extreme than any other:
examples: Though small, this restaurant offers a range of fish dishes unequalled anywhere else in London.

meanings.definition: unfairly and not in the same way:
examples: Many women felt they had been treated unequally at work.

meanings.definition: not in equal amounts:
examples: The money was unequally divided between two separate establishments.

meanings.definition: total, or expressed in a clear and certain way:
examples: The prime minister, he said, had the party's unequivocal support.
The church has been unequivocal in its condemnation of the violence.

meanings.definition: clear and firm:
examples: The answer is an unequivocal “Yes.”

meanings.definition: in a way that is total, or expressed very clearly with no doubt:
examples: She unequivocally denied the allegations.
He unequivocally ruled out the possibility of military intervention.

meanings.definition: not causing sexual feelings or pleasure:
examples: The paintings are on such a scale that they are entirely unerotic.
The story is awkward and wholly unerotic.

meanings.definition: never failing to hit a target
always accurate in your judgment or ability:
examples: He has an unerring talent for writing catchy melodies.

meanings.definition: always right; never wrong:
examples: She brings an unerring sense of timing to the role.

meanings.definition: in a way that hits a target without failing:
examples: The ball went unerringly into the hole.
He stands on the training ground, pinging shots unerringly past the poor young goalkeepers.

meanings.definition: in a way that is always accurate or good, never failing or making a mistake:
examples: The writing is razor-sharp and unerringly intelligent.
The standard of music is unerringly high.

meanings.definition: If a fact or situation is unescapable, it cannot be ignored or avoided:
examples: These are the unescapable consequences of delaying a decision.
The price impact of changing the policy is unescapable.

meanings.definition: If a place is unescapable, it is impossible to escape from it:
examples: They somehow managed to escape from the unescapable castle.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization: a department of the United Nations that aims to encourage peace between countries through education, science, and culture
not having anyone with you when you go somewhere, especially someone in authority:
examples: Any person requiring unescorted access to the port needs to obtain a security pass.
The prisoner was given permission to travel unescorted.

meanings.definition: not yet accepted or respected because of having existed for only a short period of time:
examples: The effectiveness of the treatment is still unestablished.
The unestablished claim that the president and the prime minister are brothers is mentioned as a fact.

meanings.definition: If someone is unestablished, they are not yet known for doing a job well, because they have only been doing it for a short time:
examples: The prize is given to new or unestablished figures in the industry.
They employ young actors, unestablished in their careers.

meanings.definition: not ethical (= based on moral beliefs)
not morally acceptable:
examples: unethical business practices

meanings.definition: morally wrong:
examples: The Financial Services Authority's probe into unethical and illegal trading is focussing on the top 20 fund managers of unit trust companies.
unethical behaviour/conduct/practices
What is considered unethical in one country may be standard business practice in another.

meanings.definition: not checked or examined for quality, importance, amount, value, etc.:
examples: The impacts of the research remain largely unevaluated.
The team is assessing risks at thousands of unevaluated sites.

meanings.definition: not level, equal, flat, or continuous:
examples: Be careful on that path - the paving stones are uneven.
There is an uneven distribution of wealth across the country from the north to the south.
The contest was very uneven - the other team was much stronger than us.

meanings.definition: different in quality; often used to avoid saying bad:
examples: Your work has been a little uneven this term, Matthew.

meanings.definition: not even :
examples: The contest was uneven because one team was much stronger than the other.

meanings.definition: not even :
examples: an uneven surface

meanings.definition: varying in quality; not always good:
examples: It’s an uneven movie, but some of the scenes are hilariously funny.

meanings.definition: not following a regular or steady pattern, or not the same in every part:
examples: The regional impact of the fall in house prices is uneven, with modest declines predicted in the south-east, while values are set to fall much more sharply in the south-west.
Politicians should be trying to tackle issues of economic fairness, such as the uneven distribution of benefits in the global financial system.
uneven progress/recovery/expansion

meanings.definition: two horizontal bars of different height that are used in an event in women's gymnastics, or the event itself
in a way that is not level, equal, flat, or continuous:
examples: The two boxers were unevenly matched.
The main problem with regular backpacks is that the weight is unevenly distributed.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not always of a good quality:
examples: The team played unevenly for the first two months of the season.
They play well and sing unevenly.

meanings.definition: the quality or fact of not being level, equal, flat, or continuous:
examples: This calculation illustrates the general unevenness of the distribution of family responsibilities.
The tops of these walls are perfectly horizontal and without regard to the unevenness of the earth's surface.

meanings.definition: the fact of not always being of the same high quality:
examples: This brutal schedule accounts for the frustrating unevenness of the musical performances.
The production is gripping, but it suffers from unevenness of tone.

meanings.definition: An uneventful time or situation is one in which nothing interesting or surprising happens:
examples: It was an uneventful journey.

meanings.definition: without any unusual events:
examples: The flight to Europe was uneventful.

meanings.definition: in a way that is uneventful (= where nothing interesting happens):
examples: The weekend passed rather uneventfully.
The flight took off uneventfully at 8.00 a.m.

meanings.definition: not examined or checked:
examples: These matters have been left unexamined for many years.
Baggage on most domestic flights still goes unexamined.

meanings.definition: better than anyone or anything else:
examples: The engine was unexcelled for reliability and efficiency.
He is a politician with an unexcelled ability to detect the mood of the general public.

meanings.definition: not bad; having nothing that anyone could criticize or disapprove of:
examples: an unexceptionable speech

meanings.definition: ordinary, not exceptional:
examples: He was a hard-working, if unexceptional, student.

meanings.definition: calm and not easily made excited, angry, etc.:
examples: The country's unexcitable prime minister is a man who never seems to get angry.
The pigs were tame and unexcitable.

meanings.definition: not excited or enthusiastic:
examples: He sounds profoundly unexcited at the prospect of winning an award.
The audience were in a calm and unexcited state.

meanings.definition: (of an atom, etc.) in a normal state of energy:
examples: When an electron reverts from an excited to an unexcited state, it gives out light.

meanings.definition: not exciting:
examples: He found life in the small town unexciting and wanted to travel the world.
The museum has a pleasant but unexciting café.

meanings.definition: Something that is unexcused is not accepted, allowed, or forgiven because a reason, or a good enough reason, has not been given for it:
examples: School officials will contact parents after students have several unexcused absences.
He apologized for his unexcused exit from the match.

meanings.definition: used to describe a financial arrangement such as a share option (= the right to buy or sell shares at a particular price by or on a particular date) that the buyer or seller of the option has not used:
examples: The figure does not include the value of new, unexercised stock options.

meanings.definition: not exotic (= unusual and exciting):
examples: She grew up in a pleasant but distinctly unexotic village near London.
I was disappointed by how unexotic everything looked.

meanings.definition: not expected:
examples: Her resignation was completely unexpected.
How lovely to see you here - this really is an unexpected pleasure!

meanings.definition: not expected; surprising:
examples: What an unexpected treat to meet you here!

meanings.definition: in a way that is not expected:
examples: Their campaign was unexpectedly successful.
She showed up unexpectedly at the match.

meanings.definition: not spent or used:
examples: We are trying to identify projects that the unexpended money could be used for.
Any unexpended funds must be returned and she cannot use them in her next campaign.
The destroyer still had ten unexpended torpedoes.

meanings.definition: If something that lasts for a fixed length of time is unexpired, it has not yet come to an end or stopped being in use:
examples: The senator retired from office, leaving an unexpired term of two years.
The prisoner will now have to go back to prison to serve the unexpired portion of his sentence.

meanings.definition: used to describe an agreement, contract, etc. that has not finished yet:
examples: an unexpired lease
I asked for a refund on the unexpired portion of our insurance but this was refused.

meanings.definition: impossible to explain or understand:
examples: She says that she has seen several unexplainable things in the sky.
Life is full of mystery, and so much that happens is unexplainable.

meanings.definition: Unexplained events, behaviour, etc. are ones for which people do not know or understand the reason:
examples: an unexplained death/noise
He was shot dead earlier this year in unexplained circumstances.

meanings.definition: lacking a good explanation:
examples: Experts say the 747 is not noted for problems or unexplained crashes.

meanings.definition: bleeding from the digestive system for which the cause is not known
An unexploded bomb has not exploded:
examples: The army said there were still unexploded bombs throughout the city.
The team clean up unexploded ordnance that the army left behind after the war.

meanings.definition: An unexplored place is one where people have not been to find out what is there:
examples: unexplored territory

meanings.definition: An unexplored plan, idea, or subject is one that has not been examined to find out what it involves:
examples: The subject of alternative medical care for older people has been entirely unexplored.

meanings.definition: covered by something:
examples: Harsh winter weather can leave even unexposed skin dry.
It may not be possible to dredge unexposed portions of the riverbed.

meanings.definition: secret or not known about :
examples: Why was the problem left completely unexposed for so long?
A great song exposes parts of reality that otherwise go unexposed.

meanings.definition: Someone who is unexposed to a disease or infection has not been near anyone who has it, and therefore is unlikely to get it or be affected by it:
examples: People here are relatively unexposed to the disease and have not built up natural immunity against it.
Younger people in the city were unexposed to the virus, due to improvements in sanitation.

meanings.definition: Unexposed film has not had any light shone onto it when it is in a camera, so there is no picture on it. :
examples: We found an old camera with some unexposed film inside.

meanings.definition: (of feelings or thoughts) not expressed, either in words or actions:
examples: Unexpressed emotions can stop you from recovering, so it may be helpful to talk to someone.
Her hands became twisted with unexpressed anger.
The play focuses on the internal world of unexpressed thoughts and emotions.

meanings.definition: An unexpurgated book, article, film, etc. is complete and contains everything, including parts considered likely to cause offence.
ordinary, and not unusual, special, unexpected, or strange in any way:
examples: Perhaps her very unextraordinary singing is part of the reason people like her.
This is the story of my unextraordinary life.

meanings.definition: If a positive quality of someone's character is unfailing, it shows itself at all times:
examples: unfailing enthusiasm

meanings.definition: (of a positive quality of someone’s character) showing itself at all times:
examples: She was known for her unfailing good humor.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows itself at all times:
examples: She's unfailingly cheerful no matter what the circumstances.
The party unfailingly supports the president.

meanings.definition: not treating people in an equal way, or not morally right:
examples: an unfair system
It's unfair to blame Robert.

meanings.definition: not fair :
examples: It seems unfair to tax you both where you work and where you live.

meanings.definition: not morally right, or not treating people in an equal way:
examples: Businesses argue that the tax idea is unfair because it is based on revenue, rather than profit.
We will not accept unfair treatment of individuals whether it be because of race, sex, age or religion.
Critics of the bill think that new service providers will be given an unfair advantage over cable companies with existing franchise agreements.
unfair competition/practices/subsidies
It is unfair to judge infrastructure services on the basis of return on investment.
It seems unfair that the Scottish and Irish fishing industries should be hardest hit when other EU countries have also contributed to the over-fishing problem.
grossly/really unfair

meanings.definition: a situation in which an employer orders someone to leave their job, when there is not a good reason to do so:
examples: She decided to launch proceedings for unfair dismissal against her former employer.
You may be able to claim for unfair dismissal if your actions were the result of provocation.
After winning a case for unfair dismissal, he went on to become an employment lawyer.

meanings.definition: a situation in which someone who has been unfairly told to leave their job starts legal action against their former employer in order to get money from them:
examples: Her unfair dismissal claim with the Employment Tribunal was rejected, and her appeal to the Employment Appeal Tribunal was unsuccessful.
Two former employees are now bringing an unfair dismissal claim against the company.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not right or does not involve equal treatment:
examples: They claim the police treat minorities unfairly.
She believes she's being unfairly criticized.

meanings.definition: the quality or fact of not treating people in an equal way, or of being morally wrong:
examples: The Act does not really address the fundamental unfairness of the system.
They can recall the lasting resentment caused by a teacher's blatant unfairness.

meanings.definition: having a sexual relationship or experience with a person who is not your husband, wife, or usual sexual partner:
examples: If a man was unfaithful to me I'd leave him no matter what the circumstances.

meanings.definition: not loyal or able to be trusted:
examples: an unfaithful friend

meanings.definition: Unfaithful also means having a physical relationship with a person who is not your husband or wife.
the fact of having a sexual relationship or experience with a person who is not your husband, wife, or usual sexual partner:
examples: His sister accused their father of adultery and unfaithfulness.
Many people discover that their partner's unfaithfulness leaves them feeling deeply betrayed.

meanings.definition: real and not made to look real or valuable in order to deceive people:
examples: These are completely genuine, unfaked photographs.
He uses his acrobatic skills in a series of astonishing, unfaked action sequences.

meanings.definition: (of emotions) honest and sincere:
examples: The actors' emotions feel universal and unfaked.
The song combines unfaked feeling with gentleness.

meanings.definition: never stopping or losing strength; not faltering:
examples: unfaltering commitment/support/belief

meanings.definition: not known to you:
examples: I noticed several unfamiliar faces in the meeting room.
His name was unfamiliar to me.

meanings.definition: not previously experienced or known:
examples: I’m unfamiliar with that word – what does it mean?

meanings.definition: not famous or known by many people:
examples: It's an unfamous play by a very famous playwright.
I was unfamous for a very long time before I became successful.

meanings.definition: plain and ordinary, rather than decorative, complicated, or expensive:
examples: I prefer traditional, unfancy dishes.
It's a busy but unfancy restaurant that serves excellent food.
The hotel has fine rooms at unfancy prices.

meanings.definition: not modern or popular:
examples: They paid less for the house because it was in an unfashionable part of town.

meanings.definition: to release or open something that is fixed or closed:
examples: I can't unfasten this button/belt.
This blouse unfastens (= can be unfastened) at the back.

meanings.definition: to make looser or take apart something that fastens or is fastened:
examples: Cal loosened his tie and unfastened his collar.

meanings.definition: not giving much attention to small details or not needing everything to be correct, perfect, or clean:
examples: He has always been surprisingly unfastidious about his business arrangements.
The house is in need of decoration, but the unfastidious (= unfastidious people) could live there safely.

meanings.definition: impossible to understand:
examples: For some unfathomable reason they built the toilet next to the kitchen.

meanings.definition: in a way that is impossible to understand:
examples: We are just a speck in an unfathomably large universe.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         unfavourable
having or showing a negative opinion:
examples: The play received generally unfavorable reviews.

meanings.definition: not tending to help; not likely to lead to a positive result:
examples: Unfavorable weather conditions this morning caused a postponement of the launch of the space shuttle.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not give you an advantage or a good chance of success:
examples: The salaries compare unfavorably to other fields of work.
It was only a small country, unfavorably situated, with an indifferent soil.

meanings.definition: in a negative way that shows that you do not like something:
examples: You might look at her home routine and compare it very unfavorably with my busy job in the city.
I will look unfavorably at people who can't be bothered to turn up to practice.

meanings.definition: not giving you an advantage or a good chance of success:
examples: Current conditions are very unfavourable for new businesses.
We have to be prepared for an unfavourable outcome.

meanings.definition: negative and showing that you do not like something:
examples: He always talks about her in an unfavourable way.
Of those surveyed, 62 percent said they had an unfavourable opinion of the president.
The film has had unfavourable reviews.

meanings.definition: not good, and likely to cause problems or prevent success:
examples: Other countries may lure private equity executives offshore if the tax regime in Britain became unfavourable.
unfavourable conditions/terms
unfavourable prices/exchange rates

meanings.definition: showing that someone does not like something or disapproves of it:
examples: The company has attracted unfavourable comparisons with its rivals.

an unfavourable report/review
