meanings.definition: not surprised or worried:
examples: She seems unfazed by her sudden success and fame.

meanings.definition: not feasible (= able to be done or achieved)
in a way that is not feasible (= able to be done or achieved):
examples: There was a blonde woman with an unfeasibly large amount of luggage.
The closure of the tunnel has made the return journey unfeasibly long.

meanings.definition: not having been given food to eat:
examples: There are claims that elderly patients are routinely left unfed and lying in filthy sheets.
The unfed troops resorted to looting and terror.

meanings.definition: not feeling sympathy for other people's suffering:
examples: She accused me of being unfeeling because I didn't cry at the end of the film.

meanings.definition: not feeling sympathy for other people’s suffering:
examples: an unfeeling man

meanings.definition: not felt, noticed, or experienced:
examples: Many acts of kindness go unnoticed and unfelt.
Most of the earthquakes have been so minor that they went unfelt.

meanings.definition: having characteristics that are not traditionally thought to be typical of or suitable for a woman:
examples: I think many women are afraid of appearing unfeminine.
I'm not interested in the opinions of men who believe that sporty women are unfeminine.

meanings.definition: not surrounded by or having a fence:
examples: The property has a large garden with an unfenced pond.
Most of the border is unfenced and easy to cross.

meanings.definition: If a food or drink is unfermented, it has not gone through fermentation (= a process of chemical change because of the action of yeast or bacteria, which may cause it to produce bubbles or heat, or turn sugars in it into alcohol). :
examples: Unfermented grape juice was mixed with mustard seeds to make mustard.
The drink is a mixture of black fermented tea and unfermented green tea.

meanings.definition: Unfertile land or soil is not good enough for plants or crops to grow well there:
examples: These projects show what we could do on this unfertile soil.
The refugees face difficult living conditions on unfertile land.

meanings.definition: An unfertile person, animal, or plant cannot have babies, produce young, or produce new plants:
examples: The procedure has enabled many unfertile couples to have a child.
Research has shown that many of the bulls in the herd are unfertile.

meanings.definition: An unfertilized egg has not joined with a male cell and started developing into a new young animal or plant:
examples: The process uses an unfertilized egg to create new cells.
Because eggs for sale have to be unfertilised, all the male chicks are killed.

meanings.definition: Unfertilized plants or areas of ground have not had natural or chemical substances spread on them in order to make the plants grow well:
examples: The yield from the unfertilized maize was lower.
Weed infestation was highest in the unfertilised fields.

meanings.definition: not limited by rules or any other controlling influence:
examples: Poets are unfettered by the normal rules of sentence structure.

meanings.definition: not controlled, limited, or prevented by anyone:
examples: The law gives the governor unfettered discretion to make these appointments.

meanings.definition: not showing the qualities that are expected of a good daughter or son:
examples: Failing to care for one's elderly parents has been publicly shamed in the village as "unfilial behaviour".

meanings.definition: An unfilled job or position has no one doing or holding it:
examples: McCaffrey's job remains unfilled.
All the hospitals in the area have unfilled positions right now.

meanings.definition: not suitable or able to be filmed:
examples: The director has found a way to film this supposedly unfilmable novel.
The author announced that her book was unfilmable.

meanings.definition: not having had solids removed with a filter:
examples: unfiltered apple juice

meanings.definition: with no information removed:
examples: The radio station provides millions of people with unfiltered news and political debate.

meanings.definition: used for referring to cigarettes or cigars without filters in one end to remove harmful substances
impossible to find:
examples: With her agent carefully guarding her whereabouts, she had made herself virtually unfindable.
Corn syrup, which is used in so many recipes in the States, is unfindable in the UK.

meanings.definition: not ended or completed
not finished or complete:
examples: An unfinished apartment building in North Hollywood caught fire shortly after midnight.

meanings.definition: a matter, especially a disagreement, that is not yet decided or agreed:
examples: I still have some unfinished business with you.
The energy plan is one of the most important pieces of unfinished business we have.
He was returning to Winnipeg in order to take care of some unfinished business there.
She still has some unfinished business to deal with before she can truly move on with her life.
I had some unfinished business with Max.

meanings.definition: An unfired gun or bullet has not been shot:
examples: An inspection found that the rifles were clean and unfired.
Two unfired shotgun shells were found at the crime scene.

meanings.definition: If an object made of clay is unfired, it has not been fired (= heated in a a special oven so that it becomes hard):
examples: If it is left unfired, the clay will slowly crumble.
Unfired materials, such as clay, have been used in building for a long time.

meanings.definition: not suitable or good enough for a particular purpose or activity:
examples: The building was declared unfit for human habitation.

meanings.definition: not healthy because you do too little exercise:
examples: I used to take plenty of exercise, but now I'm terribly unfit.

meanings.definition: lacking the qualities needed or expected for something; not suitable:
examples: The court ruled that she was an unfit mother and ordered that the child be placed in a foster home.

meanings.definition: used to describe a house that is too dirty or dangerous for people to be allowed to live in it:
examples: Some parts of the city were unfit for human habitation.
Inspectors declared that the building was unfit for human habitation.
The damp and lack of sanitation made the dwellings unfit for human habitation.
Someone from the Health Department inspected the house and found it unfit for human habitation.
He still rented out the house, even though it had been deemed unfit for human habitation.

meanings.definition: If a quality, such as energy, interest, or enthusiasm, is unflagging, it never becomes weaker:
examples: He thanked Tony for his unflagging energy and support.

meanings.definition: not liking or trying to be noticed by other people, for example because of the way you talk or dress:
examples: His manner is unflamboyant and modest.
She has a meticulous and unflamboyant political style.

meanings.definition: not likely to get worried, nervous, or angry even in difficult situations:
examples: She's totally unflappable - you have to be when working in such a high-pressure environment.

meanings.definition: not flashy (= intended to get attention and admiration by looking very bright, big, and expensive):
examples: The hotel has an atmosphere of unflashy glamour.

meanings.definition: not flattering, or making someone look less attractive or seem worse than usual:
examples: an unflattering photo/dress/colour
The book portrays her in a very unflattering light.

meanings.definition: not frightened of or not trying to avoid something dangerous or unpleasant:
examples: It is a brave and unflinching account of prison life.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows someone is not frightened or is not trying to avoid something:
examples: The film takes an unflinchingly honest look at an issue that faces us all.
She stared back unflinchingly at him.

meanings.definition: (of an aircraft) not able or suitable to be flown:
examples: If both the main and standby instruments fail, the plane basically becomes unflyable.
It is likely that the fleet will become almost unflyable in a few years.

meanings.definition: (of weather) not suitable for flying in:
examples: The race was delayed by unflyable weather.
The number of unflyable days is now only about one percent of the total.

meanings.definition: not seeing clearly:
examples: Bowman looked up at her, his gaze slightly unfocused.

meanings.definition: not giving a clear image:
examples: The portrait looks more like an unfocused snapshot.

meanings.definition: not having a central subject or aim:
examples: The book is slightly unfocused, as if the author is unsure whether she is writing a romance or a forensic investigation.

meanings.definition: used to describe someone who does not have a particular aim or intention:
examples: There's a part of me that's lazy and unfocused.

meanings.definition: to open or spread out something that has been folded:
examples: He watched her expression as she unfolded the letter.

meanings.definition: If a situation or story unfolds, it develops or becomes clear to other people:
examples: Like a lot of people, I've watched the events of the last few days unfold on TV.

meanings.definition: to tell a story or explain something such as a plan:
examples: Gradually, the author unfolds a fantastical tale.

meanings.definition: (of a situation or story) to develop or become clear:
examples: Events unfolded in a way that no one could have predicted.

meanings.definition: to open or spread out something that has been folded:
examples: She took the old wedding dress out and carefully unfolded it.

unhappy:

done as a result of your own decision, rather than being forced by someone else:

meanings.definition: happening or done without any effort:

meanings.definition: An unforeseeable event or situation is one that cannot be known about or guessed before it happens:
examples: Loss due to unforeseeable circumstances is borne by the purchaser.
These countries were facing a very grave crisis with unforeseeable consequences.

meanings.definition: not expected:
examples: Due to unforeseen circumstances the cost of the improvements has risen by 20 percent.
Unless there are any unforeseen problems the whole project should be finished by the spring.

meanings.definition: unexpected and often unwanted:

meanings.definition: not expected:

unforeseen complications/difficulties/problems

meanings.definition: not covered in forest:
examples: There are 500,000 hectares of unforested land that can be used for this project.

meanings.definition: An unforgettable experience has such a strong effect or influence on you that you cannot forget it.
(of an experience) having such a strong effect or influence on you that you cannot forget it:
examples: One unforgettable morning, we were among the elephants, perfectly situated to watch their descent to the river.

meanings.definition: in a way that has such a strong effect that you cannot forget it:
examples: His descriptions are often unforgettably vivid.
These scenes are unforgettably horrible.

meanings.definition: (of behaviour) too bad to forgive:
examples: The way he spoke to his brother was unforgivable.

meanings.definition: in a way that is too bad to forgive:
examples: You were unforgivably rude.
He has behaved unforgivably!

meanings.definition: not willing to forgive people for things they do wrong:
examples: My wife is unforgiving by nature.

meanings.definition: unpleasant or difficult to deal with:
examples: The unforgiving seas make search and rescue very difficult.

meanings.definition: An unforgiving fabric or item of clothing can make you look fat:
examples: Satin is gorgeous but can be unforgiving and emphasize bulges.

meanings.definition: not forked (= with one end divided into two parts):
examples: A hummingbird's tongue has a forked tip that picks up more nectar than an unforked tongue would.
A few of the trees had main stems that forked, but most had unforked stems.

meanings.definition: An unformulated question, idea, plan, etc. is not yet completely developed:
examples: The questions remained unformulated in his mind.
Many unformulated ideas may influence our experience at the same time.

meanings.definition: unfriendly, unhelpful, and not willing to talk or give information:
examples: She was unforthcoming and claimed she could not remember any of the details.

meanings.definition: (of a place) not protected or made stronger:
examples: It's a large unfortified town in the interior of the country.

meanings.definition: Unfortified food or drink has not had vitamins or minerals (= natural substances that are necessary in small amounts for the growth and good health of the body) added to it:
examples: Unfortified salt was used in the preparation of various common foods.

meanings.definition: Unfortified wine has not had a spirit (= a type of strong alcoholic drink), especially brandy, added to it:
examples: The unfortified table wines from this area are often excellent.

meanings.definition: unlucky or having bad effects:
examples: She has inherited her father's large nose, which is very unfortunate.
It was unfortunate (that) he called at the exact moment when our guests were arriving.

meanings.definition: (of remarks or behaviour) not suitable in a way that could cause embarrassment or offence:
examples: The housing director's comment that "the homeless could do more to help themselves" was unfortunate.

meanings.definition: an unlucky person who is in a bad situation:
examples: He was one of the poor unfortunates who invested in the company and now finds himself a few thousand pounds poorer.

meanings.definition: unlucky or having bad effects:
examples: What happened to Monica was just a freak accident – it was very unfortunate.

meanings.definition: (of remarks or behavior) unsuitable in a way that could cause offense:
examples: It was an unfortunate remark that he later regretted.

meanings.definition: used to say that something is sad, disappointing, or has a bad effect:
examples: Unfortunately, I didn't have my credit card with me, or else I would have bought it.

meanings.definition: Unfossiliferous rock, clay, etc. does not contain fossils (= shapes of bones, shells, plants, or animals that have been preserved in rock for a very long time):
examples: These rocks were believed to be completely unfossiliferous.
This segment includes unfossiliferous sandstones.

meanings.definition: If a claim or piece of news is unfounded, it is not based on fact:
examples: Our fears about the weather proved totally unfounded.

meanings.definition: (of a claim or piece of news) not based on fact; untrue:
examples: unfounded rumors

meanings.definition: (of a picture or mirror) not in a frame:
examples: Prices start at £1,500 for unframed prints.
These beautiful photographs are available both framed and unframed.

meanings.definition: limited or controlled:
examples: The country's press is essentially unfree.
They have accepted an unfree, unfair election because it has given them victory.

meanings.definition: Unfree labour is work that people are forced to do, or the workers who do this work:
examples: Slavery, like other forms of unfree labour, has existed for many centuries.
There was a strong connection between modernisation and rising living standards and the plight of unfree labour in the British West Indian territories.

meanings.definition: a lack of freedom:
examples: There are two problems with unfair imprisonment: injustice and unfreedom.
The liberty of the few is often built upon the unfreedom of the many.

meanings.definition: to stop (something such as pay or prices) being fixed at a particular level and allow them to increase:
examples: About one-third of employers plan to unfreeze salaries.
The company sprang a surprise on its customers by unfreezing its prices.

meanings.definition: to make an economy or market active again, or to become active again, after a period of no activity:
examples: The loan was intended to help unfreeze Iceland's economy.
Unless global credit markets unfreeze and start lending again, there will be a recession.

meanings.definition: to make money available again after it was previously not allowed to be used:
examples: The first initiative is aimed at unfreezing loans for homeowners.
The loan would provide an important first step towards unfreezing the deposits of approximately 300,000 customers who have been unable to withdraw money.

meanings.definition: to end an official and legal rule preventing money or property from being used or moved:
examples: The supreme court cleared him of any wrongdoing and unfroze his assets.
Unless bank accounts are unfrozen, production could be disrupted.

meanings.definition: to raise the temperature of something so that it is no longer frozen, or to become no longer frozen:
examples: He uses his father's blowtorch to unfreeze the pipes.
Spring is the time when the earth unfreezes and life returns to the ground.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         defriend
the quality or fact of being unfriendly:
examples: He was received with suspicion and unfriendliness.
He had shown incompetence, unfriendliness, and an excessive willingness to lead his group into danger.

meanings.definition: showing dislike and no sympathy
having an attitude or acting in a way that shows you do not like people and do not care if they like you:
examples: an unfriendly person

meanings.definition: likely to cause problems or prevent success:
examples: Plastic bags are an unfriendly choice for environmental sustainability.
an unfriendly tax regime
Companies are migrating to the suburbs to avoid governments perceived as unfriendly to business.

meanings.definition: a situation in which one company gets control of another when the owners of that company do not want to sell it:
examples: an unfriendly takeover attempt/bid/offer
Law firms and investment bankers are sometimes employed by a target company to fend off unfriendly takeovers.

meanings.definition: behaving in a way that is serious and not silly:
examples: She has an unfrivolous approach to fame.
She was a charming, sensible girl, and very unfrivolous.

meanings.definition: plain and with no silly or unnecessary features:
examples: She wore flat, sensible, unfrivolous shoes.
The best bike on the track was fast, loud, and totally unfrivolous, a mercilessly effective speed machine.

meanings.definition: An unfrivolous claim is based on fact or good reasons, or relates to something that is important, so that it is worth taking to court because it is likely to succeed:
examples: Occasionally, an unfrivolous claim of citizenship may be tried by a court.
The issue became unfrivolous, so we took it to court.

meanings.definition: not having been frozen, or no longer frozen:
examples: If you have fresh (unfrozen) turkeys available at your market, buy one of those.
Check that your animals always have access to clean, unfrozen water.

meanings.definition: (of money, bank accounts, etc.) available for use again after previously not being allowed or able to be used:
examples: According to records of his assets, only about £200m remains unfrozen.
Her family collected $26 million from unfrozen assets.

meanings.definition: (of pay or prices) no longer fixed at a particular level and allowed to increase:
examples: Salaries are now unfrozen after many years of no pay increases at all.

meanings.definition: not producing any good or valuable result:
examples: The two sides have been involved in lengthy - but so far unfruitful - negotiations.

meanings.definition: not producing fruit or crops:
examples: If allowed to spread too quickly, the vine will end up with a lot of bare, unfruitful wood.
In the new colony the soil was unfruitful and the settlers knew nothing of farming.

meanings.definition: not producing children:
examples: They had both agreed to adopt after two years of unfruitful marriage.

meanings.definition: If something such as a promise or an arrangement is unfulfillable, it is not possible to make it happen:
examples: Their plans are impractical, and their promises are unfulfillable.
His election campaign raised unfulfillable expectations.

meanings.definition: If a wish, hope, promise, etc. is unfulfilled, it has not happened or been achieved:
examples: an unfulfilled ambition/dream

meanings.definition: unhappy because you think you should be achieving more in your life
an unfulfilled order or contract has not been delivered or completed:
examples: Reports of unfulfilled orders indicated that the firm was in trouble.

meanings.definition: not yet achieved or done:
examples: Close associates say his unfulfilled ambition is to see the group in the FTSE 100 index.
The report accused the nuclear industry of making unfulfilled promises.
After years of unfulfilled potential, the $158-million makeover of the museum hopes to capture the imagination of city residents.

meanings.definition: used to describe a financial arrangement that has been agreed but for which there is not enough money available:
examples: The unfunded liability for Social Security's old age and disability funds will be $3 trillion by 2070.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         short-term debt
not funny:
examples: The jokes are painfully unfunny.

meanings.definition: If a flag, sail, or banner unfurls, it becomes open from a rolled position, and if you unfurl a flag, etc., you make it do this:
examples: The demonstrators unfurled a large banner.

meanings.definition: (of a flag, sail, etc.) to become open from a rolled position, or to cause something to become open from a rolled position

past simple and past participle of 
        
         unfurl
If a flag, sail, or banner unfurls, it becomes open from a rolled position, and if you unfurl a flag, etc., you make it do this:
examples: The demonstrators unfurled a large banner.

present participle of

If a flag, sail, or banner unfurls, it becomes open from a rolled position, and if you unfurl a flag, etc., you make it do this:
examples: The demonstrators unfurled a large banner.

meanings.definition: An unfurnished room, house, or other building has no furniture in it:
examples: unfurnished accommodation

meanings.definition: Unfused bones, cells, etc. are not physically joined together:
examples: These mammals had shorter limbs than other carnivores and unfused wrist bones.
The pain is coming from a bone in my back that has become unfused.

meanings.definition: An unfused explosive does not have a fuse (= a string or piece of paper connected to an explosive product by which it is lit, or a device inside a bomb that causes it to explode after a fixed length of time or when it hits or is near something):
examples: Five sticks of unfused dynamite were discovered.
Unfused bombs may remain explosive for many decades.

meanings.definition: awkward and without grace (= moving smoothly and attractively) in movement:
examples: Ducks are ungainly on land.

meanings.definition: awkward in movement
(of a man or his behaviour) rude and unkind, especially towards women, and especially when in public:
examples: They were surprised to hear of his ungallant behaviour.
It would be ungallant of me to say what I really think of them.

meanings.definition: in a way that is ungallant (= rude and unkind, especially towards women, and especially when in public):
examples: Two weeks after they broke up, he announced, ungallantly, that he had never loved her.
"I'd much rather be talking to her than to you," he said ungallantly.

meanings.definition: If food is ungarnished, it is plain and not decorated with a small amount of a different food:
examples: The cheese is left ungarnished or covered with herbs or pepper.
Pancakes may be topped with cream or sugar, or they may be served ungarnished.

meanings.definition: If a building, room, or piece of furniture is ungarnished, it is simple and plain, without much decoration:
examples: The castle has big towers, ungarnished with leaves or plants.
It will take a lot to make this place look nice — it's so plain and ungarnished.

meanings.definition: If a story or piece of information is ungarnished, it is true and does not have any unnecessary details:
examples: The book contains nothing but the plain ungarnished truth about these politicians.
The biography is presented in a straightforward, ungarnished way.

meanings.definition: relating to a company whose capital is all in the form of shares and that has no debt, for example in the form of bonds:
examples: The company's ungeared balance sheet means they could soon be on the look-out for acquisitions.

meanings.definition: not referring to a particular gender and including all genders:
examples: The handbook was rewritten with ungendered language.

meanings.definition: intended or suitable for people of any gender:
examples: They produced an ungendered clothing range for children.

meanings.definition: not having or not being given a gender:
examples: The book's protagonist remains unnamed and ungendered.

meanings.definition: not willing to give money, help, kindness, praise, etc. to other people, or only willing to give a little:
examples: an ungenerous welfare benefits system
It is not being ungenerous to the team to suggest that it, too, has many weak points.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows unwillingness to give money or help:
examples: The Treasury has ungenerously said no to the charity's request.

meanings.definition: in a way that is unkind or unfair, because someone deserves better:
examples: I assumed - perhaps ungenerously - that he did this just for the publicity.

meanings.definition: (of a person) unpleasant and unfriendly:
examples: Her ungenial host made some bitter remarks about her performance.

meanings.definition: (of a place or the weather) unpleasant:
examples: The climate is wet and ungenial, because the mountains are frequently covered in misty clouds.
All of the plants died in the exposed and ungenial location.

meanings.definition: not typical of a high social class:
examples: My mother was a good woman, who came from an ungenteel family.
When the young ladies arrived, their appearance was neither ungenteel nor unfashionable.

meanings.definition: not polite, gentle, or graceful:
examples: He believed that it was very ungenteel to be too curious.
He asked for his money, but said that he did not intend to be ungenteel.

meanings.definition: unkind, and not calm:
examples: He is a gentle man, but he has an ungentle side.
This sort of ungentle conduct is often directed against scientists.

meanings.definition: violent, severe or strong:
examples: He seized her by the arm in an ungentle grip.
He was tall, strong, and ungentle.

meanings.definition: (of a man's behaviour) not polite and not behaving well towards other people:
examples: He was sent off the pitch for ungentlemanly conduct.

meanings.definition: If a place is ungentrified, it has not been changed from being a poor area to a richer one, by people of a higher social class moving to live there:
examples: We lived on a road of ungentrified old houses and flats.
He comes from an ungentrified part of London's East End.

meanings.definition: An ungerminated seed has not yet started growing or developing:
examples: The number of ungerminated seeds was recorded for each species.
The seeds that were under water remained ungerminated until the water level fell.

meanings.definition: lacking special ability or intelligence:
examples: I was a keen but ungifted student.
I have always thought of myself as ungifted.

meanings.definition: not gimmicky (= using something that is not serious or of real value to attract people's attention or interest temporarily, especially to make them buy something):
examples: The food on the menu is seasonal and ungimmicky.
It's an absolutely straight and ungimmicky article.

meanings.definition: If something is unglamorized, it is not made to seem better or more attractive than it really is:
examples: The documentary portrays the average, unglamorized life of a typical American citizen.
This unglamorised insider's view of the sport is what makes the book worth reading.

meanings.definition: not glamorous (= especially attractive and exciting):
examples: unglamorous work/surroundings

meanings.definition: (of a window) not containing glass:
examples: There was a small, unglazed window high up on the wall.
The dry heat and lack of rain mean that you can leave the windows unglazed.

meanings.definition: (of objects made of clay or similar substances) not having a shiny surface made by putting a liquid substance onto the object and leaving it or heating it to dry :
examples: The unglazed tiles are available in various sizes and colours.
The dish is made of unglazed stoneware.

meanings.definition: extreme or unacceptable:
examples: I had to get up at some ungodly hour in the morning to take her to the airport.

meanings.definition: unable to be governed or controlled
moving in a way that is not smooth, relaxed, or attractive, or not having a smooth, attractive shape :
examples: He was described as a large, ungraceful dancer.
I felt old, clumsy and ungraceful.

meanings.definition: behaving in a way that is not polite or pleasant:
examples: He was ungraceful in defeat after he lost the match.
She had an ungraceful and disagreeable manner of speaking.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not smooth, relaxed, or attractive:
examples: He slipped on the tiled floor, and fell ungracefully.
I had to walk ungracefully down three flights of stairs in my high heels.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not polite or pleasant:
examples: He gave in ungracefully when he realised that he could not win.
She declined my invitation rather ungracefully.

meanings.definition: If a piece of work is ungraded, it has not yet been given a grade (= a letter showing how good a piece of work is):
examples: He was carrying a pile of books and ungraded student papers.
The strike is over, but hundreds of exams remain ungraded.

meanings.definition: not separated into different levels of quality, size, importance, etc.:
examples: Ungraded vegetables do not necessarily have a bad taste.
The cotton that they took to the market was ungraded and of poor quality.

meanings.definition: not grammatical
difficult or impossible to understand:
examples: The presenter talked to scientists about facts and ungraspable theories.
The meaning of the text is unfixed and ungraspable.

meanings.definition: not showing or expressing any thanks
not showing or expressing thanks, esp. when it is expected or deserved
whole and not made into small pieces or a powder by being pressed between hard surfaces:
examples: We compared real, unground coffee beans with instant coffee.
This box is ideal for storing unground spices.

meanings.definition: not put into a group, or forming a unit with other things or people:
examples: The elements of the pattern can be ungrouped and moved to create new designs.
Few of the ungrouped candidates have much hope of election.

meanings.definition: not guarded or protected:
examples: You shouldn't leave your bag unguarded like that.

meanings.definition: If you make an unguarded remark or say something in an unguarded moment, you tell someone something that you would usually keep secret, sometimes in a way that shows bad judgment:
examples: In an unguarded moment, I said that I didn't trust Charles.

meanings.definition: a thick substance, usually with a pleasant smell, used to treat skin problems or make the skin soft:
examples: She smelled powerfully of bath salts and unguents.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         unguis   specialized
If something such as an answer or a secret is unguessable, it is not possible to guess it:
examples: Your password should be unguessable.
Some of the features have been included by the designer for some unguessable reason.

meanings.definition: without someone to show you where to go or how to do something:
examples: The visitor centre has details of a range of guided and unguided tours.
No unguided skiers are allowed on the mountain.

meanings.definition: If a bomb or other missile (= flying weapon) is unguided, its direction is not controlled, for example by radio signals, after it has been fired:
examples: Unguided missiles would almost certainly hit civilian areas.
Very few of the unguided bombs hit their target.

meanings.definition: a nail, claw, or hoof of an animal
An unhackneyed phrase or idea has not been said or used so often that it has become boring or without meaning:
examples: The themes in the novel are familiar, but they seem fresh and unhackneyed.
This is a fresh, unhackneyed performance of the concerto.

meanings.definition: without anyone or anything making it difficult for you to do something or for something to happen:
examples: The inspectors were able to work unhampered.
His career has so far gone unhampered by his lack of talent.

meanings.definition: to take your hands off someone:
examples: Unhand me, sir, for shame!

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         unhand
to take your hands off someone:
examples: Unhand me, sir, for shame!

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         unhand
to take your hands off someone:
examples: Unhand me, sir, for shame!

meanings.definition: in a way that shows or involves sadness:
examples: They had been unhappily married for years.
The story ends unhappily.

meanings.definition: the quality of being sad or not satisfied:
examples: There is widespread unhappiness with the government's economic, foreign and trade policies.
She talked about her deep unhappiness and loneliness.

meanings.definition: sad or not satisfied:
examples: That's enough to make anyone unhappy.
an unhappy marriage
I was very unhappy with the service.

meanings.definition: not feeling pleasure or satisfaction:
examples: It was an unhappy time of her life.
They were unhappy about their hotel room (= did not like it) and asked to be moved.

meanings.definition: (of a condition or situation) not lucky:
examples: We found ourselves in the unhappy situation of having had our bags, passports, and money stolen.

meanings.definition: not hurt or damaged:
examples: Both children escaped unharmed from the burning building.

meanings.definition: having an unpleasant tune or harmony (= the sound of different notes being played or sung at the same time):
examples: We all joined in a splendidly unharmonious rendition of Auld Lang Syne.
The listener from the very first minute is stunned by the opera's intentionally unharmonious muddled flow of sounds.

meanings.definition: not friendly and peaceful:
examples: Some leadership techniques can tend to create an unharmonious atmosphere in the office.
Unharmonious protests erupted during the Olympic torch's stops in London, Paris, San Francisco and elsewhere.

meanings.definition: not looking, tasting, or working well together:
examples: These groups have fundamentally different and unharmonious doctrinal beliefs and practices.
Joe suggested planting a tree between the main house and the rental unit to disguise the unharmonious juxtaposition of the two structures.

meanings.definition: to remove a harness (= a piece of equipment with straps and belts, used to control an animal or hold it in place) from a horse or a dog, or to remove a piece of equipment that connects a horse or a dog to a vehicle:
examples: He left the kitchen and went to unharness the horses.
The dogs need to be unharnessed and given some straw to sleep on.

meanings.definition: (of crops) not picked or collected:
examples: At least half of the unharvested crop was damaged by the storm.
Some corn was left in the fields unharvested when the weather changed.

meanings.definition: If an egg is unhatched, it has not broken open or been broken open to allow a young animal to come out:
examples: The nest contained several unhatched eggs.
Most of the eggs remained unhatched.

meanings.definition: If an animal is unhatched, it has not yet come out of its egg:
examples: The purpose of the egg is to provide nutrients to the unhatched chick.
The researchers studied the unhatched crocodiles in their underground nests.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees: an organization that is part of the UN (= the United Nations) and is responsible for protecting and helping refugees (= people who have had to leave their own country to escape war or suffering):
examples: At the beginning of the conflict UNHCR predicted that as many as 1.5 million refugees would stream out of the country.
Dozens of relief agencies have started working in the region under the UNHCR's leadership.

meanings.definition: If a cut or other injury is unhealed, it is not physically better:
examples: She has unhealed wounds to her thumb and two of her fingers.
There is still some risk of unhealed ulcers.

meanings.definition: If a bad situation or a painful emotion is unhealed, it has not improved or ended:
examples: It is an unhealed wound in our country's history.
Her emotional wounds remain unhealed nearly ten years after the accident.

meanings.definition: not good for your health:
examples: Any diet has the potential to be healthful or unhealthful.
Heart disease and cancer may be caused by years of eating unhealthful foods.
Some elements of my lifestyle are unhealthful.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not good for your health:
examples: She is unhealthily thin.
Nowadays, children have become less active and eat unhealthily.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not good for someone or not acceptable because it does not seem normal:
examples: He has become unhealthily obsessed with her.

meanings.definition: not good for your health:
examples: an unhealthy diet
The consequences of an unhealthy lifestyle include a higher risk of diabetes, heart diseases, stroke, and cancer.

meanings.definition: (of a person, animal, or part of the body) not strong or well:
examples: I had smoked for over 20 years and was very unhealthy.

meanings.definition: not good for someone or not acceptable because it does not seem normal:
examples: Parents should be aware if young people develop an unhealthy interest in death and begin to appear depressed.
There are healthy and unhealthy ways to express angry feelings.

meanings.definition: ill or appearing to be ill
harmful to your health:
examples: It’s unhealthy to eat fatty foods all the time.

meanings.definition: surprising or shocking because not known about or previously experienced:
examples: It was unheard-of for an unmarried couple to live together.

meanings.definition: surprising or shocking because not known about or previously experienced:
examples: Price wars have sliced prices to unheard-of lows.

meanings.definition: not made hot or warm:
examples: Move the plants into an unheated greenhouse during the winter months.
The rooms were damp and unheated.

meanings.definition: not surrounded or bordered by a hedge (= a line of bushes or small trees planted very close together, especially along the edge of a garden, field, or road):
examples: The field sloped down to an unhedged road.
The lane dropped into a valley before climbing between two unhedged fields.

meanings.definition: not protected by hedging (= a way of controlling or limiting a loss or risk):
examples: Thousands of small firms are carrying an unhedged exposure to the mortgage market.
He is under investigation for unauthorised use of a computer in connection with unhedged transactions.

meanings.definition: ignored or not listened to:
examples: It is unfortunate that all the doctor's warnings went unheeded.
There were reports of many unheeded warnings and missed opportunities.

meanings.definition: ignoring or not listening to something:
examples: He played music in a station full of unheeding commuters.
Thousands of vehicles a day rush unheeding past the park.

meanings.definition: not improving a difficult situation:
examples: The instructions were badly written and unhelpful.
I don't need any more of your unhelpful advice!

meanings.definition: not wanting to help someone, in a way that seems unfriendly:
examples: The shop assistant was rude and unhelpful.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not help:
examples: Rather unhelpfully, the chapters are not clearly identified on the contents page.
This data unhelpfully groups together millions of elderly people.

meanings.definition: not previously known about or recognized for hard work or great achievements:
examples: In America, the band is largely unheralded and does not have a record deal.
She is a relatively unheralded artist who lives in New York.
Some extraordinary accomplishments have gone unheralded.

meanings.definition: Something that is unheralded is unexpected, or there are no previous signs that it is coming:
examples: Their argument was interrupted by the unheralded arrival of a detective.
Food inspectors sometimes make unheralded visits to restaurant kitchens.

meanings.definition: not brave or great:
examples: The text presents him as a failed and unheroic king.
We want audiences to like his character, but he seems distinctly unheroic.

meanings.definition: not suitable for a hero (= a person who has done something very brave, or the main character in a story):
examples: We met in the distinctly unheroic setting of the school canteen.
The country stayed neutral by making unheroic compromises.

meanings.definition: without anyone or anything making it difficult for you to do something or for something to happen:
examples: Someone in front of me was arguing with the inspector so I was able to pass unhindered.
UN investigators should be given unhindered access to investigate abuses.

meanings.definition: to cause mental illness in someone:
examples: The threats of the modern world have unhinged us.
Her mind was completely unhinged by shock and grief.

meanings.definition: mentally ill:
examples: I sometimes think that your mother is a little unhinged.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         unhinge
to cause mental illness in someone:
examples: The threats of the modern world have unhinged us.
Her mind was completely unhinged by shock and grief.

meanings.definition: not fashionable, modern, or popular:
examples: Their last album was deeply unhip, yet it became the most popular sound of the summer.
The theatre is very successful despite its unhip suburban location.

meanings.definition: not connected with studying or representing things from the past:
examples: This article is misleading because it is unhistorical and untrue.
Some of her colleagues claim that her recent work is unhistorical.

meanings.definition: (especially of a ball) impossible to hit:
examples: He unleashed a variety of pitches that were literally unhittable.
The target became so small it was unhittable.

meanings.definition: If a bowler or pitcher (= a player who throws the ball in a sports game) is unhittable, it is impossible to hit a ball that they throw:
examples: He was an outstanding baseball player, being a virtually unhittable pitcher.

meanings.definition: used to describe a combination of things when it is very bad, harmful, or unpleasant:
examples: Religious fanatics have formed an unholy alliance with right wing groups.

meanings.definition: extremely unpleasant:
examples: an unholy mess/row/noise

meanings.definition: not pure or religious:
examples: He described their actions as unholy.

meanings.definition: Unhomogenized milk has not been homogenized (= treated so that the cream is mixed into the other parts of the liquid):
examples: The dessert is made with unhomogenized whole milk.
She prefers milk that is pasteurized but unhomogenized.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         unhonoured
not shown great public respect for something:
examples: She should not be allowed to pass unhonoured and neglected.
He died unhonoured at the age of 85.

meanings.definition: having or giving little hope:
examples: Although they were usually extremely confident, they sounded very unhopeful.
Some young people see only a very unhopeful future.

meanings.definition: without a place to live:
examples: Hundreds of unhoused students are still searching for accommodation.
Homes are lying empty while the poor remain unhoused.

meanings.definition: not doing something too quickly; slow:
examples: He has an unflustered, unhurried approach to penalty taking.
a pleasant and unhurried pace of life

meanings.definition: not harmed
not having been through the process of hydrolysis (= a chemical reaction in which one substance reacts with water to produce another):
examples: It should be noted that the unhydrolyzed salt is itself soluble.
The testing process utilizes unhydrolyzed urine.

meanings.definition: not clean, in a way that may cause disease:
examples: unhygienic conditions and a lack of clean water

meanings.definition: An unhyphenated word is not written with a hyphen (= the symbol -):
examples: This exercise looks at hyphenated and unhyphenated compound words.
The word is printed as a single unhyphenated word unless it appears at a line end.

meanings.definition: not using a hyphenated word (= including the symbol -) to describe your culture, politics, or family background:
examples: Eventually, Irish-Americans, German-Americans, Italian-Americans, etc., simply became unhyphenated Americans.
Many people just want to be unhyphenated Canadians.

meanings.definition: calm, controlled, and sensible:
examples: Her book offers an unhysterical portrait of her family.
He was obviously intelligent and seemed quite unhysterical.

meanings.definition: in a calm way, rather than showing extreme emotion by behaviour such as shouting, crying, or using strong language:
examples: She relayed the information calmly, efficiently, and unhysterically.
Can we describe what happened honestly and unhysterically?

meanings.definition:
informal for
        
         university  :
examples: Which uni was she at?

meanings.definition: having or consisting of only one:
examples: unilateral
unisex

meanings.definition:
a 
        
         monobrow
(of a parliament) having only one group of members:
examples: a unicameral legislature

meanings.definition: a law-making body made up of one group of elected officials
abbreviation for United Nations Children's Fund: a department of the United Nations whose aim is improving children's health and education, especially in poor countries
A unicellular organism is made of only one cell:
examples: Most algae are unicellular.

meanings.definition: describes a living thing that is made of only one cell
an imaginary white creature like a horse with a single horn growing from the front of its head
a start-up (= new business) whose value is considered to be over $1 billion
someone or something that is difficult or impossible to find:
examples: The good $15 Pinot Noir is the unicorn of the California wine industry - highly sought after, but no one is actually sure whether it exists or not.

meanings.definition: consisting of a combination of a number of colours, typically including purple, pink, white, light blue and light green, that are used together to decorate food, clothing, etc. :
examples: The easiest way to get that unicorn effect is through soft pastel colours like pinks, greens, and blues.
We offer seven different hanging party decorations in unicorn colours.

meanings.definition: an imaginary creature like a horse with a single horn growing from the front of its head
a company that was previously valued at $1 billion dollars but that is now worth much less:
examples: Over-optimistic initial valuations can turn unicorns into unicorpses.

meanings.definition: a vehicle like a bicycle with only one wheel
unable to be recognized:
examples: Police were alerted when an unidentifiable package arrived at the offices of a prominent law firm.
Much of the food was unidentifiable, but at least it was edible.

meanings.definition: whose name is not known or is being kept secret:
examples: Police are investigating the death of an unidentified man whose body was found yesterday.
The airline is currently having merger talks with an unidentified rival.

meanings.definition: (of a person or image of a person) whose name is not known:
examples: The photo shows the two leaders shaking hands, with an unidentified woman behind them.

meanings.definition: an object seen in the sky whose origin is not known, and that some people think is possibly a spacecraft from another planet:
examples: Unidentified aerial phenomena are officially defined as sightings "that cannot be identified as aircraft or known natural phenomena from a scientific perspective".
The Office of the Director of National Intelligence submitted to Congress a preliminary report regarding Unidentified Aerial Phenomena.

meanings.definition: any object that is seen in the sky, ocean, or space whose origin is not known and that cannot be explained:
examples: A study team was commissioned to scientifically examine unidentified anomalous phenomena (UAPs).
An unidentified anomalous phenomenon is an event that is observed that cannot be identified as an aircraft or known natural phenomenon.

meanings.definition: an object seen in the sky whose origin is not known and which some people think may be a spacecraft from another planet:
examples: Residents of the area insist that an unidentified flying object crashed in a local field in 1947.
They claim to have documented evidence of unexplainable encounters with UFOs - short for unidentified flying objects.

meanings.definition: not based on or influenced by any ideology (= a particular set of ideas or beliefs):
examples: It is one of realism's central claims that it is fundamentally unideological.
He is an unusually unideological figure in today's political world.

meanings.definition: (of language, music) not sounding natural as well as correct:
examples: The following sentence does seem curiously unidiomatic to me.
I thought his performance was excessively gloomy, and his German unidiomatic.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for United Nations Industrial Development Organization: a department of the United Nations that is responsible for encouraging industrial activity in developing countries:
examples: In response to requests by member countries, UNIDO is implementing global and regional initiatives on the use of technology.

meanings.definition: the act or process of bringing together or combining things or people:
examples: the unification of East and West Germany
His party's long-term goal remained eventual unification.

meanings.definition: the forming of a single thing by bringing together separate parts:
examples: Germany was transformed after the fall of the Berlin Wall and the unification of the country.

meanings.definition: brought together, combined, or united:
examples: We have to be able to speak with a unified voice on this subject.
The politicians find themselves unusually unified on everything from tax policy to foreign affairs.

meanings.definition: involving several people, organizations, or countries that all work together:
examples: China and Russia have agreed to create a 'unified energy market' in Central Asia.
a unified approach/strategy/policy
No business can survive without a unified vision in terms of goals and strategic direction.

meanings.definition: a unified system, process, etc. has the same rules or laws for all the people, organizations, or countries that are affected by it:
examples: A spokeswoman for the Financial Ombudsman has called for the FSA to oversee the travel insurance market, and to make efforts to apply 'a coherent and unified system of statutory regulation'.
unified business rates

meanings.definition: a particular set of clothes that has to be worn by the members of the same organization or group of people:
examples: military/school uniform
a nurse's uniform
I love a man in uniform!

meanings.definition: a type of clothes that is connected with a particular group of people:
examples: Photographs show him wearing the T-shirt and ripped jeans that were the student's uniform of the time.

meanings.definition: the same; not changing or different in any way:
examples: The office walls and furniture are a uniform grey.
Small businesses are demanding that they receive uniform treatment from the banks.

meanings.definition: a special set of clothes worn by people belonging to an organization to show others that they are members of it:
examples: soldiers in uniform

meanings.definition: the same; not varying or different in any way:
examples: The laws for adopting a child are not uniform among the states.

meanings.definition: Uniform means not changing in speed or power; constant.
not changing or different in any way:
examples: Making the rules more uniform should reduce the number of cases taken before district law courts.
A proposed new framework has been widely praised for providing a uniform approach to the problem of waste disposal.
Trying to impose a uniform system in all the countries affected has proved very problematic.
uniform policies/procedures/standards

meanings.definition: in the UK, a local tax on buildings that are used for business or industrial purposes, which is calculated in the same way all over the country:
examples: Increases in the uniform business rates are linked to the inflation rate.

meanings.definition: a public sale in which a fixed number of similar things are sold at the same price. Each buyer asks for a particular amount and offers a particular price that they are willing to pay. The buyer that offers the most is the first to receive the goods that they have asked for, and then the goods are sold to other buyers in order, according to how much they have offered, until all the goods are gone. The price of the goods is then fixed at a level that is the same for every buyer:
examples: The sale will be conducted as a uniform price auction, and prospective buyers will be asked to submit sealed bids.

meanings.definition: wearing a uniform:
examples: uniformed officers/police/soldiers
About a dozen uniformed guards performed the searches.

meanings.definition: the quality or fact of being the same, or of not changing or being different in any way:
examples: We do not seek to impose total uniformity on every single decision that is made.
He apologized for the bland uniformity of the hotel.

meanings.definition: in a way that is the same everywhere or for everyone :
examples: Critics were uniformly enthusiastic about the production.
The impact of interest rates is not felt uniformly across the country.

meanings.definition: to bring together; combine:
examples: If the new leader does manage to unify his warring party it will be quite an achievement.

meanings.definition: to bring separate parts of something together so that they are one:
examples: With his speech, the president sought to unify the country.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         unify
to bring together; combine:
examples: If the new leader does manage to unify his warring party it will be quite an achievement.

meanings.definition: impossible to ignore:
examples: On my journeys, I encountered unignorable evidence of landscape damage and environmental degradation.
Only when matters had become serious and unignorable did they seek outside help and call a doctor.

meanings.definition: involving only one group or country:
examples: The party leader has actually declared her support for unilateral nuclear disarmament (= giving up her country's nuclear weapons without first waiting for other countries to do the same).

meanings.definition: done independently by one group or country:
examples: a unilateral action

meanings.definition: done by only one of the groups, organizations, or countries involved in an activity or process:
examples: More than 70 developing countries have undertaken unilateral trade liberalization initiatives during the last 20 years.
Opponents of the government have criticized the president's unilateral approach and believe broader international alliances are required.
unilateral actions/decisions/concessions

meanings.definition: a formal agreement in which only one of the people or groups involved agrees to do something
the process or fact of deciding a policy or action without involving another group or country:
examples: He has made the world more dangerous by his arrogant unilateralism.
Our position in the world has been weakened by too much unilateralism and too little cooperation.

meanings.definition: a policy of getting rid of your country's nuclear weapons without first waiting for other countries to do the same:
examples: the party's switch from unilateralism to a policy of nuclear deterrence

meanings.definition: a person who believes in acting independently, without involving another group or country:
examples: They are both, in different ways, outspoken unilateralists.

meanings.definition: a person who believes in getting rid of your country's nuclear weapons without first waiting for other countries to do the same:
examples: He is a left-winger and apparently still a committed unilateralist.

meanings.definition: of or relating to unilateralism (= the process or fact of deciding a policy or action without involving another group or country):
examples: There's a return to a more unilateralist worldview.
He has aggressively criticized the president for his unilateralist approach to the world.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves doing or deciding something without first asking or agreeing with another person, group, or country:
examples: The law is part of a disturbing trend to act unilaterally without regard to the legitimate interests of others.
Employers cannot unilaterally change your contract terms.

meanings.definition: failing to give any new information about a subject or to make it easier to understand:
examples: The unilluminating statement from the competition management only added to the confusion.
Unfortunately, the report is both unreadable and unilluminating.

meanings.definition: Something that is unimaginable is difficult to imagine because it is so bad, good, big, etc.:
examples: unimaginable pain/wealth

meanings.definition: difficult to imagine, esp. because of being very unlikely or very undesirable:
examples: It was a time of drought and despair, of the Dust Bowl, of unimaginable suffering.

meanings.definition: in a way that is difficult to imagine because it is so bad, good, big, etc.:
examples: Our family has suffered unimaginably since his death.
In the winter it is unrelentingly, unimaginably cold.

meanings.definition: not new, original, or clever; not showing any imagination
in a way that is not new, original, or clever:
examples: We walked to the top of the accurately if unimaginatively named Low Hill.
Many schools teach languages unimaginatively through tedious grammar lessons.

meanings.definition: not having been immunized against a disease (= protected against it by putting a special substance called a vaccine into the body):
examples: Chickenpox can spread quickly among unimmunized children in the same classroom.
If babies are unimmunised, they can infect older kids who don't have the boosters.

meanings.definition: not damaged in a way that would make something less effective:
examples: The agency's mandate is to preserve wild places in a natural and unimpaired state.
He has shown throughout this tournament that his powers of leadership remain unimpaired.

meanings.definition: Unimpassioned speech, writing, or thought is calm and lacking in emotion:
examples: If there is any subject that should be considered with calm reason and unimpassioned judgment, it is marriage.
The final applause was prolonged but unimpassioned.

meanings.definition: of such a high standard of honesty and moral goodness that it cannot be doubted or criticized:
examples: A spokesman said the Bishop was a man of unimpeachable integrity and character.

meanings.definition: not stopped, blocked, or prevented by anything:
examples: From this position you can enjoy an unimpeded view of the waterfall.
The new bike path allows bicycles to ride unimpeded through the city.

meanings.definition: not important:
examples: Staffing is still a relatively unimportant issue compared to our other problems.

meanings.definition: not important:
examples: The money we lost is relatively unimportant, but the emotional stress of being robbed is hard to get over.

meanings.definition: having an appearance that does not seem important or cause admiration:
examples: He was an unimposing man who had the habit of fidgeting with the frames of his glasses while speaking.
The art in this show is unimposing, orderly, measured, a little bit dull.

meanings.definition: not impressed (= made to feel admiration or respect):
examples: They looked at the house, but they seemed unimpressed (by it).

meanings.definition: not making you feel admiration or respect:
examples: Improvement was needed after the team's unimpressive start to the season.
Despite its promises, this government's record is unimpressive.

meanings.definition: not officially part of a town or a city:
examples: Some unincorporated areas of counties become their own cities, such as Malibu and West Hollywood.

meanings.definition: not officially part of a town or a city:
examples: Bonsall is unincorporated and thus under the control of the county government.

meanings.definition: used to describe a business that is not a limited company:
examples: There are some further rules that must be observed if the business is unincorporated.

meanings.definition: not provided with an index (= a list or collection of information in alphabetical order):
examples: The index can be used as a cross-reference to other unindexed newspapers of the period.
The collection of 20,000 documents is housed in inadequate conditions, and is unindexed.

meanings.definition: Unindexed investments or payments are not linked to the general level of prices and do not change by the same amount as they do. :
examples: It is unlikely that indexed annuities will ever catch up with unindexed ones.
The bond was for 6 years, unindexed in the first year and fully indexed thereafter.

meanings.definition: not officially accused of a serious crime, especially by a grand jury or international court:
examples: He was listed as an unindicted co-conspirator in the bombings.
He is so far unindicted by the Hague tribunal examining war crimes.
Until last Friday he remained unindicted, even after close associates had been charged.

meanings.definition: An unindustrialized area or country has not developed a lot of industry:
examples: A struggle was underway for influence in the unindustrialized regions of the world and access to their resources.
GDP can be hard to measure in unindustrialized countries.

meanings.definition: not infected with a particular disease, bacteria, virus, etc.:
examples: Half of the babies in the study were born to uninfected mothers.
Transmission of the disease occurs when people who are uninfected inhale the droplets.

meanings.definition: not inflated (= filled with air):
examples: Hopes of rescuing the crew finally faded after the discovery of the trawler's second uninflated lifeboat.
The football will be sent by standard post and arrives uninflated.

meanings.definition: Uninflected word forms or languages do not have changed spellings or endings that show how a word is used in sentences:
examples: We usually use uninflected forms when talking about one thing, and the inflected forms when speaking about more than one thing.
English is a relatively uninflected language, whereas many other languages have dozens or even hundreds of verb forms.

meanings.definition: An uninflected voice, sound, or performance does not change much in tone (= expression) or pitch (= level):
examples: He spoke softly, in a mostly uninflected voice with a slight Texas twang.
The tone and style of the narrative remains cool and relatively uninflected.

meanings.definition: not influenced by someone or something:
examples: These groups developed their own independent styles of dress relatively uninfluenced by popular fashion.
How can you guarantee it is a balanced, open, uninfluenced presentation of the facts?

meanings.definition: not providing much or any useful information:
examples: The catchy but utterly uninformative title refers to the novelist's thoughts about childhood reading.
His comments to the press are usually both brief and uninformative.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not provide much or any useful information:
examples: The first time the son appears, he is called, uninformatively, "the little boy".
A final section uninformatively labelled "Methods and Results" contains mainly archaeological materials.

meanings.definition: not knowing much or having much information about something:
examples: For a journalist, he seems surprisingly uninformed about what is happening in the news.

meanings.definition: Uningratiating behaviour shows that you are not influenced by wanting people to like you:
examples: The film features an outstanding, uningratiating performance by John Garfield.
The artwork is largely uningratiating, often based on elaborate insider jokes.

meanings.definition: not habitable (= suitable to live in):
examples: If there's no roof then the house is uninhabitable.

meanings.definition: An uninhabited place has no people living in it:
examples: an uninhabited island

meanings.definition: free and natural, without embarrassment or too much control:
examples: The students we spoke to were surprisingly uninhibited in talking about sex.
We watched two hours of glorious, uninhibited tennis.
She gave a loud, uninhibited laugh.

meanings.definition: not having knowledge or experience of a particular subject or activity:
examples: The author's goal was to introduce uninitiated readers to the area.
To the uninitiated outsider, all this would be completely incomprehensible.

meanings.definition: people who are without knowledge or experience of a particular subject or activity:
examples: Michelle, for the uninitiated, is the central female character in Netflix's latest comedy series.

meanings.definition: not injured:
examples: The driver of the car was shocked but uninjured.

meanings.definition: (of a person, animal, or plant) not having been inoculated against a disease (= given a weak form of the disease as a protection against it) :
examples: Uninoculated control plants were grown under the same conditions as the inoculated plants.
Animal wardens began night patrols to round up unregistered and uninoculated dogs.

meanings.definition: not inspected (= checked or visited to make sure that everything is correct and legal):
examples: Too many care facilities go uninspected, and complaints go unresolved for months at a time.
The airline had continued to fly the uninspected planes even after it found cracks in some of them.

meanings.definition: not exciting or interesting:
examples: an uninspired performance

meanings.definition: not making you feel excited or interested:
examples: The menu looked fairly uninspiring.

meanings.definition: to remove a computer program from a computer:
examples: The program ran so slowly, I had to uninstall it.
To uninstall this demo, double-click the Add/Remove icon.

meanings.definition: An unistall computer program removes other programs from a computer:
examples: There is still a lot of software that comes without an uninstall program.

meanings.definition: to remove a piece of software from a computer:
examples: Free up disk space by uninstalling programs that you never use.

examples: The program ran so slowly, I had to uninstall it.
