meanings.definition: not expected:
examples: unlooked-for joy

meanings.definition: not easy to love
not loved:
examples: He found himself alone and unloved.

meanings.definition: not showing love towards someone:
examples: He grew up in an unloving foster home after his parents died in a car crash.
The children were always trying to gain the approval of their distant, unloving father.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not lucky:
examples: The team started the match well and finished unluckily.
Unluckily for him, his comments were recorded and broadcast on that day's news.

meanings.definition: not lucky:
examples: The couple were unlucky enough to be in the hotel when the terrorist group struck.

meanings.definition: having or bringing bad luck:
examples: For the unlucky people who get the flu, the health department advises: Stay home!

meanings.definition: not lyrical (= expressing personal thoughts and feelings in a beautiful way):
examples: The critics called his new collection of poetry bland, cold, and unlyrical.
It's one of the most unlyrical songs I have ever heard.

meanings.definition: not macho (= behaving forcefully or showing no emotion in a way traditionally thought to be typical of a man):
examples: He impresses in this film with his portrayal of a decidedly unmacho bank robber.
Despite his long career as a boxer, he comes across as very unmacho when you meet him.

meanings.definition: If a bed is unmade, its sheets and covers are still untidy from having been slept in.
to destroy a reputation or a career:
examples: Actors' reputations have been made and unmade on this London stage.

meanings.definition: not malicious (= intending or intended to harm or upset other people):
examples: She seems like an agreeable, unmalicious person.
It's wrong to label the whole of social media as evil but, equally, it is a difficult place for the unmalicious exchange of views.
He had a kind, unmalicious smile on his face which distracted me from what he was saying.

meanings.definition: not maliciously (= in a way that is intended to cause harm, upset, or damage):
examples: The court agreed that she had behaved unmaliciously in contacting him.
He gave his mum a big fright , but quite unmaliciously, by peering in at the window.

meanings.definition: impossible to deal with or manage:
examples: 74 percent of teachers said their paperwork was unmanageable.
Long, curly, unmanageable hair needs a good conditioner.

meanings.definition: impossible to deal with or manage:
examples: We offer specialist debt advice for self-employed people who face unmanageable debts.

meanings.definition: in a way that is impossible to deal with or manage:
examples: Birth rates are unmanageably high in some rural parts of the country.
We need to be careful that the new boundaries don't create districts that are unmanageably large.

meanings.definition: not controlled or organized, or not managed in an active way :
examples: No one is suggesting that unmanaged immigration is desirable, but policies need to be sympathetic to the reasons for people wanting to immigrate.
The growth of opioid addiction was left unmanaged for far too long.
Unmanaged investment funds tend to follow the stock exchange as there is no fund manager actively adjusting the make-up of the portfolio.

meanings.definition: used to describe a tracker (= a financial product that only follows the general level of particular shares), rather than an investment that is managed in an active way:
examples: One unmanaged fund is American Gas Index that invests in about 75 stocks from an index developed by the American Gas Association.

meanings.definition: not having been manipulated (= changed, often unfairly or dishonestly):
examples: The newspaper was adamant that the pictures they had published were unmanipulated.
Can you be absolutely certain that the data on which these conclusions are based is unmanipulated?

meanings.definition: used to refer to a spacecraft, or a place where military guards work, that has no people present to operate or be in charge of it:
examples: an unmanned mission to the planet Mars

meanings.definition: not having or not needing people to operate or work correctly:
examples: Both designs represent a new generation of unmanned aircraft, which began in the 1990s with robotic spy planes.

meanings.definition: not represented on a map:
examples: The explorers ventured into previously unmapped territory.
The only parts of the world that remain unmapped are some regions of the ocean floor.

meanings.definition: having no signs or marks showing what something is:
examples: an unmarked police car
She died penniless and was buried in an unmarked grave.

meanings.definition: having no signs or symbols on the outside:
examples: an unmarked police car

meanings.definition: that cannot be sold or made attractive to buyers:
examples: The houses were in an unmarketable condition because of the issues with subsidence.
The scandal in which the actor was involved had made him unmarketable.

meanings.definition: not spoiled:
examples: The national park remains unmarred by the extensive industrial development in the country.
Despite there being a lot of graffiti elsewhere, the mural has remained largely unmarred.

meanings.definition: not married:
examples: an unmarried mother
Their youngest son remained unmarried.

meanings.definition: having no husband or wife:
examples: Their youngest son is still unmarried.

meanings.definition: not masculine (= having characteristics that are traditionally thought to be typical of or suitable for men):
examples: The ballet dancer's athletic style of dancing helped to challenge the preconception that ballet was unmasculine.
Skin cancer rates are higher in men because many of them still think that it is unmasculine to apply sun cream.

meanings.definition: to show the bad, and previously hidden, truth about someone or something:
examples: At the end of the play the villain is unmasked.

meanings.definition: to show the previously hidden truth about someone or something:
examples: He was unmasked as the author of the article.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         unmask
to show the bad, and previously hidden, truth about someone or something:
examples: At the end of the play the villain is unmasked.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         unmask
to show the bad, and previously hidden, truth about someone or something:
examples: At the end of the play the villain is unmasked.

meanings.definition: of very high quality and therefore impossible to copy:
examples: The orchestra excelled at this time and were playing at a level that seemed unmatchable.
The sequels have all been successful and were well-made films but couldn't really compare with the unmatchable original.

meanings.definition: having no equal; better than any other of the same type:
examples: For years they have enjoyed a standard of living unmatched by any other country in Europe.

meanings.definition: not intended:
examples: He forthrightly claimed that any implication that he disagreed was unmeant.
She was absolutely devastated that the unmeant slight had upset her friends so much.

meanings.definition: that cannot be measured:
examples: We know that there is a huge but unmeasurable growth in gambling in the country.
The difference in the mood in the city since the ceasefire is unmeasurable.

meanings.definition: not having been measured:
examples: Gang activity in this state has gone unmeasured for far too long - we need to start measuring and then reducing it.
The minister stated that not only has immigration been uncontrolled, it has also been unmeasured.

meanings.definition: not mechanized (= involving using a machine to do something that used to be done by hand):
examples: Furniture production in these factories is still largely unmechanized.
The unmechanised infantry troops stood little chance against the enemy's tank batallions.

meanings.definition: not having received medicine of some kind:
examples: Unmedicated patients are more likely to react with violence.
She's HIV-positive but has been unmedicated and healthy for over 15 years.

meanings.definition: not containing a medical substance:
examples: Make sure you use unmedicated body lotion as that is less likely to irritate your skin.
Unless you have dandruff or another scalp condition, I recommend that you use an unmedicated shampoo.

meanings.definition: unpleasant to listen to:
examples: There was excessively loud, unmelodic "thrash metal" music blaring from loudspeakers.
Unmelodic music was playing from a distant temple.

meanings.definition: not melodious (= pleasant to listen to):
examples: This bird has a distinctive, shrill, and unmelodious call.
It's an understatement to say that his singing is unmelodious - he's practically tone deaf.

meanings.definition: not likely to be remembered, or not worth remembering:
examples: It was a very unmemorable dinner party - awful food and boring conversation.
She was a phenomenally successful singer and songwriter but I'm afraid I find her songs totally unmemorable.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not likely to be remembered or worth remembering:
examples: After all the exciting games earlier, the season ended unmemorably with some uninspiring nil-nil draws.
He found the long summer holidays unbearably boring, with one day blurring unmemorably into the next.

meanings.definition: shocking or embarrassing, and therefore not allowed or disapproved of as a subject of conversation:
examples: the unmentionable possibility that we might lose the war

meanings.definition: underwear
not referred to or spoken about:
examples: There is another issue that cannot go unmentioned and that I must raise now.
Despite the government's promise to address the issue of child poverty, the subject was almost completely unmentioned in the budget.

meanings.definition: that is not deserved:
examples: His reputation as being a person who is difficult to work with is totally unmerited, and really he is just a bit shy.
She was a very humble person and insisted that all the praise she received was unmerited.

meanings.definition: not happy, or making you feel unhappy:
examples: They were a particularly unmerry group so I tended to do my own thing rather than mix with the others.
It was one of the most unmerry Christmases I have ever experienced as we had no electricity for two days.

meanings.definition: not satisfied, or achieved:
examples: These children have many unmet needs.
The demand for affordable housing is largely unmet.

meanings.definition: that has not been metabolized (= turned by chemical processes in the body into energy, new growth, and waste products):
examples: A toxicology report showed large amounts of unmetabolised cocaine in his body.

meanings.definition: an unmetered internet service is one that you can use as much as you want for a fixed amount of money each month:
examples: The UK has the cheapest unmetered internet access for businesses in Europe.

meanings.definition: not relating to, typical of, or suitable for the armed forces:
examples: Disrespecting a senior officer, neglect of duty, or any other unmilitary conduct is subject to court-martial.
The soldier was clearly drunk and was wearing his cap at a very unmilitary angle.

meanings.definition: (of grain, seeds, etc.) that has not been crushed into flour or powder:
examples: They collected the grains of unmilled rice that had fallen on the floor.
The highest concentrations of magnesium are found in whole seeds such as legumes, nuts, and unmilled grains.

meanings.definition: (of a mineral, metal, etc.) not dug out of the ground:
examples: There is gold, but it is in the form of unmined ore.
They estimate that up to 600 million pounds of uranium remain unmined.

meanings.definition: not obtained or made use of:
examples: A presidential candidate does not want to leave any potential source of votes unmined.
From the point of view of tourism, the area's links with popular music are an unmined resource.

meanings.definition: not fully explored or discovered:
examples: The style of her comedy is observational, and a rich vein of satire is left unmined.
The writer had a traumatic childhood, and she leaves no sensitive topic unmined throughout her memoir.

meanings.definition: An unmissable film, play, etc. is so good that it must be seen:
examples: Critics are describing the musical as "unmissable".

meanings.definition: not likely to be confused with something else:
examples: There was an unmistakable smell of incense in the air.

meanings.definition: not likely to be confused with something else; clearly recognized:
examples: There was an unmistakable smell of chocolate.

meanings.definition: in a way that is very easy to see and not likely to be confused with something else:
examples: The discussions are unmistakably going in the wrong direction.
She had an air of chic that was unmistakably French.

meanings.definition: complete, often describing something bad or unsuccessful that has no good or positive points:
examples: The whole venture has been an unmitigated disaster.

meanings.definition: (esp. of something unpleasant or unsuccessful) complete:
examples: Her new business proved to be an unmitigated disaster.

meanings.definition: to separate something that was mixed, or to become separated:
examples: Cream lightens coffee when it is poured into it but doesn't unmix so easily.
According to her, the legal anomalies are due to the mixing up of law and morals, and we need to unmix them.

meanings.definition: not able to be mixed:
examples: Emulsification occurs when two unmixable liquids, such as oil and water, become combined so that large drops of one are spread evenly throughout the other.
I see us as two opposite and unmixable elements, like fire and water.

meanings.definition: kept separate, and not mixed or combined with any other substance or objects:
examples: The artist loved pure, unmixed colours, and she used them boldly.
The cross-section shows dark layers relatively unmixed with the layers of ice.

meanings.definition: pure, and not mixed with any other feeling or quality:
examples: They looked forward to the event with unmixed pleasure.
His feelings of friendship were not unmixed with a desire for comfort and protection.
Tourism is not exactly an unmixed blessing (= something completely good) for people who live on the island.

meanings.definition: not made more modern:
examples: The house has an unmodernized kitchen with appliances that are over 20 years old.
The region suffers from an unmodernized infrastructure, with crumbling roads and bridges and poor communication links.

meanings.definition: not having been changed, especially in a way that is intended to improve something:
examples: The biofuel can be mixed with petroleum diesel and used in unmodified diesel engines.
This is a wild jungle habitat unmodified by man.
The supermarket chain is committed to selling genetically unmodified produce.

meanings.definition: not following the current fashion:
examples: She opened her own restaurant, serving seasonal produce in an unmodish, unfussy, classic menu.
As a young man he sported a rather unmodish moustache as a homage to his grandfather.

meanings.definition: (of a voice, style, etc.) not having the sound, style, etc. changed to fit a mood or situation:
examples: We could hear the loud, unmodulated boom of his voice.
Her Irish brogue is unmodulated by 40 years of living in London.
Her paintings are simple and stylized, featuring thick strokes of unmodulated colour.

meanings.definition: allowed to remain or go somewhere without being touched, damaged, stopped, etc.:
examples: It's virtually impossible to walk out of the supermarket unmolested by people who want you to sign a petition about something.
The sailors' graves have been left unmolested for decades.

meanings.definition: not watched or listened to in order to check that something is safe or that no rules or laws are broken:
examples: The parcels were stolen from a loading dock that was unmonitored by security cameras.
The prisoner was allowed to make a series of unmonitored calls from a mobile phone.

meanings.definition: to unfasten a boat from something connecting it to land or to the bottom of the sea, a lake, a river, etc.:
examples: He had attempted to steal a 45ft yacht, without first unmooring it.
On the 23d of October I unmoored and made ready for sea.

meanings.definition: to become less involved with, connected with or influenced by something, or to make someone or something do this:
examples: J. K. Rowling has succeeded in unmooring the boarding school story from wealth, class and snobbery.
The institution needs to grow, even if that means unmooring itself from its founder's educational ideals.

meanings.definition: (of a boat) no longer tied in place:
examples: The unmoored boat was drifting off to sea.

meanings.definition: having little confidence and being uncertain about how you should feel or behave, or what you should do:
examples: Paul is unmoored by his parents' divorce.
Was he crazy or just temporarily unmoored by jealousy?

meanings.definition: not wanting to do something, or not wanting to do something well:
examples: unmotivated students

meanings.definition: to make a disk or disk drive no longer available for use on a computer:
examples: In order to unmount a CD-ROM, you should use the unmount command.
If you cannot safely unmount your hard drive, power down the computer by holding down the power button for six seconds.

meanings.definition: If a piece of jewellery, art, etc., is unmounted, it is not set on or attached to something to display it:
examples: 24 carats refers to the weight of the unmounted diamond, before it is set into a ring.
All photographs submitted to the contest should be unmounted and cut to size.

meanings.definition: not riding a horse or other animal, or (of an animal) without a rider:
examples: Two dozen unmounted police officers were on patrol at the parade.
The painting shows an unmounted white charger loose on the battlefield.

meanings.definition: (of a disk or disk drive) no longer available for use on a computer:
examples: Once unmounted, a CD-ROM can be automatically ejected.

meanings.definition: not able to be moved:
examples: My foot seemed to be wedged beneath an unmovable hunk of rock.
They slept in small compartments with unmoveable benches and shelves.

meanings.definition: not able or willing to change:
examples: She glared at them, unmovable in her disapproval.
Each side in the dispute has its unmovable supporters.

meanings.definition: not feeling any emotion:
examples: Both men appeared unmoved as the judge read out their sentence.

meanings.definition: not feeling any emotion:
examples: When the eclipse took place, no one was unmoved.

meanings.definition: not having changed in value:
examples: The drugs giant was unmoved on 2396p.
The share price was unmoved at 182p.

meanings.definition: not moving:
examples: His body was still and unmoving, his gaze fixed. He was oblivious to everything else in the world but her.
How many of us have sat in a line of unmoving cars next to an empty bus lane?

meanings.definition: not making you feel any emotion:
examples: He stars in a strangely unmoving biopic of the star.
Against my expectations, I found the funeral service unmoving.

meanings.definition: not pleasant to listen to; not sounding like music:
examples: The birds are not noisy but most of their notes are harsh and unmusical.

meanings.definition: not skilled in making music; not enjoying listening to music:
examples: All mothers, even the unmusical ones, sing to their babies.
After his stroke, the patient, who had been unmusical, discovered a passion for music.

meanings.definition: to make a sound or device able to be heard again after it has been muted (= made unable to be heard):
examples: I couldn't see how to unmute the TV without using the remote.

meanings.definition: to make a person able to be heard, for example when using video conferencing software: :
examples: Participants will be able to unmute themselves if they need to contribute to the discussion.

meanings.definition: to allow someone's messages, pictures, etc. to appear on a social media website when you look at it, after a time when they have been stopped:
examples: Click the "X" next to the name of the person you want to unmute.

meanings.definition: An unmyelinated nerve is one that does not have a myelin sheath (= a layer that surrounds and protects some nerves):
examples: The lower pain threshold in these patients may be caused by abnormal unmyelinated nerve fibres.
The peripheral nerves are largely comprised of myelinated and unmyelinated axons, typically grouped in fascicles.

meanings.definition: difficult or impossible to name or describe:
examples: Her mother's death had left her with a huge and unnameable sense of loss.
We are living in a world where the enemy is unseen and unnameable.
Giant wheels, staircases, mazes, and unnamable contraptions occupy the stage.

meanings.definition: An unnamed person or thing is talked about, but their name is not known or mentioned:
examples: The article quoted an unnamed source from the White House.

meanings.definition: not named, esp. in order to keep a name secret or unknown:
examples: Both news stories relied on unnamed sources.

meanings.definition: not natural
not found in nature; artificial:
examples: Nothing unnatural or polluting can be used.
The recordings have an unnatural sound.

meanings.definition: Behavior or feelings that are described as unnatural are not usual or acceptable.
in a way that is not natural:
examples: Her skin looked unnaturally yellow.
Not unnaturally (= naturally) people were offended.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not needed or wanted, or more than is needed or wanted:
examples: We don't want to alarm people unnecessarily, but they should be aware of potential dangers.
The rules are unnecessarily complicated.

meanings.definition: not needed or wanted, or more than is needed or wanted:
examples: I thought a lot of the violence in the movie was totally unnecessary.
The idea is to kill the animal as quickly as possible without causing unnecessary suffering.

meanings.definition: An offensive remark or action that is unnecessary could have been avoided:
examples: He just humiliated her in front of everyone - it was so unnecessary.

meanings.definition: not needed or wanted, or more than is needed or wanted:
examples: unnecessary expenses
The key to successful investing is to avoid taking unnecessary risks.

meanings.definition: not needed:
examples: They urged motorists not to buy unneeded petrol during the shortage.
It costs money to shut down generating capacity when unneeded and then start up the generators again.
Some of the outside help was unwelcome and unneeded.
The new rules are creating unneeded difficulty in many people's jobs.

meanings.definition: Something that is unnegotiable cannot be changed by discussion:
examples: While we might be able to talk about the salary, other parts of the contract are simply unnegotiable.
The heartbreak that comes with being a parent is one of the unnegotiable facts of life.

meanings.definition: not able to be walked, driven or travelled across:
examples: The city's cobblestone streets are virtually unnegotiable by car.
In the late 19th century, engineers figured out a way to pull train carriages up the steep, previously unnegotiable slopes.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel less confident and slightly frightened:
examples: I think it unnerved me to be interviewed by so many people.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel less confident and slightly frightened:
examples: The long silence unnerved him.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel nervous or less confident:
examples: Talk of an economic slowdown has so far failed to unnerve American markets.
Investors were unnerved by recent profit warnings.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         unnerve
to make someone feel less confident and slightly frightened:
examples: I think it unnerved me to be interviewed by so many people.

meanings.definition: making someone feel less confident and slightly frightened:
examples: Meeting a twin brother I didn't know I had was an unnerving experience.
He has an unnerving habit of repeatedly glancing over my shoulder and out of the window.

meanings.definition: in a way that makes you feel less confident and slightly frightened:
examples: The gunfire is unnervingly close at times.
He sees an actor who looks unnervingly like him.

meanings.definition: not anxious (= worried and nervous) in a way that is too much or more than normal:
examples: He has grown into a confident person who is unneurotic about what people might say about him.
She wanted to send the message that she was a down-to-earth, unneurotic person with a level head on her shoulders.

meanings.definition: (of an animal) that has not been castrated or spayed (= had part of its sex organs removed so that it cannot produce young animals):
examples: He said that unneutered dogs are almost three times more likely to bite than neutered dogs.

meanings.definition: not important, interesting, or unusual enough to be described in a news report:
examples: This was a highly-orchestrated stunt attempting to attract the media to an otherwise unnewsworthy event.
Happily married for 25 years, the star is more than content to be considered boring and unnewsworthy.

meanings.definition: difficult or impossible to notice:
examples: Digital hearing aids are available that are so tiny as to be virtually unnoticeable.
The dish was tasty enough, but the chilli was unnoticeable.
The procedure leaves a small, unnoticeable scar.

meanings.definition: without being seen or noticed:
examples: We managed to slip away unnoticed.
His contribution did not go unnoticed.

meanings.definition: not seen, or not attracting any attention:
examples: She saw flaws that normally would have gone unnoticed.

meanings.definition: not giving someone the things they need from food in order to grow and stay healthy:
examples: I was living on cheap, unnourishing junk food.
The carnival vendors were selling hot dogs and candy floss, and all sorts of unnourishing fare.

meanings.definition: not showing or understanding the slight differences between things or how complicated they are:
examples: The film makes an unnuanced, cartoonish distinction between good guys and bad guys.
Her criticisms are harsh, unnuanced, and one-sided.

meanings.definition: not able or likely to be disliked or opposed by people, because of not being unpleasant or wrong in any way:
examples: This statement is seemingly unobjectionable, but there are one or two problems with it.
The best that can be said about the film is that it's unobjectionable family viewing.

meanings.definition: not able to be seen or watched, especially in a scientific way:
examples: According to him, a feeling is an unobservable mental event, which happens only in our consciousness.
The supply of money can be measured, but demand is unobservable.

meanings.definition: without anyone watching or noticing:
examples: So tiny that they often go unobserved, biting gnats can be only 0.5 mm long.

meanings.definition: not blocked, so that it is easy to see something or go somewhere:
examples: Because they are built on a steep angle, the seats provide unobstructed views.
All fire exits were well marked and unobstructed.

meanings.definition: not prevented from doing something:
examples: The First Amendment guarantees the press unobstructed access to information.

meanings.definition: not able to be obtained
not noticeable; seeming to fit in well with the things around:
examples: Make-up this season is unobtrusive and natural-looking.

meanings.definition: not noticeable; seeming to belong:
examples: A good waiter is efficient and unobtrusive.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not easy to notice:
examples: He asked if he could unobtrusively observe the convention.
The houses blend unobtrusively into the landscape.

meanings.definition: the quality or fact of not being easy to notice:
examples: Her quietness and unobtrusiveness had made them forget her presence.
The camera is suitable for street photography because of its small size and its unobtrusiveness.

meanings.definition: without anyone in it, or not busy:
examples: Are there any unoccupied seats in that row?

meanings.definition: without anyone in it, or not busy:
examples: Are there any unoccupied seats in that row?

meanings.definition: not official; not from a person in authority, the government, etc.:
examples: unofficial estimates/figures/reports

meanings.definition: not connected with or coming from a recognized office or authority:
examples: We think of him as the unofficial town historian.

meanings.definition: not officially approved by a person in authority, the government, etc.:
examples: Profits were below unofficial estimates.
Based on early and unofficial data, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.12 points.

meanings.definition: not part of an official plan or someone's official business:
examples: The company has an unofficial policy of allowing a number of houses to fall into disrepair before seeking private contractors to do the work.

meanings.definition: a strike that has not been approved by a trade union:
examples: At least 20,000 workers are taking part in unofficial action over pay.

meanings.definition: a rate for exchanging one currency for another that is not decided by a government, but that people use, often illegally:
examples: A gallon of gas costs 6.3 cents at the pump at the unofficial exchange rate.

meanings.definition: a strike that has not been approved by a trade union:
examples: They called for legislation to reduce the number of unofficial strikes.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not official, or not from a person in authority, the government, etc:
examples: They said she had unofficially agreed to the idea.
Unofficially, police estimated there to be 200,000 demonstrators.

meanings.definition: not able to be opened:
examples: The windows had long ago been painted shut and were unopenable.
I don't understand why the device's batteries are inside an unopenable casing.

meanings.definition: not having been opened:
examples: an unopened envelope
unopened mail
The champagne remains unopened.

meanings.definition: with no one trying to compete against you:
examples: The governor is running unopposed in the March Democratic primary.

meanings.definition: (of goods, etc.) not having been requested by a customer:
examples: Companies are prohibited by law from sending unordered merchandise and then demanding payment for it.
Several generous plates of canapés, unordered, were sent to our table.

meanings.definition: not arranged in order:
examples: The unordered data set was uploaded into a spreadsheet.
The new ID tags are unordered, so you will have to sort through them to find yours.

meanings.definition: the same as a lot of other things and therefore not interesting or special
not decorated with any ornament (= a decoration that is added to something to make it more beautiful):
examples: She wore a stately, unornamented red gown with a loose gold sash.
The company's office was located in an unornamented low-rise grey building off the ring road.

meanings.definition: done in a simple style with nothing extra added:
examples: They make pure, unornamented classical ballet exciting.

meanings.definition: different from what is usual or expected in behaviour, ideas, methods, etc.:
examples: Steiner was recognized as an original if unorthodox thinker.

meanings.definition: (of behavior, ideas, or methods) different from what is usual or expected:
examples: He has an unorthodox teaching style.

meanings.definition: different from what is usual or expected in behaviour, ideas, methods, etc.:
examples: Regulators began to scrutinize the company's unorthodox accounting methods.

meanings.definition: not obviously showing your money, possessions, or power in an attempt to make other people notice and admire you:
examples: She lives in a large but unostentatious house.
The bistro is simple and unostentatious, with red chequered tablecloths on the tables.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not obviously show your money, possessions, or power, because you are not interested in making other people notice or admire you:
examples: They are very wealthy, but live relatively unostentatiously in a small town.
She always dressed unostentatiously, often in black.

meanings.definition: not belonging to anyone:
examples: They have a problem with a large population of unowned, feral cats.
The village green is not unowned — it belongs to someone.

meanings.definition: not having oxygen added:
examples: In the human body, the pulmonary artery carries unoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs.
It's important to aerate the soil in your garden, because unoxygenated areas can kill off helpful bacteria.

meanings.definition: to remove things from a suitcase, bag, or box:
examples: I haven't even had time to unpack (my suitcase/clothes).

meanings.definition: to explain or examine something in order to make its meaning clearer:
examples: He read the agreed statement to the group and then began to unpack it for them.

meanings.definition: to remove things from a container:
examples: I haven’t even unpacked my bags yet.

meanings.definition: An unpaid debt, tax, etc. has not been paid:
examples: $50,000 in unpaid taxes

meanings.definition: Unpaid work is work that you do without getting any money for it:
examples: unpaid work/employment

meanings.definition: owed, or without receiving payment:
examples: unpaid bills
an unpaid leave of absence

meanings.definition: used to describe a debt, tax, etc. that has not been paid:
examples: The oil giant's accounts were frozen by authorities seeking to recover $3.4bn in unpaid taxes.
The borrowers must clear the unpaid bills on their credit reports.

meanings.definition: used to describe work that someone does without being paid for it:
examples: How do you factor in unpaid work when planning a market economy?
Unpaid overtime is a violation of corporate policy.

meanings.definition: used to describe people who do not receive payment for the work that they do:
examples: unpaid volunteers/workers
UN lorries lie stranded because the drivers, unpaid for six weeks, have gone on strike.

meanings.definition: a dividend that a company has announced but has not yet paid:
examples: The company now owes preference shareholders more than £100m in unpaid dividends.

meanings.definition: a period of time that someone is allowed away from work for holiday, illness, or another special reason, but that they are not paid for:
examples: Parents of young children are allowed 13 weeks of unpaid leave.

meanings.definition: not painted:
examples: The basement was dark and drab, with unpainted concrete walls.
She wore no make-up and left her nails unpainted.

meanings.definition: An unpalatable fact or idea is unpleasant or shocking and therefore difficult to accept:
examples: the unpalatable truth/facts about the war

meanings.definition: Unpalatable food is unpleasant to taste or eat.
having no equal; better or greater than any other:
examples: They enjoyed success on a scale unparalleled by any previous rock band.

meanings.definition: having no equal; better or greater than any other:
examples: We have an unparalleled record of solid growth.

meanings.definition: not having been infected with a parasite (= an animal or plant that lives on or in an animal or plant and feeds from it):
examples: All unparasitized hosts laid eggs that developed on the same leaf.
58% of sampled larvae remained unparasitised.

meanings.definition: (of behaviour) too bad to forgive or be accepted:
examples: They had committed an unpardonable sin.

meanings.definition: not possible to travel on, through, or across:
examples: Rain had made the roads almost unpassable.
The river had stretches of rapids and rocky terrain that were unpassable by boat.

meanings.definition: Unpasteurized foods and drinks have not been pasteurized (= heated at a controlled temperature for a fixed period of time in order to kill bacteria):
examples: The milk was unpasteurized and unhomogenized.
The new code banned restaurants from using raw, unpasteurized eggs in dishes.
This cheese is often sold unpasteurised.

meanings.definition: If something is unpatentable, it is not possible to receive a patent for it (= the legal right to be the only company that can make it or sell it):
examples: They claimed that his work was unpatentable because his methods merely built on prior research.
Natural, unpatentable, unprocessed foods include the herbal sweetener stevia.

meanings.definition: showing that you do not love or support your country or are not proud of it:
examples: Major conservative magazines ran articles smearing war opponents as "unpatriotic" and worse.
The people who raised questions about the cost of the Olympic Games were accused of being unpatriotic.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you do not love or support your country or are not proud of it:
examples: MPs said the bank was acting unpatriotically by supporting the foreign takeover.
It was suggested that the other side was unpatriotically using the tragedy to benefit itself.

meanings.definition: An unpaved road or track has not been covered with a hard, flat surface of stone, concrete, etc. :
examples: It was about a mile to the house, along a narrow unpaved road.
The streets are unpaved.

meanings.definition: Unpeeled fruit and vegetables have not had their peel (= skin) removed:
examples: Cut ripe, unpeeled tomatoes into quarters.
Scrub the potatoes, but leave them unpeeled.

meanings.definition: not seen, noticed, or realized:
examples: Women were being sent to prisons designed for men, causing previously unperceived problems.
I wished to slip unperceived out of the house.

meanings.definition: having or showing a lack of understanding because of not noticing things:
examples: They seem to be woefully unperceptive.
The response of historians was surprisingly unperceptive.

meanings.definition: (of a play, piece of music, dance, etc.) not able to be performed, usually because of being too difficult or not suitable:
examples: Not long ago his operas were thought to be undramatic, boring, and unperformable.
These works were once considered by the author himself to be unperformable.

meanings.definition: (of a piece of music, play, etc.) that has not been performed:
examples: Most of his major works remain unperformed in the UK.
The opera lay unperformed for nearly half a century.
It was possible to imagine that the play was an unperformed work by a famous playwright.

meanings.definition: not having been persuaded that you should believe or do a particular thing, and therefore not accepting it:
examples: For some, her speech was an eloquent call to unite, but others remain unpersuaded.
He remains unpersuaded that there is a valid reason for this rule.
The judge was unpersuaded by this argument.

meanings.definition: not making you want to believe or do a particular thing:
examples: The court found their argument unpersuasive.
This distinction is unpersuasive to modern readers.

meanings.definition: not worried about something, especially when this is slightly surprising:
examples: He seemed completely unperturbed at the idea of having to sing in a room full of strangers.

meanings.definition: to cut or remove the stitches from a line of sewing
If you unpick a difficult subject, you separate and examine its different parts carefully:
examples: He expertly unpicks the significant features of each painting.
If I try to unpick my own motivation, I think mostly I was jealous.

meanings.definition: to gradually destroy or remove the good effects of what someone has done or created:
examples: The former leader now has to watch his successor unpicking what he strived so hard to achieve.

meanings.definition: (of a place or thing) ugly or not attractive:
examples: The funfair was in the rather unpicturesque setting of the town-centre car park.
The landscape was dotted with unpicturesque farm buildings and bungalows.

meanings.definition: used to refer to percussion instruments that do not produce sounds of a definite pitch
If something is unplaceable, it is impossible to say where it is from or what it is:
examples: Her voice is flat and her accent is unplaceable.
The band's music still has unplaceable electronic sounds.

meanings.definition: If a person is unplaceable, it is impossible to find a suitable place for them:
examples: No child in care should be considered unplaceable for adoption.

meanings.definition: (of a horse in a race) not one of the first three to finish:
examples: The sole British runner, White Knight, was unplaced.
The horse she bet on finished unplaced.

meanings.definition: not planned or expected:
examples: an unplanned pregnancy

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         implausible
An unplayable ball is hit or thrown so hard or skilfully that it is impossible to hit.
If an area of ground that is usually used for sports is unplayable, it cannot be played on, especially because of bad weather conditions.
A piece of music that is unplayable is too difficult to perform.
not enjoyable or pleasant:
examples: an unpleasant surprise
the unpleasant truth

meanings.definition: rude and angry:
examples: When we complained, the waiter got very unpleasant with us.

meanings.definition: not attractive or enjoyable or easy to like:
examples: an unpleasant surprise
unpleasant memories
an unpleasant young man

meanings.definition: in a way that is not enjoyable or pleasant:
examples: By May, the weather is beginning to get unpleasantly hot and humid.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being enjoyable or pleasant:
examples: The cold, raw temperatures of late January only added to the general unpleasantness of the climate.
I wanted, foolishly, to protect you from the unpleasantnesses of life.

meanings.definition: the quality of being rude and angry:
examples: She'd had enough of Louisa's constant unpleasantness.
It might be better to leave before there was open unpleasantness.

meanings.definition: annoyed or unhappy:
examples: I could see that she was not unpleased, even though she tried to hide it.
She did not seem to be entirely unpleased by what she had heard.
Union negotiators were unpleased with the way the talks were developing.

meanings.definition: not giving a feeling of satisfaction or pleasure:
examples: It was not an unpleasing way to spend the day.
Food served in these plastic containers can be unpleasing to the eye.

meanings.definition: Unploughed ground has not been dug to make it ready for planting seeds:
examples: They are creating wildlife habitats along the unploughed edges of fields.
We keep our cattle on unploughed grassland.

meanings.definition: An unploughed road has not had the snow removed from it by a snowplough:
examples: We drove a short distance down the unploughed road, and nearly got stuck.
Trains are delayed, and the roads are unploughed.
