to take the plug of a piece of electrical equipment out of the place where it is connected to the electricity supply:
examples: Did you unplug the iron?

meanings.definition: to remove what is blocking something:
examples: The video shows you how to unplug a bath drain full of hair.

meanings.definition: to remove a plug for an electrical device from a socket:
examples: I unplugged the TV.

meanings.definition: used to refer to musicians performing without electric instruments and without amplification (= electronic equipment that makes sound louder)
ordinary and not very beautiful or emotional, and therefore not typical of poetry:
examples: He writes poetry about thoroughly unpoetic subjects.
The play wasn't awful, just unpoetic and uninteresting.
In her writing, she tries to disprove the view that modern life is unpoetical.

meanings.definition: not controlled or checked, especially by the police:
examples: The dog breeding industry is still relatively unpoliced and unregulated.
There are hundreds of square miles of unpoliced desert in the region.

meanings.definition: Something that is unpolished has not been rubbed using a piece of cloth, a brush, or a machine to clean it and make it shine:
examples: Prices for rough, unpolished diamonds have increased this year.
His black shoes were unpolished and he hadn't brushed his hair.

meanings.definition: not showing great skill, especially because of a lack of practice or experience:
examples: His singing style is unpolished, but seems more intimate as a result.
I went to a slightly unpolished performance of the play.

meanings.definition: not affected by pollution (= damage caused to water, air, etc. by harmful substances or waste):
examples: In areas with unpolluted air, tree branches are often covered with grey, brown and green lichen.
The wild salmon needs cold, clear, unpolluted water to survive.
Glacier Bay is wild, clean and unpolluted.

meanings.definition: not spoiled by something:
examples: She grew up in Liverpool and speaks in a lilting accent, wholly unpolluted by the years she's spent in London.

meanings.definition: not liked by many people:
examples: Night flights from the airport are unpopular.
The president is becoming increasingly unpopular.

meanings.definition: not liked or enjoyed by many people:
examples: I’m not surprised the mayor is unpopular.

meanings.definition: the quality of being disliked by many people:
examples: There is no doubt about the deep unpopularity of the tax-reform programme.
She is prepared to risk unpopularity by tackling social issues of concern.

meanings.definition: An unposed photograph or painting looks natural and is not of someone who has moved or been moved into a position in order to be photographed or painted:
examples: The unposed picture shows the star at a public event.
The photos are generally unposed and spontaneous.

meanings.definition: Unpractical arrangements, ideas, or methods cannot be done or used easily or effectively:
examples: When large numbers of samples are needed, this method is expensive and unpractical.
He made lots of wildly unpractical suggestions.

meanings.definition: Unpractical clothes, devices, etc. cause problems when used in normal situations:
examples: I fell in love with the unpractical and expensive shoes.
This equipment is unpractical to work with because it makes it difficult to move.

meanings.definition: Unpractical people are not naturally good at doing useful jobs such as making or repairing things:
examples: They are sweet and full of optimism, but totally unpractical.

meanings.definition: never having happened or existed in the past:
examples: This century has witnessed environmental destruction on an unprecedented scale.

meanings.definition: never having happened or existed in the past:
examples: We’ve entered an age of unprecedented prosperity.

meanings.definition: in a way that has not happened or existed before:
examples: The banks rejected claims that they have lured customers into unprecedentedly high levels of borrowing.
This was a prime minister who— unprecedentedly—won three big election victories.
Two rivers burst their banks, making the town flood unprecedentedly.

meanings.definition: the quality or fact of being unpredictable (= likely to change suddenly and without reason):
examples: Probably the only predictable thing about the British weather is its unpredictability.
His unpredictability is what makes him so difficult to play against.

meanings.definition: likely to change suddenly and without reason and therefore not able to be predicted (= expected before it happens) or depended on:
examples: The weather there can be unpredictable - one minute it's blue skies and the next minute it's pouring rain.
The hours in this job are very unpredictable - you sometimes have to work late at very short notice.

meanings.definition: tending to change suddenly and without reason or warning, and therefore not able to be depended on:
examples: unpredictable weather
The world is pretty unpredictable.

meanings.definition: if something is unpredictable, it is likely to change suddenly and unexpectedly, so cannot be planned for:
examples: To protect it from the unpredictable nature of software sales, the company has adopted a new business model.
Unpredictable events can have a huge impact on bond values.
It is a very unpredictable market.
The turmoil on Wall Street is emblematic of how the credit mess is spreading in unpredictable ways.
an unpredictable outcome/result

meanings.definition: in a way that is likely to change suddenly and without reason:
examples: The disease seems to strike unpredictably, appearing in patients with no family history.
He reacts emotionally, and therefore unpredictably.

meanings.definition: able to be fair because you are not influenced by an unreasonable opinion of someone or something:
examples: All that is required is an open, unprejudiced mind.
It's almost impossible to find a jury who are unprejudiced by pre-trial publicity.

meanings.definition: (especially of a crime or something unpleasant) done without being planned
not prepared; not ready:
examples: He was completely/totally/wholly unprepared for what he saw.
The extreme cold weather caught them unprepared.

meanings.definition: not ready:
examples: He was completely/totally unprepared for what he saw.

meanings.definition: the state of not being prepared for a particular situation:
examples: The report criticized the unpreparedness of emergency services for such an incident.
Their unpreparedness for the weather conditions was immediately obvious.

meanings.definition: not interesting, attractive, or impressive:
examples: We were disappointed at the unprepossessing exterior of the hotel.

meanings.definition: Unpressed clothes have not been ironed (= made flat and smooth using a piece of equipment called an iron, that has a handle and a flat base and is usually heated with electricity):
examples: His shirt was clean, but unpressed.

meanings.definition: An unpressed cheese does not have something heavy put on it during preparation to make it firm or to form it into a shape:
examples: Saint-Marcellin is an uncooked and unpressed cheese from the Isère Valley.

meanings.definition: not feeling or making someone feel pressure (= a strong influence) to do something:
examples: You can browse the store in a relaxed, unpressured atmosphere.
They were all unpressured, voluntary participants.

meanings.definition: If something such as a container or plane is unpressurized, the air pressure inside it is not controlled and may be lower than the air pressure outside it:
examples: The captain said he did not want to go up to 14,000 feet in the unpressurized plane.
The pipe was part of an unpressurised drainage system.

meanings.definition: not feeling or making some feel pressure (= a strong influence) to do something:
examples: With non-commissioned customer advisors, buying a car is unpressurised and enjoyable.

meanings.definition: simple and/or sincere; not pretentious:
examples: The food is delicious and unpretentious.

meanings.definition: not attractive to look at:
examples: Unpretty it may be, but the sculpture has become a striking landmark.

meanings.definition: not pleasant:
examples: What emerges is an unpretty picture of life in the colony.

meanings.definition: having or showing no moral rules or standards of good behaviour
having or showing no moral rules or standards of good behavior:
examples: an unprincipled politician

meanings.definition: containing offensive language and therefore not acceptable in printed form, for example in a newspaper:
examples: He was known for his incendiary remarks, most of them unprintable in a family newspaper.

meanings.definition: Unprivileged people or groups in society do not have any advantages because they are not rich, do not come from a high social class, or do not belong to a particular race or gender:
examples: She came from a relatively unprivileged background herself.

meanings.definition: not having any special rights or ability to do things that others cannot, especially in computing:
examples: This is used for hiding some databases from unprivileged users.

meanings.definition: Unprivileged information is not secret and can be shared in a law court:
examples: The prosecutor should disclose unprivileged mitigating information to the court and to the defence.

meanings.definition: Something that is unproblematic does not cause any problems or disagreement:
examples: The whole process was simple and unproblematic.
He admits that this approach is not unproblematic.

meanings.definition: not having had any sort of chemical or industrial treatment in order to preserve it, or improve its taste or appearance:
examples: There are ways to eat healthy, unprocessed food on a budget.
Alien species often arrive in unprocessed wood.

meanings.definition: (of documents) not having been dealt with in an official way:
examples: They made efforts to deal with the backlog of unprocessed applications.
There is a mounting pile of unprocessed claims for unemployment benefits.

meanings.definition: (of information) not having had a series of operations performed on it by computer:
examples: All unprocessed data is stored locally.
In order to create useful information, data (unprocessed facts and figures) must be collected and organized in some meaningful pattern.

meanings.definition: (of difficult or sad feelings) not thought about so that they can be accepted:
examples: Unprocessed grief can affect your daily life for many years.
It used to be believed that depression, anger and unprocessed emotions are what cause cancer.

meanings.definition: An unproduced play, film, etc. has been written, but not performed or filmed:
examples: an unproduced screenplay/script/play
She later worked on an, as yet, unproduced sequel to the film.

meanings.definition: not producing very much
not having positive results:
examples: It was such an unproductive meeting - we didn't make a single decision.

meanings.definition: not useful, or not creating anything:
examples: We wasted three days in unproductive discussions.

meanings.definition: not producing goods, crops, profits, etc. in a satisfactory amount:
examples: unproductive investments/jobs/projects
Grass planted on currently unproductive land could form a useful extra income for farmers.

meanings.definition: not achieving good results:
examples: 70% of managers said they could save 10% of their time if they could avoid unproductive meetings.
Falling prices forced companies to cut unproductive workers.
Sales supervisors can help salespersons convert unproductive time into productive time.

meanings.definition: not showing the standard of behaviour or skill that is expected of a person in a skilled job:
examples: Doctor Rivers was charged with unprofessional conduct and improper use of dangerous drugs.

meanings.definition: not showing the standard of behavior or skills that are expected of a person in a skilled job:
examples: Dressing like that was very unprofessional of him.

meanings.definition: not showing the standard of behaviour or work that is expected of a person doing their job:
examples: Two employees have been suspended after allegations of unprofessional behaviour.
The tribunal upheld her complaint that he had treated her in an unprofessional manner.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not show the standard of behaviour that is expected from someone doing a particular job :
examples: She's acting unprofessionally, so you need to tackle this problem as soon as possible.
The social worker behaved unprofessionally and was disrespectful.

meanings.definition: not making a profit:
examples: Rural railway lines risk being axed because they are unprofitable.

meanings.definition: not resulting in profit:
examples: unprofitable investments/businesses

meanings.definition: not making a profit:
examples: When the Asian financial crisis hit, it shut 32 unprofitable businesses.
unprofitable markets/operations/products
It promises $80m of savings and that means shedding unprofitable customers.

meanings.definition: not planned, especially as part of an event or activity:
examples: An unprogrammed performance of a new work by a young composer preceded the advertised programme.

meanings.definition: In Quaker groups (= a Christian religious group called the Society of Friends), an unprogrammed meeting is one where there is no planned ceremony and people sit in silence until someone wants to speak:
examples: Unprogrammed meetings do not have a pastor and the leadership role is a volunteer position assumed by a meeting member.

meanings.definition: (of computers or computer equipment) not given a set of instructions to operate in a particular way:
examples: This is an unprogrammed control module and requires a smart card and reader to program it.

meanings.definition: (of a cell) not given instructions by the body to become a particular type of cell and therefore able to develop into any type of cell:
examples: These unprogrammed embryonic stem cells have the ability to become any cell in the body.

meanings.definition: Unprogressive ideas or systems do not encourage change in society or in the way that things are done:
examples: The society was a complex network of vested interests, was unprogressive, and was shot through with corruption.

meanings.definition: A unprogressive tax system is one in which the rate of tax is the same on small and large amounts of money:
examples: Unprogressive taxes tend to be things such as sales tax.

meanings.definition: Something that is unpromising does not show any signs that it will be enjoyable or successful:
examples: The car broke down, which was an unpromising start to the holiday.

meanings.definition: without being told to say or do something:
examples: Jim was remarkably charming this evening - he even said, unprompted, how nice Margot looked in her dress.

meanings.definition: difficult to say or (of something written) difficult to know how to say:
examples: Scotch whiskies have great character and unpronounceable names, like Bruichladdich.

meanings.definition: not likely to be successful, or not showing any signs of success:
examples: It may have seemed an unpropitious time for a general election.
She assumed power in distinctly unpropitious circumstances, facing union unrest, and a failing economy.

meanings.definition: not successful, especially not earning much money:
examples: He plays the dedicated, but unprosperous proprietor of a specialist record store.
They lived in an unprosperous neighbourhood.

meanings.definition: not protected and therefore able to be harmed or damaged:
examples: Water and other liquids can stain unprotected wood surfaces.
Although some marine mammals are protected by environmental laws, many remain unprotected.
The lack of a shell leaves the larvae unprotected against predators.

meanings.definition: not safe from injury, damage, or loss:
examples: Many of our forests remain unprotected by environmental laws.

meanings.definition: not able to be proved:
examples: In the end, his ideas boil down to no more than unprovable assertions.
It's an interesting concept, but unprovable.

meanings.definition: not having been shown to be true:
examples: This unproved allegation suggested that local police were turning a blind eye.

meanings.definition: not having been shown to be good enough or to be able to do something:
examples: It is relying in large part on developing unproved technology.

meanings.definition: not having been shown to be good enough or to be able to do something:
examples: It would be unwise to throw billions at unproven technology.
a group of talented but unproven young players

meanings.definition: not having been shown to be true:
examples: Unproven allegations have ruined his career.
The suspicion, as yet unproven in court, is that he may have withheld important information.

meanings.definition: If an unpleasant action or remark is unprovoked, it has not been caused by anything and is therefore unfair:
examples: an unprovoked attack on her character

meanings.definition: (esp. of an unpleasant action or remark) not caused by anything and therefore unfair:
examples: Witnesses said the attack was unprovoked.

meanings.definition: An unpruned plant or tree has not been pruned (= had some branches cut off so that it will grow better):
examples: The garden was full of unpruned roses and rampant weeds.
Plants will become sprawling and woody if left unpruned.

meanings.definition: If something is unpublicized, information about it is not made generally available:
examples: It is the kind of change that goes largely unpublicized until a census highlights a trend.
The plans were drawn up at an unpublicised meeting in Tokyo last month.

meanings.definition: written but not yet published:
examples: After his death, his daughter found an unpublished manuscript among his papers.
a collection of unpublished poems

meanings.definition: not published or made available for people to see:
examples: Unpublished European studies show significant reductions in all the cholesterol-clogging fats.

meanings.definition: A person who is unpublished has not written anything that has been published.
not arriving, doing something, or happening at the expected or correct time:
examples: The trains were notoriously unpunctual.
They say he is disorganized, unpunctual, and incompetent.

meanings.definition: the fact of not arriving, doing something, or happening at the expected or correct time:
examples: She got a reputation for unpunctuality and skipping classes.
As a manager, he was notorious for his intolerance of unpunctuality.

meanings.definition: (of writing) with no punctuation marks (= symbols):
examples: The letter contains two long, unpunctuated sentences.

meanings.definition: with no pauses or interruptions:
examples: It was one of those rare British summer days unpunctuated by rain.

meanings.definition: not punished:
examples: If a referee allows a foul like that to go unpunished he's asking for trouble.

meanings.definition: If a book is unputdownable, it is so exciting that you do not want to stop reading it:
examples: "Was it a good read?" "Oh, totally unputdownable - I finished it in two days."

meanings.definition: An unqualified person does not have the qualifications needed for a particular job.
not limited in any way; to the largest degree possible:
examples: We achieved a lot but I wouldn't say that the project has been an unqualified success.
The proposal has the unqualified support of the entire committee.

meanings.definition: lacking the skills and experience needed for a particular job:
examples: I liked her, but she was unqualified for the job.

meanings.definition: not limited in any way:
examples: My first attempt was an unqualified success.

meanings.definition: not able to be measured:
examples: Many benefits are vague and unquantifiable.
We faced a small but unquantifiable risk.

meanings.definition: not able to be measured:
examples: Finance people can't value employee attitudes, working environment, or other indirect variables with unquantifiable benefits.

meanings.definition: used for describing a feeling that is so strong that it cannot be satisfied:
examples: an unquenchable thirst/desire

meanings.definition: obvious and impossible to doubt
not open to question or doubt; indisputable:
examples: Her achievements are unquestionable.

meanings.definition: in a way that is obvious and impossible to doubt:
examples: She is unquestionably good at physics.
The operation has unquestionably improved the wellbeing of most patients.

meanings.definition: accepted as true or right by everyone, or trusted and respected by everyone:
examples: He's the unquestioned leader in his field (= no one would say that he is not the leader).

meanings.definition: not doubted:
examples: unquestioned loyalty

meanings.definition: Unquestioning obedience is total, and given without thinking, asking questions, or doubting:
examples: Like all tyrannical leaders, he demanded unquestioning obedience from his followers.

meanings.definition: in an unquestioning way (= without doubting or asking questions):
examples: We unquestioningly support their policies and actions when they are clearly morally wrong.
She was unquestioningly loyal to her friends.

meanings.definition: troubled and worried; not peaceful or calm:
examples: One can only hope that his unquiet spirit found some peace in the grave.

meanings.definition: unlisted

→ 
        
         unlisted company

→ 
        
         unlisted shares
not lifted to a high position:
examples: Unraised screens and unbanked seating mean that half the audience can only see the heads of the people in front.

meanings.definition: Unraised bread or similar food is flat because it does not contain yeast (= a type of fungus that makes bread rise):
examples: A tortilla is a thin, flat, unraised pancake.

meanings.definition: An unraised question or issue has not been mentioned or discussed:
examples: Yet the unraised question nags.

meanings.definition: An unranked team or sportsperson is not successful enough to be on a list of the most successful teams or players:
examples: They became the first top five team to lose to an unranked opponent this season.

meanings.definition: not organized into higher and lower positions:
examples: The naming committee will develop a list of three unranked names with pros and cons for each.

meanings.definition: not given a value in a ranking or rating system, especially the rating system for films, that says which ones children can watch:
examples: an unrated coming-of-age tale

meanings.definition: not given a value in a ranking or rating system, esp. the rating system for movies that tells which ones children may watch:
examples: an unrated coming-of-age tale

meanings.definition: used to describe a bond for which risk has not been calculated by a ratings agency:
examples: Investors should be wary of lower-rated or unrated securities.

meanings.definition: If a piece of knitted or woven cloth, a knot, or a mass of thread unravels, it separates into a single thread, and if you unravel it, you separate it into a single thread:
examples: You'd better mend that hole before the whole sweater starts to unravel.
I had to unravel one of the sleeves because I realized I'd knitted it too small.

meanings.definition: If you unravel a mysterious, unknown, or complicated subject, you make it known or understood, and if it unravels, it becomes known or understood:
examples: We have a long way to go before we unravel the secrets of genetics.

meanings.definition: If a process or achievement that was slow and complicated unravels or is unravelled, it is destroyed:
examples: As talks between the leaders broke down, several months of careful diplomacy were unravelled.

meanings.definition: If a person or their life unravels, they are no longer able to control their emotions or what is happening to them:
examples: Stress caused by the loss of a loved one, financial problems, or job loss can cause people to unravel.
Those who help the homeless see people whose lives have unravelled completely.
In the waiting room of the clinic a woman was unravelling — she sat rocking from side to side and talking to herself.

meanings.definition: (of woven cloth) to separate into threads, or to separate the fibers of a thread, rope, or cloth:
examples: My sweater is unraveling.
fig. The movie unraveled at the end (= was not complete and satisfying).

meanings.definition: to solve a crime or explain a mystery:
examples: You will discover what the title means as you unravel the movie's mysteries.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         unravel

present participle of 
        
         unravel
If a place or thing is unreachable, it is not possible to get to it, or to get hold of it:
examples: The village had been unreachable because landslides had blocked the roads.
Sometimes the solution is as simple as lowering the height of a table if crayons and pencils are unreachable.

meanings.definition: If a person is unreachable, it is not possible to contact them:
examples: Some tech company offices in major cities were unreachable by phone last Tuesday.

meanings.definition: If a level, especially a high one, is unreachable, it is not possible to achieve:
examples: After achieving a goal thought unreachable so early in the track season, Webb still has much to aim for.

meanings.definition: An unreached person or place has not been communicated with or visited by someone:
examples: A lot of the survivors are still unreached, and this is a problem for foreign aid workers.

meanings.definition: too boring, complicated, or badly written to be worth reading:
examples: I found James Joyce's "Ulysses" to be totally unreadable.

meanings.definition: illegible (= impossible to read because not clear or untidy):
examples: completely unreadable handwriting

meanings.definition: the state of not being prepared or ready for something:
examples: The media lamented the country's unreadiness for Monday's earthquake disaster.

meanings.definition: unwillingness to do something:
examples: Some are frustrated by their unreadiness to look for their own independent solution.

meanings.definition: not prepared for something, or not prepared or willing to do something:
examples: Two of the Army's 10 divisions were deemed unready for battle.
Parents who still look and feel young may be unready to acknowledge that their children are growing up.

meanings.definition: as if imagined; strange and dream-like:
examples: The whole bizarre evening had an unreal quality to it.

meanings.definition: extremely or surprisingly good:
examples: We saw so many shooting stars that night, it was unreal!

meanings.definition: as if imagined; strange and like a dream:
examples: His face was an eerie, unreal color.

meanings.definition: surprising, unusual, or hard to believe:
examples: We just ate and ate, and I was so full it was unreal.

meanings.definition: having a wrong idea of what is likely to happen or of what you can really do; not based on facts:
examples: I think these sales forecasts are unrealistic, considering how slow sales are at present.
It's unrealistic to expect an answer before next week.

meanings.definition: not reasonable, or not likely to be achieved:
examples: We’re placing unrealistic demands on our schools.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not based on facts or not likely to be successful:
examples: Our expectations have become unrealistically high.
They give an unrealistically optimistic assessment of their own skills and abilities.

meanings.definition: the quality of not being or seeming to be real:
examples: There was a feeling of unreality about the trip, as if I'd stepped into another world for two weeks.
There are tensions in the story, especially between reality and unreality.

meanings.definition: not able to be achieved:
examples: Owning a home of their own seemed like a totally unrealizable dream.
Some fear they are creating unrealisable expectations.

meanings.definition: not able to be sold to get money:
examples: Some people are sitting on sizeable assets which are unrealisable.

meanings.definition: If a plan or a hope is unrealized, it has not been achieved or has not happened:
examples: Her promises for sweeping reforms remain unrealized.
He left dozens of plans for unrealised projects.

meanings.definition: An unrealized profit or loss exists when you own something that will create a future profit or loss when you sell it:
examples: The bank is sitting on unrealized gains on its holdings worth billions.
The company also has roughly 100 billion yen of unrealised losses from falling property prices.

meanings.definition: not yet done or achieved:
examples: The group's big unrealized ambition is to offer a single trading system for American and European derivatives.
The company has considerable but thus far unrealised potential.

meanings.definition: used to describe an amount of profit or loss from an investment, where the investment has not been sold so that, in the case of a profit, there is no real gain, because it has not been turned into cash, and in the case of a loss, it is not a real loss:
examples: unrealized depreciation/loss
When an investment increases or decreases in value but we do not sell it, we record an unrealized gain or loss.

meanings.definition: not fair or acceptable:
examples: unreasonable demands
It seems unreasonable to expect one person to do both jobs.

meanings.definition: not based on or using good judgment; not fair:
examples: It’s unreasonable to expect him to work every weekend.

meanings.definition: not fair or acceptable:
examples: A merchant is not required to satisfy a customer's unreasonable demands.
It is not unreasonable for technical jobs to be filled by people with particular skills honed in industry.
It would be unreasonable to expect annuity rates to remain high.
an unreasonable cost/expense/price

meanings.definition: in a way that is not fair or acceptable:
examples: I knew I was behaving unreasonably, but I couldn't stop myself.
The woman, not unreasonably (= in a way that is easy to understand), was furious.

meanings.definition: Unreasoning feelings or beliefs are not based on reason or judgment:
examples: unreasoning hatred

meanings.definition: not willing to listen to and accept new ideas and suggestions:
examples: He initially appeared unreceptive to the idea.
Advertisers don't want to waste spending on unreceptive audiences.

meanings.definition: Unreclaimed land is in poor condition or cannot be used, and has not been reclaimed (= made suitable for use):
examples: Plans are being made for the reforesting of unreclaimed strip mine sites.
Much of the heathlands in these areas are unreclaimed to this day.

meanings.definition: very different to before, or changed very much, and therefore not able to be recognized:
examples: She returned to the United States to find a country that seemed almost unrecognizable from the one she had left as a young woman.
He had been beaten so severely that he was unrecognizable.

meanings.definition: not clear enough or known well enough to be able to be recognized:
examples: The other picture was of an unrecognisable small boy, holding a hand up to the camera.
The truck was flying an unrecognizable flag.

meanings.definition: in a way that is difficult to recognize:
examples: My home town has now changed almost unrecognizably.
Today things are unrecognisably different.

meanings.definition: If something is unrecognized, people do not know what it is, especially because they have not seen, heard, or experienced it before:
examples: The illness often goes unrecognised and untreated.

meanings.definition: If someone is unrecognized, people do not realize who they are even though they may have seen them before:
examples: She sat unrecognised in the crowded cafeteria.

meanings.definition: not generally accepted as legal, true, or important, and if someone's achievements are unrecognized, they are not shown official approval:
examples: It is a minority political party that is unrecognised by the authorities.
Their work goes largely unrecognized.

meanings.definition: (of someone's achievements) not shown official approval:
examples: His contributions as a political reformer still remain largely unrecognised.

meanings.definition: Unreconcilable beliefs, decisions, differences etc. are opposite to each other and cannot exist together:
examples: There is a severe, perhaps unreconcilable, difference of opinion on this issue.
It has been argued that these divisions are unreconcilable.

meanings.definition: Unreconciled people or groups cannot agree with each other and therefore do not have a friendly relationship:
examples: Sectarian groups in the country remain unreconciled.

meanings.definition: unable to accept something:
examples: Elements within the party have remained unreconciled to the deal.

meanings.definition: (of an account, number, etc.) not been checked against another account to make sure that it is accurate:
examples: There are unreconciled differences between what the company's books show and what the bank statement shows.

meanings.definition: having opinions or behaving in a way not considered to be modern or politically acceptable in modern times:
examples: She describes herself as an unreconstructed feminist.

meanings.definition: not written about before, and therefore not known about:
examples: Patterson discovered the previously unrecorded animal in 1999.

meanings.definition: (of sounds or moving pictures) not recorded on electronic equipment:
examples: The singer told fans he had a new unrecorded song to try out on them.

meanings.definition: If something, such as money or information on a computer, is unrecoverable, you cannot recover it (= get it back):
examples: More than £75 million of debt was written off as unrecoverable.
This makes the deleted files unrecoverable.

meanings.definition: used to describe money that someone has lost or lent and will never get back:
examples: The credit union had unrecoverable loans totalling 235 billion yen.

meanings.definition: used to describe information on a computer that has been lost and cannot be found:
examples: The data recovery company could restore the client's unrecoverable data from the hard drive.

meanings.definition: used to describe a mistake in a computer program that cannot be corrected:
examples: The critical systems folder was deleted, which might have resulted in an unrecoverable system crash.

meanings.definition: a computer software mistake that causes a mistake in a process, calculation, etc. that cannot be corrected:
examples: The signal occurs where an unrecoverable error requires an immediate termination of the process.

meanings.definition: If something that is lost or spent is unrecovered, you have not got it back:
examples: The figures do not include unrecovered costs.
A total vehicle loss is where your vehicle is written off, or stolen and unrecovered.

meanings.definition: not able to be recycled (= treated to produce useful materials that can be used again):
examples: The resort has limited the use of unrecyclable materials.
This approach steers you away from buying things that are unrecyclable.

meanings.definition: impossible to correct, improve, or change:
examples: It's possible for a dark novel full of unredeemable characters to be an engrossing read.
The human condition is messy and perhaps unredeemable, but a great work of art can make you believe otherwise.

meanings.definition: If something representing a particular amount of money is unredeemed, it has not been exchanged for that amount of money or for goods to that value:
examples: Most unredeemed gift cards are simply misplaced or go unused by recipients.

meanings.definition: An unredeemed debt has not been paid back:
examples: The unredeemed debt puts massive pressure on banks' balance sheets.

meanings.definition: If someone or something is unredeemed, they have not done anything to improve or for people to forgive them for something bad:
examples: The character is a wholly unredeemed villain, and the primary antagonist of the story.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that has been given as security on a loan, and which the lender keeps because the borrower has not paid back the loan:
examples: Unredeemed articles become the property of the pawnbroker at the end of the period and may be sold in order to repay the loan.

meanings.definition: not exchanged for money or goods:
examples: Retailers gain a huge amount of revenue through unredeemed gift cards.

meanings.definition: If something wrong that has been done is unredressed, nothing is done to put it right:
examples: In the absence of independent advocates, rights would go unprotected and wrongs unredressed.
Wrong conduct of a public authority too often goes unredressed.

meanings.definition: in a natural state, without having been through a chemical or industrial process to remove unwanted parts; not refined:
examples: unrefined sugar

meanings.definition: not thinking carefully about something, or not showing careful thought:
examples: He argues that their unreflective, politically unaware outlook is typical of their generation.
Her writing is honest but surprisingly unreflective.

meanings.definition: not typical of how something actually is:
examples: He argued that the demonstrations were small and unreflective of local sentiments.

meanings.definition: (of a person or system) not changed or improved :
examples: Throwing money at unreformed public services is guaranteed to lead to waste.
He has been described as an unreformed autocrat.

meanings.definition: not kept cold in a fridge:
examples: Store, unrefrigerated, in a cool, dark place for up to 3 weeks.
Energy bars will keep all day unrefrigerated without any problem.

meanings.definition: (of a room or container) not kept at a very low temperature:
examples: Some foodstuffs are transported in unrefrigerated containers.
The sample deteriorated after it was stored in an unrefrigerated evidence room.

meanings.definition: not on an official list or record:
examples: He was stopped by police and found in possession of an unregistered firearm.
It's an area with a large number of unregistered voters.

meanings.definition: used to describe a person or organization that has not put information such as their name and address on an official list or record:
examples: State law allows police to take the vehicles of unlicensed and unregistered drivers.

meanings.definition: An unregulated type of business or activity is not controlled and directed by fixed rules or laws:
examples: Parents have the right to expect information to guide them through a growing, yet unregulated market (place).

meanings.definition: not controlled, esp. by laws, police, or a government department:
examples: Campaign finance reform is designed to prevent large, unregulated contributions to politicians.

meanings.definition: used to describe a type of business or activity that is not controlled and directed by rules or laws:
examples: Credit counseling has become a big and largely unregulated business in recent years.
A dozen firms currently operate in this completely unregulated market.
unregulated investments/loans/trading

meanings.definition: not practised or planned:
examples: The interviews appear to be unrehearsed.
He was forced to defend his policies in public and to answer unrehearsed questions from ordinary citizens.

meanings.definition: An unreinforced building is made of materials, such as bricks or concrete, that do not contain metal rods to make them stronger:
examples: Two people were killed when the two-story unreinforced brick structure collapsed.
Unreinforced masonry buildings are generally recognized as most likely to collapse in an earthquake.

meanings.definition: having no connection:
examples: Police said his death was unrelated to the attack.

meanings.definition: not having a connection:
examples: His answer was completely unrelated to my question.

meanings.definition: A person who is unrelated to you is not part of your family.
worried or not comfortable:
examples: He's still tense and unrelaxed around new people.
Her head and shoulders were unrelaxed.

meanings.definition: extremely determined; never becoming weaker or admitting defeat:
examples: She will be remembered as an unrelenting opponent of racial discrimination.

meanings.definition: extremely determined; never weakening or ending:
examples: unrelenting toughness/opposition
unrelenting neglect/pollution

meanings.definition: in a way that never becomes less or better:
examples: The film is utterly humourless and unrelentingly grim.
Trading conditions have remained unrelentingly tough.

meanings.definition: the quality of not being able to be trusted or believed:
examples: It is difficult to reconstruct exactly what happened because of the unreliability of witnesses.
He was starting to lose patience with her unreliability.

meanings.definition: not able to be trusted or believed:
examples: The bus service is unreliable.
unreliable evidence

meanings.definition: not to be trusted or depended on:
examples: Their carpenter was totally unreliable – he never finished the job.

meanings.definition: When a bad situation or emotion is unrelieved, it is continuous and never improves, not even for a short period:
examples: She held the family together through years of unrelieved poverty.

meanings.definition: in a way that is continuous and never improves:
examples: Voters' views of the Government are unrelievedly negative.
She does not disguise how unrelievedly grim life is for the villagers.

meanings.definition: willing to do something:
examples: He was an unreluctant hero who liked to tear open his shirt and show off his scars.
He leaves, taking the unreluctant Sara away with him.

meanings.definition: ordinary and not interesting:
examples: an unremarkable town

meanings.definition: in a way that is ordinary and not interesting:
examples: The second half of the match started unremarkably.
She was dressed unremarkably in a black sweater, black pants, and flat shoes.

meanings.definition: not remembered:
examples: Borglum, now largely unremembered, was responsible for the presidents' heads on Mount Rushmore.
She campaigned vociferously on behalf of a particular group of valiant but unremembered heroes.

meanings.definition: never stopping, becoming weaker, or failing:
examples: Our thanks are due to Bob Lawrence whose unremitting labours have ensured the success of the whole project.

meanings.definition: in a way that never improves or becomes less:
examples: The news appears to be unremittingly bad.
It was a cold night in late autumn and the rain lashed down unremittingly.

meanings.definition: not able to be removed:
examples: The offender wears an unremovable ankle monitor.
After being dismantled, it will leave behind in the ground an unremovable mass of concrete.

meanings.definition: An unrepeatable event, price, etc. cannot happen again:
examples: an unrepeatable offer/opportunity
an unrepeatable experience

meanings.definition: An unrepeatable word or remark used by another person is too rude or too difficult for you to repeat:
examples: an unrepeatable joke/name

meanings.definition: not repentant (= feeling sorry for something that you have done)
in a way that is not repentant (= feeling sorry for something bad you have done):
examples: She giggled unrepentantly.
She's an unrepentantly risqué entertainer.

meanings.definition: not reported to someone official, such as the police:
examples: These crimes often go unreported and don't show up in the police statistics.
Another key priority is addressing illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing.

meanings.definition: not reported on television, in newspapers, etc.:
examples: Many incidents go unreported in the national media.
The country is in the grip of an unreported humanitarian disaster.

meanings.definition: income that someone illegally does not include in their tax return (= document in which income is reported) because they are trying to avoid paying taxes:
examples: She owes $30,000 in unpaid taxes based on $100,000 of unreported income.

meanings.definition: not typical of a larger group of people or things; not representative
the fact of not being typical of a larger group of people or things:
examples: There is clear evidence of unrepresentativeness in the sample.
Polls have many flaws as measures of public opinion, such as the risk of unrepresentativeness.

meanings.definition: having no one to speak for you officially, for example in a law court or a parliament:
examples: Martins, who was unrepresented, was banned from driving and fined £200.
This left the voters of the state unrepresented in Washington until an election could be held.

meanings.definition: not present or not shown, especially as part of a group of people or things:
examples: We have been working to increase participation rates of students from a region which, by and large, has been unrepresented in university places.

meanings.definition: expressing your feelings freely, especially feelings that some people are embarrassed or ashamed to show:
examples: I was shocked at how outgoing, adventurous, and totally unrepressed the people were.
Children delight in the unrepressed and disgusting behaviour of others.

meanings.definition: (of feelings, thoughts, and qualities) expressed freely, without embarrassment or shame:
examples: He shouted out in unrepressed joy.
This figure is a blatant representation of unrepressed sexuality.

meanings.definition: If love that you feel for someone is unrequited, it is not felt in the same way by the other person:
examples: It's just another poem on the pain of unrequited love.

meanings.definition: (of love) felt toward someone who does not feel the same way toward you
without any doubts or feeling uncertain; total:
examples: Critics expressed unreserved enthusiasm for the book.

meanings.definition: An unreserved seat, ticket, etc. is not being kept for a particular person to use:
examples: I searched the pub for an unreserved table.

meanings.definition: completely, without any doubts or feeling of being uncertain:
examples: The paper's editor has apologized unreservedly to the senator.
Where there is corruption, this must be unreservedly condemned.

meanings.definition: (of a problem or disagreement) not able to be solved or ended:
examples: Generally, these kinds of problems rarely turn out to be unresolvable.
Civil wars are often the result of deep-rooted and seemingly unresolvable disagreements.

meanings.definition: If a problem or difficulty is unresolved, it is not solved or ended:
examples: The question of contracts remains unresolved.

meanings.definition: (esp. of a problem or difficulty) not solved or ended:
examples: The mayor’s race remains unresolved.

meanings.definition: not considered to be socially acceptable because of bad character, appearance, or behaviour:
examples: There was something glamorous and at the same time excitingly unrespectable about groups of artists living together.

meanings.definition: not reacting in a quick or positive way to something :
examples: Depression can make a new mother unresponsive to her baby.

meanings.definition: not reacting or moving at all because of being unconscious or very ill :
examples: The patient was collapsed and unresponsive when he was brought into hospital.

meanings.definition: not reacting or answering, or not reacting or answering satisfactorily:
examples: The company has been unresponsive to her efforts to discuss a settlement.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows no reaction to something:
examples: She listens unresponsively as her husband plans their return to Croatia.
She took his hand but he let it lie unresponsively in hers.

meanings.definition: the fact of not reacting to something or of not reacting in a quick or positive way :
examples: Customers expressed frustration at the bank's unresponsiveness to multiple inquiries.
Those who seek protection are frustrated by the unresponsiveness of state agencies.

meanings.definition: the fact of not reacting or moving at all because of being unconscious or very ill:
examples: After establishing unresponsiveness, which of the following actions should the nurse take first?

meanings.definition: disagreements or fighting between different groups of people:
examples: It is feared that the civil unrest we are now witnessing in this country could lead to full-scale civil war.

meanings.definition: disagreements or fighting between groups of people:
examples: civil/social/labor unrest
The president is cutting short an international trip because of growing unrest in his country.

meanings.definition: not calm and relaxed, or not making you feel calm and relaxed:
examples: The body and mind are both in an unrestful state, which affects everyone present.
The condition can cause insomnia, unrestful sleep, and daytime sleepiness.
This tension makes for an unrestful environment.

meanings.definition: If something old is unrestored, it has not been returned to an earlier better condition:
examples: an unrestored medieval fortress
This car is unrestored and in original 1964 condition.

meanings.definition: not limited or controlled:
examples: unrestrained joy/anger/criticism

meanings.definition: not limited in any way:
examples: unrestrained fury
unrestrained capitalism

meanings.definition: in a way that is not limited or controlled :
examples: Libby put her head down on the table and cried unrestrainedly.
She was unrestrainedly ambitious, cruel, and prone to screaming at her servants.

meanings.definition: not limited or controlled by rules or laws:
examples: The company allowed the reporters unrestricted access to data from around the time of the accident.

meanings.definition: not limited or controlled by rules or laws:
examples: A public library must allow the town's citizens unrestricted access to its resources.

meanings.definition: An unretouched picture, photograph, etc. has not been retouched (= had small changes made to improve it):
examples: We can tell you that the photo was unretouched.
I think people need to see the unretouched original images.

meanings.definition: An unreturnable ball in sports such as tennis is one that your opponent cannot hit back across the net:
examples: He took the game with a brilliant, unreturnable serve.
She unleashed a string of unreturnable shots.

meanings.definition: Something that is unreturnable cannot be returned:
examples: The warehouse contains hundreds of unclaimed and unreturnable packages.

meanings.definition: not revealed (= made known or shown):
examples: Some details are unrevealed.
An unrevealed number of staff have been disciplined.

meanings.definition: not giving any useful or interesting information, or not showing what you are thinking:
examples: There are a few interesting stories in her otherwise unrevealing autobiography.
His face was like a mask - hard and unrevealing.

meanings.definition: (of clothes) not showing more of the body than is usual:
examples: She chose to conceal herself in unrevealing clothes.

meanings.definition: An unreviewable decision or power cannot be questioned or considered again:
examples: This makes the governor's decision virtually unreviewable.
Local officials hold largely unreviewable powers to issue business licences.

meanings.definition: If something is unreviewed, it is not considered again in order to make changes to it or to give a new opinion on it:
examples: Properties had been allowed to run down, and rents had gone unreviewed.
The initial test result sat unreviewed by city officials for about two years.

meanings.definition: If a book, film, etc. is unreviewed, it has no reviews (= reports giving an opinion about it):
examples: Books in the field are mostly unreviewed and its discoveries are unreported.

meanings.definition: not changed, corrected, or considered again:
examples: This is an uncorrected, unrevised copy of the transcript.
GDP growth was unrevised from an initial estimate of 0.7 per cent.

meanings.definition: not involved in, typical of, or related to a political revolution (= a major change in the way a country is governed, often using violence):
examples: He was eventually denounced for unrevolutionary behaviour.

meanings.definition: not completely new or having a great effect:
examples: It's a fun but unrevolutionary game.

meanings.definition: If someone is unrewarded, they do not get anything in exchange for something they have done:
examples: Your hard work won't go unrewarded.
There are a lot of people whose actions go unrewarded and unrecognized.

meanings.definition: An unrewarding task does not give you any reward, such as making you feel satisfied that you have done something important or useful:
examples: It's a tough, unrewarding job.
The trip was exhausting, expensive, and ultimately unrewarding.

meanings.definition: Unrhetorical speech or writing is clear and simple, not rhetorical (= intended to seem important or to influence):
examples: There is a helpful and unrhetorical commentary accompanied by maps and other illustrations.

meanings.definition: Unrhymed poetry does not use words that rhyme (= have the same last sound):
examples: The narrative is written in unrhymed verse.
Haiku is a popular form of unrhymed Japanese poetry.

meanings.definition: not morally correct:
examples: How can we tell what are righteous and what are unrighteous things?
They believe that for man to be a sinner he must be ungodly and unrighteous.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not morally correct:
examples: I care nothing about being unpopular and unrighteously attacked for things I have not done.
Every man was arguing that his neighbours held the land unrighteously.

meanings.definition: (of food or crops) not yet ready to be eaten or collected; not yet ripe:
examples: Here are some ideas for what you can do with unripe green tomatoes.

meanings.definition: Unripened fruits or crops are not fully developed and ready to be eaten:
examples: There were crates of unripened tomatoes.
Green beans are the unripened fruit pods of various species of beans.

meanings.definition: Unripened cheese has not been left to develop its full flavour:
examples: This is a soft, unripened fresh cheese with a texture like yogurt.
The whey is drained and the curds are pressed - this is fresh or unripened cheese.

meanings.definition: having no equal; better than any other of the same type:
examples: The museum boasts an unrivaled collection of French porcelain.

meanings.definition: having no equal; better than any others:
examples: unrivaled beauty

meanings.definition: having no equal; better than any other of the same type:
examples: The museum boasts an unrivalled collection of French porcelain.

meanings.definition: to open and become flat from a rolled position, or to cause something to do this:
examples: She unrolled the most beautiful carpet.

meanings.definition: to open and become flat from a rolled position, or to cause something to do this:
examples: She unrolled a bolt of silk for us to look at.

past simple and past participle of 
        
         unroll
to open and become flat from a rolled position, or to cause something to do this:
examples: She unrolled the most beautiful carpet.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         unroll
to open and become flat from a rolled position, or to cause something to do this:
examples: She unrolled the most beautiful carpet.

meanings.definition: not doing things to show your love for your partner:
examples: He is rough and very unromantic and would prefer male company.

meanings.definition: not very exciting or special:
examples: I was given the unromantic job of weeding.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not typical of romantic love:
examples: I ask him to marry me, unromantically, one Monday night outside the pub.
When I unwrapped the ring he unromantically announced that we were getting married.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not exciting, mysterious, or special, but instead in a way that is practical or ordinary:
examples: The car is known rather unromantically as "chassis number 205".
Cavolo nero is often known here, somewhat unromantically, as black cabbage.

meanings.definition: not making something seem better than it really is:
examples: The show is an unromanticized account of the birth of a nation.
She is a walking treasury of Hollywood lore, much of it unromanticised.

meanings.definition: without a roof, either because a roof has not been built or because it has been destroyed:
examples: Part of the building was still unroofed, and in another section only the foundations had been laid.
The building has been unroofed for many years.

meanings.definition: calm; not nervous or worried, usually despite a difficult situation:
examples: For a man in danger of losing his job, he appeared fairly unruffled.

meanings.definition: Unruled paper does not have any lines across it:
examples: The book consists of large, white, unruled pages.
He used unruled exercise books as his notebooks.

meanings.definition: not governed or controlled:
examples: For many years they remained unruled.

meanings.definition: the quality of being difficult to control:
examples: He is a peaceful person who dislikes unruliness and disorder, and prefers calm.
It was not the unruliness of the pupils that drove her to quit.

meanings.definition: Unruly people are difficult to control and often do not obey rules:
examples: an unruly class of adolescents

meanings.definition: Unruly hair is difficult to keep tidy, often sticking up or out:
examples: an unruly mop of black hair

meanings.definition: difficult to control or manage:
examples: Her unruly behavior caused chaos in class.

meanings.definition: not done in a hurry, or not feeling that you must do something quickly:
examples: I got up in time to have an unrushed breakfast with my wife.
She got everything ready the night before - she wanted to be calm and unrushed in the morning.

meanings.definition: to take the saddle off a horse or to cause someone riding a horse to fall off

not safe
An unsafe conviction (= legal decision that someone is guilty) may be wrong because it is based on bad evidence:
examples: an unsafe conviction/verdict

meanings.definition: dangerous, or at risk:
examples: The bridge is closed because it’s unsafe.
Carol feels unsafe in planes.

meanings.definition: not said, although thought of or felt:
examples: I know she's put on weight, Michael, but some things are better left unsaid!

meanings.definition: not spoken, although thought of or felt:
examples: Some things are better left unsaid.

meanings.definition:
mainly US spelling of 
        
         unsaleable
working without payment, or done for no payment:
examples: All of the organization's officers are unsalaried and give their time on a voluntary basis.
She was paid briefly and then had a temporary, unsalaried position.

meanings.definition: paid for particular pieces of work, rather than being paid a regular fixed amount as an employee:
examples: The change would affect salaried as well as unsalaried employees.
He taught for fifteen years as an unsalaried lecturer.

meanings.definition: not easy to sell or not suitable for selling:
examples: The warehouses were full of unsaleable stock.
In areas where flood risk was high, homes became virtually unsaleable.

meanings.definition: If an idea or plan is unsaleable, it is not possible to persuade people that it is good and likely to be successful:
examples: His message may be unsaleable, but he will not be deterred.
It seems you consider her ideas to be correct but unsaleable.

meanings.definition: with no salt added:
examples: unsalted butter
unsalted nuts

meanings.definition: not able to be saved after being damaged or destroyed, or after failing:
examples: The boat was gutted and is unsalvageable.
Critics say the system is unsalvageable.

meanings.definition: not officially allowed or approved:
examples: Police detained several opposition leaders after an unsanctioned rally in the capital.
These players have taken part in an unsanctioned competition.

meanings.definition: not given a punishment, especially an official punishment:
examples: This does not mean that hate speech goes unsanctioned.
Drug use in sport can go unrecognized and unsanctioned over a long period.

meanings.definition: dirty or unhealthy and therefore likely to cause disease:
examples: unsanitary toilets
unsanitary living conditions

meanings.definition: dirty, esp. in a way that is dangerous to health:
examples: unsanitary conditions

meanings.definition: in a way that is not good enough:
examples: Prices for corn and soybeans have remained unsatisfactorily low for many farmers.
At the end of the novel, we are unsatisfactorily left to draw our own conclusions.

meanings.definition: not satisfactory
not good, or not good enough:
examples: Jacob’s answers were unsatisfactory.

meanings.definition: feeling that something is not enough or not good enough:
examples: After dinner he still felt unsatisfied.

meanings.definition: If you have an unsatisfied wish, you have not got what you wanted:
examples: There is unsatisfied demand for the product.
unsatisfied curiosity/desire

meanings.definition: not satisfying
Unsaturated fat or oil is either monounsaturated or polyunsaturated, found in plants, vegetable oil, and fish, and thought to be better for your health than saturated fat.
containing less of a substance than can be absorbed, and therefore not in a state of balance
used to describe a hydrocarbon in which the carbon atoms do not join as many hydrogen atoms as possible

Unsaturated also describes a hydrocarbon in which the carbon atoms do not join as many hydrogen atoms as possible.
unpleasant, or morally offensive:
examples: unsavory sexual practices
an unsavory reputation

meanings.definition: unpleasant or morally offensive:
examples: He has a history of unsavory business dealings.

meanings.definition: unpleasant, or morally offensive:
examples: unsavoury sexual practices
an unsavoury reputation

meanings.definition: Unsayable things should not be said because they are too shocking, rude, painful, etc.:
examples: He seems determined to say these unsayable things, in spite of the fact that it could be political suicide.
Some of the things that happened during the war are unsayable.

meanings.definition: not able to be climbed:
examples: The tower was unscalable from the outside.
The inner security zone was surrounded by a 3-metre-high unscalable fence.
They were trapped in an alley with unscaleable walls.

meanings.definition: not able to be successfully dealt with or controlled:
examples: Their one-nil lead suddenly looked like an unscalable barrier.
The political hurdles look unscalable.

meanings.definition: not able to be made larger in size, amount, or importance:
examples: Developers must assess the feasibility of using potentially unscalable technologies.
Renewable energy at that time was said to be too uncertain and too unscalable.

meanings.definition: (of skin) without a scar (= a mark left after an injury has healed) on it:
examples: The skin is then replaced with unscarred skin.
The light struck the unscarred side of his face.

meanings.definition: without any damage to a person's mental or emotional health, or not showing any damage of this kind:
examples: They have both experienced a great deal, and both have emerged not quite unscarred, but with their spirit intact.
He looked unscarred by his difficult childhood.

meanings.definition: (of a place) without any signs of physical destruction:
examples: The pictures present a world in which animals roam free in landscapes that are peaceful and unscarred.
This was a city relatively unscarred by war.

meanings.definition: without injuries or damage being caused:
examples: Her husband died in the accident but she, amazingly, escaped unscathed.

meanings.definition: without injuries or damage being caused:
examples: I came away from the accident unscathed, but the car got badly damaged.

meanings.definition: not having had any pleasant-smelling substances added to it:
examples: Even though a product is labeled "unscented," "hypoallergenic," or even "fragrance-free," it may still contain fragrances that could trigger a rash or allergic reaction.

meanings.definition: (of flowers) not having a sweet smell:
examples: The Spanish bluebell has unscented flowers borne all round the stem.

meanings.definition: not planned:
examples: The train made an unscheduled stop.
We may need to perform unscheduled maintenance.

meanings.definition: showing that someone has not studied a subject in a serious and detailed way:
examples: His unscholarly lack of precision leaves us wondering what he intends to say.
This generalization is simply unscholarly and inaccurate.

meanings.definition: not obeying scientific methods or principles:
examples: I carried out a highly unscientific study of several friends who had recently become parents.
My guess, although very unscientific, is that the project will take not less than a year but not more than two.
an unscientific account/claim/method

meanings.definition: in a way that does not obey scientific methods or principles :
examples: He was accused of unscientifically making experiments prove whatever he thought they should.
We polled a couple of thousand visitors to our website, very unscientifically I might add.

meanings.definition: to discover the meaning of information given in a secret or complicated way:
examples: You need a decoding device to unscramble some of the signals sent out by satellite and cable TV.

meanings.definition: Unscreened people or things have not been checked or tested to discover if anything is wrong or not wanted:
examples: These workers are untrained, unscreened, and unsupervised.
In these areas the disease was spreading through unscreened blood transfusions.

meanings.definition: An unscreened film or programme has not been shown or broadcast to the public:
examples: The documentary included unscreened film from his video diaries.
He directed the unscreened pilot of the show.

meanings.definition: not hidden, separated, or covered by a screen (= a vertical structure that is used to separate one area from another or to cover a door or window) :
examples: Prisoners shared cramped cells with an unscreened toilet.
The seats in these rows will be left unscreened.
In malarial areas, sleep in rooms with properly screened doors and windows - but if you are in an unscreened room, use a net impregnated with insecticide.

meanings.definition: with no checks or tests being done to discover if anything is wrong or not wanted:
examples: The men were able to pass unscreened through security checkpoints in several buildings.
The parasite passed unscreened through an aging water treatment plant.

examples: I can't unscrew the top of this jar - it's really tight.

meanings.definition: to remove something by taking the screws out of it
to remove the lid or top from something by twisting it, or to remove screws from something:
examples: Unscrew the gas cap.

An unscripted speech or broadcast has not been written before it is made.
not from or relating to the holy writings of a religion:
examples: They were concerned about a creeping acceptance of unscriptural practices.
He believed that this was a hideous and unscriptural doctrine.

meanings.definition: behaving in a way that is dishonest or unfair in order to get what you want:
examples: an unscrupulous financial adviser

meanings.definition: willing to lie or cheat to succeed:
examples: an unscrupulous salesman

meanings.definition: behaving in a way that is dishonest or unfair in order to get what you want:
examples: Counterfeit documents make it easier for unscrupulous employers to knowingly hire illegal workers.
We protect consumers by going after unscrupulous lenders or unscrupulous contractors or unscrupulous real estate agents.
unscrupulous businesses/companies/practices

meanings.definition: in a way that is dishonest or unfair, in order to get what you want :
examples: A very small number of medical practitioners unscrupulously exploit the system for financial reward.
He accused the media of unscrupulously trying to exploit this misfortune.

meanings.definition: If computer files are unsearchable, it is not possible to search for words, numbers, and other information in them. :
examples: Please note that the information you provide is entered into an unsearchable database.
The reports were posted on the internet as unsearchable PDF files.

meanings.definition: mysterious and impossible to understand:
examples: He gazed into the unsearchable abyss of her dark eyes.
The apostle spoke of the gospel as containing something that was unsearchable.

meanings.definition: not usual or expected for the time of year:
examples: When you're used to snow in January, warm sunny weather feels unseasonable.

meanings.definition: (of weather) not usual for the time of year:
examples: We had an unseasonable warm spell in January.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not usual or expected for the time of year:
examples: unseasonably warm weather
The weather was unseasonably cold most of the week.
unseasonally heavy snow

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         unseasonable  :
examples: unseasonal weather

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         unseasonably
Unseasoned food has not had salt, pepper, herbs, or spices added to it:
examples: Add the unseasoned breadcrumbs.
Add salt if you use unseasoned chicken stock.

meanings.definition: Unseasoned wood has not been left to dry in the usual way before being used:
examples: He makes sculptures of unseasoned wood.
The use of green, unseasoned timber is thought to be a reason for the church's crooked spire.

meanings.definition: An unseasoned iron pan has not been protected with oil:
examples: Rusting is common in unseasoned cast iron pans.
You can buy unseasoned, "bare" cast iron cookware.

meanings.definition: not having a lot of experience of doing something and therefore not knowing how to do it well:
examples: Only an unseasoned editor would want to work in this way.
These judgments are extremely difficult for the unseasoned investor.

meanings.definition: to remove someone from power, especially as a result of an election:
examples: The opposition candidate failed by only 39 votes to unseat the cabinet minister.

meanings.definition: If a horse unseats its rider, it throws them from its back.
to remove someone from a powerful job, esp. a job to which a person is elected:
examples: She has a good chance to unseat the governor.

meanings.definition:

to remove someone from power, especially as a result of an election:
examples: The opposition candidate failed by only 39 votes to unseat the cabinet minister.

meanings.definition: If a horse unseats its rider, it throws them from its back.
