         unseat
to remove someone from power, especially as a result of an election:
examples: The opposition candidate failed by only 39 votes to unseat the cabinet minister.

meanings.definition: If a horse unseats its rider, it throws them from its back.
(of a ship) in a condition that is not good enough for it to travel safely on the sea
relating to a loan (= an amount of money that is lent) for which the person who has lent the money has no right to take property from the person who has borrowed it, if the money is not paid back:
examples: With an unsecured loan you do not offer your home as security and it is therefore a popular form of borrowing among consumers.

meanings.definition: not made safe; not protected from danger or risk:
examples: According to the insurance company's report, the garage door had been left unsecured.

meanings.definition: relating to a loan for which the lender has no right to the property or other assets of the borrower if the money is not paid back:
examples: While we may request security for your loan, it can be unsecured.
Total unsecured borrowing has increased by 60% over the past year.

meanings.definition: loans for which the lender has no right to the property or other assets of the borrower if the money is not paid back:
examples: The bank has had a 50% increase in unsecured credit deals over the past three years.

meanings.definition: a person or organization that has lent money and has no right to the property or other assets of the borrower if the money is not paid back:
examples: Following the bankruptcy, it's too early to say if anything will be left for unsecured creditors.

meanings.definition: debt for which the lender has no right to the property or other assets of the borrower if the debt is not paid:
examples: The total level of unsecured debt per household stands just short of $6900.

meanings.definition: a loan for which the lender has no right to the property or other assets of the borrower if the money is not paid back:
examples: They will offer unsecured loans to anyone over 22 with comprehensive motor insurance.

meanings.definition: notes (= a type of loan) for which the lender has no right to the property or other assets of the borrower if the money is not paid back:
examples: They are in default on $45.2 million in unsecured notes owed to the life insurance company.

meanings.definition: to return to a situation in which you have not seen something:
examples: Once you have seen something, you can't unsee it.

meanings.definition: not seeded in a tennis competition
(especially of eyes) not seeing or noticing anything, although able to see:
examples: Bored out of its mind, the monkey stares out of the cage with unseeing eyes.

meanings.definition: the quality or fact of not being seemly (= socially suitable and polite):
examples: The unseemliness of your conduct is inexcusable.
He became ashamed of the unseemliness of his appearance.

meanings.definition: not seemly (= socially suitable and polite)
not suitable or polite:
examples: unseemly language
unseemly haste
unseemly behavior

meanings.definition: not seen or not able to be seen:
examples: She found the side-door open and slipped into the house unseen.
Unseen birds sang in the trees above us.

meanings.definition: not broadcast, published, or shown to the public before now:
examples: The authorities released previously unseen footage of the attacks.
The documentary contains incredible footage - much of it previously unseen.
Among the items on show are previously unseen photographs from the Hollywood star's childhood.
The new book reveals unseen photos of the pioneering punk rockers over the years.

meanings.definition: not seen or not able to be seen:
examples: She found the door open and slipped into the house unseen.

meanings.definition: not having different parts, or not divided into different parts:
examples: This is a microscopic animal with an unsegmented body.
The segmentation task involved separating unsegmented items (e.g. "deskmotherbat") into their component words.

meanings.definition: not intentionally choosing some things instead of others :
examples: Trawling is an efficient but highly unselective way of catching fish.
Medical radiation treatment is unselective: the rays damage all the tissue in their path.

meanings.definition: An unselective school, college, or university is one that students can go to without passing an examination:
examples: She said there was no evidence that selective schools produced better results than schools that were unselective.
I prefer the unselective small colleges that are inclusive rather than exclusive.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not involve intentionally choosing some things or people instead of others:
examples: The cattle grazed relatively unselectively, consuming large mouthfuls of grass.
In some places these services were provided unselectively to anyone who met minimum eligibility criteria.

meanings.definition: not worried about other people's opinions of you, about doing things in a particular way, or about being impressive:
examples: He danced with unselfconscious abandon.
The woman sits quite still and unself-conscious, her hands cradling the book.
The author evokes the little girl's un-self-conscious joy.

meanings.definition: without worrying about other people's opinions of you, about doing things in a particular way, or about being impressive:
examples: He squatted unselfconsciously in the mud.
She danced unself-consciously, beaming throughout.
They sit around quite easily and un-self-consciously in their old clothes.

meanings.definition: behaviour that shows you are not worried about other people's opinions of you, about doing things in a particular way, or about being impressive:
examples: Singing requires confidence and unselfconsciousness.
The performers' deft timing, unself-consciousness, and individuality make the performance a resounding success.
He has a laid-back un-self-consciousness that comes from growing up the way he did.

meanings.definition: An unselfish person thinks about what is good for other people, not just about their own advantage.
caring about or generous toward others:
examples: He’s an unselfish player who puts team goals first.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows you are thinking about what is good for other people rather than yourself:
examples: The award recognizes citizens who have worked unselfishly for the community.
"You choose," she said unselfishly.

meanings.definition: the quality or fact of thinking about what is good for other people rather than yourself:
examples: She will be remembered with immense fondness for her unselfishness, integrity, and humour.
One of his strengths as a player was his unselfishness.

meanings.definition: impossible to sell or not suitable for selling:
examples: The warehouse was full of unsellable goods.
The house is quite unsellable.

meanings.definition: If an idea or plan is unsellable, it is not possible to persuade people that it is good and likely to be successful:
examples: Politicians were unwilling to defend the tax, believing that it would be unsellable to voters.
Getting the public to send its soldiers to police this civil war is simply unsellable.

meanings.definition: intentionally not giving information in a way that is shocking or exciting, especially in books, newspapers, movies, etc.:
examples: This is a sober, largely unsensational account of the two gangs.
Although the book deals with scandal and excess, the tone is unsensational.

meanings.definition: not extremely good, exciting, or unusual:
examples: The rise in wages has been unsensational.
No one was interested in my (unsensational) thoughts on the poem.

meanings.definition: An unsensitized organism has not been treated in order to make it likely to react to a substance:
examples: The unsensitised particles did not show any reaction with the sera.
The cells were either sensitized with the antigen or were unsensitized (control) cells.
unsensitized mice

A respiratory sensitizer is a substance in the air that can cause someone's respiratory system to develop a condition that makes them over-react if the substance is inhaled again, even in amounts that have no effect on unsensitized people.

meanings.definition: An unsent letter, email, etc. has not been sent:
examples: He drafted the letter, but it remained unsent.
The software also monitored unsent emails.

meanings.definition: not influenced by emotions or not giving too much importance to emotions, especially love or sadness:
examples: They have an unsentimental approach to life.
Her reminiscences of her impoverished childhood are vivid and unsentimental.

meanings.definition: not having been separated or divided:
examples: This is a sponge cake made with well-beaten unseparated eggs.
The new waste processing plant will take in 100,000 tonnes of unseparated waste a year.

meanings.definition: not considered important or worth respect:
examples: He tends to portray anything he dislikes as unserious and worthy of scorn.
Both writers were dismissed as unserious by the literati of their day.

meanings.definition: not intending to achieve something or not working hard to achieve something:
examples: The government's refusal to restructure the rail industry showed how unserious it was about transport.
He was unserious in college, in spite of having a first-class intellect.

meanings.definition: intended to be funny, happy, or enjoyable, rather than serious:
examples: He is the author of these happy unserious poems.
Hawaiian shirts are probably the most unserious shirts you can wear.

meanings.definition: not bad or not having a severe effect:
examples: He left the field with an "unserious" ankle injury.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being serious about achieving something:
examples: Their position is hard to defend, and suggests unseriousness or even apathy.
They accuse political leaders of wilful unseriousness on national issues.

meanings.definition: the fact of being funny, happy, or enjoyable, rather than being important or deserving respect:
examples: Don't let our unseriousness mislead you - this is a serious topic.
They were offended by the film industry's unseriousness, by its capacity to entertain without edifying.

meanings.definition: If people or areas are unserved, something that people need has not been provided in these areas:
examples: A huge proportion of the population is still unserved.
Many of the banks closed their smaller branches, leaving communities unserved.

meanings.definition: Unserved food or drink has not been given to people, for example by putting it on plates or in cups:
examples: After the event, unserved food is taken to food banks and homeless shelters.
We recover perishable and unserved foods and deliver them to soup kitchens and crisis centrescentres.

meanings.definition: If a legal document or order is unserved, or if the person affected by it is unserved, the person has not received the legal document or order:
examples: The audit found that a large number of arrest warrants were going unserved.
They said they did not represent the unserved defendants.

meanings.definition: If time is unserved, it has not been spent as a prisoner or working in an organization or system:
examples: The remaining unserved sentence was commuted to time served.
Under this system, foster children worked unpaid for their foster parents, and could leave only if the foster parents were paid compensation for each unserved year.

meanings.definition: If a female animal is unserved, a male animal has not had sex with it. :
examples: The heifer was unserved.

meanings.definition: not suitable for use or not in good condition:
examples: Many of the boats were old and unserviceable.
The rebels handed over old and unserviceable arms to UN forces.

meanings.definition: Unserviceable debt cannot be paid:
examples: We were accumulating unserviceable debt.
They warned that the debt burden would become unserviceable and implode.

meanings.definition: (of a precious stone such as a diamond) not fixed to a piece of jewellery:
examples: She had received a generous gift of a number of unset emeralds, two of which were later made into earrings.

meanings.definition: not having become firm or hard:
examples: Top up the mould with the rest of the berries and unset jelly.
She disliked the egg white being unset and runny.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel anxious or slightly worried :
examples: Even the most experienced batsmen were unsettled by the speed of this bowler.

meanings.definition: to make something change, in a way that makes it more difficult to know what will happen:
examples: The legislation doesn't appear to have unsettled daily life in Santa Fe.
The airline's decision to cut air fares is likely to unsettle the market.

meanings.definition: likely to change suddenly; not calm or having a regular pattern:
examples: a period of unsettled weather
an unsettled political climate

meanings.definition: nervous and worried; unable to relax:
examples: Children tend to get unsettled if you continually change their routine.

meanings.definition: tending to change suddenly; not having a regular pattern:
examples: Things are unsettled in the state’s political arena.
The forecast is for unsettled weather, with more snow to come.

meanings.definition: anxious and worried; unable to relax:
examples: She was feeling unsettled the entire morning before her interview.

meanings.definition: causing change
causing worry or anxiety:
examples: One of the documentary's many unsettling images is of a child playing with her father's gun.

meanings.definition: that causes sudden, unexpected changes:
examples: A rise in unemployment has an unsettling effect on the stock market.

meanings.definition: making you feel anxious and worried:
examples: I received the unsettling news that I may lose my job next month.

meanings.definition: in a way that causes someone to feel worried or uncomfortable:
examples: The baby seals face continual danger, from jackals, sharks and, most unsettlingly, humans.
Experts say the housing market is unsettlingly quiet in some areas.

meanings.definition: not encouraging sexual feelings, not related to sexual activity, or not sexually attractive:
examples: Most people think cardigans are unsexy.
The show deals with unsexy issues like menopause.

meanings.definition: not interesting or exciting:
examples: Sanitation is unsexy - it's not glamorous, and people don't want to talk about it.
They are the richest, stupidest, and unsexiest family in the city.

meanings.definition: without a covering that stops direct light from reaching something:
examples: The windows were unshaded and the sun streamed in.
She was sitting in the unshaded area by the pool.

meanings.definition: not coloured darker than, or in a different way to, other parts of a picture, painting or diagram (= a simple plan that represents a machine, system, or idea, etc., often drawn to explain how it works):
examples: The unshaded areas represent the abnormal results.
Very few parts of the chart were left unshaded.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         unshakeable

mainly US spelling of
        
         unshakeably
If someone's trust or belief is unshakeable, it is firm and cannot be made weaker or destroyed:
examples: She was blessed with an unshakeable belief in her own abilities.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows a firm belief that cannot be made weaker or destroyed :
examples: He remains unshakeably convinced that he is right.
They believed unshakeably that the two countries should stand together.

meanings.definition: If a feeling, idea, or belief is unshaken, it has not become weaker:
examples: She insists that her resolve is unshaken.
His religious faith remained unshaken.

meanings.definition: not shocked or upset by an unpleasant experience:
examples: Unshaken, she went on to win the game convincingly.
He landed by parachute and returned that evening, slightly injured but unshaken.

meanings.definition: not having an attractive shape or form:
examples: They thought that skinny and unshapely legs were not as sexy as curvy legs.
She wore unshapely denims.

meanings.definition: not owned, divided, felt, or experienced by more than one person:
examples: We had very few unshared possessions; it was rare to have anything of my own.
They are middle-age people with a lot of unshared history.

meanings.definition: not published or made known to other people:
examples: Shared links are far more valuable to advertisers than unshared ones.

meanings.definition: not having had the hair removed:
examples: an unshaven chin/man

meanings.definition: Unshelled nuts and other foods have not had their hard outer covering removed:
examples: Unshelled nuts keep longer than shelled nuts.
Parboil the unshelled beans until they are bright green.

meanings.definition: If someone is unshockable, it is difficult or impossible to shock or offend them:
examples: Most doctors are unshockable.
He's completely unshockable.

meanings.definition: A sheep or other animal that is unshorn has not had its wool or hair cut off:
examples: The sheep were left unshorn in this study.
Shorn and unshorn animals were divided for the trial.

meanings.definition: If someone is unshorn, their hair has not been cut. :
examples: His eyes were bloodshot and he was unshorn.
He was ragged and unshorn.

meanings.definition: Unshorn hair or wool has not been cut off:
examples: In Sikhism, unshorn hair is a symbol of spiritualism.
unshorn fleeces

meanings.definition: not too obvious or extreme, and not intentionally attracting attention or admiration:
examples: Their wedding was a refreshingly unshowy event.
In conversation he is warm but unshowy.

meanings.definition: not attractive; ugly:
examples: He had undone the buttons of his shirt, exposing an unsightly expanse of white flesh.

meanings.definition: not pleasing to see; unattractive:
examples: The garden was full of unsightly weeds.

meanings.definition: (of a letter, painting, etc.) with no name or signature on it, saying who has written or painted it:
examples: an unsigned portrait in oil of an army officer
The cheque was unsigned.

meanings.definition: not having signed a contract (= a legal document stating a formal agreement) of employment:
examples: There are still a handful of players who remain unsigned for next season.
It's a weekly radio show that gives the best unsigned musicians the airplay that they deserve.

meanings.definition: If a ship or a boat is unsinkable, it cannot be sunk:
examples: An iceberg sank the "Titanic" - a ship they claimed was unsinkable.

meanings.definition: full of energy and enthusiasm, and not able to be defeated or to fail:
examples: She was staying with her grandmother, the unsinkable Olga.

meanings.definition: Unsized material, especially paper or cloth, has not been treated with size (= a substance like glue that makes the material stiff and gives it a hard, shiny surface):
examples: Newsprint is unsized, low-quality paper for printing newspapers.
She developed a technique of soaking and staining raw, unsized canvas.

meanings.definition: If something is unsized, its measurements are unknown or have not been given, or have not been changed:
examples: The kimono is unsized.
an unsized circuit

meanings.definition: not good at doing something, or lacking skills generally:
examples: Unfortunately, they made a couple of unskilful moves that played directly into the hands of their opponents.
The drivers are adventurous and even aggressive, but not unskilful.

meanings.definition: in a way that lacks skill:
examples: Unlike your predecessors who lied so effectively, you lie very unskilfully.
The surgery had been performed so unskillfully that she had to have a second operation.

meanings.definition: Unskilled people have no particular work skills, and unskilled work does not need any particular skills:
examples: unskilled workers
unskilled labour/work/jobs

meanings.definition: (of people) without any particular work skills, or (of work) not needing any particular skills:
examples: Unskilled workers may lose their jobs.

meanings.definition: used to describe people who have no particular work skills:
examples: Businesses such as restaurants are dependent on lower-paid, unskilled employees.
The workforce was largely unskilled at relatively low pay levels.

meanings.definition: used to describe work that does not need any particular skills:
examples: The hundreds of assembly jobs at the plant are mostly unskilled.
Unskilled manual jobs no longer support a family, like they did in the 1950s.
The jobs that required unskilled labor could be filled more cheaply overseas.

meanings.definition: not good at doing something, or lacking skills generally:
examples: Unfortunately, they made a couple of unskillful moves that played directly into the hands of their opponents.
The drivers are adventurous and even aggressive, but not unskillful.

meanings.definition: in a way that lacks skill:
examples: Unlike your predecessors who lied so effectively, you lie very unskillfully.
The surgery had been performed so unskillfully that she had to have a second operation.

meanings.definition: An unslakable feeling of being thirsty, or of wanting something, cannot be satisfied:
examples: His thirst was unslakable and he was sleeping up to 16 hours a day.
What is remarkable about her is not the sheer number of records she holds, but her unslakeable appetite for more.

meanings.definition: If someone's feeling of wanting something is unslaked, they have not stopped wanting it:
examples: The public thirst for information will continue unslaked.
His appetite for gossip is completely unslaked.

meanings.definition: Unslaked lime (= a white chemical substance) has not been treated with water to produce a different chemical (calcium hydroxide):
examples: Unslaked lime (CaO) was produced by heating limestone at high temperatures.
Unslaked fragments of shell are saved for the next batch.

meanings.definition: not sliced:
examples: unsliced bread

meanings.definition: seeming to involve a lot of effort, problems, or untidiness:
examples: The final result is pleasingly unslick, as though they did not want to be seen to be trying too hard.
The farmer runs a decidedly unslick operation - the truck used for transporting the grain has no brakes.

meanings.definition: (of a person) sincere and honest rather than very skilful and impressive:
examples: He's so unslick - he's not that interested in being a great entertainer - and that's why so many other comedians love him.

meanings.definition: not done in an intelligent way:
examples: Backing losers was unsmart business.
This is a pretty unsmart investment at present.

meanings.definition: not looking clean and stylish, or not attracting stylish people:
examples: The street was full of cheap, unsmart cafés.
Although caravanning does not have a good image now, it was not always so unsmart.

meanings.definition: not able to be connected to the internet or not having features that a computer has:
examples: My phone is a very old, unsmart mobile.

meanings.definition: not smiling:
examples: The officers in the old photo are lined up stiff, straight, and unsmiling.

meanings.definition: An unsmoothed surface is rough or irregular, rather than having been made smooth or regular:
examples: The edges were left unsmoothed.
The structure was covered with stones and sealed with a thick layer of unsmoothed stucco.

meanings.definition: based on average values or amounts, rather than on unexplained or unexpected values or amounts that are considered less important:
examples: The data (smoothed or unsmoothed) suggest a fairly regular pattern.
The means were then smoothed, although we also plotted unsmoothed means.

meanings.definition: not liking to meet people or to spend time with them

→ 
        
         unsocial
in a way that shows someone does not like to meet people or spend time with them:
examples: She was an unsociably solemn child who found it difficult to make friends.
They stood unsociably far apart, not looking at each other.

meanings.definition: happening at unusual times, for example very early or very late :
examples: A hotel stay the night before an unsociably early flight gives you a head start on your holiday.
There are concerns that this change may lead to unsociably early start-times.

meanings.definition: happening during the days of the week or hours of the day when most people do not have to work:
examples: I don't want to work unsocial hours.

meanings.definition: used to describe the hours during which most people are not working:
examples: Overtime payments help to compensate for low basic pay and unsocial hours.

meanings.definition: not made dirty by something:
examples: It is possible to recycle the unsoiled part of your pizza box.
The aim is for the patient's clothes and furnishings to remain dry and unsoiled.

meanings.definition: not damaged or affected by something bad:
examples: I neither smoked nor drank - I stayed unsoiled.
The image presented is of a pure and unsoiled culture.

meanings.definition: not sold:
examples: stocks of unsold goods

meanings.definition: not sold, or not yet sold:
examples: unsold inventory/goods/stock
unsold cars/holidays/homes
Thousands of tickets remain unsold.

meanings.definition: the value of shares that have not been sold at the end of the period when they are offered for sale:
examples: The group reported an unsold balance of $9.7 million.

meanings.definition: not typical of a soldier or not suitable for a soldier:
examples: He was the most unsoldierly soldier you could imagine.
Hesitancy was deemed an unsoldierly trait.

meanings.definition: not asked for:
examples: unsolicited advice

meanings.definition: not asked for:
examples: The proposed law would force senders of unsolicited e-mail to provide a valid return address.

meanings.definition: not asked for, and sometimes not wanted:
examples: Last week, they launched an unsolicited $1.23 billion takeover bid to buy the company.
Never purchase anything advertised through an unsolicited email.

meanings.definition: an offer to buy a company or property that its owners did not ask for:
examples: They made an unsolicited offer of $3.3 billion.

meanings.definition: If a problem, difficulty, or mystery is unsolvable, it is not possible to find a solution to it or the cause of it:
examples: Without further funds, this is an almost unsolvable problem.
Some of the crimes were deemed unsolvable.

meanings.definition: that has not been solved:
examples: an unsolved mystery

meanings.definition: not solved or explained:
examples: The detective has spent seven years investigating the unsolved crime.

meanings.definition: not complicated, or not showing a good understanding of culture and fashion; not sophisticated
not complicated, not educated, or without a good understanding of culture:
examples: He’s an unsophisticated man, but he has been very successful in business.

meanings.definition: the quality of being unsophisticated (= not complicated, or not having a good understanding of the way people behave, or a good knowledge of culture and fashion) :
examples: He invented the persona partly to mask his lack of education and his youthful unsophistication.
Sweet foods are often associated with unsophistication, lack of self-control, and obesity.

meanings.definition: Things that are unsorted have not been separated into groups or put into the right order:
examples: The materials are delivered unsorted to recycling facilities.
They handed over some unsorted documents.

meanings.definition: If a problem is unsorted, it has not been dealt with in a satisfactory way:
examples: She would never discuss disagreements or criticism, so any problems were left unsorted - there couldn't ever be any closure.

meanings.definition: If a person's activities or judgment are unsound, they are not good enough, acceptable, or able to be trusted:
examples: unsound accounting practices
unsound police evidence

meanings.definition: If a building or other structure is unsound, it is in bad condition and likely to fall down or fail:
examples: The bridge is one of several said to be structurally unsound.

meanings.definition: (esp. of activities) not suitable or acceptable:
examples: He was involved in unsound banking practices.

meanings.definition: (esp. of a building) in bad condition and likely to fall down or fail:
examples: The bridge is structurally unsound.

meanings.definition: not said aloud or not making a noise that can be heard:
examples: The post-vowel written r is unsounded in many British accents.
The bass fills in the unsounded beats so that there is a call and response between the two instruments.

meanings.definition: too extreme to be measured, understood, or discovered:
examples: On the surface, the characters give away very little, although they all reveal unsounded depths as the film progresses.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being good enough, acceptable, or able to be trusted:
examples: The company's financial unsoundness had been hidden from the shareholders.
The unsoundness of this assumption has already been pointed out.

meanings.definition: If a writer or speaker supplies unsourced information, they do not say where the information comes from:
examples: The article was based on an unsourced story.
Much of the detail in this volume is anecdotal and unsourced.

meanings.definition: If land is unsown, or if seeds are unsown, seeds have not been put in or on the ground:
examples: Farmers were encouraged to plough land and leave it unsown.
The plots were weeded to control unsown species.

meanings.definition: showing no kindness and no wish to hide the unpleasant truth:
examples: The documentary went through all the graphic details of the operation in unsparing detail.

meanings.definition: extremely generous with money, time, help, etc.:
examples: Last of all, our thanks go to the caterers who have been unsparing in their efforts to make this afternoon such a success.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows no kindness or no wish to hide unpleasant truths :
examples: He is unsparingly honest in everything he writes.
Miller's photographs unsparingly addressed the destruction and death she had witnessed.

meanings.definition: in a way that is extremely generous with money, time, help, etc. :
examples: I am very greatly indebted to you for the help you gave so unsparingly.
He devoted himself unsparingly to the care of the sick.
She gave unsparingly of her time and energy in order to help her community.

meanings.definition: An unspayed female animal has not had its ovaries (= the parts that produce eggs) removed:
examples: Ovarian tumours are occasionally seen in unspayed female dogs and cats.

meanings.definition: too bad or shocking to be expressed in words:
examples: unspeakable crimes
No report can convey the unspeakable suffering that this war has caused.
The stench coming from the toilets was unspeakable.

meanings.definition: too bad or shocking to be described or expressed:
examples: unspeakable crimes

meanings.definition: in a way that cannot be expressed in words, usually because it is too bad or shocking:
examples: The room was unspeakably dirty.
He described fox hunting as unspeakably cruel.

meanings.definition: not having developed particular characteristics:
examples: Stem cells are immature, unspecialized cells that can be manipulated to grow into any number of specialized cells.
Many rainforest plants have retained relatively unspecialized pollination mechanisms.

meanings.definition: not being an expert in one particular area of work or knowledge:
examples: Most of the workers are relatively unspecialized labourers.

meanings.definition: not relating to or involving one particular subject, skill, service, etc.:
examples: These publications are unspecialized.
The firm needed workers who would be ready to undertake any kind of unspecialized work.

meanings.definition: If something is unspecifiable, it is not possible to say exactly what it is or to describe it exactly:
examples: The items had been in the town's possession from a fairly early, but unspecifiable, date.
Her accent was hard to identify - it was eastern European, but otherwise unspecifiable.

meanings.definition: not clear or exact, or not relating to one particular thing:
examples: Diagnosis is difficult because the signs and symptoms are unspecific.
He made vague and unspecific accusations.
She talked at length about the problems, but was unspecific about solutions.

meanings.definition: If something is unspecified, you are not told what it is:
examples: The court awarded her an unspecified amount of money.

meanings.definition: not stated or described in detail:
examples: The company was sold for an unspecified amount.

meanings.definition: damages (= money paid for harming someone) where the amount of money is not stated or known:
examples: He asked to be reinstated, and is also seeking unspecified damages for defamation.

meanings.definition: not particularly good or great, and not causing much admiration or excitement:
examples: He ran a solid, if unspectacular, operation.
Her progress was steady but unspectacular.
The result is thoroughly unspectacular.

meanings.definition: Unspent money has not been used to pay for something:
examples: Millions have disappeared in unspent funds.
Much of the money remains unspent.

meanings.definition: If someone has an unspent conviction (= legal decision that they are guilty of a crime), the fact that they are guilty remains officially important:
examples: Potential employees are asked whether they have any unspent convictions.
Individuals with unspent criminal convictions would find it difficult to gain citizenship.

meanings.definition: Unspent energy or fuel has not yet been used:
examples: The athletes were bursting with unspent energy.
The unspent fuel would be a hazard.

meanings.definition: Unspent ammunition, such as bullets or bombs, has not been fired or has not exploded:
examples: The army collected unspent ammunition from the rubble and defused unexploded shells.
When they were shelled by anti-tank guns, they tossed the unspent shells overboard.

meanings.definition: lacking spirituality (= the quality that involves deep feelings and beliefs, especially religious beliefs, rather than the physical parts of life):
examples: He claims that existentialism is not an unspiritual philosophy.
They consider competitive sports to be unspiritual.

meanings.definition: not cut apart or not cut open:
examples: He picked up the axe and looked at the unsplit wood.
Split the aubergines lengthwise, but leave 2 cm unsplit at each end.

meanings.definition: not divided into separate parts:
examples: After the demerger, one company will be a quarter of the size of its sister company, but will carry almost half the debt of the unsplit company.

meanings.definition: An unspoiled place is beautiful because it has not been changed or damaged by people:
examples: an island with clean, unspoiled beaches
There are miles of unspoilt coastline and moors to explore.

meanings.definition: Something that is unspoiled by another thing has not been badly affected by it:
examples: These were the good old days, still unspoiled by materialism and television.

meanings.definition: An unspoiled person does not behave as if they can do or have whatever they want without paying attention to other people's feelings, but thinks about others and shows them respect:
examples: The parents from North Jersey wanted help on how to raise unspoiled children in the affluent world they inhabit.
The children are delightful and unspoilt.
After years of fame, she remains unaffected, unspoilt, modest, and generous.

meanings.definition:
mainly UK spelling of
        
         unspoiled
not spoken, although thought of or felt:
examples: unspoken doubts/fears
There's an unspoken assumption in the department that Sue will take over the post when Dan leaves.

meanings.definition: not stated, although thought, understood, or felt:
examples: We have an unspoken agreement to share the housework.

meanings.definition: If something that is wrapped tightly around itself unspools, or someone unspools it, it becomes or is made straight:
examples: The fishing line got caught on my glove as it was unspooling.
The records were destroyed when staff tried to unspool the rolls of film.

meanings.definition: When a film unspools, or someone unspools it, it is shown on a screen:
examples: This autumn, film adaptations of the two novels will unspool in cinemas.
An open-air screen on the public beach unspools old Hollywood classics each evening.

meanings.definition: When a story or an event unspools, or someone unspools it, it develops or becomes known to people:
examples: Her new novel unspools deep in the English Lake District.
The plot unspools slowly, over several different timelines.
I think I have unspooled my rambling thoughts enough for one day.
They will wait to see how the legal battle unspools before taking a decision.

meanings.definition: to become, or to make something become, less strong or less under control:
examples: Our carefully laid plans to get fit are starting to unspool in the face of chocolate cake and back-to-work stress.
As his biography shows, alcohol did unspool his mind a bit at the end.

meanings.definition: the action of something that was wrapped tightly around itself becoming straight:
examples: An acoustic signal from the fishing boat triggers the unspooling of the fishing line.

meanings.definition: the act of showing a film on a screen:
examples: "The Ten Commandments," half a century after its creation, still gets a regular prime-time network unspooling.

meanings.definition: the act of a story or an event developing, or becoming or being made known:
examples: The novel is more than another unspooling of life in the Hollywood shark-tank.
Her grandmother's reaction to that telephone call sparked the gradual unspooling of a long-held family secret.

meanings.definition: the process of something becoming less strong or less under control:
examples: Pinter's play charts the unspooling of a relationship.
The diaries document the unspooling of his sense of identity.

meanings.definition: not sporting (= showing fairness and respect, especially to opposing teams or players)
not showing fairness or respect to other people, especially towards the opposing team or player when playing sport :
examples: The coach disciplined the player for unsportsmanlike conduct and made him sit on the bench.
He was the only athlete ever to be disqualified from this championship for unsportsmanlike behaviour.
The illegal hold was seen as unsportsmanlike and dangerous.
Being a bad loser is unsportsmanlike.

meanings.definition: Unsprayed areas or crops have not had chemicals spread over them in small drops:
examples: Field margins were left unsprayed.
They sell their beautiful unsprayed peaches at the local market.

meanings.definition: not solid and firm and therefore not strong, safe, or likely to last:
examples: That chair looks unstable to me.
It is a poor and politically unstable society.

meanings.definition: An unstable person suffers from sudden and extreme changes in their mental and emotional state:
examples: emotionally unstable

meanings.definition: not firm and therefore not strong, safe, or likely to last:
examples: It is a poor and politically unstable country.

meanings.definition: An unstable person suffers from sudden and extreme changes of mental state:
examples: He’s emotionally unstable – you never know how he’ll react.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not firm or firmly fixed, and is likely to move or change :
examples: He remained standing unstably on the upper deck of the bus, looking back at her.
The guidelines relate to health care delivery to unstably housed individuals.

meanings.definition: without any dirty marks:
examples: The mug was unstained.
He found an unstained cloth.

meanings.definition: not having had the colour changed by a chemical being added:
examples: The larvae were studied using both stained and unstained specimens.
Viable cells remained unstained.

meanings.definition: If someone has an unstained reputation, it has not been spoiled or damaged, and people's opinion of the person continues to be good:
examples: The previous chairman left with an unstained reputation.
He emerged largely unstained by the scandal, but promised to improve his firm's procedures.

meanings.definition: not influenced by something bad, and remaining morally good:
examples: He remained unstained and unsullied in an evil world.
Their grandfather kept his convictions unstained by politics.

meanings.definition: If numbers or amounts are unstandardized, they are not reported in a form that makes comparisons with other numbers or amounts fair or accurate:
examples: These graphs use unstandardized information.
The data were unstandardized, which limited our ability to make comparisons.

meanings.definition: having or involving features that have not been made the same in all cases:
examples: The traditional cheeses came from an unmechanized and unstandardized age.
They warned that herbal medicines might be unstandardized, meaning that the amount of active ingredient might vary.

meanings.definition: not expecting to be treated like a star (= a famous person):
examples: He is modest, quietly spoken and the most unstarry of champions.

meanings.definition: not unexpected, or not making you feel surprise, shock, or admiration:
examples: The writer made an unstartling, but valid, point about depression going undiagnosed.
The first course, a tart, was absolutely fine, if unstartling.

meanings.definition: not said or written, but thought or known:
examples: The work is based on a series of unstated assumptions that have never been challenged.
The unstated premise was political pluralism.
There has been a view, stated or unstated, that such behaviour is unacceptable.

meanings.definition: not supported by wires or ropes:
examples: Problems developed with the boat's unstayed masts.
an unstayed rig

meanings.definition: not supported by stays (= strips of stiff material):
examples: This type of dress has a full skirt and an unstayed bodice.

meanings.definition: not stopped or prevented:
examples: This may apply if the order remains undischarged or unstayed for a period that exceeds thirty days.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves moving slightly from side to side, as if you might fall :
examples: He walked slowly and unsteadily to his piano.
Unsteadily, he made his way out of the door, and on to the street.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not smooth or regular:
examples: His voice wavered unsteadily.

meanings.definition: in a way that often changes or is likely to change:
examples: For much of the day, the market moved unsteadily, rising initially but then dipping lower before recovering in the afternoon.

meanings.definition: moving slightly from side to side, as if you might fall:
examples: She's been in bed with flu, and she's still a little unsteady on her feet.

meanings.definition: likely to change, in a way that is worrying:
examples: The report showed unemployment surging in an already unsteady economy.

meanings.definition: not smooth or regular:
examples: She said how sorry she was in a soft, unsteady voice.
A basic check can be done by monitoring a person's pulse for an unsteady beat.

meanings.definition: moving or changing, or not firm:
examples: She’s been sick, and she’s still a bit unsteady on her feet.

meanings.definition: not completely clean and not free from dirt or bacteria:
examples: The disease can be transmitted if unsterile needles are reused.
The mouth is an unsterile environment.

meanings.definition: An unsterilized object has not been made completely clean or free from bacteria. :
examples: Unsterilized instruments had been used.
Transmission through the use of unsterilised needles and syringes was common.

meanings.definition: An unsterilized animal or person has not had a medical operation to make it impossible for it or them to have young animals or babies:
examples: There are fines for owners who let their unsterilized pets run free.
These women remained unsterilized.

meanings.definition: allowing a country's money supply to be affected when money is bought or sold on international money markets:
examples: The central bank injected billions into the banking system through unsterilized intervention in the foreign exchange markets.
Some of the intervention was unsterilized.

meanings.definition: very great and not changing or ending:
examples: His work earned the public's unstinted praise.
All of these people have given us their unstinted and abiding support.

meanings.definition: extremely generous with time, money, praise, help, etc.:
examples: unstinting support/generosity
She was quite unstinting in her praise.

meanings.definition: in a way that is extremely generous with time, money, praise, help, etc. :
examples: Many people gave unstintingly of their time and energy to reduce the difficulties experienced by the refugees.
Their performances in this challenging play were unstintingly, painfully honest.

meanings.definition: to take the stitches (= pieces of thread that have been sewn to hold something together) out of something:
examples: They unstitched the sleeves from the arm-holes of a jacket to make it look tattered and torn.

meanings.definition: to change, spoil, or destroy something that has existed or been done previously:
examples: In two years she has unstitched almost every aspect of the business and re-fashioned it.
He was an astute politician whose career came unstitched when - after years of waiting in the wings - he reached the highest office.

meanings.definition: unable to be stopped or prevented from developing:
examples: The band has enjoyed a seemingly unstoppable rise in popularity.

meanings.definition: continuous, or unable to be stopped:
examples: The band was enjoying what seemed to be an unstoppable rise in popularity.

meanings.definition: in a way that cannot be stopped or prevented from developing:
examples: Suddenly it was easy to imagine the stock market crashing unstoppably downwards.
She remains unstoppably energetic and combative, and reluctant to live in the past.

meanings.definition: to open a bottle or other container by removing its stopper (= the object that fits into the top):
examples: She looked at the toiletries and cosmetics, then she unstoppered the bottles and sniffed the contents.
He was about to unstopper the jar.

meanings.definition: Unstrained food or drink has not been passed through a device with holes in order to separate solids and liquids or in order to make a thick, smooth liquid:
examples: Using unstrained fat will result in low-quality chips.
Shake the cocktail and pour it unstrained into a glass.

meanings.definition: not forced, not put under pressure, or not involving a lot of effort:
examples: The transition from singing low notes to singing high notes should be smooth and unstrained.
She gave her a warm and unstrained smile.

meanings.definition: not consisting of separate layers:
examples: Boulder clay consists of an unstratified and unsorted deposit of clay, sand, gravel, and boulders.
The authors studied the unstratified upper layer of the rainforest canopy.

meanings.definition: not having people or things arranged according to their importance, level, or type:
examples: Until recently, these groups have remained an unstratified, egalitarian society.
The sample was unstratified.

meanings.definition: not feeling worried; feeling relaxed and not experiencing stress:
examples: She said that she was feeling completely unstressed about the wedding.

meanings.definition: (of a word or syllable) not pronounced with stress (= emphasis) :
examples: Most words that are made up of more than one syllable have at least one stressed syllable and one unstressed syllable.

meanings.definition: not having a clear structure or organization:
examples: Even in a relatively unstructured situation like a brainstorming session, it is often helpful if one participant does some initial thinking.
The first set of interviews were unstructured, with only broad themes decided in advance.
The system works by turning unstructured data into structured information assets.
Parents sometimes feel children aren't learning if they have too much unstructured time.

meanings.definition: Unstructured clothes do not have a definite shape and hang loosely:
examples: The designer is famous for minimalist creations such as his unstructured jackets.
The unstructured wool coat with its leather tie-belt is both practical and stylish.

meanings.definition: no longer stuck:
examples: The packing tape on the box came unstuck and some of the contents fell out.

meanings.definition: not old-fashioned, formal, or boring:
examples: The hotel is traditional but there is a refreshingly unstuffy approach.
She was the unstuffiest person you could ever meet.

meanings.definition: not fashionable or attractive:
examples: We are a very dull nation fashionwise - extremely unstylish and conservative.
My first pair of glasses were large, round and unstylish, and by the time I was ten I regretted my choice.

meanings.definition: not having been made weaker or brought under control :
examples: His pride remained unsubdued.
Nature here is still unsubdued and existing in all her beauty and magnificence.

meanings.definition: (of people, a country, an area, etc.) not having been brought under control by fighting or force:
examples: At the present time the guerrilla fighters remain unsubdued.
The area is a place of unsubdued clans and tribes, bandits, and private armies.

meanings.definition: to get an organization or business to remove your name from its mailing list so that you no longer receive email or post from them, or to remove someone's name from such a list
to remove your name from a mailing list, especially on the internet, so that you no longer receive mail or email from a company or organization:
examples: Never email to unsubscribe or reply to spam, because then they know yours is a live email address.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         unsubscribe
to get an organization or business to remove your name from its mailing list so that you no longer receive email or post from them, or to remove someone's name from such a list

present participle of 
        
         unsubscribe
to get an organization or business to remove your name from its mailing list so that you no longer receive email or post from them, or to remove someone's name from such a list
not paid for partly by the government or another organization:
examples: Students can get unsubsidized loans, which are not based on need.
Unsubsidised theatres won't take a risk on an unproven project when a guaranteed blockbuster will pay the bills.

meanings.definition: relating to a cost, price, etc. that is paid by the customer and not partly paid by another person, an organization, or the government:
examples: Officials said the average graduate debt had risen to $17,000 in subsidized and unsubsidized loans.

meanings.definition: not supported by facts:
examples: Companies can be punished for making unsubstantiated claims about their products.

meanings.definition: noticeable, obvious, or direct:
examples: In his opening address, he sent an unsubtle message to his players: "Don't be late," he said.
My mother often drops unsubtle hints that she wants a grandchild.

meanings.definition: in a way that is noticeable, obvious, or direct:
examples: As the book's title ("The Secret Garden") unsubtly suggests, there is also a garden involved.
She made it unsubtly clear that she had no interest in the conversation.

meanings.definition: the fact of someone or something not succeeding:
examples: When an author passes away, others often attempt to recreate the characters with varying degrees of unsuccess.
The original target of 12 million visitors was over-optimistic, and has created the perception of unsuccess.

meanings.definition: not achieving the hoped for result; not successful:
examples: They made several unsuccessful attempts to reach the men.
His application was unsuccessful.

meanings.definition: not ending in success, or not achieving success:
examples: After writing three unsuccessful plays, Miller finally had a hit.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not succeed or achieve the hoped for result:
examples: He ran unsuccessfully for a parliamentary seat.
She tried unsuccessfully to start several small businesses.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being acceptable or right for something or someone:
examples: There are many ways a person can behave that would suggest their unsuitability for public life.
The committee reported on the unsuitability of the accommodation for use by student nurses.

meanings.definition: not acceptable or right for someone or something; not suitable:
examples: The software blocks material that is unsuitable for children.

meanings.definition: not right for a particular person, situation, or occasion:
examples: Parts of this movie may be unsuitable for children.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not acceptable or right for something or someone:
examples: She was deeply embarrassed to see her mother arriving in unsuitably colourful clothes.
The horse was pulled out of the race due to unsuitably soft ground.

meanings.definition: not right for someone or something, usually in character:
examples: Liberman realized Kurt was unsuited to office life, but offered him a contract anyway.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         unsulphured
not damaged or made dirty by anything:
examples: his unsullied reputation

meanings.definition: Food that is unsulphured has not been treated with sulphur dioxide (= a chemical used to preserve food):
examples: I keep a large jar of unsulphured apricots in the kitchen.
You can tell if the herbs are unsulphured as their colour differs from those treated with preservatives.

meanings.definition: not noticed or praised for hard work, courage, or great achievements:
examples: an unsung hero/heroine
Many of her achievements went unsung until after her death.

meanings.definition: not noticed or praised for doing hard work, being brave, or achieving results:
examples: A teacher is often the unsung hero of a great writer’s success.

meanings.definition: without anyone watching to make sure that nothing dangerous or wrong is done or happening:
examples: Young children should not be left alone with animals unsupervised.

meanings.definition: An unsupportable argument, statement, etc. cannot be shown to be true with evidence:
examples: The report is totally without credibility and is filled with wild, unsupportable claims.
I do not like to base my opinion on such an unsupportable argument.

meanings.definition: If something bad is unsupportable, you are not able to accept that it should continue:
examples: In the end, the cost of the wars became unsupportable.
These are unsupportable rates of population growth.

meanings.definition: If someone's opinions or statements are unsupported, they do not have any proof or evidence to show that they are true:
examples: unsupported allegations
Most of the report consists of generalized observations, unsupported by dates, names and times.

meanings.definition: not receiving any help or encouragement from other people:
examples: He made several attempts to reach the North Pole unsupported.

meanings.definition: An unsupported structure or object does not use any other object or person to support its weight, especially from below to stop it from falling:
examples: to stand unsupported
the largest unsupported marble dome in the world

meanings.definition: not certain or having doubts:
examples: I'm unsure about what to do next - can you help me?

meanings.definition: in doubt, or not certain:
examples: Officials were unsure who was in control of the city.

meanings.definition: If you are unsure of yourself, you are not confident:
examples: He has been unsure of himself ever since he failed to get that job.

meanings.definition: without confidence in yourself:
examples: As a new teacher I was very unsure of myself when I was in front of a class.
He was stuttering and unsure of himself in public.
If you feel at all unsure of yourself, remember that I'm here to help.
We had set up a new business, but we were still very unsure of ourselves.
Some of the group leaders appeared unsure of themselves.

meanings.definition: better than anything that could be achieved by someone or something else :
examples: This is an amazing part of the world, unique in its isolation, unsurpassable in its beauty.
He described the medical care he had received at the hospital as "unsurpassable".

meanings.definition: better than anyone or anything else:
examples: His knowledge of the subject is unsurpassed.

meanings.definition: not surprised:
examples: If you've used this textbook, you'll be unsurprised to learn that the author is a teacher.
She seemed unsurprised at his somewhat irrational behaviour.
Based on his previous record, we were unsurprised that the marketing director hadn't turned up for the meeting.
I was unsurprised by the negative comments of her teachers.

meanings.definition: not making you feel surprised:
examples: It is unsurprising that many people do not support the tax increase.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not surprising:
examples: Perhaps unsurprisingly, the film was not a success.
Room service is impeccable, unsurprisingly.

meanings.definition: (of an accident, injury, disease, or situation) certain to cause death:
examples: Judging by the burned wreckage of the plane, search and rescue workers considered the crash was unsurvivable.
Injuries like this were unsurvivable in previous wars.
They accepted that the patient was in an unsurvivable coma and had no consciousness.
The occupants had just seconds to escape the fire before conditions become unsurvivable.

meanings.definition: not easily influenced or affected by something:
examples: Voters had become split into two camps, with those on both sides generally unsusceptible to persuasion.
Hardened criminals like these must be unsusceptible of the influence of human feelings.

meanings.definition: (especially of an idea or statement) not able to be understood, proved, explained, etc. in a particular way:
examples: The only names which are unsusceptible of definition are the names of the simple feelings themselves.
The contradictions that exist between practice and theory are unsusceptible of any rational solution.

meanings.definition: not known or thought to exist:
examples: an unsuspected talent/complication/problem/illness

meanings.definition: trusting; not realizing there is any danger or harm:
examples: The killer lured his unsuspecting victims back to his apartment.

meanings.definition: trusting; not aware of any danger or harm:
examples: The fish sometimes leap into the air and smack into unsuspecting boaters.

meanings.definition: trusting someone or something, or not realizing the truth about a situation :
examples: Because of his unsuspicious nature and high self-confidence, he reacted calmly to criticism.
When they arrived, they found a population that was unarmed and unsuspicious of danger.

meanings.definition: Something that is unsustainable cannot continue at the same rate:
examples: This level of spending is unsustainable.

meanings.definition: causing damage to the environment by using more of something than can be replaced naturally:
examples: unsustainable fishing methods

meanings.definition: that cannot continue at the same rate:
examples: They are suffering a serious increase in inflation and an unsustainable boom in house prices.
Public borrowing had reached an unsustainable level of 8% of GDP.
The economy is running an unsustainable deficit, making tax increases inevitable.

meanings.definition: causing damage to the environment by using more of something than can be replaced naturally:
examples: Unsustainable logging of commercial forests is threatening the industry's survival beyond 10-15 years.
In March, 50,000 people took to the streets of Mallorca to protest the island's unsustainable development.

meanings.definition: growth that cannot continue at the same rate without causing economic problems:
examples: In contrast to her past concern about unsustainable growth in the economy, she forecast yesterday that economic growth would be a more sustainable 3%.

meanings.definition: growth that cannot continue at the same rate without causing environmental problems:
examples: We will never stop degrading the ecosphere unless we tackle capitalism and the unsustainable growth that lies at its core.

meanings.definition: in a way that cannot continue over a period of time:
examples: Prices have been set unsustainably high for years.

meanings.definition: in a way that causes damage to the environment and is therefore not able to continue for a long time:
examples: Water is being used unsustainably and is running out.

meanings.definition: with no sugar or other sweet substances added:
examples: unsweetened cranberry juice

meanings.definition: If someone's trust or belief is unswerving, it is always strong and never becomes weaker:
examples: unswerving loyalty/devotion/support/faith

meanings.definition: (esp. of trust or a belief) always strong; never weakening:
examples: unswerving support

meanings.definition: not sympathetic (= showing that you understand or care about someone's suffering)
in a way that shows you do not understand or care about someone who is suffering:
examples: "But I've nowhere to go." "Tough!" he replied, unsympathetically.
"You must be very nervous," Ferris said, not unsympathetically.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows that you do not like or approve of someone or something:
examples: I can't condone the way this woman was treated, no matter how unsympathetically you paint her.
His latest novel was unsympathetically received by the critics.

meanings.definition: in a style that is not suitable, and does not go well with other things that are in the same place:
examples: The castle has been unsympathetically modernized so that now the best thing about it is the view from the top.
Unfortunately, the church was unsympathetically restored in the 19th century, when most of the original interior was ripped out.

meanings.definition: not happening together, at the same or right time, or in the expected way:
examples: The unsynchronised traffic lights along major roads leave many drivers frustrated.

meanings.definition: not having been made to show the same time:
examples: You will want to know the exact time when something has happened, and so an unsynchronised clock in your system will lead to problems.

meanings.definition: not following an agreed set of methods or organized plan, in a way that is usually not helpful:
examples: The agency relies on an unsystematic system in which doctors and patients report problems when they consider them important.
He was attacked for being unsystematic in his methods, but he was praised for his superior clinical skills.

meanings.definition: the risk involved in buying a particular investment, rather than the risk that affects any investment:
examples: You can reduce unsystematic risk associated with individual stocks, but there are inherent market risks that affect nearly every stock.

meanings.definition: a risk that affects only one company or industry:
examples: The risk of a decline in house prices is likely to be an unsystematic risk, specific to the housing market.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not follow an agreed set of methods or organized plan and usually in a way that is not helpful:
examples: Recruitment was conducted haphazardly and unsystematically, and did not follow inclusive practices.
This piece is written loosely and unsystematically, and reads like the outpouring of a confused and troubled mind.

meanings.definition: not arranged according to an organized system:
examples: After a head injury, the patient may experience hallucinations and unsystematized delusions.
Creating this type of life plan is a way of understanding and framing your choices, given how messy and unsystematised the world has become.

meanings.definition: not taking care not to say or do something that could upset someone:

meanings.definition: not spoiled by anything:

meanings.definition: If a theory or argument is untenable, it cannot be supported or defended against criticism.

meanings.definition: not able to be supported or defended against criticism, or no longer able to continue:

meanings.definition: so shocking that it cannot be imagined as possible:

meanings.definition: too shocking or unlikely to be imagined as possible:

a word used in the past for a person, particularly a person from India, who belonged to the caste (= social group ) that was considered the lowest. This word is now considered offensive.
not able to be punished, criticized, or changed in any way:

meanings.definition: If something is untraceable, it is not possible to find out who made it or started it, or where it came from. :

meanings.definition: not limited by rules or any other controlling influence:

meanings.definition: not having been translated (= changed into a different language):
