meanings.definition: not able to work as intended; not able to succeed:
examples: She concluded that the plan was unviable with the resources that were available.

meanings.definition: not able to continue to exist as, or develop into, a living being:
examples: an unviable pregnancy/foetus

meanings.definition: If a place is unvisited, no one has gone there:
examples: There are still plenty of unvisited places around the world.
The field contains neat rows of unvisited graves.

meanings.definition: (of a person) not having had any visitors:
examples: He spent a month lying in a hospital bed, unvisited by his family and friends.
She spent her last days alone, unvisited by her children and grandchildren.

meanings.definition: not spoken or expressed, although thought of or felt:
examples: He takes a long time to realize that his unvoiced fears are groundless.

meanings.definition: (of a speech sound) produced without making the vocal cords move:
examples: The voiced plosives [b], [d], and [g] are produced in the same way as their unvoiced counterparts [p], [t], and [k]; the only difference is the voicing.

meanings.definition: without pay or without a paid job:
examples: The children described long hours of unwaged work.
Since I'm unwaged, I don't have a credit card.

meanings.definition: unemployed people:
examples: The entrance fee is six pounds, two pounds for the unwaged.

meanings.definition: not wanted:
examples: How can I stop unwanted emails?

meanings.definition: not desired or needed:
examples: Charities such as Computers for Schools are happy to take unwanted computers.

meanings.definition: not wanted:
examples: Unwanted emails cost consumers and business nationwide an estimated $70 billion annually in lost productivity.
The store will exchange unwanted items for other goods.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows someone is not careful about possible risks and dangers:
examples: Personal information that is unwarily spoken over the phone can be recorded, stolen, and used.
Plants that are unwarily exposed can be damaged by the lingering frost.

meanings.definition: not often involved in or eager to start wars:
examples: The ancient Greeks were a most unwarlike people.
The prince was a timid and unwarlike youth.

meanings.definition: unacceptable and wrong because there is no good or fair reason for it :
examples: The company was fined for unwarrantable failures to comply with safety rules.
I want to show that this conclusion is unwarrantable, unfair, and calculated to mislead.

meanings.definition: in a way that is unacceptable and wrong, because there is no good or fair reason for it:
examples: The commission found that the article was unfair to the complainant and unwarrantably infringed her privacy.
All too often this film unwarrantably accentuates the positive.

meanings.definition: not having a good reason and therefore annoying or unfair:
examples: People need to be protected against such unwarranted intrusions into their private lives by journalists.

meanings.definition: lacking a good reason; unnecessary:
examples: They denounced the investigation as an unwarranted interference with their business.

meanings.definition: not conscious of or careful about possible risks and dangers:
examples: He sold fake insurance policies to unwary customers.
A range of tax and technical issues can trip up the unwary (= unwary people).

meanings.definition: not washed:
examples: His football shirt was left unwashed in his locker for weeks.
Dangerous bacteria can be spread by unwashed hands.

meanings.definition: An unwatchable TV programme, film, etc. is so violent, bad, boring, or unpleasant that it is impossible to watch. :
examples: This mostly unfunny and frequently unwatchable sitcom made its debut last month.
I thought it was so pretentious and self-indulgent that it was virtually unwatchable.

meanings.definition: in a way that is so bad, boring, unpleasant, or violent that it is difficult or impossible to watch:
examples: Her career continues its downward slide with this unwatchably awful thriller.
The drama is brilliantly acted and composed, but almost unwatchably horrible.

meanings.definition: never moving or looking away from something:
examples: She met his unwavering stare.

meanings.definition: never changing or becoming weaker:
examples: Her belief in the project has been unwavering.

meanings.definition: without changing or becoming weaker:
examples: He kept to his version of the story unwaveringly in spite of evidence against him.
This is an unwaveringly romantic piece of music.

meanings.definition: without moving or looking away:
examples: The spotlight stayed unwaveringly on Juliet throughout the scene.
Her gaze was unwaveringly directed at the television screen.

meanings.definition: not covered with a thin layer of wax:
examples: I bought a couple of unwaxed oranges from the market.
Line the tray with unwaxed baking paper.

meanings.definition: If part of your body is unwaxed, it has not had the hair removed by being covered with a thin layer of wax that is then pulled off:
examples: unwaxed armpits
Few celebrities would expose an unwaxed leg to the cameras.

meanings.definition: An unweaned baby or young animal is still feeding on its mother's milk and has not started to eat other food, especially solid food:
examples: The children remained unweaned well beyond their first birthday.
The kittens were unweaned and still dependent on their mother.

meanings.definition: If clothes are unwearable, people choose not to wear them because they are uncomfortable or damaged, or because they do not look attractive:
examples: That dress looks stunning but it is completely unwearable.
The jacket had a large yellow stain that rendered it unwearable.

meanings.definition: not feeling tired or showing tiredness:
examples: His voice sounds young and unwearied.
With unwearied perseverance, she succeeded in obtaining a constant supply of food.

meanings.definition: in a way that does not feel or show tiredness:
examples: He became Bentham's most devoted follower, and laboured unweariedly upon the translation of his master's work.
To me he was unweariedly kind, and always glad to see me in the galley, which he kept spotlessly clean.

meanings.definition: not changed by the effects of sun, wind, or other weather conditions:
examples: The scientists removed the outer layer of the rock to reveal a fresh, unweathered surface.
These crystals are shiny and transparent when they are unweathered.

meanings.definition: (used especially in newspapers) not married:
examples: an unwed mother

meanings.definition: An unweighted set of numbers has not been changed in a way that gives extra importance to particular information:
examples: All of the figures in the table are unweighted averages.
My calculation is based on a crude, unweighted average of the cost of some grocery items.

meanings.definition: An unweighted object does not have something heavy fastened to it:
examples: The unweighted bundle bobbed up and down on the surface of the water.
I started by lifting an unweighted bar.

meanings.definition: not wanted:
examples: unwelcome news
an unwelcome visitor

meanings.definition: not wanted or desirable:
examples: Dogs stand watch for unwelcome visitors to the estate.

meanings.definition: not making a guest or visitor feel happy, comfortable, or wanted:
examples: The house was damp and unwelcoming.

meanings.definition: not well; ill:
examples: I hear you've been unwell recently.
If you feel unwell, tell the teacher.

meanings.definition: not good for you, and likely to have a bad effect on your life either physically, morally, or emotionally:
examples: She stays up all night in unwholesome places.
We avoid alcohol, tobacco, and other unwholesome things.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not good for you, and is likely to have a bad effect on your life either physically, morally, or emotionally :
examples: She seems to have had an unwholesomely obsessive relationship with her child.
As an organization, it has become unwholesomely bureaucratic.

meanings.definition: the quality or state of being unwholesome (= not good for you physically, morally, or emotionally):
examples: Their children perished from neglect and the unwholesomeness of their food.
The unwholesomeness of the climate put a speedy end to their lives.

meanings.definition: in a way that is difficult to manage, usually because of being too big or badly organized :
examples: Models such as those described here tend to be large and unwieldily complex.
Unwieldily long titles seem to be the norm for this genre of fiction.

meanings.definition: An unwieldy object is difficult to move or handle because it is heavy, large, or a strange shape:
examples: A piano is a very unwieldy item to get down a flight of stairs.

meanings.definition: An unwieldy system is slow and not effective, usually because it is too big, badly organized, or involves too many different organizations or people:
examples: One disadvantage for the bank is that its huge size - over 15,000 staff - makes it unwieldy and slow-moving.

meanings.definition: (of an object) difficult to move or handle because it is heavy, large, or a strange shape
(of a system) difficult to manage, usually because it is too big or badly organized:
examples: an unwieldy bureaucracy

meanings.definition: done or happening without the decision or intention of the person involved:
examples: An unwilled tear trickled down the side of his face.
I do not want to induce unwilled behaviour in the people who ask me for advice.

meanings.definition: not willing:
examples: an unwilling helper

meanings.definition: not wanting to do something:
examples: The bank was unwilling to lend her money.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves someone doing something they do not want to do:
examples: "Yes, all right. I'll go," she agreed, somewhat unwillingly.
They are being unwillingly dragged into the debate.

meanings.definition: the quality of not wanting to do something:
examples: her unwillingness to help
Many politicians have expressed unwillingness to support the prime minister.

meanings.definition: If you unwind something that is wrapped around an object, you unfasten it, and if it unwinds, it becomes unfastened:
examples: In a nearby medical tent, a US Army doctor gently unwinds Metruk's bandage.

meanings.definition: to relax and allow your mind to be free from worry after a period of work or some other activity that has made you worried:
examples: A glass of wine in the evening helps me to unwind after work.

meanings.definition: to unfasten something that is wrapped around an object:
examples: to unwind string

meanings.definition: to relax after a period of work or anxiety:
examples: I’m just going to watch some TV and unwind.

meanings.definition: to sell shares, etc. that you bought expecting that their price would rise:
examples: Institutional investors caused prices to fall as they unwound positions that they took when they were betting on rising stock prices.

meanings.definition: to buy the shares, etc. that you borrowed expecting that their price would go down and that you now need to deliver:
examples: Traders unwound short positions, expecting gasoline would be lower this time of year.

meanings.definition: to change or remove the effects of something:
examples: Financial markets believe that these imbalances can be unwound gradually, allowing the economy to land softly.
People's ability to service debt is unwinding.

meanings.definition: to relax and allow your mind to be free from worry after a period of work:
examples: The facility was built as a place where casino workers could go and unwind after their shifts.

meanings.definition: If a competition, election, fight, etc. is unwinnable, it is not possible to win it:
examples: Why are you wasting your time and energy in fighting an unwinnable battle?
He believed that the war was unwinnable and they should seek a peace agreement.

meanings.definition: stupid and likely to cause problems
not showing good judgment or understanding of a situation:
examples: We made several unwise investments and lost quite a bit of money.

meanings.definition: in a way that is stupid and likely to cause problems:
examples: It's easy to spend money unwisely.
Unwisely, she and her husband had paid for flights before obtaining visas.

meanings.definition: without knowing or planning:
examples: The two women claimed they were the unwitting victims of a drug dealer who planted a large quantity of heroin in their luggage.

meanings.definition: without knowing or planning:
examples: The harmful radiation tests were performed long ago on unwitting subjects.

meanings.definition: in a way that is done without knowing or planning:
examples: I apologize for any anxiety which I may, unwittingly, have caused.
Unwittingly, I may have given a misleading impression in my interviews.

meanings.definition: not showing the qualities, ideas, or physical features that a woman is typically or traditionally thought to have, or expected to have:
examples: In the last century, taking part in martial arts was thought of as unwomanly.

meanings.definition: unusual; not often experienced or shown:
examples: He sprang to the phone with unwonted eagerness.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being practical or of not being able to be used effectively:
examples: She tried to demonstrate the unworkability of the proposed solution.
They have introduced a number of new laws without considering their unworkability.

meanings.definition: An unworkable plan is not practical or cannot really be done successfully:
examples: To be honest, I think the plan is completely unworkable.

meanings.definition: (of a plan or a system) not practical or able to operate effectively:
examples: The budget was considered unworkable and had to be revised.

meanings.definition: If an area of land is unworked, it has not been used for growing crops, or valuable substances have not been removed from it:
examples: There are still some unworked areas of ground in the valley.
The gold mines have been left unworked since the start of the twentieth century.

meanings.definition: If a substance or material is unworked, it has not been used, shaped, etc.:
examples: There were two huge pieces of unworked marble on the floor of the workshop.

meanings.definition: not practical, or without a lot of experience of life:
examples: There was something slightly unworldly about him.
We observe her transformation from a naive, unworldly girl to a dignified adult woman.

meanings.definition: not relating to physical things or ordinary daily life in this world or on this planet :
examples: At times, the actors look unworldly, like ghosts in a dreamscape.
The vessel looked like an unworldly cross between a spacecraft and a yacht.

meanings.definition: not thinking about problems or unpleasant things that might happen:
examples: Despite her concerns, she tried to appear unworried when she met her friends.
He explained everything to me in a calm and unworried tone.

meanings.definition: in a way that deserves no respect, admiration, or support :
examples: We can all think of people whose success has been unworthily acquired.
She felt he was treating her improperly and unworthily.

meanings.definition: not deserving respect, admiration, or support:
examples: I put all unworthy thoughts out of my mind.

meanings.definition: not suitable for or characteristic of something:
examples: a practice unworthy of a democracy

meanings.definition: not deserving to be considered, given attention, etc.:
examples: The theory was unworthy of serious attention.
I felt as though I was unworthy of her love.
Previous historians had deemed these events unworthy of record.
He considered the idea unworthy of serious thought.
The report was filled with errors and unworthy of consideration.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         unwind
not having an injury such as a cut or hole in the skin:
examples: After the attack there were only twenty unwounded men left in the fort.
Those of us who were still unwounded tried to escape to the mountains.

meanings.definition: to remove the paper or other covering from something:
examples: Aren't you going to unwrap your presents?

meanings.definition: (of skin) without any small lines because of old age:
examples: The skin around her eyes was smooth and unwrinkled.
Even in his forties, his face was still young and unwrinkled.

meanings.definition: (of cloth) without any small lines or folds in it:
examples: The sheets on the bed were still fresh and unwrinkled.
She looked immaculate in an unwrinkled black suit.

meanings.definition: Something that is unwritten does not exist in a written or printed form:
examples: an unwritten constitution

meanings.definition: An unwritten rule or law does not exist officially but people generally accept and obey it:
examples: There's an unwritten rule that you don't wear jeans to work.

meanings.definition: not written
An unwritten law/rule is one that does not exist officially, but which people generally accept and obey:
examples: There’s an unwritten rule at work that you don’t wear jeans.

meanings.definition: the laws, legal decisions, and customs that govern a country that does not have a constitution (= a set of political principles) in a single written document
completely unwilling to change a decision, opinion, demand, etc.:
examples: Korea is unyielding in its demands for a new treaty.

meanings.definition: rigid (= not able to be bent or moved)
not giving up control or responsibility for (something) as a result of influence or persuasion:
examples: The economist showed an unyielding commitment to tough financial stability.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows someone is completely unwilling to change a decision, opinion, demand, etc. :
examples: On TV, he soon became known for his unyieldingly impartial interviewing and access to key decision-makers.
She stood up and stared at him unyieldingly before leaving the room.

meanings.definition: to open something by using a zip:
examples: He unzipped his suitcase.

meanings.definition: to return a computer file to its original size after it has been zipped (= reduced in size so that it can be easily sent or stored)
to open the zipper (= a fastener consisting of two rows of metal or plastic teeth) on something
to return a computer file to its original size after it has been zipped (= reduced in size so that it can be easily sent or stored):
examples: After you have unzipped the file, click on the 'Start' button.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         unzip

present participle of 
        
         unzip
towards a higher position; towards a higher value, number, or level:
examples: Put those books up on the top shelf.
A gravel road leads through the jungle and up into the Andes.
Pushing the number of unit sales up every quarter can't be continued indefinitely.
The water was up to/had come up to the level of the windows.

meanings.definition: out of the ground:
examples: He spent the afternoon digging carrots up.

meanings.definition: in or into a vertical position:
examples: Would you stand up for a minute? I want to see how tall you are.

meanings.definition: in a high position; at the top:
examples: Our boardroom is up on the 23rd floor.
You can tell which way up the crates have to be because they all say "TOP".

meanings.definition: very near:
examples: Carrying a gun, he walked up to the cashier and demanded money.
A limousine drew up (= parked) outside the hotel.

meanings.definition: to a greater degree; in order to increase:
examples: The fire heats the room up (= makes it warmer) within minutes.
Grandma always turns the TV up really loud because she can't hear very well.
Try not to get worked up (= increasingly excited or angry) - I'm sure we can resolve this.

meanings.definition: If a level or amount is up, it has increased:
examples: The cost of car insurance is up, but not very much.
Last year the company's turnover was $240 billion, up three percent on (= compared with) the previous year.

meanings.definition: not in bed:
examples: It's time to get up now!
I was up all night, finishing my essay.

meanings.definition: into existence, view, or attention:
examples: Originally the charity was set up to help orphans in urban areas.
I'm sorry, but something unexpected has come up (= has happened) at the office, and I'll be home late.
Coming up (= happening next) after the break, we have a man who claims he can communicate with fish.
Would this be a good time to bring up the issue of salary?

meanings.definition: so as to be equal in quality, knowledge, or achievement:
examples: She couldn't go to school for a few weeks because of illness, but she'll be able to catch up (with her work) quickly.
So much scientific research is being performed that it's virtually impossible to keep up (with all the new developments).

meanings.definition: in a state of being together with other similar things:
examples: You have half an hour to gather up anything you'll need for the journey.
Add up the column of numbers in your head and then tell me what the total is.

meanings.definition: tightly or firmly in order to keep something safe or in position:
examples: Tie up the top of the bag so the rubbish doesn't fall out.
You'd better wrap up (= wear warm clothes) - it's cold outside.
Can you do my shoelaces up for me?

meanings.definition: broken or cut into smaller pieces; made smaller in area:
examples: He cut the letter up into a hundred pieces.
She folded the newspaper up and put it in her bag.
The car blew up (= exploded) when flames reached its fuel tank.

meanings.definition: to a greater age:
examples: No one said that growing up would be easy or painless.
Many single parents struggle to bring their children up on a low income.

meanings.definition: used when talking or asking about what is happening or wrong:
examples: Everyone was talking in whispers, and I could tell something was up (= something unusual was happening).

meanings.definition: When a period of time is up, it is finished:
examples: When the two hours were up nobody had answered all of the questions.
Your time is up - it's someone else's turn on the training equipment now.

meanings.definition: into an improved position or state:
examples: By lap 26, Hamilton had moved up into second position.
Stein had a bad start to the race, but by the ninth lap she was up with the leaders.

meanings.definition: to an end, finish, or state of being complete:
examples: Finish up the old loaf of bread before you start a new one.
Crime won't help - you'll end up in prison.
I'd like to round up the meeting by thanking all those who were able to attend at such short notice.

meanings.definition: towards the north:
examples: On Tuesday she'll be travelling up to Atlanta from New Orleans.

meanings.definition: towards a more important place, especially a city:
examples: How often do you go up to London?
She comes up from her village about once a month on the train.

meanings.definition: on trial in a court:
examples: If he doesn't pay the fine soon, he'll be up before the magistrate.
Smith is up for armed robbery.

meanings.definition: When a road is up, it is being repaired and so is unsuitable for use:
examples: The council has got the road up because of a broken sewer.

meanings.definition: If someone's long hair is up, it is arranged on the top or back of the head:
examples: You look nice with your hair up.

meanings.definition: next to play in a game or sports match, or next to perform, happen, etc.:
examples: Next up after that is a match against Blackburn Rovers at home.
Up next is an untitled Woody Allen film.

meanings.definition: to or in a higher level or position:
examples: We followed her up the stairs to a large meeting room.

meanings.definition: at the top of:
examples: You'll find a dusty attic up these stairs.
If you want Fred, he's up that ladder.

meanings.definition: (further) along:
examples: The car shot off up the road at high speed.
They live just up the road.

meanings.definition: towards the starting point of something, especially a river or stream:
examples: Rowing up (the) river against the current was very hard work.

meanings.definition: to or at:
examples: Are you going up the club tonight?

meanings.definition: moving up:
examples: an up escalator

meanings.definition: When a system, computer, or similar machine is up, it is operating, especially in its usual way:
examples: Andy, do you know when the network will be up again?

meanings.definition: feeling happy:
examples: She's been really up since she started her new job.

meanings.definition: having more points, goals, etc. than your opponent in a match or competition:
examples: By half time they could have been six or seven up.
With 88 seconds remaining in the game, Hungary was up by five goals.

meanings.definition: to increase something such as a price:
examples: We won't be able to make a profit on the deal without upping the sale price.
It looks like tax rates are going to be upped again.

meanings.definition: higher or improved:
examples: uphill
uplift

meanings.definition: toward a higher position, or toward a higher value, number, or level:
examples: Pick up your clothes and put them away.
We need to push sales figures up higher next quarter.
The kids were jumping up and down on the bed.

meanings.definition: in or into a vertical position:
examples: She jumped up to answer the phone.
They put up (= built) the house in a matter of weeks.

meanings.definition: in a high position; at the top:
examples: They moved to a house up in the hills.

meanings.definition: to a greater degree; in order to increase:
examples: The afternoon sun really heats up this room (= increases the heat in this room).
Please speak up (= louder) – I can’t hear you.

meanings.definition: into existence, view, or consideration:
examples: I didn’t hesitate to bring up the salary issue.
Something came up at the office and I had to work late.

meanings.definition: so as to be equal in quality or achievement:
examples: It’s impossible to keep up with all the new computer developments.

meanings.definition: very near:
examples: He walked right up to me and introduced himself.
The cop pushed me up against the wall.

meanings.definition: in a state of being together with other similar things:
examples: Gather up your things – it’s time to go.
She added up the numbers in her head.

meanings.definition: tightly or firmly in order to keep something safe or in position:
examples: Tie the boat up at the dock.
You’d better bundle up (= wear warm clothes) – it’s cold outside.

meanings.definition: made smaller in area or amount, esp. by cutting or dividing:
examples: Cut the cheese up into bite-size pieces.
They broke the company up into three separate units.
He folded up the newspaper and put it in his briefcase.

meanings.definition: to a greater age:
examples: She wants to be a singer when she grows up.

meanings.definition: into an improved position or state:
examples: By the third lap, Simms had moved up into second position.

meanings.definition: toward the north:
examples: She comes up from Washington about once a month.

meanings.definition: (farther) along:
examples: There’s a coffee shop just up the street.

meanings.definition: at the top of:
examples: His house is up the hill.

meanings.definition: out of bed:
examples: What time did you get up?

meanings.definition: finished, or to an end, finish, or state of being completed:
examples: Finish up your breakfast – it’s almost time for school.
My time is almost up on the parking meter.

meanings.definition: (of a system or machine, esp. a computer) operating, esp. in its usual way:
examples: The new inventory system should be up and running by the end of the month.

meanings.definition: intended, suggested, or being considered:
examples: The house at the end of our street is up for sale.
Ray’s up for promotion.

meanings.definition: to increase the amount or level of something:
examples: We won’t be able to make a profit unless we up our prices.

meanings.definition: towards a higher value, number, or level:
examples: Share prices moved up slowly yesterday.
Pushing the number of unit sales up every quarter can't be continued indefinitely.

meanings.definition: if a level or amount is up, it has increased:
examples: The cost of insurance is up quite a lot this year.
Last year the company's turnover was up 3% on the previous year.

meanings.definition: in a state of being together with other similar things:
examples: Add up the column of figures.

meanings.definition: to an end or state of being complete:
examples: Finish up this report before you leave tonight.
I'd like to wind up the meeting by thanking you for coming.

meanings.definition: if a computer, system, etc. is up, it is operating normally:
examples: The system is up again, so we have to get back to work.
Do you know when the network will be up again?

meanings.definition: to increase something such as a price:
examples: We won't be able to make a profit on the deal without upping the sale price.
It looks like tax rates are going to be upped again.

meanings.definition: in the opposite direction to the flow of water in the river:
examples: We sailed up river.
Scientists believe that the seal had become separated from its mother in a storm and had swum up the river into a small stream.
We returned to the boat and proceeded up the river.
In spring, these fish swim up river to spawn.
She was last seen swimming up river towards the bridge.
We headed up river despite the warnings.

meanings.definition: in a very difficult situation:
examples: When he died I was left up a gum tree.
Bashing it with a mallet can help, but if the steak is of poor quality, then you are up a gum tree, whatever you do.

meanings.definition: in a difficult situation:
examples: If any more people resign, we'll be really up the creek.
He doesn't have a computer and without the library he would be up a creek.
I had absolutely no money and I was up shit creek.

up-a-the-creek-without-a-paddle.name: up a/the creek without a paddle

meanings.definition: in a difficult situation, with no way of getting out of it:
examples: Customers feel they have been left up the creek without a paddle by the bank.
If we don't address this problem now, we will be up a creek without a paddle in the very near future.
If this had happened earlier we would have been up shit creek without a paddle.

meanings.definition: used with another verb to emphasize that someone left a place or did something in a sudden and possibly unexpected way:
examples: After dinner they just upped and left/went without saying goodbye.
When things became tricky, the whole family would just up and move.
Then, one winter's day, she simply up and died.
She cooked his dinner every night until the day she up and left him.
She hadn't given Ross a thought since he'd upped and gone to Turkey.

meanings.definition: infml feeling well enough to get out of bed and move around
to be able to get out of bed and move around again after a period of illness, because your health has improved enough:
examples: I was up and about a few hours after giving birth.
Associates said he was up and about again after suffering a period of exhaustion.
Most patients who have this procedure are up and about the next day.
It's good to see you up and around so soon after the injury.
His son is convalescing and is expected to be up and around soon.

meanings.definition: sometimes successful and sometimes not successful
in one direction and then in the opposite direction, esp. repeatedly:
examples: The dog was running up and down the path.

meanings.definition: If something, especially a system or a machine, is up and running it is operating:
examples: The engineer soon got the air-conditioning up and running again.

meanings.definition: an act of moving a bow (= a thin piece of wood with hair from the tail of a horse stretched along it) over the strings of a musical instrument in an upward direction:
examples: It's generally easier to play lighter sounds on an up bow.
The score indicates that this scale is to be played with an up bow.
He makes playing up bow staccato seem easy.

meanings.definition: available and ready to be won or taken:
examples: There are hundreds of prizes up for grabs.

meanings.definition: available:
examples: The job was still up for grabs.

meanings.definition: intended, suggested, or being considered for something:
examples: That house at the end of our road is up for sale again.
Are you really up for promotion?
He is up for an Oscar for his latest performance.
She is up for an award in the folk music category.
This pizza is up for grabs (= available for taking) if anyone wants some.

meanings.definition: willing and able to do or take part in an activity:
examples: After a long day at work I wasn't really up for a party.
We're going swimming. Are you up for it?
I'm up for organizing the meeting if nobody else wants to do it.
I certainly wasn't up for babysitting his kids.
Do you think Marcus would be up for performing in our show?

meanings.definition: If you give someone an amount of money up front, you pay that person before they do something for you:
examples: He wants all the money up front or he won't do the job.
They charge £2,500 up front, and then the remainder of the bill when the work is completed.
You have to pay 50% of the fee up front.
The insurer requires 15% up front to start the cover.
If I were you, I'd be wary of any company that demands money up front.
We shouldn't have paid him all that money up front.

meanings.definition: angry or upset:
examples: The union is up in arms over the reduction in health benefits.

meanings.definition: If a matter is up in the air, it is uncertain, often because other matters have to be decided first:
examples: The whole future of the project is still up in the air.

meanings.definition: uncertain and with an unknown result:
examples: The whole future of the project is still up in the air.

meanings.definition: to or in the north of the country or region:
examples: I live in London, but my relatives live up north, in Manchester.
The weather up north was fairly cool, but it was much hotter down south.
I'm heading up north myself next week.
I'm like you, I have family up north.
She's moving down here from up north.
It gets very cold up north.

meanings.definition: a rude phrase meaning driving too close to the car in front:
examples: I had a sports car up my ass for the first 50 miles.

meanings.definition: to take all the things that you own and go and live in a different place:
examples: This is the fourth time in five years that we've had to up sticks.

meanings.definition: If you up the ante, you increase your demands or the risks in a situation in order to achieve a better result:
examples: The government has upped the ante by refusing to negotiate until a ceasefire has been agreed .

meanings.definition: to increase your risks or demands in order to get a greater advantage:
examples: The governor upped the ante in her war of words with the mayor, by calling him "dangerous" for the city.

meanings.definition: infml in a difficult situation:
examples: If any more people quit, we’ll really be up the creek.

meanings.definition: pregnant:
examples: Two days before I was due to have an appointment with the doctor, I found out I was up the duff.
There were continual rumours that the star was up the duff.
Two little ones at home and she's up the duff again.
He only went and got her up the duff.
I think he assumed I was up the duff.
I was up the duff and feeling really poorly.

meanings.definition: wasted, spoiled, or not working correctly: pregnant:
examples: He said the decision meant that nearly £3m of shareholders' money was up the spout.
Peter lost his job so that was our holiday plans up the spout.
When we moved in the heating didn't work, the ceiling leaked and the plumbing was up the spout.
She's up the spout, but she won't say who the father is.
He hated Jim for getting his daughter up the spout.

meanings.definition: until:
examples: Up to yesterday, we had no idea where the child was.

meanings.definition: used to say that something is less than or equal to but not more than a stated value, number, or level:
examples: Up to two hundred people were on board the ship.
We can teach dancers up to intermediate level here.

meanings.definition: until:
examples: Up to yesterday, we had no idea where the child was.

meanings.definition: less than or equal to, but not more than, a stated value, number, level, or time:
examples: Research suggests that up to half of those who were prescribed the drug suffered side effects.
You have up to ten minutes.

meanings.definition: being the responsibility of (someone):
examples: The decision is up to you.
If it were up to me, I’d do it.

meanings.definition: doing (something that might be bad or illegal), often secretly:
examples: When it’s so quiet, I think the kids are up to something.

meanings.definition: partly, or to a limited degree:
examples: Of course there is some truth in all this, but only up to a point.
The new traffic system worked up to a point, but it had its problems.

meanings.definition: modern, recent, or containing the latest information:
examples: We work hard to keep our database up to date.
up-to-date information

meanings.definition: having the most recent information, or using the newest methods or tools:
examples: We go to a lot of trouble to keep our database up-to-date.

meanings.definition: including or having been given the latest information:
examples: All up-to-date prices can be found on our website.
The quarterly meeting keeps staff up to date with developments in the company.

meanings.definition: modern or very recent:
examples: The company's new offices are bang up to date.
up-to-date equipment/technology

meanings.definition: feeling or performing as good as usual, with nothing wrong:
examples: Jenny had not been up to par physically and did not come close to winning a medal.

meanings.definition: reaching an acceptable standard:
examples: Your last essay wasn't up to scratch/didn't come up to scratch.

meanings.definition: as good as the usual standard:
examples: The last few episodes of the TV program haven’t been quite up to scratch.

meanings.definition: as good as it should be; of an acceptable standard:
examples: The phone system just wasn't up to snuff.

meanings.definition: good enough:
examples: Her work isn’t up to snuff.

meanings.definition: If you are up to speed with a subject or activity, you have all the latest information about it and are able to do it well:
examples: We arranged for some home tutoring to get him up to speed with the other children in his class.
Before we start the meeting I'm going to bring you up to speed with the latest developments.

meanings.definition: performing at a desirable level:
examples: It took me a while to get up to speed after the flu.

meanings.definition: shouted or written on notices to show support:
examples: Up with freedom, down with repression!

meanings.definition: to try harder and improve the quality of what you are doing:
examples: Abi has really upped her game this year, and is now in contention for a gold medal.
The budget hotel chain is upping its game with a stylish redesign.
With opposition like this, they need to up their political game.

meanings.definition: used to show that you very much dislike someone or the things that someone has just said or done
Something that is done (up) to the hilt is done completely and without any limits:
examples: The government is already borrowing up to the hilt.

meanings.definition: likely to achieve success soon or in the near future:
examples: up-and-coming young actresses

meanings.definition: likely to achieve success in the near future:
examples: Tatiana is an up-and-coming young actress.

meanings.definition: An up-and-over door opens by being lifted and then sliding into a horizontal position as it rises.
in rugby, a high kick of the ball forward that gives time for team members to run to where the ball lands:
examples: He completely misjudged a hopeful up-and-under, and the ball bounced over his head.
Bath's first try came off a speculative up and under by Barkley.

meanings.definition: in the direction of or relating to the parts of a country further from the coast, especially where there are few towns and people:
examples: We'll travel up-country by horse tomorrow.
Some people find up-country customs strange.

meanings.definition: a woman's hairstyle in which the hair is arranged on top of the head, especially for a special occasion such as a wedding
in basketball, an upward action by a player that makes it look as though he or she is going to throw the ball at the basket
an amount of money paid before a particular piece of work or a particular service is done or received:
examples: Before signing up to any mortgage deal, check what up-front fees you may have to pay.
Often, cash advances come with an upfront charge.

meanings.definition: Up-tempo music has a fast beat:
examples: Their latest hit is an up-tempo dance tune.
The track has a steady up-tempo groove of about 140 beats per minute.

meanings.definition: If you play music up-tempo, you play it with a fast beat:
examples: They perform the tune up-tempo with some masterful fiddle playing.
I prefer this band when they play up-tempo.

meanings.definition: most recent; containing the most recent information:
examples: Now we're going live to our reporter in Washington for up-to-the-minute news on the crisis.

meanings.definition: containing the very latest information or being the newest:
examples: up-to-the-minute news reports

meanings.definition: including the latest information:
examples: The website provides up-to-the-minute information on the best financial deals.
up-to-the-minute figures/prices/reports

meanings.definition: very modern and fashionable:
examples: up-to-the-minute design/style/fashion

meanings.definition: to be the type of thing that you are interested in or that you enjoy doing:
examples: Kate loves dancing, so salsa lessons would be right up her alley.
I started off as an actor, but decided that directing was more up my alley.

meanings.definition: in American football, a player whose job is to stand behind the offensive line on punting plays (= periods of action where a player drops the ball from their hands and kicks it before it hits the ground) and defend against opponents trying to tackle (= stop) the player who is kicking the ball:
examples: The defender broke through the offensive line, and only the upback was left to stop him.
A block by the upback allowed the punter to make the kick.

meanings.definition: full of hope and happiness:
examples: A number of companies remain upbeat about growth prospects in the coming months.

The book ends on an upbeat note.

meanings.definition: Upbeat music is fast and often sounds happy:
examples: This is a catchy, upbeat dance track.
Research shows that listening to an upbeat tempo will improve your mood.

meanings.definition: a musical beat that is not stressed (= played more strongly or loudly), usually coming before a downbeat (= a stressed beat):
examples: An up bow on the violin goes from right to left, and is used on weaker beats and upbeats.

meanings.definition: full of hope, happiness, and good feelings:
examples: The mood is upbeat at Shaw’s campaign headquarters tonight.

meanings.definition: positive and with hope for the future:
examples: High wheat prices have created an upbeat atmosphere in farming communities throughout the region.

meanings.definition: to forcefully or angrily tell someone they should not have done a particular thing and criticize them for having done it:
examples: In newspaper articles she consistently upbraided those in authority who overstepped their limits.
